abstract: A special to the Courier, of this city, from the Union and American, of Nashville, dated to-day, says that dispatches from Richmond state that Gen. BUTLER, commanding a fleet of one hundred guns and four thousand men, arrived at Fort Hatteras on Tuesday, and opened fire on the Fort, which was vigorously returned by the garrison of three hundred men, under the command of Capt. BARROW, formerly of the U.S. Navy.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Saturday, Aug. 31.

abstract: Hon. ERASTUS CORNING and PETER CAGGER were elected Delegates to-day to the Democratic State Convention.  SYRACUSE, Saturday, Aug. 31. The Convention of the Second Assembly District of Onondaga County, was held at the City Hall, at 2 o'clock to-day, for the purpose of electing two delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which assembles in Syracuse on the 4th of September.

abstract: -The Portland (Oregon)Advertiser publishes a private letter from Lieut. MULLAN, at the head of the party constructing a wagon road to Fort Benton. It is dated at the Camp in Bitter Root Mountain. Washington Territory. Lieut. MULLAN says: "We are now pushing through this section, and shall reach, I think, the Coeur d'Alene Mission by the 12th or 15th of July, at which time and place our heavy bridge work commences. Thus far we have done much heavy work. I have to open a section of thirty miles of new road around the northern rim of the Coeur d'Alene lake, to the Coeur d'Alene, which was necessary in order to avoid a location through a bottom which, in early Spring, has proved to be too wet for heavily ladened teams. Though the belt of mountains was dense and forbidding when we attacked them four weeks ago, we have made them, in the interval, wear a more smiling and civilized appearance, by the construction of thirty-one miles of wagon road thus far.
lead_paragraph: -The Portland (Oregon)Advertiser publishes a private letter from Lieut. MULLAN, at the head of the party constructing a wagon road to Fort Benton. It is dated at the Camp in Bitter Root Mountain. Washington Territory. Lieut. MULLAN says: "We are now pushing through this section, and shall reach, I think, the Coeur d'Alene Mission by the 12th or 15th of July, at which time and place our heavy bridge work commences. Thus far we have done much heavy work. I have to open a section of thirty miles of new road around the northern rim of the Coeur d'Alene lake, to the Coeur d'Alene, which was necessary in order to avoid a location through a bottom which, in early Spring, has proved to be too wet for heavily ladened teams. Though the belt of mountains was dense and forbidding when we attacked them four weeks ago, we have made them, in the interval, wear a more smiling and civilized appearance, by the construction of thirty-one miles of wagon road thus far.

abstract: Six weeks ago to-day our Grand army defending the Capital, sustained a great defeat  a rout, which was in the highest degree discreditable to its leadership, and to the discipline, rather than to the personal courage of the soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago to-day our Grand army defending the Capital, sustained a great defeat -- a rout, which was in the highest degree discreditable to its leadership, and to the discipline, rather than to the personal courage of the soldiers. In our flight we left prisoners, cannon, arms and military stores -- all the trophies of a victory -- in the hands of the enemy. It was the first great battle of the campaign, and the result would naturally be taken as evidence of the relative degree of military skill and prowess of the combatants. Nothing, apparently, was left to the North to disprove this evidence, but another battle and a victory so signal that it could have resulted only from a decided superiority in everything that can contribute to success. No such battle has been fought, yet we have so far recovered our ground about Washington that we may select our own time for renewing the fight, with a conviction that we are every day growing stronger and stronger, while it is manifest that the enemy must speedily win another victory or suffer the worst consequences of a disastrous defeat. The only effect upon ourselves of our disaster, was to call out such portion of our reserve power as will, to every reasonable mind, give us an immense preponderance and assure us the victory in the next contest. Previous to the Bull Run affair we had hardly touched our resources, in means and men. It was a fight upon which we had blundered, and in which no considerable portion of our strength was engaged. It disclosed enough to show why we lost when we might have won the victory. Our people have already repaired its effects by the preparations which they have been quietly, but vigorously, making to renew the contest, and which have placed us in the position we should have been in, before venturing to assail the rebel position. We have put another General at the head of our Army, whose previous successes in the war pointed him out as fitted to command. Public confidence was restored as to the ultimate success of our arms. He is earnestly and successfully occupied in correcting the errors and mistakes that led to our defeat. The whole Army had to be re-created. For this purpose we have put 100,000 new troops into the field, and added vastly to their efficiency by a better supplied Commissariat, a better subdivision of them into infantry, cavalry and artillery, and by their more complete appointment and equipment. Upon every strategical point we are accumulating vast, and what must soon be, overwhelming forces. The people, before the mortification and chagrin of a great defeat had been relieved by a single important success, have placed in the hands of Government abandant means for the vigorous prosecution of the war. With all such evidence of the extent of our resources, of our steadiness under defeat, and of our confidence in the permanency of our Government, we can well afford to select our own time for the commencement of offensive operations in Eastern Virginia, as every day only adds to our preparations for, and confidence of, victory.

abstract: The insurgents are not inclined to spare any of the energies which the usages of war place in their hands. It is stated that persons at the North who hold property in Virginia are required, by formal notification, to come forward and take the oath of allegiance to the Southern Confederacy, under penalty of a general confiscation.
lead_paragraph: The insurgents are not inclined to spare any of the energies which the usages of war place in their hands. It is stated that persons at the North who hold property in Virginia are required, by formal notification, to come forward and take the oath of allegiance to the Southern Confederacy, under penalty of a general confiscation. This fact, in connection with the proclamation of Gen. FREMONT, lends a new character to the contest. It has made it a war of confiscations. Henceforward, the inhabitant of the rebel States who cares to save to himself his lands and negroes, must make haste to swear fealty to the rebel Government; and if he do so, he at once exposes himself to all the consequences which Gen. FREMONT thunders at him from the Western war-cloud. For it must, of course, be understood that what on the one hand is threatened in Missouri, and on the other in Virginia, will not be confined in its application to those two States, but will be the law under which the contest must be fought out everywhere.

abstract: Gen. FREMONT seems determined not to allow treason, like a paralysis, to creep over the body of Missouri. He is resolved to have action, and that of the most decided character. In this, the country will applaud him. We are certainly quite as ready to meet the issues of the rebellion as are the rebels themselves. Let them be met promptly.

abstract: The Journal of Commerceannounces a change of proprietors, Mr. HALLOCK, who has been the responsible editor for 25 years, having disposed of his interest in the paper. The World is also reported to have been sold to Mr. FORD, one of its principal stockholders, for $30,000 -- the buyer to payoff the debts of the concern contracted since the 1st of July last, and also a mortgage of $17,000 on the press. The secession sheet called the Day Book has suspended indefinitely. The Daily News, heretofore owned and edited by BEN WOOD, it is said, has passed into the hands of his brother FERNANDO, BEN having incontinently left these parts. GIDEON J. TUCKER, who has lately edited the paper, leaves the concern, and GEORGE PAUL, a prominent Union Democrat from the West, takes his place.

abstract: There appears to have been no further demonstrations against our lines on the other side of the Potomac by the rebels, yesterday, and nothing was seen of their pickets in the vicinity of Ball's Cross Roads.
lead_paragraph: There appears to have been no further demonstrations against our lines on the other side of the Potomac by the rebels, yesterday, and nothing was seen of their pickets in the vicinity of Ball's Cross Roads. They contented themselves with raising a large secession flag on Munson's Hill, which could be seen plainly with a glass from the top of the ship-house at the Washington Navy-yard. They have a considerable cavalry force in the neighborhood, which could also be seen going through their evolutions.

abstract: According to theCharleston Courier, GEORGE N. SANDERS has arrived in Richmond, "manifesting an acute scent for the spoils." Surely, no one is better entitled to them. Having preceded his flight from the North with theft of public money. GEORGE has indisputable qualifications to office at Richmond, where, otherwise, as a former friend and supporter of Mr. DOUGLAS, his welcome might be less than cordial.
lead_paragraph: According to theCharleston Courier, GEORGE N. SANDERS has arrived in Richmond, "manifesting an acute scent for the spoils." Surely, no one is better entitled to them. GEORGE has indisputable qualifications to office at Richmond, where, otherwise, as a former friend and supporter of Mr. DOUGLAS, his welcome might be less than cordial.

abstract: The Confederate Congress, that was to have adjourned last Monday, held on till Wednesday, as we learn by the Richmond papers. President DAVIS was sick of the chills, and Vice-President STEPHENS was sick at Manassas. It is a bad sign to find the heads of the Confederate Government in such a failing condition. TOOMBS escaped the increasing cares of state by resigning. DAVIS and STEPHENS cannot so easily release themselves from office, and the probability is that death will do it for them.
lead_paragraph: The Confederate Congress, that was to have adjourned last Monday, held on till Wednesday, as we learn by the Richmond papers. abstract: The last day of August must stand forever accursed in the calendar of treasonable journalism. Then, it will be remembered, the venerable Journal of Commerce passed from control of a manager who doubtless with the most conscientious intentions, so grossly misdirected its influence, into that of younger and more enlightened men, who kept it within the bounds of respectful loyalty to Government, law and order. The Daily News on that day passed back from the possession of Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD, "sole editor and proprietor," to the hands of his elder brother, the Mayor, who having ejected the pestilent editorial staff of the paper, has converted it into a sound expositor of law and loyalty. There is no doubt about the News deriving from its perverse and mischievous course, the support of large numbers of perverse and mischievous people, to whom the announcement of the change will be a matter of disagreeable surprise. The surprise will perhaps take the form of disgust if their subscriptions have been paid in advance. As to the Day Book, an evening sheet, of the existence of which, as in the case of a very ancient and discreditable personage, one has no other evidence than an occasional rumor of its ill-doing, that also met its fate on the last day of August; not as in the instance of the others -- merely changing ownership, but suspending publication, if not permanently, at least so long as public safety requires its silence. There is little else to be done. The Brooklyn Eagle had previously repented, and is now doing its duty. The only malefactors yet extant are the Freeman's Journal and the Courier des Etats-Unis. Their obsequies may be set down for a very early day.

abstract: Every page of the morning edition of the New-York TIMES is stereotyped, and worked in duplicate. abstract: If regulars fire twelve hundred bullets to kill one enemy, the muskets of volunteers can only be tormidable because they are the handles of bayonets, except at close quarters; that is to say, out of hand to hand reach and far within rifle range an intermediate distance wherein the greenest hand ought to hit half the time at least, and would do great execution if he could always have a charge in his piece.
lead_paragraph: If regulars fire twelve hundred bullets to kill one enemy, the muskets of volunteers can only be tormidable because they are the handles of bayonets, except at close quarters; that is to say, out of hand to hand reach and far within rifle range -- an intermediate distance wherein the greenest hand ought to hit half the time at least, and would do great execution if he could always have a charge in his piece. We have before referred to the fact that the grand defect of the muzzle-loading arm is, that it cannot be loaded rapidly enough. Men are repeatedly caught with their fire drawn in a position where they could mow down the enemy with the most unskillful aim; and, in most of these, cases they could load the best breech-loading arms on the run, or during the shortest halt. But putting a cartridge in at the muzzle, getting the ramrod in proper position, ramming the charge home down a foul barrel, replacing the ramrod and taking aim, besides the other necessary manipulations, is a process which requires time and room; and in the midst of a skirmish a volunteer is likely to have to trust to his bayonet or his heels after his first fire is drawn. The best breech-loading rifles, however, may be instantly opened at the breech by the hand that holds them, and charged, capped and shut by the other hand, without changing the position of the piece, on the run, or in the most confined quarters, or in some of the manoeuvres of a hand to hand skirmish; and shots at this range are pretty sure to be worth a hundred times as much as those of the rank and fire at rifle range. Nor does rapid loading, as is often urged, in the slightest degree facilitate careless firing, for the operation of aiming and pulling the trigger is quite irrespective of the manner of putting the cartridge in. The only objection of any importance against breech-loading muskets is that each bullet has to pass through the barrel after the latter has been fouled by the preceding charge, and that the accuracy of the shot is thus impaired. We do not know that this Objection holds in every case, and are sure that it will be remedied when it has proved a very serious evil; but we cannot see how it will impair the effectiveness of short range or hand-to-hand firing, even if it were so great as to quite prevent all execution at the long range which expert riflemen would select. It appears that the fouling of some of the muzzle-loaders was so great at Bull Run, that charges were with great difficulty rammed home after seven or eight rounds! If this is a type of musket practice, we might as well arm our regiments with spears or lances, or some cheaper kind of bayonet handle. No possible inaccuracy of range in a breech-loader could match such a defect in the muzzle-loader. The ramming home is done by the explosion itself; no more time is expended in loading a foul barrel than a clean one, and time, time, is the great question in loading. The arm of the professional rifleman, of course, has a very different office to perform. It is never to be used as a bayonet handle, but is simply and exclusively a hunting rifle; if the linen patch, rammed in under the bullet from the muzzle, cleans the barrel, and prevents all inaccuracy and wind-age, then the time required to load is of small importance, for sharp-shooting is the most leisurely of employments. Eight per cent. of the shots ought to tell at the longest distance at which a man can be distinctly seen, and none are expected to tell without they are deliberately aimed from a clean, heavy, and extremely well-made piece. It is the cautious, stealthy and quiet work of the hunter. But in the hands of the regular infantry, aiming must be done rapidly at the best; the soldier is trembling with the fatigue of the chase, or the excitement of close combat; his musket is alternately a gun, a club, a battering-ram and a lance; hence it cannot be heavy, so as to avoid recoil, nor long, so as to give the most accurate range, nor deliberately aimed, if it had every element of perfection as a gun. The best state it can be in is loaded, for it is then ready at the right instant for its best execution. And the only chance it has of being loaded, in nine out of ten cases, when a shot is most required, is to be breech-loading. Accuracy is of small importance compared with the time required to make a gun of it, instead of a spear, or a club.

abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped at New-Dorp, Staten Island, since the 31st July, took their departure for Washington yesterday, leaving Vanderbilt's Landing in a steamboat direct for South Amboy, whence they took the cars for Philadelphia. The regiment is composed mainly of Frenchmen, with a few Germans and Americans, and numbers about 550 rank and file. Company B, which is a light artillery battery, remained behind, not having yet received their guns and equipments. The Fifty-fifth, under the name of the "Garde Lafayette," was organized about fourteen years ago, and about 400 of the original members are at present connected with the regiment. They have taken some pains to get off to the seat of war without attracting particular attention or making a show. The only persons present at their embarkation were the particular friends of the regiment. Their uniform is like that of the French infantry -- The gray overcoat, red pants, and red kepi. They were heartily cheered as the steamer left the pier, to which they as heartily responded. The Union Defence Committee have appropriated $1,000 for the benefit of this regiment. By the neglect of some one, the regiment, which was ordered to break camp at 8 o'clock A.M. and embark at 12 P.M., were kept three hours waiting in the sun on the Staten Island landing.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. HUNTER, of the U.S.A., detailed as Major-General of the Illinois Volunteers, arrived in this City last Friday evening en route for Chicago, at which point his head-quarters will be fixed for some brief time. He has been staying at the Metropolitan, but leaves for the West to-morrow. The wound in his neck is nearly well, but the injury to his leg still continues to be a source of annoyance. Many New-York officers who served under him in Virginia called yesterday at his hotel and offered him their compliments on his recovery and promotion. Gen. H. is accompanied by his nephew, Lieut. SAMUEL W. STOCKTON, of the Second Cavalry, whose conduct in connection with the Second Rhode Island Regiment in the battle of Bull Run has been warmly commended in the various official reports of that action.

abstract: Gen. THOMAS C. DE MOSQUERA, now Provisional President of the United States of NewGranada, is a man so long distinguished in military and political stations, by family connections,  versatility of taste and talents, and active patriotic services in the field, in council and in private life, that his present position demands more than a passing notice.

abstract: -- The City Hall was yesterday deserted, being inaccessible to all but officials officials. The catafalque remains in the Governor's room under the charge of a Sergeant's guard from Company A of the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, provision for their entertainment having been made by Mr. ROOME, the keeper, by direction of the Joint Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council, at a special meeting held on Saturday afternoon. Preparations have been made to embrace the City authorities in the procession, which will undoubtedly be large and imposing. Mr. VAN RANCH was directed to furnish carriages, and a Committee from the Common Council were empowered to arrange for the entertainment of the escort from Missouri at the Metropolitan Hotel. The body will be taken to the New-Haven Depot this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The officers of the Sixty-ninth Regiment New-York State Militia will assemble at their Regimental Armory, Essex Market, at 1 3/4 o'clock P.M., this day, in fatigue uniform, to take part in the funeral ceremonies in honor of Brigadier-General LYON.

abstract: Uneasiness begins to be felt here with regard to our future relations with the United Sates. The Cabinet of Washington, and the Americans of the North, show themselves, in general, deeply irritated at the hesitating attitude adopted by England in the pending civil war;
lead_paragraph: Uneasiness begins to be felt here with regard to our future relations with the United Sates. The Cabinet of Washington, and the Americans of the North, show themselves, in general, deeply irritated at the hesitating attitude adopted by England in the pending civil war; and it must be confessed that the tone in which certain English journals have criticised the Manassas affair is not calculated to modify this impression. Two circumstances may change the amicable character of our relations with the United States: One is the intention announced by the Government of Washington, to collect the Customs duties on board of vessels lying off the ports now in possession of the Confederate authorities, (and assuredly England would resist this pretension, for the reason that we would probably have to pay double duties, viz.: at sea to the Unionists, and in the port to the Confederates;) the other is the design ascribed to Mr. LINCOLN, of declaring that the ports occupied by the rebels cease to be ports. At the first glance it is difficult to understand the policy of the latter project; but the intention seems to be to request the Captains of English vessels not to enter the ports in question, and, if they persist in doing so, to consider the act as an attempt to aid and sustain the rebels against the laws of the United States, which might bring about a rupture with Great Britain. It is highly probable that the one or the other of these eventualities will give rise to disputes between the two countries. The project of declaring that the ports of the South cease to be ports is almost an avowal that a real blockade does not exist; for if the entrance to these ports were strictly closed, seaward, what need of any such declaration? If, then, English ships are able to enter the ports in question, they will certainly do so, and the result may be many causes of conflict.

abstract: The battle of Bull Run has produced an extraordinary effect upon our English asses. Ever since the news arrived they have been lifting up their voices in one huge bray, and there is no telling when they will give over. It is not a bray of sympathy, of sorrow, or even of triumph.
lead_paragraph: The battle of Bull Run has produced an extraordinary effect upon our English asses. Ever since the news arrived they have been lifting up their voices in one huge bray, and there is no telling when they will give over. It is not a bray of sympathy, of sorrow, or even of triumph. On the contrary, it is a highly moral bray, articulating lofty lessons for the advantage of all people, Englishmen especially. Yesterday we dealt with one of these big utterances, which had just been bellowed forth by the monarch of the race; to-day we pay our respects to the tamer creature which lowers its ears to the salutations of the dowager-duchesses and political flunkeys of Belgravia. Thus ruminates the Post: "A Democratic Republic which, for warlike purposes, raises one hundred millions sterling in one year, and which imposes an income tax on real and personal property, is certainly a model which Englishmen ought neither to admire nor imitate." Now, is not this asinine? We appeal to our readers, whether this stupid effusion left us a choice of similitudes. It is purely and outrageously donkeyish. We were not aware that a Democratic Republic of any sort ought to be admired, or imitated by Englishmen. We are satisfied with our Constitution, asking only that it be perfected and developed in harmony with its native spirit. We are attached to our monarchy, and should start at the idea of exchanging the throne for a President's chair. Are we to infer that, if we could only obtain solid guarantees against extravagant expenditure, the Post would go in for a "Democratic Republic?" But the sting of the objection is that this extravagant expenditure is raised for "warlike purposes," -- we as a people loving peace so well that we never spent and never will spend a stiver upon armaments. Why, the objection is disarmed in stating it. The "Democratic Republic" over the water was never more like ourselves than it is now. Yesterday it was thrifty, economical, raising a miserable revenue, denying itself the luxury of a standing army and navy, except on a scale ridiculously small. To-day it has an army almost as big as the Queen of England maintains for the defence of her wide dominions, and it is spending maney on just such a lavish scale as we were only six years ago. The Americans and we are brethren at last; equally warlike, equally prodigal. Ah! but look at the burdens which this extravagant expenditure imposes upon the people. This Democratic Republic is actually levying an income tax on real and personal property! Wherein

abstract: The Freeman's Journal, one of the rebel journals recently presented by the Grand Jury, and excluded from the mails, has ceased to exist, and in its stead we have the Freeman's Appeal, a paper which can hardly contain as much treason as the Journal used to disseminate, for it is but half the size of that sheet. This change, J.A. MCMASTER, the editor, says, will continue until "this crisis is past -- till the Press can be free." He concludes his manifesto thus:

abstract: FALCONER, the open-air temperance lecturer, who so often makes his appearance before the Tombs Police Court, was arrested in the Park, on Sunday morning, by the Second Ward Police, where he was preaching temperance to an orderly congregation of men and boys. He was taken before Justice KELLY, who, after hearing the officer's complaint, discharged him. FALCONER immediately returned to the Park, and mounting his stool renewed the discussion of his favorite theme. Another policeman almost instantly tapped the orator on the arm, and requested him to walk as far as the Tombs. FALCONER assented, and on his second arraignment before the magistrate again succeeded in procuring his discharge. The legality of FALCONER's thus appearing in public on Sundays is, at present, a matter of consideration by the Supreme Court.

abstract: Recruiting for the Army is pretty much as it, was last week. The new order, allowing the officers to accept men of 5 to 3 inches, has excercised a little influence on the business, but not much. The old regiments still continue to enlist for themselves alone,  while each of the new regiments recruits for itself,  establishes its own offices, and carries on its business
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the Army is pretty much as it, was last week. The new order, allowing the officers to accept men of 5 to 3 inches, has excercised a little influence on the business, but not much. The old regiments still continue to enlist for themselves alone, while each of the new regiments recruits for itself, establishes its own offices, and carries on its business exactly in the same manner as the volunteer regiments, a custom seldom permitted in regular Armies. The cavalry office in Hudson-street still does the best business in town. The new mounted regiment, whose head-quarters are at Pittsburgh, Penn., advanced rapidly last week, and has now nearly 300 men. The Eleventh Regiment, at Boston, the Thirteenth in Missouri, the Fourteenth at Fort Trumbull, Conn., and the Seventeenth at Fort Adams, will probably be fit for the field before any of the others.

abstract: Nations, and peoples, and men, accustomed for generations to the quiet and ease of prosperous peace, are slow to realize the stern necessities of a state of war. This is now the case with us here in the South.
lead_paragraph: Nations, and peoples, and men, accustomed for generations to the quiet and ease of prosperous peace, are slow to realize the stern necessities of a state of war. This is now the case with us here in the South. People from the North and from all foreign lands have come among us and been permitted to enjoy all the privileges of citizenship without let or hindrance, and by their skill and ingenuity or artifice have accumulated livings and fortunes from our patronage, while they have all the while been aliens, in their sympathies, to us, and enemies and revilers of our institutions, and calumniators of our character. They have, by our magnanimity, been permitted to live in peace among us and reap large profits from our patronage.

abstract: and PATRICK DONNELLY were arrested on Saturday night, by officer BLACK, of the Fourth Ward, charged with having offered a counterfeit $1 bill on the Merchants' Bank of Baltimore, to PAULINE BOUCHER, of No. 217 William-street, in payment for drinks. The character of the bill was questioned, and while PAULINE had sent for information respecting it, Officer BLACK entered, and arrested the men, who had previously offered the same or a similar bill in the saloon of HENRY GOTTLIEB, No. 21 Frankfort-street. The prisoners were theft positively told that the bill was spurious. They were taken before Justice KELLY, and committed for examination.

abstract: M. PROUDHON has just published a new work, marked by that extraordinary mingling of profundity and paradox which characterizes all the productions of his mind. The title is as written above, and the whole scope of the book is to deify
lead_paragraph: M. PROUDHON has just published a new work, marked by that extraordinary mingling of profundity and paradox which characterizes all the productions of his mind. The title is as written above, and the whole scope of the book is to deify War -- to show that it is "a religious revelation, a revelation of justice, a revelation of the ideal." Of course this involves a new theory of the law of nations, which he proceeds to develop. Whatever we may think of M. PROUDHON's ideas on politics or social economy, he remains an incomparable logician, one of the most vigorous thinkers of the age. All his books seem to be inspired by a deep love of humanity, and they should be so, for they have obtained the glorious seal of martyrdom. His disciples regard him as the master of the new politics, the prophet of modern society. While those who are not Frenchmen will hardly take this view of him and his work, his productions are of such a nature that if not absolutely true, they are, at least, well worth examining, to see what truth is in them. As to the present book -- touching on questions now so deeply agitating many minds -- all we can hope here to do is to give a few glimpses into the extraordinary melange of bold truths and equally bold fictions, paradoxes, vagaries and extravagances that seethe as in a cauldron through his pages.

abstract: yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the basement of the premises No. 905 Broadway, occupied as a liquor by SUSER & XAVIER. The stock was all destroyed, involving a loss of $1,260, which is partially covered by insurance in the Excelsior Insurance Company. The building, which is owned by Messrs. abstract: The First United States Chasseurs, some nine hundred strong, struck their tents at Camp Tompkins, on Willet's Point, L.L., about 12 M. on Tuesday, and marched to White Stone, where they embarked in the steamer Atlas for New--York. The day was very warm, the road very dry and dusty, and the men unaccustomed to marching; yet there was no evidence
lead_paragraph: The First United States Chasseurs, some nine hundred strong, struck their tents at Camp Tompkins, on Willet's Point, L.L., about 12 M. on Tuesday, and marched to White Stone, where they embarked in the steamer Atlas for New--York. The day was very warm, the road very dry and dusty, and the men unaccustomed to marching; yet there was no evidence of fatigue, and the regiment marched down Broadway by platoons with such order and regularity as is seldom witnessed, save in thoroughly drilled troops. Along the line of march through New-York, they were received with plaudits on all sides. It must be an unusual occurrence that calls out Broadway, and on this occasion that famous thoroughfare presented the appearance of a gala day. It was an elegant and well merited compliment, both to Col. COCHRANE and to Lieut.-Col. SHALER, and such an expression of public feeling must have been peculiarly gratifying to each of them. There is a remarkable circumstance connected with the march of the Chasseurs through New-York, and it should be recorded to the lasting honor of the regiment. In the entire battalion not a single man was intoxicated, not a single man left the line, and not a single man was absent at the next roll call. This, perhaps, can be said of no other body of soldiers that have marched to Washington since the war commenced. It should also be said that for men who but three days before had muskets placed in their hands as soldiers, the order observed was most creditable, and gave glowing promise of better things to come. The authorities of New-York deserve the thanks of the Chasseurs in having the line of march cleared from all obstructions.

abstract: The Secretary of the Treasury begins to be annoyed, we see, by applications fpr appointment to the offices of Assessor and Collector under the Direct Tax law passed by Congress. If there should be an average of only one Assessor and one Collector to each county in the
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Treasury begins to be annoyed, we see, by applications fpr appointment to the offices of Assessor and Collector under the Direct Tax law passed by Congress. If there should be an average of only one Assessor and one Collector to each county in the loyal States, there would be over a thousand of each class to be appointed, which would impose upon Secretary CHASE a very delicate and onerous duty; for he can know personally but few of the men who seek these places, and would have to rely on the representations of their partisan friends for their intelligence, their integrity and fitness. As Mr. CHASE would be held responsible by the country for the honesty which should characterize the assessment and collection of so large a sum of money as $20,000,000, he could not safely depute the appointment of the Assessors and Collectors to some Chief Assessor and Collector in each State. His position, should he be compelled to resort to this mode of collection, would be very embarrassing therefore, and no doubt, as an officer who loves his reputation, he would willingly avoid the risk of appointing dishonest men to serve the Government under the Direct Tax law.

abstract: Recruiting for the Army is pretty much as it, was last week. The old regiments still continue to enlist for themmselves alone, while each of the new regiments recruits for itself,
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the Army is pretty much as it, was last week. The new order, allowing the officers to accept men of 5 feet 3 inches, has exercised a little influence on the business, but not much. The old regiments still continue to enlist for themmselves alone, while each of the new regiments recruits for itself, establishes its own offices, and carries on its business exactly in the same manner as the volunteer regiments, a custom seldom permitted in regular Armies. The cavalry office in Hudson-street still does the best business in town. The new mounted regiment, whose head-quarters are at Pittsburgh, Penn., advanced rapidly last week, and has now nearly 300 men. The Eleventh Regiment, at Boston, the Thirteenth in Missouri, the Fourteenth at Fort Trumbull, Conn., and the Seventeenth at Fort Adams, will probably be fit for the field before any of the others.

lead_paragraph: We make the following extracts from the letters of a correspondent of the Charleston Mercury. He writes from Richmond, which he says is packed to suffocation by an innumerable crowd of idlers, quidnuncs, public officials and soldiers, for the most part red-capped, red-faced pussy, panting, and perspiring; with ice at 12 cents per pound, and little of that to be had for love or money; where every gate is thronged with suitors, eager for papers to go from this or permits to visit that camp; where your nose and mouth is crammed with impalpable dust, and your ears stunned with the mutterings, grumblings, and curses of discontent or disappointment." abstract: The Quincy, (Ill.,) Whig says that the order for $15,000 levy for damages sustained by the train that the rebels recently fired into near Palmyra, has been countermanded. The property holders, who would have been made to pay the tax, begged off, because the damage was done by a worthless gang of marauders, for whose sport it seemed hard (to them) that they should be made to pay; notwithstanding the fact that they had made no effort themselves to restrain the ruffians, even if they had not actually encouraged them.

abstract: Mr. FREDERICH GROVE, a Southern gentleman, who has been some time a resident of Brooklyn, was arrested by Detectives SAMPSON and DEVOE, on Saturday, at the instance of the United States Government. From intercepted letters written by the prisoner to "Extra Billy" SMITH, of Virginia, it appeared that he
lead_paragraph: Mr. FREDERICH GROVE, a Southern gentleman, who has been some time a resident of Brooklyn, was arrested by Detectives SAMPSON and DEVOE, on Saturday, at the instance of the United States Government. From intercepted letters written by the prisoner to "Extra Billy" SMITH, of Virginia, it appeared that he was not only furnishing the rebels with valuable information, but had offered his services to the Southern Confederacy in any capacity in which he could make himself of use. In his letters he also stated that he had used his influence to effect the release of the imprisoned Baltimore Commissioners, and others in confinement on treasonable charges. The Detectives yesterday morning took him to Fort Lafayette.

abstract: About 12 o'clock Saturday night, MATHEW FLANIGAN, while passing through Baxter-street, was waylaid by three men, knocked down and robbed of $15. His screams for help frightened the thieves, who dodged up an alley out of sight. EUGENE SULLIVAN, of No. 71 Baxter-street, hearing the alarm, and seeing persons running away, pursued the fugitives. He overtook one of them and detained him until Officers HYDE and DORAN, of the Sixth Ward, came up and took him to the Station-house. The prisoner gave his name as CHARLES CONCKLIN, and soon afterwards THOMAS BAKER, a German tailor, and WILLIAM RYAN, alleged to be his accomplices, were arrested by the same officers. Justice KELLY committed the prisoners for trial, each in default of $2,000 bail.

abstract: ANOTHER FRAUDULENT TICKET OPERATION,-- CHAS. BEHLING, a German arrived in this City, a few days since, from New-Haven, for the purpose of sailing direct for Bremen, in the steamship Bremen. He hired a carman to convey his luggage a to the office of the agents of Messrs. OELRICH  Co., Broad-street
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER FRAUDULENT TICKET OPERATION. -- CHAS. BERLING, a German arrived in this City, a few days since, from New-Haven, for the purpose of sailing direct for Bremen, in the steamship Bremen. He hired a carman to convey his luggage a to the office of the agents of Messrs. OELRICH & Co., Broad-street but on the way thither, he was accosted by a man, who represented himself to Mr. BEHLING to be in the employ of the Broad-street shippers. The carman then disobeyed his instructions, and drove direct to the office of PATRICK MCDONALD, ticket agent, No. 22 Albany-street, instead of to the office in Broadstreet. To allay Mr. BEHLING's suspicions, he was told by the stranger that that was the ticket office of OELRICH & Co, and that the office in Broad-street was only for the reception of luggage, freight, &c. CHAS. WINSH, a clerk in MCDONALD's office, then sold BEHLING tickets for Bremen by the steamship City of Washington, via Liverpool, instead of by the Bremen, for which he paid $35. BEHLING, subsequently learning that he had been imposed upon, appeared before Justice KELLY and made a complaint against WINSH, who sold him the ticket, for violating the State law in selling a ticket entitling him to a passage by a route, company, line and steamship other than the one he bargained for. WINSH was arrested by Officer CROSBY, of the Lower Police Court, and held to bail in $500 to answer. HENRY ARMSTRONG, of No. 152 Greenwich-street, became his bondsman.

abstract: -- The City Hall was yesterday deserted, being inaccessible to all but officials. The catafalque remains in the Governor's room under the charge of a Sergeant's guard from Company A of the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, provision for their entertainment having been made by Mr. ROOME, the keeper, by direction of the Joint Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council, at a special meeting held on Saturday afternoon. Preparations have been made to embrace the City authorities in the procession, which will undoubtedly be large and imposing. Mr. VAN RANCH was directed to furnish carriages, and a Committee from the Common Council were empowered to arrange for the entertainment of the escort from Missouri at the Metropolitan Hotel. The body will be taken to the New-Haven Depot this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The officers of the Sixty-ninth Regiment New-York State Militia will assemble at their Regimental Armory, Essex Market, at 1 1/2 o'clock P.M., this day, in fatigue uniform, to take part in the funeral ceremonies in honor of Brigadier-General LYON.

abstract: Mr. PATRICK HENRY DONEGAN, who was employed by the National Government in making tidal observations at Calcasieu, Louisiana, was arrested on Aug. 21, by order of Gen. TWIGGS. Mr. DONEGAN never sent his resignation to the Government, and continued his work until in the month of May he was requested by the State authorities to resign. The charge against him is that of being a spy. In his possession was found a draft on the United States Treasury for $80, dated in April last, and indorsed by himself. His papers will be examined by the Governor of Louisiana and Gen. TWIGGS.

abstract: Shortly before midnight the first-class ship William Tell, belonging to BOYD  HINCKEN's line of Havre packets, was discovered to be on fire. She lay at anchor in the stream, off Rector-street, N.R., and the fire had been burning at least two hours before it was seen. An alarm was then given from the vessel, by ringing the belis exhibiting bluelights and calling for assistance.

abstract: There is no victory so complete as that which solves a great political dilemma, which has rested like a pall upon the public mind, destroying all life and spirit, paralyzing all enterprise and action, and producing all the conse
lead_paragraph: There is no victory so complete as that which solves a great political dilemma, which has rested like a pall upon the public mind, destroying all life and spirit, paralyzing all enterprise and action, and producing all the consequences of a disastrous defeat. It is a happy stroke of genius that can overstep the bounds of tradition, or conventional rule, and show a clear path in a direction supposed to be be set with insuperable difficulties. Such is the service rendered the nation by Gen. FREMONT's proclamation, placing Missouri under martial law and visiting upon traitors, the penalties due to treason, with all the celerity of military dispatch. The traitor is to be divested of property, as well as life; and further, a blow is struck where it has long been seen it might fall, upon the institution which is both the cause and support of the rebellion. Self-preservation renders no other course as longer possible. If we would save ourselves, we must take from treason every weapon by which it can strike the deadly blow. We must maintain the rights of loyal men intact, but take from those in arms against us the means of keeping them in the field.

abstract: The result of the naval expedition from Fortress Monroe, under command of Gen. BUTLER, is profoundly gratifying to the country The success is indeed brilliant. The Union forces, numbering only one thousand, captured
lead_paragraph: The result of the naval expedition from Fortress Monroe, under command of Gen. BUTLER, is profoundly gratifying to the country The success is indeed brilliant. The Union forces, numbering only one thousand, captured the fort and took prisoners forty-five officers and six hundred and sixty-five non-commissioned officers and privates, -- in all over seven hundred,-and without the loss of a man of the expedition. Among the rebel officers taken were a number of high rank, including Com. BARRON, Assistant Secretary of the Navy of the Confederate States, two Colonels and a Major. Several of these unfortunate chieftains (BARRON among them) are accustomed to be spoken of as "late of the United States Navy," or "late of the United States Army," as the case may be; and it does not detract from our pleasure at the late success to find these ingrates in the hands of the Government they have betrayed.

abstract: On Saturday night five or six compositors employed in the Office of the TIMES entered an eating-house on Chatham-street for refreshments.
lead_paragraph: -- On Saturday night five or six compositors employed in the Office of the TIMES entered an eating-house on Chatham-street for refreshments. On coming out one by one they were set upon by a gang of rowdies who had followed and waited for them, and were knocked down and beaten. Their assailants claimed to be members of the First Regiment of Fire Zouaves, and declared that they took this mode of revenging themselves in part for the remarks that have been made in the columns of the TIMES on their conduct at and after the battle of Bull Run.

abstract: broke out, on Saturday evening, in the third story of the building, No. 38 White-street, occupied by Mr. ALLEN A. BURNS, jeweler, and considerable damage resulted to the property of all the tenants of the premises. The fire originated in a small apartment used as a bedroom, but in what way is not known. The loss of Mr. BURNS is estimated at $2,000, upon which there is no insurance. The frames burned through to the fourth floor, occupied by KENDRINGER & MCLAUGHLIN, silversmiths, and by Mr. BROWN, cord and tassel manufacturer. The losses, in both cases, are met by insurance -- the former having a policy on the Lorillard, and the latter on the Germania Insurance Company. J. & H. JONES, brass clock manufacturers, occupied the second floor. Their stock was considerably damaged by water. It was insured for the amount of $25,000, equally in the Astor, Home, New-Amsterdam, National, Equitable, North American and Mercantile Insurance Companies. The stock of Messrs. ADAMS & KIDNEY, jewelers, occupying the first floor, was also damaged by water. The loss is covered by insurance in the Lorillard Insurance Company. The roof of the adjoining building. No. 40, was injured considerably by the flames. The damage to the building may be repaired for $[???]. The premises belong long to the estate of the late WM. ADAMS, and there is an insurance of $8,000 upon them, in the Lorillard Company.

abstract: One of the most important alterations which has been effected in the Military Department here, since the arrival of Gen. FREMONT, relates to the care which is now being taken in selecting competent and experienced officers for the newly organized regiments. Imperatively necessary as the movement was, it required a determined will to inaugurate it, and a stern fixedness of purpose to persevere in its prosecution.

abstract: The Government has received dispatches from Minister ADAMS, which set at rest, for the present at least, the question of interference by the British Government in the affairs of the United States. He does not think any change of policy is intended so long as the blockade is continued.

abstract: In the London Money market the Funds were quite buoyant on the 21st of August, and an advance in Consols was firmly established. In the Discount market there was increased ease, and good bills were scarce and taken at 4  cent. Evidences of stagnation in trade are increasing. Applications at the Bank continued limited.
lead_paragraph: In the London Money market the Funds were quite buoyant on the 21st of August, and an advance in Consols was firmly established. abstract: The schooner My Rover, Capt. HUGHES, from Trinidad, Cuba, 18 days, sugar, &c., to MCCREADY, MOTT & Co., arrived at this port yesterday morning. Left bark Franklin, of and for Boston, loading, to sail in two or three days, and the schooner Kasbeck, for New-York, to be ready in a few days. On the 17th August, off Cape St. Antonio, during a very heavy squall, the Rover was brought to by theUnited States steamer Powhatan. On Aug. 21, lat. 25 38, lon. 80 04, was passed by a large United States propeller, which took no notice of her. On the 22d, the same ship was in sight; all day under canvas only. On the 26th, in lat. 31 10, lon. 77 45, passed a number of boxes, (supposed to be sugar boxes, as they were strapped around and on the ends with raw hide.) On the same day fell in with the wreck of a vessel or about 150 tons; could see but one side of her from keel to rail. There was loose plank and other wrecked stuff all around her. On the 29th, lat. 36 29, lon. 74 33, passed a small vessel, water logged, even with the water; no spars standing. She had a small trunk cabin, which showed about four feet above thedeck.

abstract: Right Rev. Maj-Gen. Bishop POLK has been creating quite an excitement in Memphis, by the impressment of laborers as volunteers in his army. We have already published some action taken by the City Council, which appointed a Committee to look into the matter; and the telegraph now announces that Gen. POLK will desist from this objectionable course. The following from the Memphis Argus of Saturday, will further enlighten the North on the way Confederate recruits have been obtained.

abstract: There is no traitorous organ in all the Northern States which so boldly and defiantly proclaims its object to be the absolute subjection of the United States to Jefferson Davis, as the National Zeitung, published by an association of German Democrats in New-York and Brooklyn, and edited by a couple of former office-holders under BUCHANAN, assisted by some renegade Free-Soilers. Those loyal journals which are endeavoring to prove that no peace, under any other condition than submission of the North to the traitor-government, is possible, may save all their trouble,since the National Zeitung, unblushingly and without any hesitation, avows that such is the only object of the "peace party." It professes to be a "Union" paper, because, it says, Union is impossible except upon the basis of the Montgomery Constitution; and whoever advocates the adoption, by the Northern States, of the Montgomery Constitution, is the only real Union man. In every one of its issues it announces the approaching doom of the loyal people of the North and its fierce invectives against the "usurper," the "military dictator" at Washington, coupled with the most savage threats against his "minions," leave no doubt whatever that it contemplates the outbreak of a traitorous conspiracy in the loyal States. In fact, the National Zeitung craves martyrdom, and defies the public authorities, who, it says, do not dare to touch it. It rejoices at the idea of a "terrific explosion" which is to occur, and which will of course "put to death" (to political death) "all abolitionist demagogues," etc. We subjoin some specimen bricks from the last issue of the National Zeilung:

abstract: The success of the naval expedition continues to be the theme of conversation, and the subject of congratulation among the friends of the Government. abstract: With the opening of Fall, renewed activity may be expected among all the Departments, which have been comparatively idle since the middle of July. Both branches of the Common Council commence their regular sessions on Thursday next, and will continue to meet semi-weekly throughout the remainder of the year. The confirmation of the Tax Levy by the Board of Supervisors, which will probably be effected this week, will open a new chanel for the money of such of our citizens as have any to spare, as the Receiver will immediately invite all tax-payers to walk up to the Captain's office and settle, holding out, at the same time, the inducement of a liberal deduction if they are prompt in their responses.

abstract: The remarkable success that has attended the first effort of the Government to assail the rebel States on their exposed sea-coast, will doubtless inspire our military leaders to a perseverance in the policy. The country hails the achievement as the most sensible and significant of all our war movements. If this mode of attack had been begun earlier, very few privateers would now be scourging our commerce, and emboldening the Confederates by their successes.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable success that has attended the first effort of the Government to assail the rebel States on their exposed sea-coast, will doubtless inspire our military leaders to a perseverance in the policy. The country hails the achievement as the most sensible and significant of all our war movements. If this mode of attack had been begun earlier, very few privateers would now be scourging our commerce, and emboldening the Confederates by their successes. It appeared by the papers seized in Fort Hatteras that no less than fourteen vessels, some of them carrying exceedingly valuable cargoes, have been captured by the pirates, and carried in at Hatteras Inlet to be plundered. It was literally a den of thieves, in and out of which they swarmed day and night, "running the blockade" with loads of cotton or ship-stores, capturing unsuspicious merchantmen, or doing whatever their lawless desires prompted. And all within a hundred and twenty miles of Old Point Comfort, where we have had, since May, ships and men enough to blow them to pieces. It is even given out now by the Government, elated by its success, that they had this expedition matured "before Congress met;" but red tape, we suppose, prevented its execution before the present time. This ought not to have been. Twelve of the fourteen prizes at Hatteras Inlet have been taken by the pirates since the date of the meeting of Congress. The loss to loyal citizens by the Government's delay would have paid for the expedition.

abstract: The Proclamation of Gen. FREMONT, though the first appeal to the law dissolving, in case of treason, the tie between master and slave, only states the inevitable result of the rebel war, no matter what legal provision Congress may have made. Inter arma silent-leges. Slavery is founded upon force, and the moment this is removed the subject is, for the time, free. A return of peace may leave local laws unchanged, which may entitle the master to recover his slave within the domain of such laws. But in the total dislocation and disruption of society, invaded and overrun by a conquering host, a vast number of owners will forever disappear, leaving no claimant for the temporarily enfranchised slave. Others will be too weak to enforce their legal rights. Slaves will be so scattered that identification will often become impossible, so that the previous condition of society can never be restored. Everywhere will be visible the effect of the war in those that have fled, as well as in the freed that remain behind, in working a partial extinguishment and fatal blow to the system. The lesson taught will never be forgotten. The slave, to be valuable, must be a machine in which the thought of freedom or of change of condition must never enter. No spectacle must be allowed to awaken a sentiment which is universal in the human heart. If it does, and takes firm hold, the system disappears, because it is no longer worth the maintenance.
lead_paragraph: The Proclamation of Gen. abstract: Shortly before midnight of Sunday the first-class ship William Tell, belonging to BOYD & HINCKEN's  line, of Havre packets, was discovered to be on fire. She lay at anchor in the stream, off Rector-street, N.R., and the fire had been burning at least two hours before it was seen. An alarm was then given from the vessel, by ringing the bells, exhibiting bluelights and calling for assistance. By these means, the attention of Sergeant GARLAND, of the Harbor Police, was attracted. He was then in one of the police boats, on the Battery, and procuring the services of the Hamilton Ferry boat Montague hastened to the relief of the passengers, who were screeching with terror, all of whom were saved in their night clothes. One man, a German, lost all his property -- $1,300 in gold coin, which he was unable to get out of his trunk.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before midnight of Sunday the first-class ship William Tell, belonging to BOYD & HINCKEN's line, of Havre packets, was discovered to be on fire. She lay at anchor in the stream, off Rector-street, N.R., and the fire had been burning at least two hours before it was seen. An alarm was then given from the vessel, by ringing the bells, exhibiting bluelights and calling for assistance. By these means, the attention of Sergeant GARLAND, of the Harbor Police, was attracted. He was then in one of the police boats, on the Battery, and procuring the services of the Hamilton Ferry boat Montague hastened to the relief of the passengers, who were screeching with terror, all of whom were saved in their night clothes. One man, a German, lost all his property -- $1,300 in gold coin, which he was unable to get out of his trunk.

abstract: editor of the Courrier des Etats Unis has with drawn temporarily from the conduct of the journal, -- avowedly because his advocacy of secession is not sustained or approved by any considerable portion of the American people He proposes that for the present the Courrier take no part whatever in the discussion of American politics, but content itself with the publication of news. This, though not a very dignified role, is certainly preferable to the open advocacy of rebellion. We copy his letter to M. LASALLE, the proprietor of the paper.

abstract: The Government, through its financial representative, Mr. Secretary CHASE, has made its appeal to the people for aid in the great contest, in terms befitting the grandeur of the occasion. When the rights and the political liberties of a people are assailed, they should be allowed to testify their sense of their value, by sacrifices if needs be, or by honorable participations in the means of defence. Such an appeal unites the people, by a common tie, quickens their loyalty, and binds them the more closely to Government, which is a type of the political blessings they enjoy. The answer has already anticipated the appeal. The Banks, or the representatives of the capital of the country, have already testified their confidence in and devotion to Government, by subscribing to $50,000,000 of the loan, while the people have for days thronged the office of the Assistant Treasurer of the United States, in this City, to add their contributions and testimony to the great cause. No appeal was needed to supply the wants of Government, but it will have a most happy effect in stimulating the ardor and spirit of the nation. Coming as it does, close upon the receipt of the news of a great victory, the heartiness of the response will not only add vastly to the consciousness of our own strength, but will give an assurance to other nations that we are quite equal to all the responsibilities resting upon us.

abstract: wire-pullers, who are striving to aid the rebellion by getting up a party peace movement in this State, will find their disloyalty justly and severely rebuked in the document from Tammany Hall, which we publish this morning. The Tammany Democrats very distinctly decline the invitation of the Mozart Committee to join them in sending delegates to the State Convention, partly because they will not recognize them as a Democratic organization, but mainly because they will no aid them in their attempts to cripple the Government. They declare their determination to prosecute the war with the utmost vigor, -- and to sustain the Government in every step it may take to crush the rebellion. This is the language of true patriotism, and will be heartily responded to by the great mass of the Democratic Party throughout the country

abstract: The Comptroller sent in the regular monthly statement, showing a balance of $2,096,433 15. The same officer asked that the Board would appropriate the sum of $61,000 to pay the contractors, MCSPEDON & BAKER, for work done for the Commissioners of Record, a decision having been given by the Referee in their favor. Mr. TWEED offered a resolution directing the Comtroller to pay that amount, the same having been appropriated last year, subject to the decision of the Courts. Mr. BLUNT opposed it, because the Comptroller asks for that amount, with interest, which as yet was an unknown sum; but Mr. TWEED thought that as the money was decided to be due, it ought to be paid at once. After much discussion it was ordered paid, Messrs. BLUNT, DUTCHER and DAVIE voting in the negative.

abstract: Every page of the morning edition of the New-York TIMES is stereotyped, and worked in duplicate. We have resorted to this expedient as the only means of delivering our very large and constantly increasing edition to our subscribers at a reasonably early hour in the morning. We trust that any defects in the typography and general appearance of the paper will be pardoned until they can be remedied, -- which shall be at the earliest possible moment.

abstract: The proclamation of the President confiscating all goods and effects found in transit to the rebel States, with the vehicles or vessels containing them, together with all vessels found at sea or in any port, owned in whole or in part by citizens of the seceding States, went into effect on Sunday -- the fifteen days' grace having expired at 12 o'clock on Saturday night. In anticipation of this fact, the Surveyor of the Port, R.F. ANDREWS, Esq., has been busy procuring a list of all vessels in this port which are owned wholly or in part by citizens of the rebel States, and, at an early hour on Sunday, proceeded to seize and lake possession of twenty-five vessels -- putting two revenue officers on board of each prize. Their arrival alongside of the vessels in the little steamer Birkbeck, and the formal taking possession of them, was the cause of much surprise -- in most cases the officer or ship-keeper being wholly ignorant of the nature of the visit until it was explained to him.
lead_paragraph: The proclamation of the President confiscating all goods and effects found in transit to the rebel States, with the vehicles or vessels containing them, together with all vessels found at sea or in any port, owned in whole or in part by citizens of the seceding States, went into effect on Sunday -- the fifteen days' grace having expired at 12 o'clock on Saturday night. abstract: Gen. PILLOW has seized a floating show, composed of stuffed lions, tigers and leopards, and what was represented as "Artemus Ward's" magnificent set of wax figures. abstract: The Times publishes Dr. RUSSELL's, correspendence to the 5th of August. The last letter mainly refers to the demoralized and insubordinate state of  the Army, at the same time crediting Gen. McCLELLAN with speedy reforms. He says that the Southerners believe they will be safe if they hold out until October,and that at the end of the year the Northerners will be further from their aim than ever.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Friday, Aug. 23.

abstract: A WALL-STREET BROKER CHARGED WITH PERJURY. -- ANTHONY BOYER, a broker, doing business at No. 82 Wall-street, was arrested by Officer BLUNT, of the Tombs Police Court, on a warrant issued by Justice KELLY. Mr. DEMETRIUS M. CHADSEY, the complainant, charges, under oath, that on the 4th day of June last, during the trial of a case, before the Hon. Judge LEONARD, of the Supreme Court, wherein Capt. N. POTTER was plaintiff, and Mr. CHADSEY and others defendants, the accused testified to certain matters material to the issue, which were false and untrue, and so known to be at the time. BOYER swore that he did not on the 7th day of March last charge Mr. CHADSEY $7 50 for the use of $300 for ten days, whereas Mr. CHADSEY avers that he did pay the usurous interest to the defendant; and M.Wm.W. WINANT, who was present, and witnessed the transaction, corroborates the affidavit of Mr. CHADSEY. Mr. BOYER was held to bail in $1,000 to answer. Mr. JAMES W. TRASK, of No. 166 East Tenth-street became his bondsman.
lead_paragraph: A WALL-STREET BROKER CHARGED WITH PERJURY. -- ANTHONY BOYER, a broker, doing business at No. 82 Wall-street, was arrested by Officer BLUNT, of the Tombs Police Court, on a warrant issued by Justice KELLY. Mr. DEMETRIUS M. CHADSEY, the complainant, charges, under oath, that on the 4th day of June last, during the trial of a case, before the Hon. Judge LEONARD, of the Supreme Court, wherein Capt. N. abstract: The September term of this Court opened yesterday morning, Recorder HOFFMAN presiding. City Judge McCunn, at present commanding the 37th Regiment of Volunteers, has not returned from Washington, and as far as the officers of the Court are advised, will not take his place upon the Bench during the present term. The calendar of this term is very large, but comprises no causes of special public interest. The case of Samuel H. Merritt, indicted for the murder of John Swaine, by shooting, on the 31st of May last, during a quarrel about the secession sentiments of the latter, will probably be reached next week. The accused will be defended by James T. Brady and A. Oakey Hall, Esqs. No business of importance was transacted in Court yesterday; the panel of Grand Jurors was called, but only six persons answered to their names. The absentees were fined twenty-five dollars each. Should a quorum be present, the Recorder will charge the Jury this morning.

abstract: The letter of our Paris Correspondent which we publish this morning, will challenge attention by the positiveness and importance of its statements. The writer has excellent, opportunities of being well informed on the subject, and has vindicated his reliability too often in the past to have it questioned now.
lead_paragraph: The letter of our Paris Correspondent which we publish this morning, will challenge attention by the positiveness and importance of its statements. The writer has excellent, opportunities of being well informed on the subject, and has vindicated his reliability too often in the past to have it questioned now. He asserts, in the most explicit manner, that the Emperor NAPOLEON sympathizes most heartily and thoroughly with our Government in its contest with rebellion, and wishes it the most speedy and complete success; -- and that he will do nothing whatever to afford the rebels the slightest encouragement for the prosecution of their schemes. The Emperor is probably influenced in this view quite as much by his foresight into the disastrous results of disunion as by his devotion to the principles repudiated by the rebellion. The capitalists of the Continent, our correspondent writes, fully share this sympathy of the Emperor.

abstract: Considerable excitement was created yesterday by the publication of a brief dispatch, stating that heavy cannonading was going on across the Potomae, and that the belief was Prevalent in Washington that an attack was being made by the rebels on the National lines.
lead_paragraph: Considerable excitement was created yesterday by the publication of a brief dispatch, stating that heavy cannonading was going on across the Potomae, and that the belief was Prevalent in Washington that an attack was being made by the rebels on the National lines. It appears, however, that the firing was occasioned by the exercise of our men at the heavy guns in some of the fortifications. The rebels on Munson's Hill also fired several shots from rifled cannon at the National pickets, but without doing any damage. A dispatch from Alexandria announces that the rebels have commenced fortifying about five miles out on the Little River Turnpike. Additional batteries are also being erected down the Potomac.

abstract: The Central Army Committee of the New-York Evangelical Alliance reported at a meeting of the Board, Monday evening, that, during last month, 520,600 pages of religious reading, 30,500 religious papers and 4,000 hymn-books had been sent to the Army; $120.82 liad been paid out, besides much of such matter that had been donated. Stalionery had been sent to many of the regiments.
lead_paragraph: The Central Army Committee of the New-York Evangelical Alliance reported at a meeting of the Board, Monday evening, that, during last month, 520,600 pages of religious reading, 30,500 religious papers and 4,000 hymn-books had been sent to the Army; $120.82 liad been paid out, besides much of such matter that had been donated. Stalionery had been sent to many of the regiments. The Committee was instructed to extend the work, and send reading to all the Chaplains who desire the same. The Secretary, Mr. GOSS, had visited some 40 of the regiments they were supplying at Washington. A joint Committee had been appointed at Washington, to distribute the reading, and arrangements made with the Postal Department for transportation from Washington to any point where the regiments may chance to be. A meeting is to be held next Sunday, in one of our City churches, when Mr. GOSS will give the result of his observations in the hospitals, camps and rebel prisons.

abstract: JOHN C. RAHMING, a merchant of this City, was arrested on Monday night at the instance of the Secretary of State, and confined with the rebels, traitors, and other enemies of the Government, at Fort Lafayette. He is charged with having held out inducements to the Captain of the schooner called the Arctic, to take a trip to Nassau, N.P., and convey thence a number of cannon to Wilmington, N.C., for the use of the Secessionists. The Captain having a fear that he should be unable to run the blockade, withstood Mr. RAHMING's offer, which was of a tempting character, and the cannon, as far as is known to the contrary, are still at the Bahamas. The prisoner is a West Indian by birth, and carried on business at No. 36 South-street.

abstract: The conjectures respecting the disposition of the prisoners [from] latieras Inlet have been wholly at fault. They are not to go on board of the old frigate Brandywine; but, by an order Issued yesterday, they will be placed on Governor's or Bedloe's Island, it is probable that they will be divided, a portion going to each of these forts. Fort Wood, on Bedloe's Island, is one of the strongest, as well as most convenient fortresses in this harbor for the accommodation of a garrison, and there could be no more comfortable or picturesque spot selected for the residence of the rebel prisoners than this spot. Inside of the fort proper there are good barrack accommodations for six hundred persons, with all the accessories of complete garrison quarters. Outside, there is an area of nearly five acres, handsomely, terraced from the water on all sides, with a sea wall surrounding the whole eastern portion, and the grounds Interspersed with beautiful shade-trees. The only thing which can be at all unpleasantly suggestive, is the fact that the pirate HICKS was executed oh the island. The distance from the Battery is about one mile, and nearly the same distance from the Jersey shore. The fort is supplied with water by two immense tanks, which hold several hundred thousand gallons each.

lead_paragraph: The Government has to its credit iun the SubTreasury and vaults of the banks. $50,000,000 in specie. The issue of Treasury Notes, paywable out of this fund. Would simply be cheeks against it precisely of the charaeter of those drawn by an ordinary depositor against his credits. A merchant going to Chicago or St. Louis, to make purchases of produce to the amount of $1,000,000, would take only a small portion of this sum in specie, as drafts upon New-York or Boston, or Philadelphia, would be worth to him more than specie, for exchange. If the Government should transport $5,000,000 in specie to St. Louis, to be paid out in military operations, the greater portion would speedily return to this City in the ordinary course of trude. The issue of an equal amount of Treasury Notes at St. Louis, would allow their equivalent in specie to remain on deposit, and maintain the amount held by the banks and Sub-Treasury at a uniform figure, avoiding in this way all anxiety about, or disturbance of the money market. The tendency of specie is always to the great centres, and if taken from, always returns to them. By leaving it in its proper place of deposit, and checking against it from all parts of the country, by an issue of Treasury notes, the operations of Government would harmonize with the public advantage, and save a great deal of expense and risk in the constant transmission of large sums of specie. An issue of Treasury Notes, to the amount of $20,000,000, would prevent an equal sum from being taken from the banks, to be kept moving from one point to another, or in the pockets of soldiers and officers, waiting some safe and convenient mode for transmission to their families. The withdrawal of so large a sum in coin from the vaults of the Banks could not fail to exert a very unfavorable influence over the money market and the operations of trade, no matter how probable its early return. The banks, as a matter of precaution, would always maintain a pretty uniform relation between their discounts and the amount of specie they held.

abstract: The Soutern Confederates are just now experiencing the truth of that old adage that "misfortunes never come single." The past week has been a black one in the Confederate calendar. It has been marked by the capture of Fort Halteras, and the effectual closing of Albemarle and Pamilco Sounds to the entrance or exit of privateers and their plunder.
lead_paragraph: The Soutern Confederates are just now experiencing the truth of that old adage that "misfortunes never come single." The past week has been a black one in the Confederate calendar. It has been marked by the capture of Fort Halteras, and the effectual closing of Albemarle and Pamilco Sounds to the entrance or exit of privateers and their plunder. This is the most serious blow to the piratical pursuits of the rebels that they have yet received. Hatteras Inlet was the chief and almost sole channel of communication with the ocean that Virginia and a large portion of North Carolina had left. Through it they had been enabled to continue a sort of contraband commerce in tar, turpentine and resin, tobacco and cotton. But that outlet of Confederate trade is hermetically sealed, and a convenient den of piratical sea-craft effectually broken up.

abstract: There are peculiarities in the relations of the United States Government and the insurgent States which cousiderably complicate the question of the "Blockade," a term which, for want of a better, we apply to the naval surveillance placed over the Southern ports. It is even frequently questioned whether we have a right to blockade our own ports.
lead_paragraph: There are peculiarities in the relations of the United States Government and the insurgent States which cousiderably complicate the question of the "Blockade," -- a term which, for want of a better, we apply to the naval surveillance placed over the Southern ports. It is even frequently questioned whether we have a right to blockade our own ports. Now there are on record certain cases of very great interest precisely similar to our own, and whose decision should set completely at rest any fears that our Government in its action has violated the principles of international law, or thrown itself open to reclamation on the part of foreign Powers. We shall cite two instances, the circumstances of which are identical, each to each, with those of the United States and the rebels -- that is, in which nations have set on foot a blockade of their own ports, for the purpose of more effectually suppressing armed insurrection within their own borders; and, in so doing, have been acknowledged to have committed no infringement of the law of nations.

abstract: The serenade to Commodore STRINGHAM, proposed to have been given, last night, by his fellow-citizens in Brooklyn, was postponed, on account of the non-appearance of Dodworth's Band, which had been engaged for the occasion. They did not keep their engagement, probably on account of the storm. But the people were not to be thwarted in their patriotism by the elements, and two thousand or more assembled in the Park, at 10 o'clock -- the hour appointed. The Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements stated that, owing to the absence of the band, the serenade would be postponed until to-morrow (this) evening, when the demonstration would take place, be the weather fair or foul, band or no band. These cheers were then given for Commodore STRINGHAY, three cheers for the troops who participated in the engagement at Hatteras Inlet, and three cheers for the "Old flag;" and then the large assemblage dispersed.
lead_paragraph: The serenade to Commodore STRINGHAM, proposed to have been given, last night, by his fellow-citizens in Brooklyn, was postponed, on account of the non-appearance of Dodworth's Band, which had been engaged for the occasion. But the people were not to be thwarted in their patriotism by the elements, and two thousand or more assembled in the Park, at 10 o'clock -- the hour appointed. The Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements stated that, owing to the absence of the band, the serenade would be postponed until to-morrow (this) evening, when the demonstration would take place, be the weather fair or foul, band or no band. These cheers were then given for Commodore STRINGHAY, three cheers for the troops who participated in the engagement at Hatteras Inlet, and three cheers for the "Old flag;" and then the large assemblage dispersed.
