abstract: In another column of this paper we reproduce articles from London journals, Criticising the ability of the American Government to pay the cost of the war. The London Times has for some time past devoted itself to this particular mode of attack upon the cause of the Union, as it has the advantage of inflicting...
lead_paragraph: In another column of this paper we reproduce articles from London journals, Criticising the ability of the American Government to pay the cost of the war. The London Times has for some time past devoted itself to this particular mode of attack upon the cause of the Union, as it has the advantage of inflicting what appears to be the maximum of damage with the least possible exposure of the assailant. To espouse in distinct terms the cause of the rebels; to advocate the acknowledgment of the Richmond Government; to recommend a disregard of the blockade, or the equipment of privateers, would expose, the Times to the charge of avowed sympathy with Slavery, and of substantially violating the neutrality laws. But, if it can dissuade the English capitalist from strengthening the pecuniary arm of the Northern war, while it leaves in freedom the Southern agents to effect what loans they can, the Times satisfies itself that it is as effectually promoting the overthrow of the Republic as if it gave to the insurgents ships, and men, and arms. And, as some evidence that its labors have not been unrewarded, it is to be remembered that, while the Washington Government has not gone nor had the thought to go into Lombard-street as a borrower of money, Southern negotiators have been there, and borne away large sums destined for the rebels. Witness the Bank of England bills found upon the man SERRELL, now a prisoner at Fort Lafayette, and those drafts of the Messrs. BARING found a few days since at the Park Bank. In other words, the lessons of the Times have really had their effect upon the British moneyed classes, who have never been disposed to look with favor upon American institutions or credit, because taught by mischievous instructors to regard repudiation as a cardinal doctrine of democracy, and to hold the National Treasury answerable for the deficiencies of Florida, Mississippi, and Arkansas. Of such instructors, the Times has been the most persistent and the least truthful.

abstract: Congress has decreed that the privileges extended to Don CRISANTO MEDINA to establish a national bank, have expired. It has also annulled the contract with Mr. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER to make a railroad across Chiriqui from the port of Golfe Dolce, on the Pacific, to Bocas del Toro, on the Atlantic; Mr. MEAGHER having failed to pay in the guarantee of $100,000 that he and his company would make the road.
lead_paragraph: Congress has decreed that the privileges extended to Don CRISANTO MEDINA to establish a national bank, have expired. abstract: The remains of Gen. LYON, which were deposited on Monday evening in the ear which had been prepared for them, and which was appropriately draped in black, left the depot yesterday, by the 12 1/4 train for New-Haven. There was no ceremony attendant upon the departure of the train, this hourhaving been selected by Gov. BUCKINGHAM, in order to enable the citizens of New-Haven to pay that tribute of respect to the memory of the distinguished deceased, which all desire to do.

abstract: The Funds opened rather dull on the 23d of August, but the business in the Money market caused a steady improvement, and they closed firm at 1/3 advance, and still tending upward. In the discount market the demand was limited, and the general rate remains at 4 1/2 cent. In the Stock market loans are offering at 2 1/2 @3 cent. About L100,000 in gold went into the Bank to-day.
lead_paragraph: The Funds opened rather dull on the 23d of August, but the business in the Money market caused a steady improvement, and they closed firm at 1/3 advance, and still tending upward. abstract: As many as Irvine Hall could hold --- and their name was legion, and a number of the legion consisted of ladies --- braved the storm last evening, to listen to the patriotic address of Mr. HOLT. The Chamber of Commerce, under whose auspices the address was delivered, was fully represented, so that, in point of numbers and personal character, the meeting was equal to any that has been held in the City in a building of similar size. The reception reached the utmost pitch of enthusiasm, and each of the orator's finely-rounded-sentences received its due meed of attention and applause. Those portions, particularly, which so bitterly denounced the traitors in our midst, were received with unbounded demonstrations of approval.
lead_paragraph: As many as Irvine Hall could hold --- and their name was legion, and a number of the legion consisted of ladies --- braved the storm last evening, to listen to the patriotic address of Mr. HOLT. abstract: The serenade and public reception of Commodore SRTINGHAM by his fellow-citizens in Brooklyn, at his residence, corner of Clark and Hicks streets, took place last evening.

The demonstration was creditable to the patriotism of the people, and one which will long be remembered by those who witnessed it. The time appointed by the Committee of Arrangements to assemble was 10 o'clock. Long before that hour, City Hall Square was crowded with people. abstract: The report still comes to us, with apparently strong confirmation now, that JEFFERSON DAVIS, the President of the "Confederate States," is dead. As we stated yesterday, there was nothing improbable in the announcement of his death, as it first reached us. He is known to have been a long time in feeble health.
lead_paragraph: The report still comes to us, with apparently strong confirmation now, that JEFFERSON DAVIS, the President of the "Confederate States," is dead. As we stated yesterday, there was nothing improbable in the announcement of his death, as it first reached us. He is known to have been a long time in feeble health. Seldom, for years past, has he been out of the hands of physicians; and only by incessant watchfulness of himself, and by indulging in frequent intervals of relaxation from public duty, has he been able to remain in the public service. His acceptance of the Presidency of the "Confederate States," which involved the labor of organizing a Government and creating and directing an Army and Navy, without means or credit, and without the world's sympathy, to say nothing of the formidable opposition of a nation in arms, was to annihilate all hope of restored and vigorous life. If he is a victim to his ambition, and his burdens have pressed him into his grave, he is happier than if he had lived to see his plans miscarry, and to hear his people's curses on his failure.
headline: {'main': 'The Death of Jefferson Davis.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Death of Jefferson Davis.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Corporal DIX, of the Third Iowa Regiment, while out on a scout with five men, near Kirksville, last week, was surrounded in a farm-house, when at dinner, by twenty-five rebels, who demanded the surrender of his party. This was refused, and the Secessionists made an attack on them.

abstract: The decision on the Mozart and Tammany causes much excitement, and there is some probability that an effort will be made to reconsider the action of the Convention to-morrow. This will be vigorously contested by the Mozarters, who are elated over their great triumph. The resolutions will be much as already indicated, -- decisive in support of the Government and for the prosecution of the war, but for a speedy and honorable peace, and full guarantees of equal rights under the Constitution, to all the States, and firm in opposition to the policy of the Republican Party. There will be, probably, a contest and debate on the resolutions, as many of the delegates favor a more distinctive peace policy.
lead_paragraph: The decision on the Mozart and Tammany causes much excitement, and there is some probability that an effort will be made to reconsider the action of the Convention to-morrow. There will be, probably, a contest and debate on the resolutions, as many of the delegates favor a more distinctive peace policy.

abstract: The Twentieth Regiment of Massachusetts, Col. LEE, will arrive in this City this morning. A deputation of the Sons of Massachusetts will receive the men on landing, and escort them to the Park Barracks, where they will partake of breakfast. Gov. ANDREWS, who is in this City, has been invited, and will partake of soldier's fare with them. It is expected the Governor will address them. The following gentlemen have had invitations sent them, and will no doubt be present: Gov. Morgan and staff, Wm. M. Evarts, Gen. Arthur, Com. Stringham, Col. Tompkins, Hiram Barney, David Dudley Field, W. Curtis Moyes, James Humphrey, Joseph Choate, P. Law Ohasted, George Ondyke, Capt. Marshall, Judge Bonney, J.C. Brady, William Allen Butler, Rev. Dr. Bellow, Rev. Dr. Tyng, Rev. Dr. Adams.

abstract: A company of 161 men, under command of Capt. JOHN SANDERS, of Salem, arrived yesterday from Massachusetts. Upon landing in this City, the men were marched to the Park Barracks, where they are now quartered. To-day they will leave this City for the seat of war to join Col. SANDER's regiment, which is already there. Accompanying Capt. SANDERS' commend is a baggage wagon, two ambulances and eight horses.

abstract: The carping  croakers in our midst, who can see nothing but corruption in the Government, and ultimate defeat for the Union cause, exhibit the most remarkable credulity.
lead_paragraph: -- The carping croakers in our midst, who can see nothing but corruption in the Government, and ultimate defeat for the Union cause, exhibit the most remarkable credulity. They see insurmountable financial obstacles in the path of 20,000,000 of people engaged in trade and commerce, with the money markets of the world open to them, and yet believe that 10,000,000 of an agricultural people, hemmed in by land and sea, with no national existence in the money market, and celebrated for repudiation, will have money plenty. They imagine that the North, with a superabun dance of fighting material of every kind -- of men, of arms, of ammunition, of clothing, of provisions and of medical stores, will be obliged to succumb to the South, which lacks all these essential requisites -- is suffering for nearly all of the luxuries and many of the necessaries of life -- is obliged to resort to drafting and conscription to procure men, robbery to procure food and clothing, and lying to prop a falling cause, The croakers see nothing but defeat for the North upon the sea, when every Southern port is blockaded, and the cowardly privateers are daily dodging the United States cruisers. The growlers discern death for the Union cause, in the defeat at Bull Run or at Springfield, Mo., but they can observe no damage to the rebel cause in the capture of PEGRAM and his forces, or the occupation of the forts at Hatteras Inlet. They grumble and groan and bewail every National loss, and rejoice at every rebel gain, forgetting that the defeat of the North is their own disgrace. In short, they delude themselves into believing that a nation of Northern hardy freemen, with men, money, all the paraphernalia of war, means of transportation by land and sea, and the sympathies of the world, besides justice and humanity, on their side, are to be defeated by a disorganized band of traitors of half their number, lacking the main essentials for successful warfare, cooped up like so many caged birds, and fighting against all the dictates of law, reason and humanity, with a population almost equal to their own ripe for insurrection.

abstract: The Third Regiment of New Hampshire, Col. FELLOWS, arrived at Hunter's Point, L.I., yesterday by the steamship Connecticut. From there the men were marched to the camp of instruction of Hempstead, where they will be instructed in the art of war, and form part of a division, and taught to act in concert without regiments. The men are armed with the Enfield rifle, and are a fine set of athletic young fellows, all of whom are perfectly uniformed and equipped. The regiment numbers 1,010, exclusive of officers.

From there the men were marched to the camp of instruction of Hempstead, where they will be instructed in the art of war, and form part of a division, and taught to act in concert without regiments. The men are armed with the Enfield rifle, and are a fine set of athletic young fellows, all of whom are perfectly uniformed and equipped. The regiment numbers 1,010, exclusive of officers.

abstract: The report of the death Of JEFF. DAVIS was received in Washington again yesterday, and seems to be generally credited not because the report  can be traced to a reliable source, but because it has long been believed that he must necessarily break down under the continued excitement and responsibility which he has experienced.
lead_paragraph: The report of the death Of JEFF. DAVIS was received in Washington again yesterday, and seems to be generally credited -- not because the report can be traced to a reliable source, but because it has long been believed that he must necessarily break down under the continued excitement and responsibility which he has experienced. Nothing was said, however, in reference to his demise, by persons who recently arrived from Richmond at Fortress Monroe under a flag of truce: and the Richmond Enquirer of the 29th ult., announces that he was considerably better on the day previous, and only needed a little rest to injure his perfect recovery. The Richmond Dispatch, of Tuesday, of last week, also contains a proclamation from the "President" convening the rebel Congress again on the 3d inst., on account of its failure to deliver to him for his signature a bill making military appointments.

abstract: Gen. BUTLER gives very cogent reasons why we should hold the forts on Hatteras Inlet, "the key of the Albemarle," as the rebel engineer there called it. But it is a great mistake to suppose, as has been stated, that these give us complete command of the whole of Pamlico Sound. To obtain possession of this and the adjoining waters there are three other points which it is absolutely necessary to hold, and it is a great pity that Gen. BUTLER and Commodore STRINGHAM, before returning to the pleasures of speechifying and receiving serenades, did not take the responsibility to secure them. There is, first, Oregon or New Inlet, about forty miles north of Cape Hatteras; an inlet that, like Hatteras, is of modern origin, having been formed by the tides, but affording five feet water at high tide -- quite sufficient to allow shoals of the light-draught piratical crew to issue forth. Next there is Ocracoke, which is about twelve miles southwest of Hatteras Inlet, and which the rebels have defended by a fort on Beacon Island, where there was some time ago a battery of 32-pounders, eight in number, but probably greatly strengthened since their loss. In a military point of view its possession is equally important as that of Hatteras Inlet, as it affords an easy entrance to Pamlico Sound and its numerous tributaries. Through this inlet vessels from Tarborough, Greenville, and Washington on the Pamlico River, and Waynesborough, Goldsborough, and Newbern on the Neuse River, have been in the habit of proceeding to sea carrying aid and comfort to the enemy at will. Lastly there is Beaufort, N.C., which it is absolutely necessary we get possession of. It is only by holding these three points, in addition to Hatteras, that we can be said really to command Pamlico Sound and the contiguous waters and shores. This effectually seals up the enemy and gives us control of nearly three hundred miles of coast, up to the present time the secure rendezvous for piratical expeditions. It will also deprive the enemy of that valuable internal commerce by means of which they have been enabled to supply Virginia on the one hand and North Carolina on the other. Privateers will no longer be able to reach the sea through the Dismal Swamp Canal and Albemarle Sound to annoy our commerce. Moreover, we can assemble inside of the outer coast hundreds of light-draught steamers and sailing vessels, and whenever we are ready we may throw an Army upon the main land and establish a military footing in North Carolina. In fact, an article in the Petersburgh Express of Sept. 2 admits that "the whole of the eastern part of the State is now exposed to the ravages of the merciless vandals. Newbern, Washington, Plymouth, Edenton, Hertford, Elizabeth City, are all now exposed, besides the whole of the adjacent country." These results are predicated on our obtaining possession of the three points we have indicated. Without these the light-draught vessels which have been continually annoying the Government by bringing in supplies to the rebels, and the privateers who prey on our commerce, will continue their nefarious traffic. Even as we write we have confirmations of both these facts. The Captain of a schooner, which arrived at this port yesterday morning from Baracoa, (a seaport on the northeastern coast of Cuba,) reports that on the 1st inst., when sixty miles east of Cape Hatteras, his vessel was chased by a privateer schooner, but escaped; and a late copy of the Richmond Dispatch informs us of the arrival of two vessels from Liverpool at Beaufort, N.C., laden with arms, ammunition, thread, quicksilver, etc.!

abstract: Copious extracts from the Petersburgh Express, of the 2d inst., which will be found elsewhere, convey a good idea of the intense panic and excitement created at the South by the successful coup de main upon Fort Hatteras.
lead_paragraph: Copious extracts from the Petersburgh Express, of the 2d inst., which will be found elsewhere, convey a good idea of the intense panic and excitement created at the South by the successful coup de main upon Fort Hatteras. "For the credit of the State," the editor of a Raleigh paper " forebore to describe the scene which followed the reading to the Legislature, by the Governor, of the dispatch announcing the disaster." It is hardly possible to describe the terror and apprehension which the capture of the fort has spread throughout the State and Eastern Virginia. Women and children are fleeing into the interior. The movement of considerable bodies of troops on their way to Richmond was countermanded, for the defence of menaced and unprotected towns upon Albemarle and Pamlico Sound. North Carolina has been so completely surprised, and is found so utterly defenceless, we cannot help wishing that something more than a demonstration upon a single point had not been undertaken. With a moderate force only, every important point in the eastern part of the State might have fallen an easy conquest, and a blow, overwhelming in its consequences, might have been struck.

abstract: and vigorous action taken by the Government has infused fresh courage and hopefulness into the public heart. Men who less than a week ago were desponding, are now full of confidence and resolution. The tide of events, which seemed to be adverse so long, has turned, and everything now seems to be working in favor of the Government. The splendid success of our fleet in capturing the forts at Hatteras; -- the vigor and energy displayed in FREMONT's proclamation; -- the wreck of the best of the rebel privateers; -- the reported death of their leader; -- the splendid response of the people to the call of the Government for money to carry on the war; -- the fresh life and activity visible in every department of the public service, and the highly encouraging reports which reach us from abroad, have combined to infuse hope and cheerful faith in the public mind. Business of all kinds shows the effect of this change. Men no longer fear to act. They have felt the strength and stability of the Government, and know now that it is ample for their protection. They no longer fear its overthrow, or what was far more dreadful, its decay and death from inanition. It has shown itself strong in the attachment of the people, -- the surest basis which any Government can possibly have.

abstract: Yesterday morning all the prisoners brought to this port on board the United States frigate Minnesota, were transferred to Fort Wood, on Bedloe's Island, and to Castle William, on Governor's Island. A large number of small boats, containing ladies and gentlemen, surrounded the steamboats Saturn and S.A. Stevens, which were employed to convey them to their quarters. They witnessed the disembarkation in silence; not a reproachful word was uttered, the spectators looking upon the prisoners more in sorrow than in anger.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning all the prisoners brought to this port on board the United States frigate Minnesota, were transferred to Fort Wood, on Bedloe's Island, and to Castle William, on Governor's Island. abstract: Yesterday, after the race between Ethan Allen and Flora Temple, in which Flora was beaten in three straight heats, she was seized on the track by Deputy Marshals HUNT and McCoy. It appears that from information received by the Assistant District Attorney, the owner of Flora, WILLIAM MCDONALD, of Baltimore, is engaged in raising a regiment, to be armed with double-barreled guns, in anticipation of Maryland being forced from the Union. The Marshal deputized an officer to take charge of her.

abstract: Eight of the crew of the revenue-cutter Forward, lying off Fort Carroll, were summarily dismissed, on Tuesday last, for refusing to take the oath of allegiance. They were receiving only $18 per month, while the crews of other boats are paid $20 hence their refusal to subscribe to the oath. The pay of seamen is fixed by regulation at $18 to 20 per month.

abstract: The London Saturday Review, appears to be in a most amusing state of perplexity about the financial position of this country, as contrasted with that of England.
lead_paragraph: The London Saturday Review, appears to be in a most amusing state of perplexity about the financial position of this country, as contrasted with that of England. In a recent article on the Money Market, we find an ungracious acknowledgment that though England is increasingly prosperous, still her public funds persist in remaining at low quotations, while those of this country are buoyant, notwithstanding our projected loan of $500,000,000 and our reverses at Bull Run.

abstract: nounce the appointment by Secretary CAMERON, of our townsman, THOMAS H. CANFIELD, to the responsible position of Assistant Manager of the Railways now run by the United States Government. The Government, it is well known, has now under its immediate charge, such railroads and telegraph lines as are upon doubtful territory, requiring Government aid and protection, and where there is danger of the enemy interrupting the communication. At present it has under its control the roads from Washington to Baltimore and Annapolis, and some in Virginia. The Assistant Secretary of War. Col. THOMAS A. SCOTT, is ex-officio Manager of these roads, but the active duties of this very responsible position are discharged principally by Assistant Manager CANFIELD, as Col. SCOTT's arduous duties in the War Office are about all he can conveniently attend to.

abstract: Yesterday, the sons and daughters too for that matter of Scotland were fairly represented at Jones' Wood. The occasion was the fifth annual festival of the Caledonian Club, the proceeds of which is for the
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the -- sons and daughters too for that matter -- of Scotland were fairly represented at Jones' Wood. The occasion was the fifth annual festival of the Caledonian Club, the proceeds of which is for the benefit of the widows and orphans of the gallant Seventy-ninth who fell at Bull Run. A number of the sterner sex were present, who, doubtless in the hurry and excitement of the day, had left home without any trousers. And the bonnie lasses, were they not there? Indeed were they, with the bloom of the hills and the heather on their checks; all in their "bran new goons," looking as pretty and as charming as any Jessie Browns ever did.

abstract: The news from Syracuse that Tammany Hall has finally been recognized as the regular representative of the Democracy of New-York City is of very great interest and importance. It will create a deep commotion, not only
lead_paragraph: The news from Syracuse that Tammany Hall has finally been recognized as the regular representative of the Democracy of New-York City is of very great interest and importance. It will create a deep commotion, not only here, out throughout the State; for the struggle between Tammany and Mozart has been so protracted, so bitter and notorious, that it has made almost every intelligent Democrat in the State either a sympathizer or a partisan. The quarrel, so quickly ended at Syracuse, will probably be appealed to the hustings, and, as compromise is no longer possible, the last arbitrament of main strength at the polls must be resorted to. One or the other faction will, in a few years, disappear, if the war between them is made proscriptive and unsparing.

abstract: The revenue officers, yesterday, seized the bark Laura Russ, of Belfast, Me., which is said to be partly owned in Florida. The officers of the steamship Marion, it is reported, found on board of the vessel a large Palmetto flag, and that the captain and mate denied having anything of the kind on board before it was found. The Laura Russ, according to the American Lloyd's Register, is an A 2 bark of 284 tons, built in Belfast, Me., in 1856, by PATTERSON, CARTER & Co., and owned by J.A. RUSS, of Belfast. The Palmetto flag has been carried for many years by vessels employed in Southern trade, and it used to be very commonly flown as a line signal in this harbor.

abstract: We shall probably soon hear of another battle in Western Virginia that is, if WISE and FLOYD are as anxious to meet Gen. ROSECRANS as they have pretended.
lead_paragraph: We shall probably soon hear of another battle in Western Virginia -- that is, if WISE and FLOYD are as anxious to meet Gen. ROSECRANS as they have pretended. A telegram has recently been received by the Government from Gen. ROSECRANS, which announces that he had advanced with a considerable portion of his command to a point midway between Bulltown and Flatwoods, on his way to attack the enemy in the vicinity of Summersville or Gauley Bridge. He left an ample force behind to protect the Cheat Mountain Pass, in front of LEE's position, and is ready for any attempt the latter may make to penetrate west of the mountains. Gen. ROSEGRANS was expected to join his forces with those of Gen. COX, and thus be able to drive both WISE and FLOYD to desperate straits, in the way either of fighting or running.

abstract: As a matter of course, the Herald denounces JOSEPH HOLT and his speech at Irving Hall. That secession sheet sustained BUCHANAN all through the treason which would
lead_paragraph: As a matter of course, the Herald denounces JOSEPH HOLT and his speech at Irving Hall. That secession sheet sustained BUCHANAN all through the treason which would have betrayed the Union to its destruction if Mr. HOLT had not come to the rescue. The Herald is consistent in its wickedness if in nothing else, -- and nobody was disappointed or surprised by its venomous and malignant attack in its yesterday's issue on Mr. HOLT.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. CLARKE, whose great comic powers have caused a revival in theatrical matters here, and gladdened the elegant establishment where he performs with a constant succession of crowded houses, takes his benefit to-night, and will make his last appearance but one before a New-York audience. The bill for the occasion is all that can be desired by the lovers of fun. We hope that it may draw an overbrimming house. Mr. CLARKE is one of the few comedians who combine genial [???] of style with unfailing elegance.

abstract: The TIMES is referred  to now and then as one of the newspapers which joined in the "On to Richmond" cry, and thus precipitated the movement which
lead_paragraph: -- The TIMES is referred to now and then as one of the newspapers which joined in the "On to Richmond" cry, and thus precipitated the movement which ended in the Bull Run disaster. The assertion is partly true. We did urge the Government to push forward the attack upon the rebels with greater vigor and energy than they were then showing, -- and we insisted also on the absolute necessity of compelling them to evacuate Virginia, and of surrendering Richmond, which they had made the capital of their bogus Confederacy. But we did not urge an advance upon Richmond by way of Manassas. On the contrary, we repeatedly warned the Government against allowing the rebels to dictate the time and place of battle. We remonstrated against a policy which would permit the South to collect their whole force in Virginia, and there, with their consolidated armies, meet any attack we might make upon them. What we urged, was that our Government, leaving a sufficient force at Washington to render it secure against attack, should use the Navy to make attacks upon the Southern seacoast, -- to harass and destroy the rebel forces in the very States which had been the seat of the original rebellion. This policy, we insisted, would compel them to withdraw their troops from Virginia, in order to provide for the defence of the menaced Gulf States. North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, South Carolina, each would have been under the absolute necessity of recalling all her own troops to defend her own coasts. Virginia would thus have been thrown wholly and entirely upon her own resources, -- and the path to Richmond would have been open and free to our troops from Washington.

abstract: Vast losses have no doubt been suffered by the Northern States on account of the civil war, chiefly in the temporary diminution of the internal trade of the country, which has been caused far more by apprehension of dis
lead_paragraph: Vast losses have no doubt been suffered by the Northern States on account of the civil war, chiefly in the temporary diminution of the internal trade of the country, which has been caused far more by apprehension of disasters than by those actually sustained. Yet the strength and elements of prosperity still retained will, when fully understood, be a marvel to the world, and are a most striking proof that the North, previous to the rebellion, constituted the wealth and real power of the country. There never was an instance in which a civil war, dividing a country nearly in twain, injured one portion so little and the other so much. The reason is to be found in the fact that the Northern States form a complete and rounded people in themselves, so thoroughly independent of the others that the civil war in which they are engaged does not, for a moment, compare in its onerousness, or in its disastrous consequences, with one with any respectable European power. In its effect upon the trade of the country, it is as if a certain and inconsiderable portion of it had disappeared, leaving unimpaired all the elements of its prosperity. The loss so far can be easily calculated. The reduction of the rebellion may be an expensive affair, but as soon as we have recovered our self-possession, the expenditures incurred will operate to recover the business of the country from the torpor into which it had fallen. The progress of population in the Northern States will, in a few years, with the entire cessation of that of the South, give us a trade equal in value to that we ever possessed. No hostile foot of a rebel in arms has ever trod the free soil of the North. No one of its citizens has, on account of the war, had to forego any accustomed avocation. All its internal routes of commerce have been uninterrupted, and were never more thronged with traffic than since the outbreak. The industries of a population in the Northern States, greater than that of Great Britain, have hardly been more interrupted, or really threatened by the rebels, than were those of that country by the Chinese in the recent war with that nation. With internal quiet, order and protection -- with elements of wealth, and with a capacity for its acquisition which no other nation has displayed, such an event as the rebellion, no matter what its magnitude, is really a trifling affair, because a people free, rich and unembarrassed, is assaulted by one really held by it in chains.

abstract: SEIZURE OF ARMS. -- At an early hour yesterday morning, Deputy United States Marshal S.A. FRENCH, of Jersey City, seized forty-one muskets at Strabuberg, in Borgen township. The muskets belonged to the "American Guard," of that place, who are believed to be Secessionists. The guns were brought to Jersey City, and were placed in possession of the Chief of Police until further action.

abstract: FATAL INJURY BY A FERRY-BOAT. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of JAMES KIERNAN, who was fatally injured, on Thursday afternoon, by being run down by the ferry-boat Louisa, on the East River. From the evidence at the inquest, it appears that deceased and a man named LOONEY were rowing on the river towards Green Point, and undertook to cross...
lead_paragraph: FATAL INJURY BY A FERRY-BOAT. -- Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of JAMES KIERNAN, who was fatally injured, on Thursday afternoon, by being run down by the ferry-boat Louisa, on the East River. From the evidence at the inquest, it appears that deceased and a man named LOONEY were rowing on the river towards Green Point, and undertook to cross the course of the ferry-boat, and, notwithstanding the alarm whistle was given by the man at the wheel, the row-boat was kept on its direct course, and was consequently run under. Both LOONEY and deceased were thrown into the water. They were very soon rescued; but it was found that KIERNAN was fatally injured, and he was conveyed to Bellevue Hospital, where he died yesterday. The evidence did not show carelessness on the part of the engineer or pilot of the ferry-boat. Verdict -- accidental death. Deceased was an Irishman, twenty-four years of age.

abstract: Men of business have little difficulty in understanding the pleasure of having a mean, dishonest and unscrupulous sneak for a nextdoor neighbor, or a business competitor. Those who lack opportunities for appreciating the full delights of such a situation, will do well to consider the case of newspaper Editors...
lead_paragraph: Men of business have little difficulty in understanding the pleasure of having a mean, dishonest and unscrupulous sneak for a nextdoor neighbor, or a business competitor. Those who lack opportunities for appreciating the full delights of such a situation, will do well to consider the case of newspaper Editors who are condemned to maintain a sort of business rivalry with "the bewhipped and bekicked" old vagabond of the Herald. Without the slightest regard for truth, utterly ignorant of the meaning of personal honor, -- incapable even of understanding the degradations and ignominies that have been heaped upon him so long that he would miss a congenial stimulus if they were ever to be withheld, -- unscrupulous in his choice of means as in the ends he proposes, and ready to listen at a keyhole, purloin a private letter, betray business confidence, or commit any other outrage which might stab a rival or feed for a moment his own malignity, he makes himself as a business competitor very much what a hedgehog, or a skunk, or both combined, would be as a play-fellow. Partly from instinct, and partly from choice, he has copied his style of professional warfare from the military strategy of the Chinese. So long as those weapons will serve his turn, he relies on lying and treachery; -- when these fail, and the contest waxes desperate, he resorts to stink-pots. In this style of warfare, he certainly manifests great skill, -- but his supremacy, such as it is, is due mainly to the fact that he uses weapons which, from the necessity of the case, leave him the whole field to himself. Nine-tenths of his infamous calumnies pass without notice, simply because it is more disagreeable to have anything whatever to do with him than it is to submit to his slanders.
headline: {'main': 'A Delightful Competitor.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Delightful Competitor.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SLAVES. Some question has been raised as to the law of Congress under which Gen. FREMONT'S proclamation concerning the slaves of rebels, was issued. So far as we understand the matter, Gen. FREMONT'S declaration goes somewhat beyond the letter of any law which has been enacted on this subject.
lead_paragraph: SLAVES. -- Some question has been raised as to the law of Congress under which Gen. FREMONT'S proclamation concerning the slaves of rebels, was issued. So far as we understand the matter, Gen. FREMONT'S declaration goes somewhat beyond the letter of any law which has been enacted on this subject. The law of Congress, passed Aug. 6, provides that any property which may be employed in aiding the rebellion shall be "lawful subject of prize and capture wherever found," -- and shall be "seized, confiscated and condemned." It further provides that, whenever "any person held to service or labor under the law of any State shall be required or permitted to be employed upon any fort, ship, intrenchment, or other military work against the Government of the United States," in every such case, "the person to whom such service or labor is claimed to be due shall forfeit his claim to such labor, any law of the United States to the contrary notwithstanding." This is the provision of Congress on this subject. It is very guarded in its terms, and relates exclusively to slaves that may be employed in the rebellion.

abstract: This morning, at 11 o'clock, Gen. GRANT, with two regiments of infantry, one company of light artillery and two gunboats, took possession of Paducah, Ky. He found secession flags flying in different parts of the city, in expectation of greeting the arrival of the Southern Army, which was reported 3,800 strong, 16 miles distant. The loyal citizens tore down the secession flags on the arrival of our troops.

abstract: I have been employed a little short of seven years in East Tennessee, (Polk County,) as agent for the Eureka Mining Company. The company worked its mine under a Tennessee charter and Tennessee laws. My business was to represent the Company at the mine, and do such business relating to its affairs as they would have done if present -- report periodically my proceedings to them, and receive such instructions as the Board of Direction thought proper to give. My family resides in Brooklyn, N.Y., and it was my custom and privilege, at seasonable opportunities, and at intervals of from nine to twelve months, to leave the mine and spend a few weeks with my wife and children. Shortly after the question of separation or no separation, (from the Union,) and associate questions, had been passed upon in Tenessee by the popular vote, and before the result was fully known to the public, the period arrived for a customary visit to my family, and I chose the route most free from political excitement at the time, viz.: from East Tennessee via Chattanooga, Nashville, Louisville, Ky., to Crestline, Indianapolis, Pittsburgh, Harrisburgh, &c., &c., to New-York. In East Tennessee there was a strong predominance of the Union feeling, and discussions were generally held on the highways and on the streets, by opposing political parties, with much asperity; the language of both being usually put in the superlative degree of comparison -- and being generally wound up with a significant stress placed upon the expression: "Well! wait; we'll see what next they'll do," to which Union men would add: "I wonder if (or, I hope) Government will help us."

abstract: The Susquehannah man-of-war run down from Fort Hatteras to Ocracoke Inlet, the other day, and found that the fortifications at the latter place had been abandoned by the Confederates, and "the white flag was everywhere displayed." This is good news for the "peace men" of Connecticut, who were taken with such a rage, a few days since, to "raise the white feather." The fact will confirm them in the belief that there is more real liberty in Dixie than in the United States. There the people can raise the white flag and surrender; here they are not allowed to do so. It is a humiliating contrast; but the peace party should rejoice that there is some part of the Union where white flags are not only tolerated but regarded as becoming.

abstract: The steamers Harriet Lane and Monticello arrived this morning from Hatteras Inlet. All on board are well. The latter brings intelligence of the evacuation of Fort Morgan, at Ocracoke Inlet, twelve miles south of Hatteras, by the rebels, after they had spiked their guns and destroyed their munitions of war. It mounted six guns. The Susquehannah was to go down and take possession yesterday.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Thursday, Sept. 5, Via BALTIMORE, Friday, Sept. 6.

abstract: Our news from Fort Hatteras is highly important and highly encouraging. It appears that hundreds of citizens of the old North State have a gone forth to meet the Union forces, to rejoice once more in the floating of the Stars and stripes over their heads, and to asseverate, in the solemn form of an oath, that they are true, and mean to be true to the old Constitution of their fathers.
lead_paragraph: Our news from Fort Hatteras is highly important and highly encouraging. It appears that hundreds of citizens of the old North State have a gone forth to meet the Union forces, to rejoice once more in the floating of the Stars and stripes over their heads, and to asseverate, in the solemn form of an oath, that they are true, and mean to be true to the old Constitution of their fathers. If this story is not a needless and wicked fabrication, (which we see no reason for believing,) our Government has struck a lead, in miners' phrase, in the old North State, that it has long been looking for -- the honest and hearty Unionism of the South, praying to the National Government for relief from the armed usurpers of Montgomery and Richmond.

abstract: A bill admitting Missouri into the Southern Confederacy, on certain conditions, was passed by the Confederate Congress on Monday, Aug. 10. The conditions are that Missouri shall duly ratify the Constitution of the Southern Confederacy, through her legally constituted authority, which authority is declared to be the Government of Gov. JACKSON, who was lately deposed. President DAVIS is also authorized to muster into the Confederate service, in Missouri, such troops as may volunteer to serve in the Southern Army. The bill likewise empowers the President of the Confederate States, at his discretion, at any time prior to the admission of said State as a member of the Confederacy, to perfect and proclaim an alliance, offensive and defensive, with the said Government, limited to the period of the existing war between this Confederacy and the United States, the said treaty or alliance to be in force from the date thereof, and until the same shall be disaffirmed or rejected by this Congress.
lead_paragraph: A bill admitting Missouri into the Southern Confederacy, on certain conditions, was passed by the Confederate Congress on Monday, Aug. 10. abstract: Islip, L.I., appears to be infected with a smal band of sympathisers with JEFF. DAVIS, who leave rendered themselves so obnoxious to the loyal citizens of the place that they have found it necessary to make a demonstration.
lead_paragraph: Islip, L.I., appears to be infected with a smal band of sympathisers with JEFF. DAVIS, who leave rendered themselves so obnoxious to the loyal citizens of the place that they have found it necessary to make a demonstration. The rebel sympathisers, it is said, mostly attend the Episcopal Church, and the fact that no flag has floated from that edifice while the other societies displayed their colors, has been asource of annoyance to many residents. Last week the church authorities were requested to raise a flag. This they refused to do on the ground that the Society could not afford to buy one. The Committee of loyal citizens offered to give them one if they would raise it. This offer they declined to accept, and positively refused to have a flag on the church. Last Saturday night the Committee procured a flag and placed it on the highest point of the church. The pastor and several members of the congregation were indgnant when they saw what had been done, and threatened to remove the obnoxious emblem. They were quietly told that if they tore that flag down the church would be leveled to the ground. It is hardly necessary to say that the warning was heeded and the Stars and Stripes still wave over the church.

abstract: Died, in the City of Detroit, on the 4th inst., ARTUR S. CASTLE, son of Dr. A.C. CASTLE, of this City. Cut off as he was entering upon the threshold of his manhood, ARTHUR S. CASTLE presented a high order of intellect, possessing extraordinary abilities. As an artist in painting, modeling, and sculpture, he offered great promise, at a future period, to add his name to the list and fame of American genius. For several years he was engaged in the engineering department of the Brooklyn Navy-yard, where his talents and urbane address were much appreciated. Our City has lost a promising young citizen. He died away from home, in a strange city. But the maternal care of Mrs. BUHL, wife of the Mayor of the City of Detroit; the attention of Bishop MCCLOSKY, and the brotherly nursing of Mr. HARRINGTON, did all that Christian love and human aflection could accomplish to effect his recovery, and soften his path to the grave.

abstract: -The Savannah Republican says that "the stock of flannel having been pretty well exhausted in the Southern markets," it will be doing the public a service by suggesting that a very excellent substitute may be found in the "common, coarse Georgia Osnaburgs," which make excellent undershirts -- good, especially for rheumatic complaints. We suspect that the South suffers more from a weakness in the chest, than from rheumatism. The blockade, which has been doing them "no harm" seems to have cut off their supply of flannel at all events. Possibly they may find themselves short of some other articles of necessity and comfort ere long.

abstract: The public are already somewhat familiar with the facts attending the arrest of Col. LATSON, of the Horse Artillery, encamped at Staten Island, and of his discharge. Col. BURTNETT, who represents himself as "Major Commanding the Coast Brigade at Fortress Monroe," ingratiated himself with the officers of...
lead_paragraph: The public are already somewhat familiar with the facts attending the arrest of Col. LATSON, of the Horse Artillery, encamped at Staten Island, and of his discharge. Col. LATSON, under the advice of Judge BIRDSALL, after his discharge, proceeded to ascertain the immediate cause of his persecutions. He learned that DANIEL H. BURTNETT, who represents himself as "Major Commanding the Coast Brigade at Fortress Monroe," ingratiated himself with the officers of Col. LATSON's Staff, and stirred up the difficulties with a view of superseding Col. L. in command of the said Artillery. Having learned these facts, he inquired into BURTNETT's history, and learned that he, BURTNETT, at the time the mob collected at the Daily News Office, took the American Flag and concealed it under a sofa, and then drew a pistol and threatened to shoot any person who interfered to take it, or force the proprietors to hoist the flag; also, that BURTNETT has been holding secret correspondence with Gen. BEAUREGARD, through his (Gen. B.'s) sister, who resides in Union-square; also that he (BURTNETT) was concerned in carrying on communication with the rebel Army from Fortress Monroe, by a secret telegraphic wire which he had assisted in laying from that post. These facts, by advice of the District-Attorney, were reduced to form in the office of Judge BIRDSALL, and were ready to be sworn to yesterday at 4 1/2 o'clock P.M., when BURTNETT, accompanied by GEORGE W. MEAD, Quartermaster in Col. LATSON's Staff, and three others, entered Judge BIRDSALL's office, closed and fastened the doors, drew four revolving pistols, and presented one to the head of the Colonel, saying "I will give you one minute for your life," and then, turning to a brother of the Judge, who was engaged in drawing the papers, said, "You d -- d scoundrels, you're concerned in this as well as LATSON," and snatched all the papers from his hand. Terror-stricken by the five men with drawn pistols, he begged to be released from the ruffians. Having been released, he left the place and went in search of an officer; the armed men went away with the papers and all the evidence of his (BURTNETT's) treason. The parties were subsequently all arrested, upon a warrant issued by Justice KELLY, and were committed in default of bail.

abstract: The "Spingler Institute," which was for years a prominent object on Union-square, derived its name from the family estate upon which the building stood. After Mr. ABBOT had become the proprietor of the Townsend house on Fifth-avenue, he retained for a year or two the school on Union-square, and applied the name Spingler to both establishments. But now that the Union-square Institute is converted into a hotel, there would be no propriety in retaining the name of the old house-lot for a school in another place; and at the suggestion of friends Mr. ABBOT has very properly given his own name to an institution planned and nurtured by himself.

abstract: While it is gratifying to all friends of the Union and Constitution to see the evidences of the popular faith in the Government, and its restoration which day adds unto day, it must be especially gratifying to the President to know how much this sanguine temper results from the energy recently displayed by his Administration.
lead_paragraph: While it is gratifying to all friends of the Union and Constitution to see the evidences of the popular faith in the Government, and its restoration which day adds unto day, it must be especially gratifying to the President to know how much this sanguine temper results from the energy recently displayed by his Administration. Only a few weeks ago expressions of the profoundest despondency were on every lip, and discouraged almost every patriotic movement. It was doubted whether men and money could be had to prosecute the war. Men began to accustom themselves to the worst alternative offered by an unsuccessful contest and a humiliating peace; and for a moment it seemed that the cause was likely to be sacrificed, not because the people were not in earnest, but because they could not discover in those administering the Government any sympathy with their earnestness and its aims. The events which have followed the stern lesson learned at Bull Run have almost entirely dispelled this general sentiment of despair, and replaced it with one of wholesome and amply authorized hopefulness. We now know that the Administration has some realization of the occasion and its requirements. It has entered upon a new and more active course; and it has only to persevere in the same direction, and with the same desire to exert the full powers conferred upon it by the people, to reach a triumphant result.

abstract: The news from Kentucky this morning is of the highest importance. I Yesterday forenoon Gen. GRANT, commanding the National forces at Cairo, with two regiments of infantry, one company of light artillery and two gunboats, took possession of Paducah, which has for some time been notorious as the rendezvous of Secessionists.
lead_paragraph: The news from Kentucky this morning is of the highest importance. I Yesterday forenoon Gen. GRANT, commanding the National forces at Cairo, with two regiments of infantry, one company of light artillery and two gunboats, took possession of Paducah, which has for some time been notorious as the rendezvous of Secessionists. He was not a moment too soon in this movement, as he found secession flags flying in different parts of the city in anticipation of the arrival of the rebel Army, which was repoted to be only sixteen miles distant, 4,800 strong. When Gen. GRANT entered the place, however, the loyal citizens tore down those flags. Our men then took possession of the telegraph office, the railroad depot and the Marine Hospital, and found large quantities of rations and leather intended for the rebel Army. Gen. GRANT immediately issued a proclamation, in which he assured the citizens that he had not come among them as an enemy, but to Insure the protection of loyal citizens. The importance of this movement is hardly to be estimated at present.
headline: {'main': 'NEWS OF THE DAY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NEWS OF THE DAY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: HON. J.W. VAMCE Dear Sir: I was pleased to hear from you. It is scarcely probable that we shall meet again in State Convention, where our most interesting acquaintance has taken place. Yet I feel as intensely as ever on subjects pertaining to the welfare of our Government, and fully sympathize with you in your apprehensions as to the effect of forming a new political party at this time.

abstract: The haste with which Congress closed its business and adjourned, is likely to beget several very embarrassing and, perhaps, injurious effects upon public interests. The contradictions between certain acts in the published pamphlet, the needless repetitions, the grammatical inaccuracies, which unfriendly criticism has pointed out, are of little essential importance, and may be cured at the approaching regular session.
lead_paragraph: The haste with which Congress closed its business and adjourned, is likely to beget several very embarrassing and, perhaps, injurious effects upon public interests. The contradictions between certain acts in the published pamphlet, the needless repetitions, the grammatical inaccuracies, which unfriendly criticism has pointed out, are of little essential importance, and may be cured at the approaching regular session. But it is of more moment that the Administration has already had to lament sundry deficiencies of power which it requires legislation to supply, and without which it will be difficult to give that thorough efficiency to the prosecution of the war which the people and the Executive equally desire to communicate. We have heretofore taken occasion to note some of the more prominent of such omissions. Another, likely to have highly prejudicial results, has been discovered, and to supply it the President deems it necessary to await the reassembling of Congress. We refer to the neglect to authorize the appointment of cadets at West Point to fill the places vacated by the seceded States.

abstract: We publish to-day the official reports of Major STURGIS and Brig.-Gen. SIEGEL, of the battle of Wilson's Creek, (near Springfield, Mo.) These concise and lucid reports fully confirm the accounts given by our own correspondents, and by inferior officers, of the great spirit and courage displayed on that hard-fought field by the soldiers of loyal Missouri, of Iowa and Kansas. Less than four thousand of these bold Western men attacked an enemy counting six times their number, and engaged him in close and uninterrupted conflict for six hours -- their thinned ranks ever again and again rallying and pressing forward with ever increasing vigor -- driving the enemy from point to point in confusion -- now scattering his forces in detail, and now, with desperate valor, engaging him along the entire line, "the enemy appearing in front in three or four ranks, lying down, kneeling, and standing, the lines of the combatants often approaching within 30 or 40 yards of each other" -- now, after hours of hot and bloody work, while the battle still raged with unabated fury and the fortunes of the day began to look doubtful, with the gallant LYON at the head of his shattered force, swinging his chapeau and shouting to his men to follow him, pressing the enemy back until the field seemed clear -- and then, even after that gallant soldier had gloriously fallen, unflinchingly maintaining their position and renewing the combat with greater fierceness than ever, till the enemy was precipitately driven from the field -- leaving nearly three thousand of his number hors du combat. Nearly a thousand of our troops fell; and never fell a thousand heroes on a better-contested field. The remnant retired in order and at their leisure to Springfield. Missouri, Iowa and Kansas, the three uterine brothers of the Free West, mingled their blood in a common cause; and have surrounded themselves with a halo of immortal glory.
lead_paragraph: We publish to-day the official reports of Major STURGIS and Brig.-Gen. SIEGEL, of the battle of Wilson's Creek, (near Springfield, Mo.) Nearly a thousand of our troops fell; and never fell a thousand heroes on a better-contested field. The remnant retired in order and at their leisure to Springfield. abstract: Money is unchanged. Thus far the taking of the loan has had no visible effect upon the market. Money is abundant at 5@6 per cent. on prime securities. The increasing volume of business has added somewhat to the supply of good paper. New-York owes Boston largely, although considerable specie has recently come hitherward, the banks holding seven and a quarter millions, after somewhat heavy payments into the National Treasury. Sterling bills are quiet at 107@107 1/2 -- the latter being the quotation for the best bankers' bills. The export and import trade continues favorable to this country, in its present peculiar condition. It is buying little and selling much, and thereby is financially independent of the rest of the world.

abstract: SUICIDE A MELANCHOLY CASE. A young man named WILLIAM UNDERWOOD, about 28 years of age, native of Boston, but for the last five years a merchant in the city of Milwaukee, Wis., committed suicide yesterday morning about 9 o'clock, at the private boarding-house of Mrs. AYRES, No.57 Springstreet, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE -- A MELANCHOLY CASE. -- A young man named WILLIAM UNDERWOOD, about 28 years of age, native of Boston, but for the last five years a merchant in the city of Milwaukee, Wis., committed suicide yesterday morning about 9 o'clock, at the private boarding-house of Mrs. AYRES, No.57 Springstreet, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver. For the last five years Mr. UNDERWOOD has been doing a successful business in Milwaukee, but since the war began his business, in common with others, had become embarrassed, and about three weeks ago he left the West and came to the City of New-York, in company with a young wife, to whom he had been but a short time united, for the purpose of trying to raise his sinking fortunes, and upon his arrival here, took rooms in Spring-street. Yesterday morning he went to a gun-shop in Broadway and purchased a pistol, also some powder, and several balls, returned to his rooms, and very deliberately loaded the weapon, after having carefully examined it, -- his wife all the time observing his movements without the slightest suspicion of his ultimate design. Mrs. UNDERWOOD having occasion shortly after to leave the room, the unfortunate man took the opportunity to fire the pistol. Its contents lodged in his brain, producing immediate death. Coroner SCHIRMER was notified and held an inquest yesterday afternoon, when the above facts were elicited. No cause for the commission of the fatal deed is assigned, beyond that of pecuniary embarrassment. His young and amiable wife is thus left heart-broken and disconsolate in a land of staangers.

abstract: Among the items of news brought by the Arago is one that will be hailed with pleasure by all friends of free thought in this country. It is that Protestants are to be permitted to open schools in France. Thus does the Emperor give anew the assurance that his policy is progress;" and France is made illustrious by the embodiment of the principle in her own social life.

abstract: Everything was very quiet in the vicinity of Washington yesterday not even a skirmish between pickets occurring to break the monotony. The rebels have a made several movements recently, apparently with a view to congregating a larger force around Munson's Hill, though their force, as ascertained by a balloon observation yesterday, has not been increased.
lead_paragraph: Everything was very quiet in the vicinity of Washington yesterday -- not even a skirmish between pickets occurring to break the monotony. The rebels have a made several movements recently, apparently with a view to congregating a larger force around Munson's Hill, though their force, as ascertained by a balloon observation yesterday, has not been increased. They yesterday receded on a line west from Ball's Cross-roads to the Chain Bridge, and our pickets took up corresponding advanced positions. It is believed, from information received in Washington, that a large portion of the rebel force at Manassas is being moved, but to what point is at present unknown.

abstract: Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen:  Whence this mighty gathering before me, and all around me? and for what purpose? Whence and why these spires pointing to Heaven, telling of refinement and religion? Whence these institutions of learning? Whence these beautiful abodes, these gathering places of affection around whose hearthstones a free and happy people cluster? Whence this beautiful valley spread out here, no less beautiful than this sky, so "darkly, deeply, beautifully blue?"

abstract: -- A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce will be held at 1 o'clock P.M., Monday, Sept. 9, to elect three members of "The Board of Commissioners of Pilots," to serve for a period of two years, in place of Messrs. ROBERT L. TAYLOR, CHAS. H. MARSHALL and E.E. MORGAN, whose term of service has expired. abstract: SIR: I have the honor herewith to submit a report of a short but lively affair which took place on the 3d inst. between this ship and two of the batteries located near to and back of the City of Galveston. The city is, as the accompanying sketch will show, entirely at our mercy; but I have never had any intention of troubling them, as I considered my duty was simply to blockade and stop the commerce of the port, a I frankly told the military commandant, Capt. (now Col.) MOORE, who called upon me shortly after our arrivalto inquire into the truth or falsity of a report, to wit, that I had threatened to bombard the town if my duty of blockading was interfered with by them in any way.

abstract: By an arrival from Gauley Bridge, says the Cincinnati Press of Thursday, we learn that an engagement took place some miles beyond that place on Sunday last, which resulted in the complete rout of the rebels under FLOYD, by the Eleventh Ohio and the Second Kentucky Regiments. Our informant left on Monday, and although he is unable to give all of the particulars, there can be no question as to the truth regarding the battle and the victory.
lead_paragraph: By an arrival from Gauley Bridge, says the Cincinnati Press of Thursday, we learn that an engagement took place some miles beyond that place on Sunday last, which resulted in the complete rout of the rebels under FLOYD, by the Eleventh Ohio and the Second Kentucky Regiments. Our informant left on Monday, and although he is unable to give all of the particulars, there can be no question as to the truth regarding the battle and the victory.

abstract: It is with profound pleasure that we send word to our namesake across the waters -- the Times, of London -- that there exist greatly increased facilities of foreign commerce, at present, in the Southern Confederacy. The Richmond Congress, being incensed by the blockade, have lately passed an act of a startling character, and every English bottom will be interested in it. It is an act, so the Confederate newspapers describe it, "to throw open the whole of the Southern coast for the entry of vessels."
lead_paragraph: It is with profound pleasure that we send word to our namesake across the waters -- the Times, of London -- that there exist greatly increased facilities of foreign commerce, at present, in the Southern Confederacy. abstract: During harvest-time the reports from nearly all sections of the great Northwest with regard to the crop of Spring wheat were more encouraging then we had reason to expect, taking into account the backward and unsettled weather during April and May. During the months of June and July it was said we would have scarcely half a crop; but as harvest drew near the prospects improved, and with the old wheat left over, it was generally estimated that there would be nearly, if not quite, an average. Within the past 10 or 12 days, however, it has been found that the crop does not thresh out anything like the amount expected. In the northern part of the State especially is the yield deficient. Along the line of the Galena and Chicago Railroad and its branches it will not yield on an average quite ten bushels to the acre; while last year the yield was fully thirty bushels. On the line of the Rock Island and Burlington Roads the reports are not quite so gloomy; but the highest yield we have reported to us is twelve bushels to the acre on an average, while in some places it is as low as ten bushels. From Minnesota and Northern Iowa the same gloomy reports come to hand. The Club wheat in the former State is almost a failure; but the "Fife wheat" is a fair crop. In Southern Wisconsin the reports are in substance similar to those from the northern part of this State. In some places the quality is much poorer than last year.
lead_paragraph: During harvest-time the reports from nearly all sections of the great Northwest with regard to the crop of Spring wheat were more encouraging then we had reason to expect, taking into account the backward and unsettled weather during April and May. During the months of June and July it was said we would have scarcely half a crop; but as harvest drew near the prospects improved, and with the old wheat left over, it was generally estimated that there would be nearly, if not quite, an average. Within the past 10 or 12 days, however, it has been found that the crop does not thresh out anything like the amount expected. In the northern part of the State especially is the yield deficient. Along the line of the Galena and Chicago Railroad and its branches it will not yield on an average quite ten bushels to the acre; while last year the yield was fully thirty bushels. On the line of the Rock Island and Burlington Roads the reports are not quite so gloomy; but the highest yield we have reported to us is twelve bushels to the acre on an average, while in some places it is as low as ten bushels. From Minnesota and Northern Iowa the same gloomy reports come to hand. The Club wheat in the former State is almost a failure; but the "Fife wheat" is a fair crop. In Southern Wisconsin the reports are in substance similar to those from the northern part of this State. In some places the quality is much poorer than last year.

abstract: The markets continue variable on leading articles of courtry produce, and comparing their present condition with that at the date of our last weekly review, we remark that Flour has been subject to less fluctuation than Wheat, being on the whole pretty well maintained and closing firm, with a slight improvement on some brands.
lead_paragraph: The markets continue variable on leading articles of courtry produce, and comparing their present condition with that at the date of our last weekly review, we remark that Flour has been subject to less fluctuation than Wheat, being on the whole pretty well maintained and closing firm, with a slight improvement on some brands. In Wheat, while a slight decline has taken place in red and white Winter, Spring has advanced 3c. on No. 1, and 2c. on No. 2, the ruling difference between those grades having increased from 3c., as it was formerly, to fully 4c., and on some days, prices have been very fluctuating for this season, though the variations of 1c.@2c. used to scarcely excite surprise in previous years. Corn has been dull all the time, the demand not being equal to the supply, and parcels afloat lower in proportion than parcels in store, while at the close the feeling is heavy at the inside figures of a week ago. Oats have been dull until to-day, when they rallied and sold freely at 14c. in store and 16c. on board. Rye has been quiet and unusually steady. Timothy Seed reached very low figures at $1 20@$1 30, but has partially recovered, closing firm and somewhat buoyant at $1 39@$1 40. Potatoes fluctuating, closing with higher prices. Fruits plenty but active. Highwines moderately active at the previous decline. Live Stock markets higher and firm, with rather a light supply. Hides firm but steady, Tallow very firm. Nothing doing in Provisions beyond the home trade.

abstract: Atabout 7 o'clock, on Fridayevening, as Mr. BRUNGER, of No. 88 East Thirty-first-street, was riding in a light wagon, near the Eighth-avenue, in the grounds of the Central Park, his horse became frightened and ran into the cut in Eighty-sixth-street, overturning the vehicle and fatally injuring Mrs. ELIZABETH CAMPBELL, of No. 118 Sullivan-street, who was riding with Mr. BRUNGER at the time. The Central Park Police took her to the residence of the keeper of the Receiving Reservoir, in Eighty-fifth-street, where she soon after expired, Mr. BRUNGER escaped unhurt. Mrs. CAMPBELL was the mother-in-law of Mr. EMANUEL WHITE, of the Central Police office, and about 60 years of age.
lead_paragraph: Atabout 7 o'clock, on Fridayevening, as Mr. BRUNGER, of No. 88 East Thirty-first-street, was riding in a light wagon, near the Eighth-avenue, in the grounds of the Central Park, his horse became frightened and ran into the cut in Eighty-sixth-street, overturning the vehicle and fatally injuring Mrs. ELIZABETH CAMPBELL, of No. 118 Sullivan-street, who was riding with Mr. BRUNGER at the time. The Central Park Police took her to the residence of the keeper of the Receiving Reservoir, in Eighty-fifth-street, where she soon after expired, Mr. BRUNGER escaped unhurt. abstract: The Coast Survey has hither to been known to the public as a mysterious scientific body, endowed with apparently unlimited power of swallowing appropriations. These, anuually renewed, at the rate of half a million or so dollars, have made tax-payers, non-appreciative of scientific undertakings, to groan bitterly in the inner man.
lead_paragraph: The Coast Survey has hither to been known to the public as a mysterious scientific body, endowed with apparently unlimited power of swallowing appropriations. These, anuually renewed, at the rate of half a million or so dollars, have made tax-payers, non-appreciative of scientific undertakings, to groan bitterly in the inner man. It may be some consolation to these to know that the results of the labors of the survey are now proving of the greatest practical utility in connection with the projected system of naval operations along the Southern seaboard. It is easy to see how invaluable must be the results of the minute and accurate topographic and hydrographic surveys made by this corps and published in their charts and reports. Thus it is that a work of pure science, generously undertaken by the National Government at vast cost, for the protection of the pacific interests of commerce and navigation, is found to be a most effective arm for the National defence in time of war.
headline: {'main': 'What the Coast survey is Doing for Us.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What the Coast survey is Doing for Us.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Ten days ago, Gen. PRENTISS, who commands the Union forces in Southern Illinois, finding himself in possession of an inconvenient number of prisoners, dispatched a flag of truce to Gen. PILLOW to propose an exchange. The flag was received with unexceptionable courtesy by the hero of the misplaced ditch; its bearer treated with frank hospitality, and sent back with a satisfactory answer.
lead_paragraph: Ten days ago, Gen. PRENTISS, who commands the Union forces in Southern Illinois, finding himself in possession of an inconvenient number of prisoners, dispatched a flag of truce to Gen. PILLOW to propose an exchange. The flag was received with unexceptionable courtesy by the hero of the misplaced ditch; its bearer treated with frank hospitality, and sent back with a satisfactory answer. The rebel General was only too happy to make the exchange, and doubtless by this time the barter has been effected. The consequence is, that instead of our Army on the Mississippi being weakened by having to maintain watch and ward over a few score worthless insurgents, it is relieved of that duty, and is reinforced by the return to its ranks of a large number of valuable soldiers.

abstract: The remark of all foreign observers, that the American people is to the last degree variable, petulant and easily moved to extremes of elation or depression, is one under which we shall do well to sit meekly.
lead_paragraph: The remark of all foreign observers, that the American people is to the last degree variable, petulant and easily moved to extremes of elation or depression, is one under which we shall do well to sit meekly. So much of the history of 1861 as is thus far written, is indisputable proof of the charge. With what assurance did we set out that there would be no rebellion; that a large majority of the South would remain neutral; that the rebels would be unable to set an Army a-field; that the blockade would at once settle the business; that provisions and supplies would fail them before the end of Summer; that the Slaves would at once burst into insurrection; that the enemy would never meet our armies in the field, or, venturing upon the encounter, would at once scatter like sheep; and so on through scores of irrational assumptions, which were momentary causes of our exultation, which the event converted into an equally unreasonable despondency. Then came fears quite as foundationless. Washington would be captured; Philadelphia and New-York were hardly safe; the seas would be presently swarming with an armada of privateers; England and France would deny any recognition of the blockade, or acknowledging it, would find an early pretence to break it; that they would insist on the opening of a cotton port; and so through a wearisome procession of fantastic apprehensions, which there has been no subsequent fact to justify. It is superfluous to recite the evidence of our changeable temper as a people. It is simply the diary of eight months of action and excitement. But in making the review, in the penitent temper which becomes us, let us claim that our experience has not been wholly thrown away, but that to-day the settled confidence which has become general is not based upon senseless miscalculations of our relative strength or weakness, or of the attitude assumed by the leading Powers of Europe; but upon a just, rational and trustworthy estimate of the entire situation.
headline: {'main': 'The Lessons of the Summer.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Lessons of the Summer.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: COMPTROLLER'S OFFICE -- AWARD OF LOAN FOR $100,000 CROTON STOCK. -- The Comptroller, on Saturday, awarded the loan for $100,000 of the Croton Water Stock -- due in 1883, and bearing 6 per cent. interest -- as follows: Sinking Fund of the City, $82,200, at par; MAITLAND, PHELPS Co., $10,000, at 100.25; JOHN PEARSON, $1,000, at 100.2; and R.P. DUNN, $800, at par. The Volunteer Relief Bonds remain untaken to nearly one-half of the amount authorized to be taken, ($500,000,) parties seeking investments preferring Government Treasury notes, which pay a greater rate of interest, although there is no absolute inequality in the value of the securities pledged for the redemption of either.

abstract: Recruiting for the old, regular regiments made very slight progress last week, only 12 men being enlisted in New-York, and about as many more in Boston, Rochester and Philadelphia. If there is not a decided improvement very shortly it will be necessary to close some of the offices. Recruiting parties might with advantage be sent into the country as soon as the harvest is over. They could get more men there than in the large cities.

abstract: The testimony for the prosecution in the case of Rev. HENRY BUDGE, charged with the murder of his wife, was closed before Judge ALLEN, at Rome, yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The testimony for the prosecution in the case of Rev. HENRY BUDGE, charged with the murder of his wife, was closed before Judge ALLEN, at Rome, yesterday. The counsel for the prisoner asked his discharge on the case as presented by the people's witnesses, on the ground that not only was it not proved that a murder had been committed, but that the nature of the wound, and the position and condition of the body, were such that it was not possible that Mrs. BUDGE had met her death at any other hands than her own. On the instruction of the Court, the Jury found that Mr. BUDGE was not guilty, and he was accordingly discharged from custody. The Jury were polled, and each man for himself pronounced that he found the prisoner not guilty. After the verdict, the jurymen congratulated Mr. BUDGE on the fact that his innocence had been so triumphantly established, and without calling a witness in his behalf.

abstract: The Third Rhode Island Regiment Col. BLANNING, arrived in this City by the steamship Commodore yesterday afternoon. The arrival was quite unexpected, the United States Quartermaster not having been notified of the fact. The men landed at Pier No. 1, North River, but did not leave the dock; shortly afterward they reembarked and were carried to Fort Hamilton, where at present they are quartered.
lead_paragraph: The Third Rhode Island Regiment Col. BLANNING, arrived in this City by the steamship Commodore yesterday afternoon. The arrival was quite unexpected, the United States Quartermaster not having been notified of the fact. The men landed at Pier No. 1, North River, but did not leave the dock; shortly afterward they reembarked and were carried to Fort Hamilton, where at present they are quartered. All of the men are armed and thoroughly equipped; the regiment numbers 600 men, rank and file. When the soldiers were on the dock, Gov. SPRAGUE made his appearance; he was welcomed with cheers and every demonstration of enthusiasm.

abstract: The controversy in the United States has already influenced this country. The first news of secession gave courage to Buenos Ayres to maintain also a kind of reserved State right. The determination of the United States Government to maintain its integrity has, on the other hand, given moral strength to the Confederation. The position of the Confederation and of the United States is nearly alike.
