abstract: The regular Fall season at our theatres will commence to-night with the opening of the Winter Garden, the rentree of Mrs. JOHN WOOD, and the production of an expensively-got-up spectacular piece. A few weeks ago the prospects seemed blue enough, but since then they have greatly changed, and strange as it may sound, the indications are now in favor of a good Fall season.
lead_paragraph: Mr. CLARKE's engagement, which terminated on Saturday, was a success of the best kind, and the FLORENCES, who preceded him, were also moderately prosperous. These are all we can judge by, unless we descend to the concert saloons and note their furious and crowded state, as an additional proof of reviving times. Are these places licensed, by the way, or are they permitted to oppose more reputable establishments with their discreditable allurements? There cannot be a doubt that they inflict a great deal of harm on respectable places of amusement, and exercise none but a demoralizing effect on the public taste.

abstract: FIRE, EXPLOSION AND LOSS OF LIFE. Between 7 and 8 o'clock, on Saturday night, a fire broke out on board the schooner Cornelia, of New-Bedford, which resulted in the destruction of a large amount of property, the death of one man and the serious injury of two others.
lead_paragraph: FIRE, EXPLOSION AND LOSS OF LIFE. -- Between 7 and 8 o'clock, on Saturday night, a fire broke out on board the schooner Cornelia, of New-Bedford, which resulted in the destruction of a large amount of property, the death of one man and the serious injury of two others. The vessel was lying at the Paterson dock, foot of Wayne-street, adjoining the depot of the New-Jersey Railroad, and was loaded with 800 barrels of kerosene oil. An explosion occurred in the hold of the schooner, and she was almost instantly enveloped in flames, and the fire rapidly spread to the dock, setting fire to three cars loaded with wheat. The shed covering the dock, and the cars, with their contents, were completely destroyed; but before this the vessel was burned to the water's edge. The Fire Department of Jersey City, assisted by three companies from New-York, made every effort to stay the progress of the fire, and it is believed, but for their exertions the depot of the New-Jersey Railroad would have been destroyed. The fire raged with great violence until nearly 12 o'clock, and at many times a destructive conflagration seemed imminent. At the time of the explosion there were three persons on board the schooner, ENAS DOUGLASS, the steward; FRANK SILVEY, and a boy named EMANUEL, 15 years of age. They were all seriously injured, and only escaped from the burning vessel by jumping overboard, when they were rescued by the hands on the Jersey City Ferry. They were taken to the Almshouse and placed in charge of Mr. WHITLEY, the Superintendent of that institution. Medical attendance was promptly procured, and the injured persons received every attention. At 9 o'clock yesterday morning DOUGLASS died from the effect of his injuries, but the other two, though seriously, it is believed are not fatally injured. Coroner GAFFNEY held an inquest on the body of DOUGLASS, but could not elicit any information as to the origin of the fire. It is believed to have resulted from spontaneous combustion. The report that deceased went into the hold of the vessel with a lighted candle is not only highly improbable, but is denied in the most positive manner by SILVEY. The verdict of the Coroner's Jury was that the deceased came to his death from an explosion on board the schoner Cornelia, and from the effect of internal burns. DOUGLASS leaves a wife and two children resident in New-Bedford. The total loss caused by the fire will probably exceed $50,000. The schooner belonged to the Captain, GEO. CRASSO. His loss is $3,000, covered by insurance. The cargo belonged to RICHARDSON & Co., of New-York. Loss $12,000; no insurance. The cars destroyed belonged to the New-York and Erie Railroad Company, whose loss is about $9,000, partly insured.

abstract: The publishing trade, never very lively at this season, is not especially brisk just now. From the HARPERS we have a reprint of The House on the Moor, a novel by the very popular author of Margaret Mailland, The Laird of Norlaw, Days of My Life,
lead_paragraph: -- The publishing trade, never very lively at this season, is not especially brisk just now. From the HARPERS we have a reprint of The House on the Moor, a novel by the very popular author of Margaret Mailland, The Laird of Norlaw, Days of My Life, &c. The story is managed on the principle of light and shade; -- the contrusts of character are as marked as they could possibly be drawn. Thus we have a confirmed misanthrope placed side by side with a practical philanthropist; a sullen, reserved and unnatural youth in close juxtaposition with a bright and joyous one. The plot of the story seems to have never been very clearly determined in the author's mind previous to its conclusion, action and dialogue scarcely keep pace with each other, and too many characters are introduced to allow any one of them to play a very prominent part; nor is the conclusion of the novel very satisfactory. A mysterious recluse is introduced, but the mystery shrouding him is never thoroughly explained. His life was embittered by an unjust will, but why that will was made in the first place, or why no attempt was subsequently made to set it aside, all this the reader is left to determine to his own satisfaction. Perhaps, however, it is the intention of the author to publish a sequel, in which all these things will be made plain. The interest of the book is well maintained from the first chapter to the last, and the reader will not be likely to lay it aside until he reaches the colophon.

abstract: One JAMES W. WALL, living somewhere in New-Jersey, and representing himself to be a son of Hon. GARRET D. WALL, who at one time represented that State in the Senate of the United States, has opened an interesting correspondence with the Postmaster-General, Mr. WALL labors with a grievance.
lead_paragraph: One JAMES W. WALL, living somewhere in New-Jersey, and representing himself to be a son of Hon. GARRET D. WALL, who at one time represented that State in the Senate of the United States, has opened an interesting correspondence with the Postmaster-General, Mr. WALL labors with a grievance. He is a subscriber to a notorious secession print in this City -- doubtless having paid the subscription in advance -- and may possibly be an adventurer in the several lotteries of which that sheet is the official organ. The recent order, excluding the journal in question from the mails, deprives Mr. WALL of the satisfaction derived from the perusal of the leading articles with which it instructs willing minds, and also robs him of a knowledge, of schemes, and classes, and drawings, the absence of which must of itself be to the interested a source of inconceivable distraction and intolerable uncertainty. To Postmaster BLAIR, Mr. WALL therefore addresses himself, and plies that officer with constitutional law, argument, passionate invective, and pathetic appeal, so eloquently, that we can only wonder how the Postmaster-General can confine himself in reply to the few apathetic lines, represented to-day in these columns.

abstract: It appears that the die is cast in Kentucky and that in spite of the earnest efforts of loyal Unionists to preserve the State from the horrors of the war that is now desolating Virginia and Missouri, the tramp of hostile armies is now felt on her soil.
lead_paragraph: It appears that the die is cast in Kentucky and that in spite of the earnest efforts of loyal Unionists to preserve the State from the horrors of the war that is now desolating Virginia and Missouri, the tramp of hostile armies is now felt on her soil. The telegraph is not a very clear narrator of facts; but from the dispatches of the past three days we gather the following: That on the night of the 4th inst. a considerable body of Confederate troops were thrown into Western Kentucky at Hickman, a town above New-Madrid on the Missouri side, but some distance below Columbus on the Kentucky side. On the next day, Gen. GRANT, commanding at Cairo, knowing of this movement of the rebels into Kentucky, and being assured of the march of about 3,800 of their forces towards Paducah, steamed up to the latter place with two regiments of infantry, one company of artillery and two gun-boats, and took possession of that important town, in advance of the rebels.

abstract: The news from Washington this morning indicates the speedy opening of active hostilities. Gen. McCLELLAN on Saturday made a balloon assention with Prof. LOWE, and spent two hours in making reconnoisances of the enemy's positions.
lead_paragraph: The news from Washington this morning indicates the speedy opening of active hostilities. Gen. McCLELLAN on Saturday made a balloon assention with Prof. LOWE, and spent two hours in making reconnoisances of the enemy's positions. This was followed yesterday morning at daylight by a movement of our pickets, who were advanced one mile from their former positions, the rebel pickets retreating before them without any attempt at resistance. It has recently been discovered that the rebels, in addition to their fortifications on Munson's Hill, have recently erected a formidable battery, commanding the Leesburgh turnpike, about seven miles from the Chain Bridge. There does not appear, however, to be any considerable body of troops in that vicinity. It appears, also, that on Wednesday last the rebels actually made an attempt to effect a crossing of the Potomac at Great Falls, about sixteen miles above Washington, but were repulsed with considerable loss. They planted a battery of rifled cannon upon an eminence and fired about a hundred guns at a body of our troops on the Maryland, side, attempting, meantime, to cross by constructing a temporary bridge with planks. The Sharp-shooters of the Pennsylvania Seventh, however, met them with such a galling fire that they were forced to give up the enterprise, and retired with their battery. Only one man was slightly wounded among the Pennsylvanians.

abstract: We noticed, early in the Summer, an experiment made in cotton-planting by Mr. H.B. JENKS, of Bridesburgh. In each of 2,500 pots were placed three seeds, covered with a compost consisting of three parts of vegetable mould and one of woodland leaf mould. They were ranged in a hothouse on 26th March, under a temperature of 75 degrees, and germinated on the 31st of that month. They were set in the field on 11th May following, covering an acre, and a month after ranged in height from a foot to eighteen inches. They are now from three to four feet high, and having mostly blossomed, the balls vary in size from a large pea to a good-sized cranberry. In a month's time, provided the frost does not kill them, they will reach the size of walnuts and burst, when the cotton will be ready to pick.

abstract: DEDICATION OF SAINT ANNE'S CHURCH. There was a large and appreciative audience present at the dedication of Saint Anne's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, yesterday forenoon. The church is located at the corner of Front and Gold streets, and is a most elegant, costly and tasteful structure, in every respect creditable to the taste of the architect, Mr. KEELY, of Brooklyn, and to the directing church authorities.
lead_paragraph: DEDICATION OF SAINT ANNE'S CHURCH. -- There was a large and appreciative audience present at the dedication of Saint Anne's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, yesterday forenoon. The church is located at the corner of Front and Gold streets, and is a most elegant, costly and tasteful structure, in every respect creditable to the taste of the architect, Mr. KEELY, of Brooklyn, and to the directing church authorities. The pastor of the church is Rev. Father B. GLEASON, who has become generally popular by his services to his congregation. The church contains about two hundred pews, and will seat nearly one thousand persons. There are seven windows of stained glass upon each side, each a gift, bearing the giver's name. These are generally ornamented in the most tasteful and gorgeous manner. Three of these windows bear representations of saints -- one of St. Anne, one of St. Joseph, and the third of St. Bridget. The central window, above the altar, contains a representation of the Virgin Mary and the child Jesus, and was the gift of the sailors belonging to the North Carolina. The altar is of solid marble, set off with magnificent decorations. In the rear of the altar are paintings representing St. Peter, St. John, and the Adoration of the Angels. One of the most costly and elegant ornaments of the church is a statue of St. Patrick in marble. The church roof or dome is supported in the centre by a series of arches based upon heavy posts or pillars. Between the several windows and set in the wall, are fourteen representations in basso relievo, of Scripture scenes. These are in each case surrounded by beautifully ornamented frameworks. Three pieces of diminutive marble statuary in the rear of the altar add to the taste of its appearance. The roof and arches of the building are gorgeously adorned with kaleidoscopic figures, no less than fifteen or twenty different shades of colors being used in the paintings of the walls and windows. The services usual upon such occasions commenced at 10 1/2 o'clock. There were present Bishop LOUGHLIN, Father MOONEY, (Chaplain of the Sixty-ninth Regiment,) Rev. Father MALONE, of Williamsburgh; Rev. Father J.P. CAHILL, of Albany; Father MCCARTY, of New-York, and Father FAGAN, of Brooklyn. Also Fathers MCCAHILL and KEEGAN -- the latter deacon and the former sub-deacon. Father J.R. MCDONALD acted as Master of Ceremonies upon the occasion. The sermon was preached by Bishop LOUGHLIN, and was a timely and eloquent discourse. Mass was celebrated -- Mercadante in four parts; offertory, Quamdelecta and Veni Sancti. The principal singers present, especially for these services, were Madame VON BERKEL, soprano; Miss GOMRIEN, alto; M. WEINLICH, bass, and M. FREDEL, tenor. The principal singer of the permanent choir is Miss PAGENDARM, soprano, whose merit in Brooklyn is by no means unappreciated. The ceremonies were generally impressive, and lasted about two and a-half hours.

abstract: GEN. BEAUREGARD, COMMANDER OF THE CONFEDERATE  ARMY Dear Sir: With a grievous and torn heart, I address you. If it is in your power, will you give a word of comfort to a distressed spirit? I allude to the death of the gallant Col. CAMERON, of the National Army, on last Sunday, 21st July. We are all God's creatures, alike is his sight. It is a bereaved sister that petitions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26, 1861.

abstract: In the Supreme Court, in Buffalo, on Tuesday, in the case of The New-York and Erie Bank vs. A.D. SHEPARD & Co., of this City, and WILLIAM B. MANN & Co., of Buffalo, a question was decided of some importance to bankers and others. The action was on two drafts drawn by MANN & Co. on SHEPARD & Co. It appeared that MANN & Co. were employed by SHEPARD & Co.,  row money in Buffalo and remit to SHEPARD & Co., and accordingly applied to the Bank and procured the drafts in suit, to be discounted, requesting the proceeds in drafts on New-York. The Bank accordingly paid the proceeds to MANN & Co., in eight drafts on New-York, charging 1/2 per cent. premium, that being the usual rate of exchange on New-York. The defendants claimed that this charge for exchange constituted usury, and set up the same as a defence to the discounted paper. The Court decided that these facts did not make out a defence, and ordered judgment for the plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: In the Supreme Court, in Buffalo, on Tuesday, in the case of The New-York and Erie Bank vs. A.D. SHEPARD & Co., of this City, and WILLIAM B. The defendants claimed that this charge for exchange constituted usury, and set up the same as a defence to the discounted paper. The Court decided that these facts did not make out a defence, and ordered judgment for the plaintiff.

abstract: A soldier was to be shot yesterday near Washington for sleeping at his post. The offence was committed at the hour between 3 and 4 A.M. on the 31st day of August, while on picket guard, near Camp Lyon, District of Columbia. Found guilty at Court-martial, Gen. MCCLELLAN confirmed the finding and the sentence, and private WILLIAM SCOTT, of the Third Vermont Volunteers, would have received a volley of bullets from his comrades, as a tragic, terrible vindication of military discipline, had not the Presidential pardon saved him.

abstract: The Government will shortly put afloat two more expeditions, destined to land upon the coast of the rebel States. Their exact destination is not generally known, but I shall not be surprised if one lands upon the inviting shores of South Carolina, and the other may possibly find manifest destiny drawing it towards the harbor of Brunswick, Georgia. In the early part of the rebellion, there was a Collector of United States revenue at one of the South Carolina ports, who not only refused to hand over the public funds to the pirates of Charleston, but also declined to swear allegiance to the rattlesnake flag, and was imprisoned by the rebels. It is rightly conjectured that a man so loyal and patriotic would not have lived alone in that portion of the world, and that there must be quite a crop of Union sentiment to be gathered thereabouts, if the reapers are sent in. I recollect some years ago, when it was incubating as a first-class Naval station, I read in a circular that Brunswick was not only the finest harbor in the world, but that Providence had undoubtedly destined that harbor to be the great commercial mart of the world of Georgia, Florida, Tennessee, Alabama, Western South Carolina, and also that illimitable West, which stretches so far beyond South Carolina towards the great Pacific. On a map which showed the outlines of the harbor of Brunswick, and the site of the projected Navy-yard, and the docks that were to be, was also laid down with geometrical acouracy the various natural and artificial channels of communication which linked Brunswick with all the world and the rest of mankind. There was, too, if I recollect aright, a well-conceived sketch of large steamships and giant vessels of war, inward and outward bound, with innumerable smaller craft shooting here and there over the broad expanse of waters. I shall not be surprised if the Southern Slaveholders in this embryo city, were suddenly surprised some pleasant morning to find the last picture a living reality, and to see the capacity of Brunswick harbor tested by the big and little vessels of Uncle Sam's Navy.
lead_paragraph: The Government will shortly put afloat two more expeditions, destined to land upon the coast of the rebel States. Their exact destination is not generally known, but I shall not be surprised if one lands upon the inviting shores of South Carolina, and the other may possibly find manifest destiny drawing it towards the harbor of Brunswick, Georgia. In the early part of the rebellion, there was a Collector of United States revenue at one of the South Carolina ports, who not only refused to hand over the public funds to the pirates of Charleston, but also declined to swear allegiance to the rattlesnake flag, and was imprisoned by the rebels. It is rightly conjectured that a man so loyal and patriotic would not have lived alone in that portion of the world, and that there must be quite a crop of Union sentiment to be gathered thereabouts, if the reapers are sent in. I recollect some years ago, when it was incubating as a first-class Naval station, I read in a circular that Brunswick was not only the finest harbor in the world, but that Providence had undoubtedly destined that harbor to be the great commercial mart of the world of Georgia, Florida, Tennessee, Alabama, Western South Carolina, and also that illimitable West, which stretches so far beyond South Carolina towards the great Pacific. On a map which showed the outlines of the harbor of Brunswick, and the site of the projected Navy-yard, and the docks that were to be, was also laid down with geometrical acouracy the various natural and artificial channels of communication which linked Brunswick with all the world and the rest of mankind. There was, too, if I recollect aright, a well-conceived sketch of large steamships and giant vessels of war, inward and outward bound, with innumerable smaller craft shooting here and there over the broad expanse of waters. I shall not be surprised if the Southern Slaveholders in this embryo city, were suddenly surprised some pleasant morning to find the last picture a living reality, and to see the capacity of Brunswick harbor tested by the big and little vessels of Uncle Sam's Navy.

abstract: We are glad to observe that the elements of a Volunteer Navy make their appearance at various points. The Salem Gazette mentions two vessels of that port, the Kingfisher and Gemsbok; both of which have been overhauled, repaired, strengthened and armed, and gone into commission, with officers appointed by the Navy Department from among the tried and trusty shipmasters of Salem. An immense number of officers have been appointed at New-York, Boston and other seaports, to the command of volunteer naval vessels, and we may look forward soon to see a powerful mercantile marine afloat, that will prove an auxiliary of incalculable importance to the Government, forming a Naval Police in protection of our commerce, and clearing the seas of the pirates that now infest them.

abstract: A large and spirited meeting of the Mozart Hall General Committee, was held last evening at their Head-quarters, in Broadway, near Eleventh-street, the object being to hear the report of the delegates appointed to attend the Democratic Convention at Syracuse, and to take such action thereon as the state of the country demands. Mr. P.G. MALONEY occupied the Chair; and P. DAILY was chosen Secretary. The discussions were harmonious, and the voting upon the resolutions and the report unanimous.

abstract: THIS RELIEF FUND. -- The Chairman of the Ward and Town Volunteer Relief Committees issued a call for a meeting, to be held last evening, in the Common Council Chamber, City Hall. At the time named in the call -- 7 1/2 o'clock -- and at half an hour later, there being no quorum present, the Board adjourned, to meet again on Thursday evening next. The special object of the meeting is to devise some means, if possible, for a more economical distribution of the money raised for the families of volunteers.

abstract: Mr. HOLT indicated, the other day, a characteristic of the present war which the future historian will have occasion to record as the most remarkable metaphysical fact of the times. "I have nowhere in the North," said he, "found any feeling of exasperation against the people of the South." European journalists emphasize the same characteristic, and some even go so far as to assert that we will never conquer until we grow more "vindictive."
lead_paragraph: Mr. HOLT indicated, the other day, a characteristic of the present war which the future historian will have occasion to record as the most remarkable metaphysical fact of the times. "I have nowhere in the North," said he, "found any feeling of exasperation against the people of the South." European journalists emphasize the same characteristic, and some even go so far as to assert that we will never conquer until we grow more "vindictive." We need not be surprised that the calmness and forbearance of the North astonish the world; for it was a universal foreboding among ourselves at the outbreaking of the strife that civil war between the North and South would be embittered by such horrors of fraternal hatred and rancor as history does not record.

abstract: The dispatches from Washington apprise us that the letter of the Emperor of Russia to the President of the United States, expressing a deep concern for the preservation of the American Union, has produced a "profound sensation" in the diplomatic circles. The sympathy manifested in the letter with our Government is so sincere and hearty in expression, breaking over all the reserve of ordinary diplomatic cold-heartedness, that we recognize the earnest friend, sooner than the great ruler of an empire, in its author. But after having taken to our hearts the comfort and cheer of the communication, and done justice to the political wisdom that characterizes it, we recur with exalted pride to the fact that it is the voice of one of the most illustrious monarchs of Europe, whose moral and physical power gives an emphasis to his judgment on the affairs of nations.
lead_paragraph: The dispatches from Washington apprise us that the letter of the Emperor of Russia to the President of the United States, expressing a deep concern for the preservation of the American Union, has produced a "profound sensation" in the diplomatic circles. The sympathy manifested in the letter with our Government is so sincere and hearty in expression, breaking over all the reserve of ordinary diplomatic cold-heartedness, that we recognize the earnest friend, sooner than the great ruler of an empire, in its author. But after having taken to our hearts the comfort and cheer of the communication, and done justice to the political wisdom that characterizes it, we recur with exalted pride to the fact that it is the voice of one of the most illustrious monarchs of Europe, whose moral and physical power gives an emphasis to his judgment on the affairs of nations.

abstract: As the outbreak of the rebellion found its leaders a coalition for active operations, with definiteness of purpose and unity of counsels, the result of years of preparations, during which they had exclusive possession of the Government, which they believed they had so thoroughly undermined by corrupting the loyalty of a large number of its officers as to render it incapable of any vigorous action for its permanence or safety, their policy was clearly that of a vigorous offensive, and to strike an overwhelming blow before any effectual resistance could be offered. Up to the bombardment of Fort Sumter the hands of the Government were tied by the sentiment of a large party at the North against coercion. At that moment the rebels were relatively stronger than they have been at any subsequent one. They had an excitable population which could, by appeals to their pride, their love of power and hatred to the North, be called, in mass, almost instantly into the field, and in a condition well fitted for any enterprise which had a smack of hazard, or one in which the dash which distinguishes Southern character would be a good substitute for military training. Both their internal and foreign commerce were entirely free. Not a single industry had been interrupted. If they did not have the sympathy of foreign Powers, they certainly impressed them with the conviction they thus could not be put down by any force that Government could exact. The North was divided and only united by the conduct of the rebels themselves. It took it, always slow in its deliberations and action, a long time to come to the conviction that mischief was intended; and equally long, through its cumbrous methods, to prepare, first for effective resistance, and then for a vigorous offensive.

Up to the bombardment of Fort Sumter the hands of the Government were tied by the sentiment of a large party at the North against coercion. At that moment the rebels were relatively stronger than they have been at any subsequent one. They had an excitable population which could, by appeals to their pride, their love of power and hatred to the North, be called, in mass, almost instantly into the field, and in a condition well fitted for any enterprise which had a smack of hazard, or one in which the dash which distinguishes Southern character would be a good substitute for military training. Both their internal and foreign commerce were entirely free. Not a single industry had been interrupted. If they did not have the sympathy of foreign Powers, they certainly impressed them with the conviction they thus could not be put down by any force that Government could exact. The North was divided and only united by the conduct of the rebels themselves. It took it, always slow in its deliberations and action, a long time to come to the conviction that mischief was intended; and equally long, through its cumbrous methods, to prepare, first for effective resistance, and then for a vigorous offensive.

abstract: THE MCMANUS OBSEQUIES. -- The Executive Committee of the McManus Obsequies held a meeting yesterday at No. 6 Centre-street, Mr. JOHN O'MAHONEY in the Chair, Mr. M. DOHENY Secretary. Committees were appointed for different objects, and the Corresponding Secretary was empowered to enter into immediate correspondence with prominent gentlemen out of the City, and request their cooperation. The Chairman appointed a Committee to collect funds to defray the expenses attendant upon the obsequies, and divided them into four groups, namely: 1. Owen Keenan, Patrick O'Rourke, Edward Costello, John Murphy, Philip Callaghan. 2. John McNichol, Michael Connolly, J.B. Kirker, John McKeon, James Sandford. 3. John McGrath, Edward L. Carey, Richard J. Lalor, Wm. L. Cole, John Kerr. 4. John O'Mahoney, Philip O'Hanlon, Jr., John Clancy, J.J. Bradley, James Bagley. The Committee adjourned to meet again on Wednesday next, at 1 o'clock, at the same place, when Committees' reports will be received and final arrangements made for the programme.

abstract: The representatives of the Mozart branch of the Democratic Party returned from the Syracuse Convention, in political parlance, "sore headed." No wonder. They were flattered by a recognition on the part of the State Convention; but the compliment was amputated. They were voted equal to half a delegation, and Tammany Hall was called on to eke out the allotted seats of New-York City by an equal addition to the "happy family." Mozart being decidedly hungry for the spoils, concluded that "half a loaf was better than no bread," and was quite willing to accept this scant fare. Not so Tammany. With a sturdy and uncompromising obstinacy, the old Wigwam demanded exclusive honors, and refused to let Mozart gather even so much as crumbs from the Democratic table. The State Convention, after a full review of the case of the contestants, withdrew their invitation to Mozart, gave its admitted delegates their hats, and most uncivilly turned them out of doors.
lead_paragraph: The representatives of the Mozart branch of the Democratic Party returned from the Syracuse Convention, in political parlance, "sore headed." No wonder. With a sturdy and uncompromising obstinacy, the old Wigwam demanded exclusive honors, and refused to let Mozart gather even so much as crumbs from the Democratic table. The State Convention, after a full review of the case of the contestants, withdrew their invitation to Mozart, gave its admitted delegates their hats, and most uncivilly turned them out of doors.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The regular Fall season at this house opened last evening under the favorable auspices of a crowded house and a hearty reception to the leading artists. When we say this, we include the name of Mr. A.H. DAVENPORT -- a gentleman who has been South and attained to some disgrace there, but for no reason that should affect a Northern audience. A few hisses were raised when Mr. DAVENPORT made his appearance, but they were speedily drowned in a torrent of applause. The critic has nothing whatever to do with these matters, and it is a degradation of his office, as it is a degradation of Art to record their occurrence. If the public likes anartist, it records its approval in an unmistakable way; if it dislikes him, its condemnation is equally emphatic. We shall content ourselves, on the present occasion, with saying that Mr. DAVENPORT, on his return, was accepted with unequivocal warmth. The few who hissed exhibited individual spleen, but not popular disfavor.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFHAN, James Kelly, aged 18, and Thos. The robbery was committed in Chatham-square a week ago today, upon the person of Jas. W. McGuire.

abstract: The next steamer from Havre and Southampton, now nearly due at this port, will bring the Prince DE JOINVILLE, with his son, a lad of some sixteen years of age, whom his father has decided to place in a United States Naval School. The circumstance will be regarded as complimentary to our country and its Navy. The school which will have the honor of receiving the princely pupil will probably be that now established at Newport, R.I., on board the United States ship Constitution. Some twenty years ago the Prince DE JOINVILLE visited this country on board the French ship-of-the line Belle Poule, which was anchored, during his stay in the United States, near the spot where the Constitution now lies. The son, who comes now to receive instruction in the Naval School of the United States, has for his mother a daughter of the Emperor of Brazil, and a Brazilian war vessel, which opportunely arrived in our harbor yesterday, will, no doubt, pay the illustrious visitors all the honors upon their arrival.

abstract: ANOTHER TICKET-SWINDLING CASE -- PETER KELLY made a charge against JAMES MCCARRON, who keeps a ticket office at No. 146 Liberty-street, before Justice KELLY, at the Tombs, yesterday morning, for selling him a ticket which was worthless. He alleges that he applied to the accused for a passage ticket, either to Bremen or Havre, he was not particular which. Instead of such a one, he received a ticket for Liverpool on the Harvest Queen, of the Black Ball line of packets, for which he paid $18, which ticket was not a genuine one. The magistrate held MCCARRON to bail in $5,000 to answer.

abstract: The annual problem of our social economy -- what to do with the unemployed labor of the City? -- presents itself as usual this sea-son, and seems destined, as usual, to remain unsolved. Not that the solution is particularly difficult. Fortune has favored this country in its capacity for production. The food of all Europe might be obtained from the rich prairies and bottom-lands of the West. There is still a demand for the products of our soil from England, and our seaboard, and of course, parallel with this demand, continues the demand for labor for the Western households and farms. Wages still range high -- consideringthe cost of living, probably double the rate here; in many districts so many of the males have enlisted for the war that hands enough to gather the harvest cannot be obtained. Everywhere the want of female labor is complained of, and it would appear that hundreds and thousands of able-bodied women could at once secure good homes and remunerative employment in most of the extreme Western States. Marvelous reports are circulated of the cheapness of provisions; we hear of corn at five and six cents a bushel, and even in some districts of its being used as fuel in the locomotives, such a drug has it become; of wheat at thirty cents, and of good beef at five cents a pound. Such prices cannot, of course, prevail generally; but it is certain that the expenses of living for a laboring man in many parts of the West are reduced down to the lowest scale. From a recent report of a Western agent of the Children's Aid Society, who has visited various States with the express object of ascertaining just what the demand for labor is, we learn that the best opportunity for families of laborers is presented in Minnesota and Wisconsin, while in Illinois, Indiana and Iowa, there is a constant call for women of good character for housework.

abstract: DESERTERS ARRESTED. -- The police of this city, recently, have been driving a pretty brisk business in arresting deserters, principally from the different regiments stationed in the vicinity of New-York. Yesterday three men were arrested on a charge of having deserted from a regiment at Staten Island; when the fact was brought to light they had enlisted in five different regiments, and received an advance of money in each instance. They were locked up, and subsequently transferred to the military authorities to be dealt with according to law.

abstract: Very interesting disclosures respecting the charter and burning of the steamer Cataline at Fortress Monroe, on the evening of the 2d of July last, have come before the criminal authorities of this City within the past few days. A person named JAMES LARKIN, who was employed on the steamer at the time of her destruction, is in custody on suspicion of having set her on fire, and yesterday an examination of the circumstances attending the matter was commenced at the Jefferson Market Police Court, before Justice QUACKENBUSH.

A person named JAMES LARKIN, who was employed on the steamer at the time of her destruction, is in custody on suspicion of having set her on fire, and yesterday an examination of the circumstances attending the matter was commenced at the Jefferson Market Police Court, before Justice QUACKENBUSH.

abstract: We publish in the TIMES to-day a speech just delivered by Hon. JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, at a great Secession barbecue given in Madison County, Ky. It was a very large gathering, and prominent Secessionists were present from many parts of the State. Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, in this speech, has thrown off all disguise, and openly counsels and urges his fellow-citizens of Kentucky to resist the laws of the United States in respect to the tariff and war-tax. His language is bold, specific and unmistakable. And so far as his influence was required to carry the point, it was used successfully in persuading his hearers, who are citizens of the United States, to organize a policy of insurrection against the Government; for, after hearing the Senator's speech, and being moved thereto by his inflammatory appeals, they adopted resolutions, declaring that they would not obey the law levying a Government tax upon them. They are, therefore, with Mr. BRECKINRIDGE at their head, in open defiance of the Government, and rebels against the laws.

They are, therefore, with Mr. BRECKINRIDGE at their head, in open defiance of the Government, and rebels against the laws.

abstract: Were England at this moment to announce to the world its intention to make the speediest possible conquest of France, or were France to make the same declaration as to England, the world would laugh at the egregious folly that had inspired the design and prompted the boast. The world would grant that, supposing either people to be infatuated enough, and obstinate enough, it could inflict enormous and irreparable injuries on the other, but only at the cost of equal injuries to itself. The ball once, started, Fortune might befriend this side or that; it might give to either great victories or periods of advantage; it might even place one eventually over the head of the other, but still only at a cost utterly out of proportion to the value of the miserable result. Now, that is the case of two Confederates across the Atlantic, where the surviving half of an effete Federal Union has undertaken to reduce the other half to its Federal duties. We say that this is the case, but before we proceed a step further, it is necessary to observe that the case of the Northern Americans is in some important respects more difficult than ours would be. They are not so united as we have always found ourselves in war. Their Border States feel a divided allegiance. They have to protect more than a thousand miles of land frontier, including one closely beleagured position surrounded by foes or ill-affected adherents. Speaking the same language as their foe, they have no means of excluding spies from their lines, or even traitors from their ranks. They have to make a standing Army and a fleet. They have to learn the first elements of tactics, and even military discipline. They are without soldiers, or officers to command and to train them. Their revenue, at its best, before the war, was only just sufficient to meet the interest of the debt likely to be incurred by two years of the war on its present scale. That revenue, however, is, to begin with, maimed by the loss of the seceders and by the stoppage of traffic, so that it is questionable whether it will be possible to do more than repair that loss by the new taxes now imposed. American credit is not so good as British, nor is the credit of a Federal Union in process of dissolution likely to be equal to that of a united people. Lastly, war, which changes its character according to circumstances, establishes special rules of probability for different localities. The one rule established by all American warfare is that the advantage is on the side of the defence. Our offensive operations always failed against fortified positions, against breastworks thrown up in a night, against forests full of an invisible foe; against heat, hunger and thirst; against the ever imminent flank attack; against the certainty that every step diminished the number, the strength and the munitions of our own men, and increased those of the enemy. The present war might, for its incidents, be a chapter in our own disastrous wars on that soil. The Northerners have advanced upon a fortified position, but a day's march from Washington. They have arrived at the point with a force already melting away, far short of the list on paper, beaten with heat, hunger, thirst and a long march, and surprised on both flanks by the sudden outpourings of railways. While this has occurred in Virginia, almost within sight of Washington, a column of 8,000 Federalists, advancing against a foe thrice their number, has met with the same fate, no doubt for much the same reasons, at Springfield, four or five hundred miles to the West, -- as if in order to warn the Northern States that what has happened is no accident, no result of peculiar circumstances or personal failure, but by inevitable rule.

abstract: The refusal of Mr. TREMAINE to accept the nomination to the office of Attorney-General, tendered him by the Convention held at Syracuse on the 5th instant, was not unexpected by his friends. Had that Convention been content with the passage of the first three of the series of resolutions which now constitute the Democratic platform in this State, adding only a pledge of unqualified support of the Government in its struggle to preserve the Union, he would doubtless have felt himself bound to acquiesce in the determination of his party to make him a candidate. Buthe belongs to that portion of the Democracy in whose patriotism there is no qualification, no insidious condition, no mental reservation, -- who consider their allegiance to their country as superior to their allegiance to party, and who will stand by the national flag, in whatever direction their former political associates may choose to drift. He could not, therefore, in justice to himself, consent to occupy the position of a candidate upon a platform which came far short of his views of patriotism and duty at the present crisis.
lead_paragraph: The refusal of Mr. TREMAINE to accept the nomination to the office of Attorney-General, tendered him by the Convention held at Syracuse on the 5th instant, was not unexpected by his friends. He could not, therefore, in justice to himself, consent to occupy the position of a candidate upon a platform which came far short of his views of patriotism and duty at the present crisis.

abstract: Eight prisoners were sent to St. Louis this morning. They were captured in a skirmish between the Home Guards and the rebels at Douglas Prairie, in Gasconade County. Two of the rebels were killed; and in another skirmish the same day ten more of the rebels were killed and thirty-two horses captured. At another place near Cuba, two scouts were taken with Provost-Marshal McKINSTRY'S passes in their pockets.

abstract: A fire broke out at 11 o'clock Monday night in the livery stables Of MATTHEW CARROL, at Quarantine Landing, Staten Island. abstract: There appears to have been no military movement of importance across the Potomac yesterday, with the exception of a reconnoissance in the vicinity of the Chain Bridge, in which a skirmish took place with a considerable force of the enemy, resulting in the death of several of our men. The Government has received another proof of the loyalty existing in North Carolina, in the tender of a full brigade from that State to fight the battles of the Union.
lead_paragraph: There appears to have been no military movement of importance across the Potomac yesterday, with the exception of a reconnoissance in the vicinity of the Chain Bridge, in which a skirmish took place with a considerable force of the enemy, resulting in the death of several of our men. The Government has received another proof of the loyalty existing in North Carolina, in the tender of a full brigade from that State to fight the battles of the Union.

abstract: The regular meeting of the Board was held yesterday, to receive the report of the Special Committee on the proposed reduction of the City taxes. Some unimportant bills were appropriately referred. The County Clerk asked for 5,000 copies of the Laws respecting Registers and Inspectors of Election. A communication was received from A.R. LAWRENCE, Jr., Esq., informing the Board that the title to the land in the Park, selected for the site of a new Courthouse, was duly vested in the Board, at the price fixed by the Commissioners appointed to appraise the same, viz.: $240,000, comprising nearly the whole front on Chambers-street, from Broadway to the present Court-house, with a depth of 150 feet.

abstract: The British schooner Aigburth, Capt. GAGE, from Matanzas on Aug. 17, with molasses to orders arrived at this port yesterday. She was bound, to St. John, N.B., and was captured, on Aug. 31, off Florida, by the United States sloop-of-war Jamestown, in consequence of her being on the coast, and some informality in her papers. Acting Master CHISHOLM and eight men were put on board of her, while the mate and three seamen of the schooner were transferred to the Jamestown. Her cargo consists of 57 hhds., 52 tcs. and 12 bbls. molasses, consigned to order.

abstract: The game of war is very often compared to a game of chess. But those who are familiar with chess do not need to be told that it is not professional to speak of putting a Bishop "in check." Such a move, however, has actually been made on the Western theatre of military operations. Gen. PILLOW, a Knight (errant) of the Confederate Army, about two months ago moved from Memphis and Fort Randolph a large body of rebel troops, and debarked them at New-Madrid, Mo. He planted batteries there, and went regularly into camp, and into the recruiting business, until he had accumulated an Army of about 20,000 men -- so it was said. He sent scouts northward, then pickets, then detachments, and dug wells industriously by the way-side, (PILLOW must always be digging something, e. g., his Camargo ditch,) and, to the world, he indicated unmistakably his purpose to approach Bird's Point -- to capture it, and proceed to Winter quarters in St. Louis. This was a long-headed scheme, undoubtedly the creation of the late Rev. Bishop POLK, now Major-General of the Confederate Armies in the West.
lead_paragraph: The game of war is very often compared to a game of chess. But those who are familiar with chess do not need to be told that it is not professional to speak of putting a Bishop "in check." Such a move, however, has actually been made on the Western theatre of military operations. Gen. PILLOW, a Knight (errant) of the Confederate Army, about two months ago moved from Memphis and Fort Randolph a large body of rebel troops, and debarked them at New-Madrid, Mo. He planted batteries there, and went regularly into camp, and into the recruiting business, until he had accumulated an Army of about 20,000 men -- so it was said. He sent scouts northward, then pickets, then detachments, and dug wells industriously by the way-side, (PILLOW must always be digging something, e. g., his Camargo ditch,) and, to the world, he indicated unmistakably his purpose to approach Bird's Point -- to capture it, and proceed to Winter quarters in St. Louis. This was a long-headed scheme, undoubtedly the creation of the late Rev. Bishop POLK, now Major-General of the Confederate Armies in the West.

abstract: A period of peace continued till a generation had passed away, and with it the embittered recollections growing out of an unprovoked, on our part, and cruel war, had apparently brought England and the United States into relations of amity and mutual esteem. The two seemed in a fair way to prove an exception to the law by which nations almost universally misinterpret the character and sentiments of each other.
lead_paragraph: A period of peace continued till a generation had passed away, and with it the embittered recollections growing out of an unprovoked, on our part, and cruel war, had apparently brought England and the United States into relations of amity and mutual esteem. The two seemed in a fair way to prove an exception to the law by which nations almost universally misinterpret the character and sentiments of each other. The visit of the heir apparent to the British throne, and the welcome he received, appeared to seal the bond of good fellowship, and unite as closely as two people so widely separated by distance, can be brought together. But hardly had our royal guest turned his face homeward, the messenger, we supposed, to a grateful nation, of his generous, not to say enthusiastic reception, than a great calamity befell us, threatening not only the destruction of our Government, but the subversion of those very institutions which form the brightest and most cherished portions of the British Constitution. The standing taunt in England against the United States had been Slavery. The sole object of the rebellion was to make this institution paramount to every other, both North and South. In our strait we expected sympathy and a hearty wish for our success. To our astonishment, we found that for the past forty years the hostile sentiments always imputed to the ruling classes in England, in reference to the United States, had only remained in abeyance, overlaid by commercial relations, and had gathered strength instead of being weakened by a long period of repose. Our political experiment is pronounced a miserable failure, our Government effete, and no other future for our people but all the disasters of anarchy, or a reconstruction of our institutions upon the model of the monarchies of the old world.

abstract: In March last, a friend who knew the country well, and who was just returned from the Southwest, wrote to me, that "all the Slave States would secede, except Maryland and Missouri; war is inevitable." I well knew the South meant to secede, and that war was the inevitable consequence, but I wrote him that he was mistaken in one particular. Kentucky would not secede. I know the spirit of Kentucky very well.
lead_paragraph: THE BEECHES, September, 1861.

abstract: This regiment, Col. STRICKLAND commanding, arrived yesterday morning in the steamer Commodore, at Hunter's Point. From there the cars were taken for the Camp of Instruction at Hempstead, where the regiment will be attached to Gen. SHERMAN's Division. At present the regiment can muster only 800 men, but will be raised to the maximum number of 1,046 men, the regimental depot at Augusta, Me., being still kept open for the enrolment of recruits. Most of the men already enlisted were raised in the region of Moosehead Lake, Bangor, Ellsworth and Augusta.

abstract: The anticipated arrival of the Prince of JOINVILLE has prompted extraordinary displays of hospitality on the part of this Government. Escorts have been provided; instructions to Custom-house officers that unusual courtesies and facilities may be offered, have come from Washington; and the princeling, his son, is to have a place in the Naval Academy, which thousands of American sons have sought in vain.
lead_paragraph: The anticipated arrival of the Prince of JOINVILLE has prompted extraordinary displays of hospitality on the part of this Government. Escorts have been provided; instructions to Custom-house officers that unusual courtesies and facilities may be offered, have come from Washington; and the princeling, his son, is to have a place in the Naval Academy, which thousands of American sons have sought in vain. Nothing but the sensible suggestion of the Brazilian Consul has prevented a formal demonstration, which would at least equal that given to the heir apparent of the British throne. When we remember that Prince NAPOLEON, the possible successor to the Emperor of France, whose intended voyage hither must have been communicated by the Legation at Paris long before his departure, was permitted to land without the slightest notice, and has been the recipient of no official or marked demonstrations at any point of his progress, we may naturally ask with surprise why this unusual exhibition of hospitality to a private gentleman, without any claim whatever to public recognition?

abstract: The Confederate troops, without provocation advanced from Tennessee into Kentucky, and seized the town of Hickman and a place called Chalk Bluffs in the immediate vicinity of Columbus, and went to erecting fortifications at both points. A few hours afterwards a Confederate Army of from three to four thousand started from Tennessee to take possession of Paducah, but was anticipated in the occupation of that town by Gen. GRANT, with a United States force from Cairo. The presumption is that the Confederate invasions of Kentucky from Tennessee were made under the authority and by the instructions of the Government at Richmond, for it is scarcely supposable that Gen. POLK, who is reputed to be a prudent officer, would have taken the responsibility of the adoption of a policy certain to be productive of vast and solemn consequences. The presumption, we repeat, is that the Government of the Confederate States ordered the advance of its troops to various points in Kentucky, and, if it did, the whole purpose of that Government was to force the war at once upon and into our State. We know that the authorities at the Confederate Capital have been strenuously urged by the secession leaders in Kentucky for some time past to adopt this course and it seems they have done the outrageous and fearful deed at last.

lead_paragraph: There are fifty-two officers in the United States who can claim to be placed on the retired list, under the recent act of Congress. The most prominent are Gens. Scott, Wool, Harney and Mansfield, InspectorGeneral Churchill, Surgeon-General C.A. Finley, Commissary-General George Gibson, Assistant ditto J.P. Taylor, Paymaster-General B.F. Larned, Col. J.A. Albert, Engineers; Gen. Ripley, Chief of Ordnance; Col. Craig, Ordnance; John Erving, Colonel First Artillery; J.L. Gardner, Colonel Second Artillery; W. Gates, Colonel Third Artillery; F.I. Belton, Colonel Fourth Artillery, and the following Colonels of Infantry: Carlos A. Waite, First; Benjamin L.G. Bonneville, Second; Gen. W. Whistler, Colonel Fourth Infantry; John J. Abercrombie, Seventh; Pictairn Morrison, Eighth, and George Wright, Ninth; Col. Loomis, Fifth Infantry, commanding the forces on Governor's Island; Col. Daniel D. Tomkins, Quartermaster, State-street, New-York; Dr. R.S. Satterlee, Medical Purveyor, Grand-street; Major Leslie, Paymaster, State-street, and Col. Delafield, Superintendent of the West Point Military Academy, have each served upwards of forty years and are therefore entitled to be retired, if they wish it.

abstract: The People's Convention, called by no one knows whom, has astonished its contrivers. For several days it has been apparent, from the number and character of the delegations announced from the various sections of the State, that an influential and highly respectable body of men would be in Syracuse to-day, in response to the volunteer call. Yesterday the town began rapidly to fill up, and before daylight this morning all the first-class hotels were overflowing.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, Tuesday, Sept. 10, 1861.

abstract: The period has passed which I indicated as the limit of danger to the Capital, and though battle between the confronting hosts on the right  bank of the Potomac may still be considered imminent, there is no apprehension left, in any loyal mind, that the National Army, when such conflict comes, will not he entirely successful. The heart of the troops is entirely restored.

abstract: The leaders of the Southern rebellion have counted much on the demonstrations in their favor, to be furnished by the elections in the Northern States. They have been looking for evidences of sympathy on a large scale in their favor. They reckoned that the people would be disheartened by the desperate nature of the conflict, and frightened by the burthens which the war would necessarily impose upon them. The elections in Maine and Vermont have been held. There was but one party in either State, and that in favor of a vigorous and energetic prosecution of the war. There was not opposition enough to make up a respectable number of votes to be counted among the scattering. It will be so in New-York and in all the Eastern, Northern and Western States. The politicians who prate of "olive branches" and "compromises" with armed rebellion, will be as utterly and hopelessly annihilated as were the supporters of the Hartford Convention nearly half a century ago. Sympathy with treason will be microscopic, as developed by the elections in the Northern States.

abstract: A few days since allusion was made in the TIMES to the case of a woman, living in Grand-street, who had been prevented from committing suicide by Capt. HELME, of the Eighth Precinct Police. She had been defrauded of her property by a worthless husband, who then deserted her, leaving her without friends and suffering from the effects of pulmonary consumption. Her misfortunes prompted her to make away with herself, and she went methodically to work in order to carry out her intention, by purchasing a burial lot and arranging with an undertaker for the funeral, when her conduct became known and her purpose was frustrated.

abstract: Yesterday the bodies of EDWIN L. LYON and WILLIAM GERMAN, who were killed by railroad accident at Cockeysville last Sunday, were sent on to Connecticut to be buried. Orderly Sergeant DANIEL WHITAKER, and four privates of the Harris Light Cavalry, had the bodies in charge. The remains arrived here on Tuesday evening, and were placed in the Park Barracks. GERMAN's body was sent to Collinsville, Conn. EDWIN L. LYON was cousin to Gen. LYON. His body was taken on to Eastford, his native place, where it will be interred by the side of the late Gen. LYON.

abstract: His men appear to have been generally ignorant of the conspiracy to remove them permanently from the camp, but followed the Captain as they had been accustomed to do. Capt. CRESTO, in order to effect his purpose without observation, was made officer of the guard by his own request, and then selected the picket mostly from his own company, taking a few others to avoid suspicion. One of the privates to whom the matter had been confided revealed the plot to the Colonel, who sent for CRESTO with the intention of arresting him, but the Captain refused to go to the Colonel's quarters, and thus avoided arrest. Previously a guard had been placed on the road to intercept CRESTO. Col. LEGENDRE was on the road with two officers to meet the fugitive Captain, when he heard the discharge of a pistol, followed by the volley of musketry and the outcries of the wounded men. When he reached the spot Capt. CRESTO's men, excepting the dead and wounded had left the ground. Drs. ALLYN and BLOODGOOD, of Flushing, were sent for, who arrived before 2 o'clock A.M., and proceeded immediately to care for the wounded.

abstract: There will be no delay, we trust, in bringing forward the case of the Baltimore engineer who the other day exposed a large body of troops to destruction, and actually sacrificed several lives. It is hardly probable that a Maryland jury will consent to his punishment; but the investigation will be of service in showing the origin of the difficulty which provoked the fellow to seek such murderous vengeance, and may perhaps exculpate the officers of the regiment from charges which, to say the least, are extremely discreditable. The transactions at Harrisburgh, even when reported by the friends of Col. KILPATRICK, exhibit that gentleman as showing a violent and insubordinate temper, which was very far from being the proper example for his men. The engine on the Baltimore road was not ready in time; but there was no reason why an indiscriminate raid should be made upon the engines of innocent companies, and that a scene of riotous and disgraceful violence should be enacted, to the scandal of public order. Investigation will probably show that the entire fault lay with the officers of the regiment. The managers of the inland line complain that their time-table for transport trains is so arranged that the soldiers can be placed in Washington as promptly as by the other route. And they also assert that in cases where the conductor is permitted to move the train according to rule, there is no delay or detention. But the difficulty lies in the interference of the officers and the insubordination of the men. They insist on stopping at casual stations, and of willfully remaining hours where the time table stipulates for minutes; and in the presence of such arbitrary dictation and interruption it is impossible to maintain connections. The reported conduct of Col. KILPATRICK and his men gives color to these allegations. We trust the examination at Baltimore will throw broader light upon them.

lead_paragraph: A BAKER OF UNFERMENTED BREAD IN TROUBLE. -- RICHARD DAVIES, a middle-aged Englishman, was brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH, on two complaints of having defrauded by means of false representations. The accused, it is said, claimed to have discovered a method of making bread without fermentation, and opened a large bakery at the corner of Third-avenue and Fourteenth-street, for the purpose of bringing his bread before the public. Before commencing business, in July and August last, he procured from Messrs. W. & J.T. LEWIS, carpet-dealers, at No. 12 Fourth-avenue, a quantity of carpets, oil-cloths and rugs, which, adding the labor of putting them down, made a bill of $179 10. These goods were all obtained upon credit, which the merchants gave upon the strength of representations made by the accused as to his solvency, which it is now alleged were untrue. Another complainant is Mr. MILTON B. GRIFFIN, of No. 123 Ninth-avenue, who charged that the accused obtained from him, also by fraudulent and specious statements, a quantity of flour, valued at $1,189 20, and he had been swindled to that amount. The accused was arrested by Officer WILLIAMS, of the Second District Police Court, and he was required to give bail for trial on both complaints, respectively, in the sums of $500 and $1,500.

abstract: The Quartermaster-General's Department in Richmond, says the Charleston Mercury, has received 5,000 of a new kind of shoes, of a rather curious description, that promises to answer well in the great scarcity of shoe-leather. The upper portions of the shoe are made of canvas, instead of leather. The canvas is prepared so as to make it impervious to the weather, and is said to equal, in comfort, durability and all respects of wear, the best of shoe-leather.

abstract: The examination of Mr. John A. Machade, on a charge of fitting out the bark Mary Francis from this port of the Slave-trade, was commenced yesterday
lead_paragraph: The examination of Mr. John A. Machade, on a charge of fitting out the bark Mary Francis from this port of the Slave-trade, was commenced yesterday before United States Commissioner OSBORNE. The Mary Francis sailed from this port on the 17th of October last for Wilmington, N.C., whence she sailed ostensibly for one of the West India Islands, but as it afterwards turned out, proceeded direct for the Coast of Africa, where she took on a cargo of negroes, and subsequently landed them on the Island of Cuba. Thus much is susceptible of abundant proof already in the hands of the Government, but who fitted the vessel out, and in whose interest she sailed on her slave trading expedition is more difficult to establish. Mr. Machado was arrested some two or three weeks ago charged with fitting out not only the Mary Francis, but half-a-dozen other slavers that are known to have sailed from this port during the last five years. On his first examination, he was discharged for want of proof, the Government witness having failed to arrive from Boston, and the counsel for Mr. Machado, stated at the time that his [???] would hold himself in readiness for examination whenever called for, and would voluntarily surrender himself without putting the District Attorney to the trouble of arresting him. In accordance with this agreement, Mr. Machado, on learning that the witnesses for the Government had arrived, voluntarily appeared at the examination, accompanied by his counsel, Judge Bebee. Mr. Andrews appeared on behalf of the Government, and called to the stand Wm. Murray, who testified that he was a sailor on board the Mary Francis; shipped at this port on the 15th of October last, and sailed on the 17th for Wilmington; on the night the vessel sailed saw a man on the dock who looked very like Machado, but couldn't swear it was he; vessel lay at Pier No. 52 East River; witness shipped as a sailor at French's office in South-street; was thirteen days on the passage to Wilmington; stopped at Wilmington seven days, during which time they discharged some empty barrels, and took in half a cargo of lumber, and filled some water casks; Williams, who was master of the bark when she left New-York, left her two days after they arrived at Wilmington, and Capt. Parker took his place; while lying in the stream at Wilmington the day the bark sailed, Mr. Machado came on board, accompanied by Mrs. Watson; spent most of the time in the cabin with the captain; didn't hear any of the conversation; witness and another sailor took them ashore in a boat.

abstract: We have glorious news from Western Virginia which fully confirms the correctness of our recent anticipations, that there would be Struck the next telling blow against the rebellion. The command  of the rebel FLOYD, consisting of five thousand men, has been ignominiously routed, leaving behind...
lead_paragraph: We have glorious news from Western Virginia which fully confirms the correctness of our recent anticipations, that there would be Struck the next telling blow against the rebellion. The command of the rebel FLOYD, consisting of five thousand men, has been ignominiously routed, leaving behind them all their camp equipage, wagons, horses, large quantities of ammunition, fifty head of cattle -- in fact, everything, even to the personal baggage of FLOYD and his officers. The rebel army was found by Gen. ROSECRANS to be intrenched in a powerful position on the top of a mountain at Cannix Ferry, near Summerville, on the west side of Gauley River, and, after suitable reconnoissances, an engagement commenced at 3 o'clock, on Tuesday afternoon. FLOYD had sixteen field pieces, and his rear and both flanks were, from the nature of the ground, inaccessible, while his front was masked with heavy forest and a close jungle. Notwithstanding these difficulties, however, the success of our arms was complete, and with a comparatively small loss of life. The enemy's position was first discovered by four companies from the Ohio Tenth Regiment, acting as scouts, who unexpectedly came upon a parapet battery, and a long line of palisades for riflemen, when the battle opened with great fierceness, and continued until dark. The Tenth, Twelfth and Thirteenth Ohio were immediately brought into action, and engaged the batteries with good effect, while MCMULLIN's howitzer batteries and two field-pieces were got into position, and succeeded in silencing several of the enemy's guns. The battle raged furiously as night approached, and the German Brigade, under Col. MCCOOK, was brought up, soon after which the firing ceased, on account of the darkness, and the troops lay in position on their arms, ready to resume operations with the morning light. During the night, however, the rebels fled precipitately across the river, leaving everything behind them, and destroying the temporary bridge which they had constructed, so that pursuit was impossible, the river at that point being deep and turbulent. The National loss is but fifteen killed and about seventy wounded. The loss of the rebels is not known, as they carried their dead and wounded with them.

abstract: IMPORTANT MOVEMENT IN CITY POLITICS. -- A preliminary meeting of prominent merchants and business men, without distinction of party, was held in the large dining-room of the St. Nicholas Hotel last evening, to institute steps for a grand Union movement of the People at the coming election, by which it is designed to wrest the City Government from the control of the corrupt politicians, party hacks, and spoilsmen, who have so long ruled, and so nearly ruined, the metropolis. The movement originated with the better class of our citizens, who have heretofore taken no prominent part in City politic -- partly from disinclination, and partly from the apparent hopelessnessof effecting any reform -- but who are now satisfied that the time has arrived when the People, beholding the ruin brought upon our National Government by party spirit and political corruption, may be induced to discard the one and denounce the other, while they unite in rescuing our City Government from a similar fate. It is designed to place men in nomination for the various City offices without reference to their past party antecedents, and with sole reference to their known capability, honesty, and worth. Several thousand of our most prominent, substantial, and trustworthy, citizens have already given their signatures to the movement, and hundreds of new names are daily being added. The meeting last evening was a preliminary one for consultation only, but a mass meeting will soon be called, when all our citizens who desire an honest and economical City Government, will have an opportunity to identify themselves with the movement.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT MOVEMENT IN CITY POLITICS. -- A preliminary meeting of prominent merchants and business men, without distinction of party, was held in the large dining-room of the St. Nicholas Hotel last evening, to institute steps for a grand Union movement of the People at the coming election, by which it is designed to wrest the City Government from the control of the corrupt politicians, party hacks, and spoilsmen, who have so long ruled, and so nearly ruined, the metropolis. The movement originated with the better class of our citizens, who have heretofore taken no prominent part in City politic -- partly from disinclination, and partly from the apparent hopelessnessof effecting any reform -- but who are now satisfied that the time has arrived when the People, beholding the ruin brought upon our National Government by party spirit and political corruption, may be induced to discard the one and denounce the other, while they unite in rescuing our City Government from a similar fate. It is designed to place men in nomination for the various City offices without reference to their past party antecedents, and with sole reference to their known capability, honesty, and worth. Several thousand of our most prominent, substantial, and trustworthy, citizens have already given their signatures to the movement, and hundreds of new names are daily being added. The meeting last evening was a preliminary one for consultation only, but a mass meeting will soon be called, when all our citizens who desire an honest and economical City Government, will have an opportunity to identify themselves with the movement.

lead_paragraph: New-York will express her sentiments on the rebellion in a very explicit and unmistakable manner, at the November election. The attempt of the Democratic Party leaders to thrust upon the people the exploded party issues of the past, for the purpose of aiding the rebels in dividing the Union, has met with a deserved rebuke. The people, without regard to party, have put in nomination an anti-rebellion ticket, which will be elected by more than a hundred thousand majority.

abstract: The inquisition into the death of the two soldiers of the New-York Rifles, who lost their lives in the emeute near ROE's Tavern, on Monday night, was continued at EDWARDS' Hotel, Flushing, yesterday. Several witnesses were examined, but nothing material was elicited in addition to the facts already laid before the public. Dr. ALLEIN's testimony merely referred to the nature of the wounds, which were sufficient to cause death.

abstract: Not withstanding the diagrams of one of our morning cotemporaries,showing the exact disposition of the entire rebel Army, as well as that of our own, there are very serious doubts as to the whereabouts of Gen. BEAUREGARD, and the main body of his troops. That they have left Manassas has been ascertained
lead_paragraph: Not withstanding the diagrams of one of our morning cotemporaries,showing the exact disposition of the entire rebel Army, as well as that of our own, there are very serious doubts as to the whereabouts of Gen. BEAUREGARD, and the main body of his troops. That they have left Manassas has been ascertained by the military authorities at Washington. But whether they have gone Southward, or Northward, or Westward, has not been discovered; and may, perhaps, only be learned when they appear in full force at an unexpected point. It is gratifying, however, to know that the disposition of our forces is such that a surprise at any point is out of the question; and that so perfect are our communications and preparations, it will be possible, in a few hours, to transport an adequate force to any portion of our extended lines where the enemy may choose to make his attack.

abstract: OBTAINING TREASURY NOTES BY FRAUD.--A  man named GEORGE B. CLEMENTS was committed yesterday by Justice KELLY, charged with forgery. The complainant, Mr. WILLIAM B. BEND, a clerk in the office of LIVERMORE, CLEWS  MASON, No.41 Wallstreet, stated that CLEMENTS showed him a letter, purporting to have been written on the 2d inst....
lead_paragraph: OBTAINING TREASURY NOTES BY FRAUD. -- A man named GEORGE B. CLEMENTS was committed yesterday by Justice KELLY, charged with forgery. The complainant, Mr. WILLIAM B. BEND, a clerk in the office of LIVERMORE, CLEWS MASON, No.41 Wallstreet, stated that CLEMENTS showed him a letter, purporting to have been written on the 2d inst., by M. BARKER & SONS, of Jersey City, representing that they desired $2,500 of the two years six per cent. Treasury notes, which he (CLEMENTS) might purchase for them, at the lowest cash price, to be paid for on delivery. CLEMENTS said he wanted to know the price of notes, and when he could obtain them. Mr. BEND made a statement of the prices, and said that next morning, at 10 o'clock, the notes could be delivered. At the time mentioned, CLEMENTS returned to the office, and presented to the complainant another letter from BARKER & SONS, containing a check for $2,466 93, in favor of LIVERMORE, CLEWS & MASON, purporting to have been certified by the Cashier of the Bank of Jersey City. In consideration of this check, five $500 Treasury notes were delivered to CLEMENTS, who went away. The check was placed in the Bank of the Commonwealth for collection, when it was found, upon presenting it at the Bank of Jersey City, that the certification upon the check was a forgery, and that BARKER & SONS kept no account there. A warrant was therefore issued for the arrest of CLEMENTS, who was found, after much difficulty, by Detective NIVEN, of the Second Precinct. He denied having been guilty of any offence.

abstract: Among the results of the present war is the disintegration of political parties all over the country. Party platforms, differences on questions of governmental policy belonging to the past, have all been swept away by the rush of events, or buried beneath the living issues of....
lead_paragraph: Among the results of the present war is the disintegration of political parties all over the country. Party platforms, differences on questions of governmental policy belonging to the past, have all been swept away by the rush of events, or buried beneath the living issues of the present. Party rallying cries have lost their potency; party discipline has ceased to be regarded. Nobody talks about the "Chicago platform." Nobody thinks of the Baltimore resolutions. "Popular Sovereignty" and "Slavery expansion "have ceased to be discussed. Whether a citizen was last year a Democrat, a Republican, a Union conservative, is no longer a subject of thought or inquiry. The practical question is: What are his opinions Now -- to-day, on the subject of the crisis through which the country is passing? and where does he stand in reference to an uncompromising and vigorous prosecution of the war, until the Union shall be reinstated in its length and breadth, and the Constitution vindicated in all its sanctions? Such are now the tests of political orthodoxy, and they are rapidly relaxing the cohesiveness of political organizations. Men of all parties and of every subdivision of party are standing side by side in the ranks of the Army, periling their lives in defence of the country without inquiry as to the political faith of either, and the people seeing this, ask why those who remain at home should not go to the polls together as the soldiers go to the war, and vote as the soldiers fight, for the preservation of the Union, without reference to past political associations or sympathies. Loyalty to the Constitution is everywhere acknowledged as of infinitely higher obligation than fealty to party. Though ancient leaders may attempt to stem the current thus setting in towards the demolition of political organizations, yet they are swept away by the resistless rush. "Who cares for party now, when the Constitution is in danger, and the Union imperiled? The question whether we have a country or not, is the first in order. Let us settle that, and we will talk about party afterwards." Such is the response to the appeals of party leaders, and it comes up from the patriotic millions all over the North. The strifes of the factions are awed into quietude by the majesty of the popular movement. Partisan hates are stifled by its power. Inspired by a love of country, men of all shades of opinion on the issues of former days fraternize earnestly, in view of the stern and practical issues of these perilous times.
