lead_paragraph: The condition of affairs in this country has long been a puzzle to foreigners, but is daily assuming a shape intelligible and exceedingly satisfactory to Ourselves. Unlike European Governments, our own has never depended upon standing armies for its maintenance or defence -- a vast force to be launched like a thunderholt, upon an instant notice, against a disquieted or insurgent province or community. Upon the breaking out of the great rebellion, we, for the first time, had to create that which at all times has engrossed the chief attention of other Governments, an immense and efficient army, the most difficult of all human contrivances. This Army, too, was to be directed against those who, a few months ago, were in the relation of citizens and friends. Our unwillingness to embark in such bloody work, lead us to try every expedient to avoid it if possible. This feeling, for a long time, had all the appearance of imbecility, and of the want of anything like a definite purpose or policy. When forced to extreme measures, we had to commence what had been entirely neglected for forty years. Our citizens were wrapped up in peaceful pursuits, which they were suddenly called upon to forego, for the sterner duties of war. It was inevitable that, to the experienced Captains of Europe, we should fall into many blunders, and suffer many mortifying disasters, which alone could train a people so situated to final success. In all this we have been judged by results, rather than by the causes that lead to them, or by the inherent strength we really possess. We have been pronounced effete; broken to pieces; with the whole current of our nationality changed, and have been regarded as people, like those of Poland, about to be blotted out from the list of nations, even before, with the utmost diligence, we could adapt ourselves to our unlooked-for dilemma. We were given up for lost before any event had happened that put us in real peril. Such has been the foreign view of our condition, certainly in most striking contrast to our own. We have never shown, because we have never felt, any tropidation or doubt. It was evident that we had great task before us, to the execution of which we set ourselves methodically at work, by raising and putting in condition for vigorous operations a vast army and navy. The disasters suffered have only had the effect to pioneer us on to victory. The favorableness of our condition, in the circumstances, has never been paralleled. Suppose England to be divided into two great hostile camps, the rebels holding nearly one-half its territory and menacing its Capital with a vast army -- what would be the price of consols? Would people crowd to the public offices to compete for Government stocks at the market rate of money for investment? Consols ranged only a little above fifty per cent. for more than twenty years when England was engaged in foreign wars only. The securities of this country are nearly at par with 150,000 or 200,000 rebels in arms in the sight of Washington. At the office of the Assistant Treasurer, in this City, the people took, yesterday, $1,050,000 of the new Government loan. This is outside the action of the Banks. Five hundred such offices are to be immediately opened, at which the whole available capital of the country, if need be, will be proffered to the Government, not out of a sentiment of patriotism, but as a pure business transaction.

abstract: COMMODORE STEWART. -- A City journal gives currency to a story about Commodore STEWART, which does infinite injustice to the most loyal and gallant of officers. The Commodore is represented as having been a passenger on board the Canada on its recent voyage from Liverpool; and as having announced his intention to go at once to the South, and take a commission in the rebel navy, having boasted that he had shipped 25,000 muskets from Europe to the insurgents, one-half of which had reached them. The statement proceeds to say that both the Commodore and his wife are Southerners, owning vast estates in the Southern Confederation. Hence their violent affection for treason.

abstract: United States Marshal SANDFORD, of Rhode Island, arrived here on Wednesday morning, with Mr. JOHN W. ANDREWS, a resident of New-Orleans, whom he arrested in Providence, charged with being an officer in the Louisiana Militia, and actively engaged in the rebel movement.
lead_paragraph: United States Marshal SANDFORD, of Rhode Island, arrived here on Wednesday morning, with Mr. JOHN W. ANDREWS, a resident of New-Orleans, whom he arrested in Providence, charged with being an officer in the Louisiana Militia, and actively engaged in the rebel movement. The prisoner was transferred to Marshal MURRAY, who is investigating the question of his identity, there being, as appears, two Louisianians by the name of JOHN W. ANDREWS, and the one under arrest denying that he is the rebel sought for. Should his identity with the rebel officer be established, he will be sent to Fort Lafayette; but the announcement in the Tribune and Herald, of yesterday, that he had already been sent thither, was a mistake.

abstract: GOOD NEWS FROM THE SEAT OF WAR. -- We present this morning very favorable news from Western Virginia and Missouri. In Virginia, Gen. ROSECRANS column, about which much apprehension has been felt, has encountered and routed the great thief of the rebels, Gen. FLOYD, capturing his tents, camp equipage, and personal effects of FLOYD and his officers. The route was complete, and not only relieves all fear as to the safety of ROSECKANS, but clears Western Virginia of rebels. The moral effect of this victory will be most excellent, and proves Gen. MCCLELLAN'S declaration that we have suffered our last defeat, was not a vain boast. In Missouri, the Government troops are rapidly dispersing the bands of marauding rebels, and will soon drive them from the State. New expeditions are being fitted out from Fortress Monroe, encouraged by the brilliant result of the Hatteras expedition. From Gen. MCCLELLAN's command no news is good news, as every day adds to his strength and preparations for at advance.
lead_paragraph: GOOD NEWS FROM THE SEAT OF WAR. -- We present this morning very favorable news from Western Virginia and Missouri. In Virginia, Gen. abstract: Ex-Gov. GEORGE N. BRIGGS, of Massachusetts, whose death, in consequence of a gun-shot wound accidentally received, has already been announced, was born in Adams, Berkshire County, April 12, 1796. His father was a blacksmith, and when his son was seven years old he moved to Manchester, in Vermont, and two years afterward to White Creek, Washington County, in this State. At the age of 18 he entered a law office in his native town, after a year's attendance upon an academy, and in 1818 was admitted to the Berkshire Bar, and for years was successful in his profession. Mr. BRIGGS was elected to Congress in 1831, and served six terms. During the Twenty-seventh Congress he served us Chairman of the Committee on the Post-office. In 1843 he was elected Governor of Massachusetts, which station he filled until the election of Mr. BOUTWELL in 1851. As Chief Magistrate he was a strong friend of all the moral, religious, educational, industrial and military organizations of the State, and his administrations gave general acceptance.
lead_paragraph: Ex-Gov. GEORGE N. BRIGGS, of Massachusetts, whose death, in consequence of a gun-shot wound accidentally received, has already been announced, was born in Adams, Berkshire County, April 12, 1796. His father was a blacksmith, and when his son was seven years old he moved to Manchester, in Vermont, and two years afterward to White Creek, Washington County, in this State. At the age of 18 he entered a law office in his native town, after a year's attendance upon an academy, and in 1818 was admitted to the Berkshire Bar, and for years was successful in his profession. Mr. BRIGGS was elected to Congress in 1831, and served six terms. During the Twenty-seventh Congress he served us Chairman of the Committee on the Post-office. In 1843 he was elected Governor of Massachusetts, which station he filled until the election of Mr. BOUTWELL in 1851. As Chief Magistrate he was a strong friend of all the moral, religious, educational, industrial and military organizations of the State, and his administrations gave general acceptance.

abstract: The demand for sewed army shoes for the United States troops, as well as for sewed and pegged shoes for the different States shows no signs of diminution. Last week a gentleman of Indianapolis left two orders for 5,000 pairs of pegged shoes each for the State of Indiana, and several lots, ranging from 3,000 to 5,000 pairs of sewed shoes, were disposed of at good prices for New-York, Missouri and other States. Government contracts were also placed in Boston for about 25,000 pairs of cavalry boots at profitable rates. These goods are to be made from 8 1/2 ounce oak upper leather. Some of our manufacturers who received contracts on Saturday were cutting and giving out stock on Monday, ready to turn out the goods at the rate of from one to two hundred pairs daily. In every shoe town in the State workmen are engaged in sewing Army shoes, on which they are getting about 50 cents a pan for bottoming. Good workmen are now having steady employment, and making $1 to $1 50 a day. Six hundred thousand pairs of sewed shoes are being made up in Massachusetts, for which Uncle Sam will pay considerably over a million of dollars. A low average of the amount paid for work, bottoming, fitting, &c., would be 60 cents a pair, equal to $360,000 distributed among the journeymen in the State for making the shoes. This is exclusive of the large amount of both sewed and pegged work for the State, as well as of cavalry boots, which will not fall short of one-half the above amount, or $180,000. The Department will commence paying for goods about the middle of September, when our contractors will have a chance to finger some of Uncle Sam's gold.
lead_paragraph: The demand for sewed army shoes for the United States troops, as well as for sewed and pegged shoes for the different States shows no signs of diminution. Last week a gentleman of Indianapolis left two orders for 5,000 pairs of pegged shoes each for the State of Indiana, and several lots, ranging from 3,000 to 5,000 pairs of sewed shoes, were disposed of at good prices for New-York, Missouri and other States. Government contracts were also placed in Boston for about 25,000 pairs of cavalry boots at profitable rates. These goods are to be made from 8 1/2 ounce oak upper leather. Some of our manufacturers who received contracts on Saturday were cutting and giving out stock on Monday, ready to turn out the goods at the rate of from one to two hundred pairs daily. In every shoe town in the State workmen are engaged in sewing Army shoes, on which they are getting about 50 cents a pan for bottoming. Good workmen are now having steady employment, and making $1 to $1 50 a day. Six hundred thousand pairs of sewed shoes are being made up in Massachusetts, for which Uncle Sam will pay considerably over a million of dollars. A low average of the amount paid for work, bottoming, fitting, &c., would be 60 cents a pair, equal to $360,000 distributed among the journeymen in the State for making the shoes. This is exclusive of the large amount of both sewed and pegged work for the State, as well as of cavalry boots, which will not fall short of one-half the above amount, or $180,000. The Department will commence paying for goods about the middle of September, when our contractors will have a chance to finger some of Uncle Sam's gold.

abstract: Hon. GIDEON WELLES, Secretary of the Navy, visited the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday. He was received with the honors due to his position, viz.: a salute of seventeen guns. The guard was turned out and presented arms, both on his arrival and departure. The Honorable Secretary was accompanied by the Naval (vessel) Examining Board, consisting of the following gentlemen: E.D. MORGAN, Naval Constructor POOK, Capt. BELL, U.S.N., and Chief-Engineer KIMBALL of the navy. The party was conducted round the Yard by Commodore BREESE and Capt. ALMEY, and spent, two hours in examining with great attention the various works now going on, particularly the gun-boats. Before returning to Washington, Secretary WELLES will visit all the private ship-yards in the vicinity of New-York where vessels are in the course of construction for the Government. He will no doubt also visit all the Navy-yards in the States.

abstract: Governor MORGAN has pardoned Dr. THOMAS T. ELLIS, who, as our readers may remember, was convicted over a year and a half ago, of constructive larceny, before Judge BARNARD, and sentenced to the State Prison for three years and a half. The alleged offence was proved by the testimony of a woman known to be of disreputable character, who testified that while on a visit to Dr. ELLIS he asked her to show off a diamond ring which she wore; that she took it off her finger and handed it to him, and that he neverreturned it. This was the whole case against him. Evidence of her character was offered and ruled out. Proof was adduced to show that the woman had once before made complaint and withdrawn it; that she had given the Doctor a receipt for the ring, and that she had acknowledged giving it to him for the purpose of borrowing money upon it: -- but the jury was instructed to disregard all these matters, and to be governed in their verdict by the evidence of woman alone. They did so, and convicted the Doctor, who was on the spot sentenced for the long term mentioned. He has already been in prison a year and a half. Several lawyers, of high position and eminent ability, united in representing to the Governor that the conviction, under the circumstances, was an outrage upon law and justice, and that the punishment already inflicted was greater than the crime would have deserved, even if it had been proved. Upon these representations, and after a careful examination of the records, Gov. MORGAN granted an unconditional release to the Doctor, whose professional and personal standing, previous to this affair, was very good. Various statements are made in regard to the influences which affected the case on its trial, which may possibly be made the subject of inquiry hereafter, and to which therefore, no further allusion need now be made.

abstract: Gen. BEAUREGARD's report of the skirmish of July 18 has at length come to light, though why it was delayed so long or extended to such a length does not clearly appear. Still, the document is prepared with far less of the usual gasconade of the Southern official papers, and certainly contains one of the clearest descriptions of the country at Bull Run we have yet seen. It is a good business document, and embellished -- considering The General's propensity -- with but a moderate proportion of falsehood.
lead_paragraph: Gen. BEAUREGARD's report of the skirmish of July 18 has at length come to light, though why it was delayed so long or extended to such a length does not clearly appear. abstract: The rebels commenced an advance on both pikes yesterday morning, towards Elk Water and Cheat Mountain Summit. They succeeded in surrounding the fort on the summit, and cut the telegraph wire. They continued to advance on Elk Water until within two miles of our troops, when a few shells from Loomis' Battery dispersed them. Skirmishing was kept up all night.

abstract: The letter-sheet and envelope combined, ordered some time since by the Department, has been issued from the establishment of Mr. NESBIT, of this City, the contractor for the Government Envelopes. It is a neat and convenient contrivance, and will, we have no doubt, at once become quite popular. In business transactions it will overcome a difficulty which has often been experienced in legally connecting the envelope with the inclosure, while to the traveling correspondent they will be found exceedingly handy, as the paper, envelope and stamp are all combined in one. There are two sizes, note and letter, of three cents postage rate each. The small size are sold at 91 cents per package of twenty-five, or $3 64 per hundred. For the letter size, 97 cents per package of twenty-five, or $3 88 per package of one hundred. -- Holbrook's United States Mail.

abstract: There can be no reasonable doubt of the loyalty of Kentucky, so far as the action of its Legislature can make it so. That body not only refuses to join the Southern rebellion, but has notified the Confederates under Gen. POLK to vacate the soil of the State. It has practically repudiated the fallacy of neutrality, and will, we hope, respond to the national exigencies by passing a law raising the quota of State troops, and providing for the paymentof that portion of the national taxation for the support of the war assigned to Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: There can be no reasonable doubt of the loyalty of Kentucky, so far as the action of its Legislature can make it so. abstract: The burden of every foreign mail is Cotton. We can all, without concern, read over tables of mortality, which tell us that we have so many years to live, provided they do not fix the precise moment of our demise. Were our span limited to a day, though it embraced a hundred years, the fatal hour, forever present to the imagination, would embitter our whole life. Cotton has come to be the vital air to the great industry of England. In so many months the last whiff will be taken, unless new supplies be obtained from an unforeseen and unexpected quarter. Every bale used is looked upon with a sort of apprehension that it may be the last. The subject, consequently, is the all-pervading one in that country, and the Press of the nation is filled with discussions of means possessed for eking out the scanty supply, and of the probability of such a development of the plant in other countries as will entirely throw off the galling independence on the United States.

abstract: Marshal KANE, of Baltimore, Col. DAWSON, of Virginia, and two or three other prisoners, arrived at Fort Lafayette yesterday, from Fort McHenry, near Baltimore. The prisoners came from Philadelphia by the Camden and Amboy line, and were taken to Fort Lafayette in the steamboat Stockton, which plies between this City and Amboy. They were accompanied by a detachment of Company B, Twenty-first Regiment Indiana Volunteers.
lead_paragraph: Marshal KANE, of Baltimore, Col. DAWSON, of Virginia, and two or three other prisoners, arrived at Fort Lafayette yesterday, from Fort McHenry, near Baltimore. They were accompanied by a detachment of Company B, Twenty-first Regiment Indiana Volunteers.

abstract: Major BARRY's Battery of Flying Artillery, which arrived by the steamer Cahawba from Fort Pickens, left by railroad at 6 o'clock last evening for Washington. This troop consists of three officers, 86 non-commissioned officers and privates, 60 horses, two 12-pounder howitzers, two 6-pounder guns and four caissons. They left for Fort Pickens in April last, and arrived there at a time of imminent peril. They were compelled to swim their horses half a mile to land, losing eight by drowning and exhaustion. On the 5th inst. they embarked on board the Cahawba, which sailed on the same day. The steamer was detained thirty hours at Key West taking in water. Major BARRY mounted his battery on the spar-deck of the steamer, and kept the guns shotted constantly, as considerable alarm was entertained of an attack from the pirate Sumter, which was thought to be prowling about the Southern waters. The men were armed with sabres and revolvers, and kept a sharp look-out continually. They reached this City, however, without interruption. Major BARRY was compelled to shoot one of his horses, his leg having been broken during the process of landing. About 4 o'clock in the afternoon, the troop left the foot of Canal-street, marched through Broadway, Fulton, Greenwich and Murray streets -- at the foot of which a tug lay ready to receive them.

abstract: On motion of Mr. WOODFORD, Assistant District-Attorney, it was this morning ordered by the Court that the Prize Commissioners be empowered to break their seals upon the hatches of prize vessels in their custody, for the purpose of having them examined by the agent of the Navy Department in this City, said examination to be conducted in the presence of one of the prize Commissioners, and the hatches to be immediately resealed after such examination.

abstract: The Daily News calls loudly for peace, and for a treating with the Southern rebels as the way to procure it. It urges strenuously that it would be neither "dishonorable, unusual, impolitic or inexpedient." Of what is honorable or dishonorable, we fancy the Daily News will hardly be accepted as the best judge, however it may be as to matters of policy; and as it simply gives its own opinion on this point, without arguing it, the opinion may safely be left to itself.

abstract: The Prince de JOINVILLE, who visits this country for the purpose of placing his son, if possible, in the Naval Academy, now located at Newport, arrived in the Africa, last evening, and was waited upon by the Surveyor of the Port, and other officials, who tendered every courtesy to him. The Prince remained on board the steamer until this morning, when he debarked, and proceeded to the Brevoort House, on 8th-avenue corner of 8th-street, where he had previously engaged accommodations. He is accompanied by the following suite, as registered on the books of the hotel: Prince de Joinville and Son, Comte de Paris, Duc de Chartres, Capt. Masolean, Mons. Fauvel, Dr. Leclerc, and five servants, occupying a suite of thirteen apartments. The entire party, it is worth observing, are registered as coming from Claremont, in England, the residence of the Prince. The Prince is a tall, fine-looking gentleman, bearing a marked resemblance to the late MORTIMER LIVINGSTON. It is not known how long his stay in this City may be prolonged.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington inform us that no movement of the National troops took place yesterday. The rebels, however, in the afternoon, moved a large body of men from Fairfax Court-house towards Falls Church, with the purpose, as is supposed, of resisting any occupation by our troops of the ground reconnoitered on Wednesday, when the skirmish took place near Lewinsville. Signal fires were seen in the direction of the rebel camp last night-indicating,...
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington inform us that no movement of the National troops took place yesterday. The rebels, however, in the afternoon, moved a large body of men from Fairfax Court-house towards Falls Church, with the purpose, as is supposed, of resisting any occupation by our troops of the ground reconnoitered on Wednesday, when the skirmish took place near Lewinsville. Signal fires were seen in the direction of the rebel camp last night -- indicating, probably, that the troops had occupied the positions assigned them. Government has received reliable information that the strength of the rebels at Fairfax Court-house and vicinity is one hundred and ten thousand, the estimate being based upon the number of rations issued. BEAUREGARD is there in person.

abstract: Detectives SAMPSON and DEVOF, who are detailed for duty in the United States Marshal's office, yesterday made three arrests of persons alleged to be guilty of misprison of treason. Their offences are all connected with the operations of the Virginian, MILLNER, who was sent to Fort Lafayette on Tuesday. One of the prisoners is BENJAMIN F. CORLIES, a member of the firm of CORLIES & MACY, stationers, No. 33 Nassau-street. MILLNER recently came from the South in search of arms and to have bank notes manufactured, and he induced Mr. CORLIES to have $150,000 in bills of the Bank of Pittsylvania, Va., made for him at the establishment of CONRAD FATZER, engraver, No. 216 William-street. This fact came to the knowledge of the authorities, and resulted in the arrest of both CORLIES and FATZER. The bank notes were also seized by the detectives at a house in Second-street, where they had been secreted. They were finished, excepting the signatures of the bank officers.
lead_paragraph: Detectives SAMPSON and DEVOF, who are detailed for duty in the United States Marshal's office, yesterday made three arrests of persons alleged to be guilty of misprison of treason. abstract: It is impossible not to be impressed with the modest simplicity of the dispatch in which Gen. ROSECRANS alludes to the defeat of FLOYD. We say alludes, because the account does not state that a battle had occurred; that, with splendid gallantry, the Ohio troops had stormed the rebel batteries, had compelled the rebel forces to save themselves by a hasty retreat, and had secured a position of great strategic value.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible not to be impressed with the modest simplicity of the dispatch in which Gen. ROSECRANS alludes to the defeat of FLOYD. We say alludes, because the account does not state that a battle had occurred; that, with splendid gallantry, the Ohio troops had stormed the rebel batteries, had compelled the rebel forces to save themselves by a hasty retreat, and had secured a position of great strategic value. We merely hear of driving in the enemy's pickets and a single regiment, of a "strong reconnoisance," and of the escape of the rebels while our exhausted soldiers were resting on their arms. We also hear with amusement of rifled cannon fired at the retreating fugitives for "a moral effect." What really occurred, how admirably the attack was conceived and conducted, and how important the success, we are obliged to gather from other witnesses, who do more liberal justice to the real merits of the affair.

abstract: Gen. CASS, in a recent conversation with President FAIRCHILD, of Hillsdale College, Michigan, said that though he had always been heretofore opposed to Abolition, yet this was now the only way to successfully and permanently end the contest. Without Abolition, if we had peace to-day, we should have war to-morrow.

abstract: This time the Confederates have been outmaneuvered, and Kentucky, which they have exerted all their powers to obtain possession of, is at the present moment virtually lost to them. When Gen. PILLOW first landed at New-Madrid, it was the intention of the enemy to pass Bird's Point, and by way of Pilot Knob and the Iron Mountain Railroad, march straight upon St. Louis, while McCULLOCH kept Gen. LYON'S command busy at Springfield.

lead_paragraph: The great blessing which Savings Banks be stow upon the civilized race consists in the opportunity they afford to invest safely small savings. The Army and Navy Savings Banks in the English service and in that of many other European countries, are of incalculable usefulness. Millions upon millions are saved from dissipation and employed for reproduction. Mr. POINSETT, when Secretary of War, earnestly discussed the introduction of Army Savings Banks, with the writer of this communication, but it was found that our Army was too small and too much dispersed over our extensive territory.

abstract: The new steamship Hansa belonging to the North German Lloyd, Bremen, was safely launched at Greenock, Scotland, on the 23d ult. She is 2,868 tons built measurement, and will register 3,500 tons, being the largest vessel ever constructed at Greenock. She will be fitted for the accommodation of 250 cabin and 460 steerage passengers, and will be commanded by Capt. H.J. VON [???] late of the steamship New-York.

abstract: The testimony before the Coroner's July at Flushing touching the death of the two men who were shot while in the act of leaving camp in charge of Capt. CRESTO, was concluded on Thursday evening. The Foreman dismissed the Jury with the proper charge to consider, and bring in their verdict. After a brief consultation, and comparison of all the evidence, the jury returned, and rendered a verdict as follows: That FREDERICK MARCO and DOMINICK SASSI came to their death by rifle-bullets fired bya squad of men belonging to the New-York rifles, by order of Lieut. GEORGE. As there was no sufficient charge against Capt. CRESTO, to warrant his detention, he was discharged by the Coroner, and returned to the camp at Willett's Point, Yesterday morning he left, and came to this City, and reported himself to Gen. YATES, at the Division Armory, accompanied by Gen. HAMILTON, of the Flushing Artillery. Capt. CRESTO declared his purpose of having no further connection with the Le Gendre Regiment, and reported a list of his grievances. A Court of Inquiry has been ordered by Gen. YATES, composed of competent officers, which was ordered to assemble at Willett's Point yesterday, at 1 o'clock P.M. This puts an end to the civil proceedings in the case, butthere will now be a thorough investigation under military authority, which, it is presumed, will place the blame of the transaction where it belongs.

abstract: Mr. JOHN W. ANDREWS, who was brought here on Wednesday in custody of the Rhode Island Marshal, charged with being a Colonel in the rebel Army, has been released, it having been proved beyond question that he is a loyal citizen, and in no way connected with the person of the same name in the Confederate Army. Mr. ANDREWS is a New-Englander by birth, but a resident of New-Orleans, which place he left two or three weeks since for a visit, to his mother in Providence. He owns a largo property in New-Orleans, and claims to be a good Union man.

abstract: The rumors which have for the past day or two prevailed in reference to Gen. FREMONT, alleging that he had been or was to be superseded in the command of the Department of the West, will be set at rest by the letter to him from the President, which we publish this morning.
lead_paragraph: The rumors which have for the past day or two prevailed in reference to Gen. FREMONT, alleging that he had been or was to be superseded in the command of the Department of the West, will be set at rest by the letter to him from the President, which we publish this morning. It will be seen that the feature of the Proclamation recently issued by Gen. FREMONT, regarding the liberation of the slaves of rebels, is modified so as to conform strictly with the law passed by Congress at the late session, entitled "An act to confiscate property used for insurrectionary purposes." This is done with the full consent, -- in fact, at the request of Gen. FREMONT himself.

abstract: The geographical position of Maryland, has, from the very outbreak of the rebellion, rendered its possession by the contending parties of the greatest possible moment.
lead_paragraph: The geographical position of Maryland, has, from the very outbreak of the rebellion, rendered its possession by the contending parties of the greatest possible moment. To the loyal States it interposed between them and their capital, to lose which would be the surrender of all the records and insignia of their nationality. With foreigners such a defeat would be conclusive of our inability to make headway against the rebellion. Although its loss would only add to the magnitude and cost of the war, it would inflict the deepest disgrace upon our character and our arms. The possession of Maryland is that of Chesapeake Bay, with all its magnificent affluents, which, as lines of defence, or communication, or bases of offensive operation, are unequaled in importance and value in the United States. The North have every motive that can be addressed to a people to retain it, and the rebels equally cogent ones to carry it with the South. So long as a single Slave State maintained its loyalty, secession was only partially accomplished, because the dividing line had no relation to the only thing which marks the difference between the two sections of the country. The North were first in the race, and occupied the soil. The South have been unceasing in their efforts to possess it, which promises speedily to culminate in a great battle. The rebels must have Maryland or disband. Should such a purpose be given up, it would demoralize and dissipate their whole army. The people of the seceding States have always been assured that the capture of Washington was an easy matter; that from Washington they would march triumphantly to Baltimore; from Baltimore to Philadelphia, and onward till the power of the North was completely broken. Washington was to be razed as example of their power, and to satiate their revenge in its destruction. The war was to be wholly waged on Northern soil. Unless these assurances, the certain realization of which has become a religious conviction at the South, be performed, a moral defeat is sustained so complete as to forbid all hopes of success in the field.

abstract: DESCENT UPON RUNNERS. -- For a long time past, the New-York and Erie Railroad Company have been annoyed by runners and hack-drivers, who cross over to the New-Jersey side to solicit passengers, and have determined to put a stop to it. Yesterday, complaint was made before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, and warrants were issued for the arrest of quite a number of them. Chief of Police MARINUS and a squad of officers proceeded to the railroad depot, when some one on the lookout went to New-York and gave notice to the runners, by which they mostly saved themselves from Jersey law. OWEN BOYLE, JAS. SMITH and JOHN BRADY were taken into custody, and in default of $20 fine each, were committed to the county jail. It was afterwards ascertained that two other runners escaped by jumping overboard and clinging to the forward rudder of the ferry boat.

abstract: Messrs. ALTHAUSE, proprietors of the extensive iron works on the corner of Houston and Greene streets, have just completed 100 gun-carriages, with caissons, ammunition, wagons, and all the et ceteras pertaining thereto, under contract with the State authorities. Sixteen of these massive and substantially-built carriages were delivered yesterday at the Arsenal, and the remainder will be delivered on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of this week. Messrs. A. have completed the entire number within thirty days, and they intend to turn out with the same promptness 113 others for which they have also a contract. Those finished' yesterday are intended for 10-pound brass rifled guns, and the others for those of a different calibre.

abstract: The doctrine of State rights has been singularly illustrated by a little financial operation of Gov. BROWN, of Georgia. The Governor, it seems, anticipating the probable occurrence of war, some time before the commencement of hostilities purchased, on account of the State, two hundred tons of saltpetre and one hundred tons of sulphur, which he laid quietly away until the necessity for powder carried these articles to an advance in price of something over fifty per cent. of the purchase. He then sold the lot to the Confederate States at that rate, and felicitates himself in a recent report upon his speculation in favor of Georgia. The Confederates, it is true, do not comprehend the patriotism of the operation, but Gov. BROWN is a State right's man, and as such is as ready to plunder the Confederacy as the Union. In matters where his State is concerned, all is fish that comes to his net. Patriotism, he intimates, is a capital thing to talk about, but financially considered, it is a delusion when the interests of his own State are concerned.

abstract: The news we get from Mexico is of that indeterminate character, which always places the affairs of that anomalous country beyond the reach of ordinary judgment. That the Liberal Government has acquired additional strength from the defeat and dispersion of the reactionary force, which has infested for months the very suburbs of the capital, is in itself a circumstance that should give encouragement. But then the victory was extremely imperfect. All of the insurgent generals, fourteen in number, and including MARQUEZ, ZULOAGA, and other capable leaders, effected their escape; and, it is needless to say, while the Church has means, and priests can exert the weapons of superstition, such leaders will not long want followers. And while a prolongation of civil war is thus secured, nothing can be more insecure than life upon any of the roads in the Republic. No diligence escapes attack; and no day passes without reports of frightful assassinations and robberies, foreigners suffering chiefly from these murderous assaults. Even in the streets of the capital, they are remorselessly shot down or stabbed. This inability to protect the persons of its citizens extends to its own protection and the enforcement of its authority. Thus, notwithstanding distinct orders to the contrary, Senor ROBLES, the reactionary general, remains undisturbed at Guanajuato, and COMONFORT, whose coup d'etat introduced this immediate chapter of Mexican troubles, enjoys the hospitality of VIDAURRI at Monterey. Without money, or strength, or authority, it requires more than a casual victory to save the perishing government. It will require the intervention of a foreign State powerful enough to occupy the country, and enforce an authority, which may perhaps be left formally in the present hands, but which must be mediately derived from some wiser source. To this duty Mr. CORWIN's negotiations may have already committed us; but we may be assured, if we do not accept the mission, it will be fulfilled by England, or France, or both.
lead_paragraph: The news we get from Mexico is of that indeterminate character, which always places the affairs of that anomalous country beyond the reach of ordinary judgment. abstract: Arms, ammunition, food and clothing, tents for the soldiers, together with the means of conveying baggage and munitions, are things which cannot be dispensed with in war, and without which, neither numbers, skill, nor bravery, can be rendered available.
lead_paragraph: Arms, ammunition, food and clothing, tents for the soldiers, together with the means of conveying baggage and munitions, are things which cannot be dispensed with in war, and without which, neither numbers, skill, nor bravery, can be rendered available. Behind all these, and controlling all, is the necessity for money -- not the doubtful issues of overpressed and non-redeeming banks, nor the still more doubtful issues of a Government whose credit is based upon moonshine, and whose ability, present or remote, to pay, has no visible foundation in any of the ordinary resources of nations, but hard cash or its equivalent in evidences that can at all times he converted into coin. Without this absolute prerequisite, an Army cannot be sustained for any considerable length of time. A single campaign may be fought, lasting so long as the first burst of enthusiasm may continue, or the first supplies remain unexhausted. But the chill blasts of Autumn, the bleak storms of Winter, will cool the ardor of men accustomed to the common necessaries and comforts, if not the luxuries of life, when these shall be wanting. Lack of food, of clothing, of shelter from the storm, unshod feet blistered by marching, or bitten by frost, are stern and practical facts which no enthusiasm can overlook, or false patriotism dispel. They are present and palpable evils hard to be borne, and whose cure can be effected only by the possession and use of money. Military contributions levied at the point of the bayonet, the plunder of a country in which an army may be operating, of its food, its surplus clothing, its means of subsistence and transportation, can at best afford a temporary resource, against which is to be set off the indignation of an incensed and outraged people. Supplies gathered in this way are soon exhausted, and a return to the stern necessity for money must be made. In all modern wars the nation possessing the largest and surest resources in this respect has, with scarcely an exception, been the victor in the strife of arms. Triumph has almost invariably followed the standard supported by the largest and most available supply of cash. Especially has this been so when other circumstances have been anything like equal between the belligerents.

abstract: There is one laughable fantasy that is continually appearing in that portion of the French Press that enjoys Secessionist subsidies. France, they argue, should surely sympathize with the South, seeing that the...
lead_paragraph: There is one laughable fantasy that is continually appearing in that portion of the French Press that enjoys Secessionist subsidies. France, they argue, should surely sympathize with the South, seeing that the Latin race is the basis of the Southern population! It is rather adroit of the rebel emissaries to exploit this notion, as it takes Frenchmen in a very weak spot. There is no delusion to which they are more susceptible than historical affiliations of race. It is only a few years ago since the British American Provinces were violently alarmed by a publication entitled Canada Reconquered by France, in which ethnologic considerations were urged in favor of oversetting the English rule and reinstating France in possession. And it is but the other day that a monument to WILLIAM the Conqueror was raised in the port whence he sailed for England, menacingly announcing to perfidious Albion that, should a French fleet ere long land on her shores a mass of Gallic legions, it would be in pursuit of those race-affinities and race-rights established eight hundred years ago by the boat-loads that went over under the Norman bastard.

abstract: The Captain-General of Cuba has authorized the admission of vessels bearing the flag of the Confederated States into all the ports of the island. They are to be received on the footing of the most favored nations;...
lead_paragraph: The Captain-General of Cuba has authorized the admission of vessels bearing the flag of the Confederated States into all the ports of the island. They are to be received on the footing of the most favored nations; and while a reservation is made that such hospitality is not to be regarded in the light of full recognition, it practically, as the reader will readily see, amounts to such an act. There are no means of judging whether this action of the Captain-General originates at Madrid or at Havana. In the latter case, it may be disavowed by the Spanish Government. In the former, it can only be regarded as an expression of unfriendly feeling toward this Government; and as a bribe offered to Southern fillibusterism that it let Cuba alone. The fact is not one which we can accept as merely an insult and not as an injury. In assuring the rebels that they have only to evade the blockade to find ample supplies of everything they most need awaiting them in friendly ports so convenient as those of Cuba, and that their bastard flag shall protect their privateers from pursuit and capture so long as they remain in Spanish waters, is to offer a huge premium for breaking the blockade, and a bounty upon privateering. All those who now find difficulty in forwarding their wares from the North to the greedy markets of the South, will hereafter ship them to the Antilles, and there dispose of them to customers, who, by using vessels of light draft, which can penetrate any of the keys, bayous, and rivers of the Southern coast, will find little difficulty in reaching supplies. Against this sort of adventure, it will be imposible to make the blockade proof. No vigilance can confine or exclude such inconspicuous craft; and we shall witness a cordon established at so great an expense rendered valueless because of these inevitable evasions. We need not indeed be surprised, if the ports of Cuba, under the new rule, be made depots for cotton which can be gathered up along the coasts by these small bottoms, which will only put to sea when the watching cruiser has left the mouth of the particular estuary. Possibly, this is the sort of smuggling to which the English are looking so confidently, as destined to give them at least one-third of the crop.

abstract: Bridgeport (Conn.) was alive with Union enthusiasm yesterday. Not only did the entire city turn out en masse in honor of the day, but overwhelming delegations from Fairfield, Stamford, Greenfield, Easton, Stratford, and even many from this City,...
lead_paragraph: Bridgeport (Conn.) was alive with Union enthusiasm yesterday. Not only did the entire city turn out en masse in honor of the day, but overwhelming delegations from Fairfield, Stamford, Greenfield, Easton, Stratford, and even many from this City, flocked to swell the demonstration, and listen to the patriotic speeches of the patriots DICKINSON and MEAGHER. One meeting would not suffice to quench the popular fire of enthusiasm. So two gatherings were made, one in the morning, and the other in the evening. The Committee of Arrangements -- prominent among whom was the omnipresent showman, BARNUM, had planned to make the occasion known far and wide, and their efforts were crowned with success The city was fairly overrun with the almost numberless vehicles that brought participants to the meeting, while the railway station was crowded from morning far into the night. Fairest of all the fair sights of the day, was the exhibition of Connecticut's fair daughters. Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these, with faces beaming with patriotic smiles, they adorned the vehicles in the procession, or flocked to the vestibules of houses, or helped to pack the mammoth, tent in which the orators of the day and evening held forth. Their presence lent an animation and beauty to the scene rarely to be found on similar occasions, and presenting a striking rebuke to the reputation of their unfair sisters of Washington.

abstract: A novel exhibition is now open to the Public at the establishment of TIFFANY  Co., the Broadway jewelers. Closely adjoining the well-known centre showcase, which encloses the richest and rarest gems and...
lead_paragraph: -- A novel exhibition is now open to the Public at the establishment of TIFFANY Co., the Broadway jewelers. Closely adjoining the well-known centre showcase, which encloses the richest and rarest gems and articles de luxe in the way of ornament, on the continent, is now placed another and larger case, containing the opima spolia of a ten years' campaign in the field of magic. HERMANN, the Prestidigitateur, fills this case, and it might, in legal parlance, be denominated the great case of "HERMANN vs. a large party of crowned heads, nobles, artists and less nototorious dilettanti." By the little cards attached to each piece, the Public can see that, if HERMANN be indeed Devil, as the honest Hamburghers once thought him, nevertheless Christian and Jew, Emperors, Kings, Dukes, Duchesses, Marquises, Counts, Marshals, Generals, Dons, Vons, Monsieurs, Scientific Academies, Benevolent Associations, and even -- Editors, have paid him substantial tributes of admiration. Does His Majesty require a time piece? The King who sits on the throne of "Ferdinand the Catholic" presents him a superb English lever, with chain and diamond-mounted seal thrown in; the head of the Greek Church puts in his pocket an exquisite little watch and leontine so deftly cased in pearls and amethysts as to make plain gold appear base stuff in the eyes of a CESAR; a Spanish Duke does him homage in the shape of a beautifully enameled Genevese horologe, with chatelaine, dainty enough for a Queen; a Polish Prince, doubtless appreciating the Satanic taste for the mediaeval, makes him the possessor of two Nuremburg eggs; and lastly, some devil of a fellow on our own shores tickles his fancy by the contribution of an honest chronometer in a magic case. The wand with which his majesty evokes "spirits from the vasty deep," is a baton of pure gold, about two feet in length, artistically engraved with arabesques, cunningly inclosing a portrait and other characteristic designs, and tipped at one end by a fine diamond, while the other displays a large sapphire. In strict justice to a very worthy class in society, we feel obliged to state that this elegant presentation was made in January last, by the Press of Havana, the Gaceta, the Prensa de Habana, the Diario de la Marina, and one other journal contributing. Of course His Majesty must have a hunting-knife; and recognizing this necessity, in 1859, His other Majesty, Don PEDRO, King of Portugal, sent him from the Royal Armory a couteau de chasse, the choice antique that his ancestors might not so readily have parted with -- a fine Toledo blade, the hilt a rare piece of jasper, some three inches in length, profusely garnished with diamonds of the finest water, and the sheath beautifully mounted in gold and brilliants, with the ruby-eyed dragons of the national quarterings forming the guard. For full dress, the contributions are particularly rich, and by no means few. In 1859 certain admirers in Oporto, the little city as famous for its production of exquisite work in silver filigree as for its wine, made him a present of a gold crown of rare beauty. The same year the Duchess of Palmela, at Lisbon, craves his acceptance of a gold card-case, in one side of which, by the springing up of an enameled medalion, a tiny watch is discovered. The year before the Emperor of Brazil furnished for his neck adornment a unique scarf pin, headed with two pearls of magnificent proportions and oriency. For a change he has three other scarf-pins, of brilliants, presented by European admirers. A very pretty enameled eyeglass, containing a watch, is the tribute of another Duchess. A pair of choice rubies set in small diamonds for shirt studs, were the gift of the Archduke of Oldenburg, in 1851, to which, not thinking his majesty in this respect suitably furnished, the Archduchess of Hohenzollern added a pair of splendid sapphires, similarly mounted, in 1860. His choicest sleeve-buttons were presented by the Archduke JOSEPH, of Austria, being amethysts, each containing a large diamond in the centre, the gold nowhere apparent. A complete set of diamond buttons, twelve in number, for the wrist, bosom and vest, are the gift of the Austrian Emperor. Another parure of thirteen diamonds shows the appreciation of a Spanish Calderon, and there is still another of pearls and rubies from a second grandee of Madrid. For his lady, the Queen ISABELLA, who had already given him a very beautiful commander's cross of Her Order, furnished a superb bracelet of brilliants -- the King of Spain a pair of diamond hair-pins, -- the Emperor JOSEPH, of Austria, in 1851, a unique brooch, in the shape of a butterfly; the Archduke CHARLES a large diamond solitaire ring, and Marshal RADETSKY a gold and coral bracelet at Verona, the same year; in 1852, at St. Petersburgh, the Emperor NICHOLAS a very curious brooch, formed of a large pearl, with emeralds and diamonds, wrought into the semblance of a dragon; in 1855, at Copenhagen, King FREDERICK, of Denmark, a fine pair of solitaire diamond ear-rings; and in 1851, at Munich, LOLA MONTEZ's old dotard, LUDWIG, another pair of ear-rings of fine pearls, with brilliants.

abstract: The Prince DE JOINVILLE, though absent from the Brevoort House the greater part of yesterday, received numerous calls from prominent and influential citizens, French and American, and from officers of the Brazilian corvette now at anchor in the North River. In the afternoon, he was the recipient of a magnificent basket of flowers, most tastefully arranged, the initials of his name being inserted around the edge of the basket in yellow berries. It was the gift of some lady whose name the messenger very properly declined to give any one but the Prince.
lead_paragraph: The Prince DE JOINVILLE, though absent from the Brevoort House the greater part of yesterday, received numerous calls from prominent and influential citizens, French and American, and from officers of the Brazilian corvette now at anchor in the North River. abstract: To-day the unpleasant but imperative duty devolves upon us of bidding our readers and subscribers a temporary, but, we trust, a short farewell. After...
lead_paragraph: To-day the unpleasant but imperative duty devolves upon us of bidding our readers and subscribers a temporary, but, we trust, a short farewell. After this morning's issue, the publication of The Daily and The Weekly News will be suspended for a time. We make this announcement with a feeling deeper than regret, for it is a consequence of events that should have been impossible of occurrence in the Republic where we claim the rights and immunities of citizenship. We have stood manfully at our post while the slightest hope remained of weathering the storm; but as our area of action has been narrowed until even the possibility of our rendering service to our countrymen has vanished, we lay down our pen in the bitterness of despair, and await, for its resumption, the propitious hour when persecution shall no longer strike the implement of labor out of the hand of industry.

abstract: We give place elsewhere to the mortuary remarks with which Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD consigns the Daily News to the limbo of disloyal journalism. It is due to this gentleman to confess that he has shown infinite pluck and doggedness in the prosecution of his war upon the Government; to the very last, with the fear of Fort Lafayette before his eyes, urging his treason with matchless sophistry, and an assumption of patriotism, the audacity of which is simply astounding. But Mr. WOOD's aspirations to martyrdom have been foiled. He has not been mobbed his dying newspaper has left no legacy to the county in the form of a claim for damages; the proprietor walks the streets with as much impunity as if he were a true man. It will be in vain for him to attempt to convince any reasonable number of men outside of the State-prison and the lunatic asylum, that while the individual has a right to assail the Government, and even to make his assault, if possible, absolutely mortal, Government has no right to repel the attack and punish its assailant. It will also be difficult to make many converts to the belief, that society is so much less important than the individual, that it must perish and give way to anarchy, rather than impose a wholesome restraint upon personal license and liberty. And yet, the demonstration of these two propositions is necessary before Mr. WOOD can be justified.

abstract: When the Duke of WELLINGTON entered Portugal he found that although his men were brave, they were raw and inexperienced. Pittedagainst them were the very flower of the French Army, under a leader whose name alone almost assured victory wherever he raised his banner. The English General cautiously felt his lines at every point, and then determined on a masterly movement. He commenced a series of fortifications, the strength of which has rendered their creator's name as famous as his after success at Waterloo. As they progressed, he turned his encampment into a vast play-ground. The raw soldiers, under the genial influence of cricket and other games, gained vigor and confidence in their own resources. The officers hunted as freely and with as much abandon as in their own homes; ample supplies were sent from England, and, apparently, the men had ceased to remember that they were sent to fight -- and seemed intent only on amusement. The English at home, with their national fondness for grumbling, which we so largely inherit from them, complained incessantly and bitterly; their leading Presses denounced the inactivity of the Peninsular Army, and demanded an immediate advance. The leader of the English host, as prudent as he was brave, quietly awaited his time, and the men continued to disport themselves behind the lines of Torres Vedras. In the meanwhile the vast Army of MASSENA, shut out from prompt channels of supplies, chafing under inactivity, and kept at bay, it knew not why, became demoralized and lost its unity. For the first time in his military career Marshal MASSENA found that the men he had so often led to victory hesitated. When armies do this, like women they are lost. The English fell on them like an Alpine torrent, and drove them through Spain, through the Pyrenees, even unto Bayonne.

abstract: The United States steam gun-boat Sumter arrived in this port yesterday morning, from St. Paul de Loando, Africa. She is the avant-courier of the African squadron, the whole of which has been summoned home. Seven other vessels composing the squadron had sailed, or were about to sail, so that the Navy Department will soon have an effective force of eight vessels to add to the blockading force, or to cooperate in offensive operations along the Southern coast. The oath of allegiance will no doubt be immediately administered to the officers and crews of these ships, and their services be put in prompt use.

abstract: We give place in this issue to the very able and patriotic speech of Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, delivered to the Union meeting at Bridgeport on Saturday. The topics are not entirely new; but Mr. DICKINSON handles them with a freshness and vigor which are new, not only with him, but with the public; and does much to strengthen and reanimate the popular patriotism, which is never worse for such eloquent stimulus.

abstract: Bridgeport (Conn.) was alive with Union enthusiasm on Saturday. Not only did the entire city turn out en masse in honor of the day, but overwhelming delegations from Fairfield, Stamford, Greenfield, Easton, Stratford, and even many from this City, flocked to swell the demonstration, and listen to the patriotic speeches of the patriots DICKINSON and MEAGHER.
lead_paragraph: Bridgeport (Conn.) was alive with Union enthusiasm on Saturday. Not only did the entire city turn out en masse in honor of the day, but overwhelming delegations from Fairfield, Stamford, Greenfield, Easton, Stratford, and even many from this City, flocked to swell the demonstration, and listen to the patriotic speeches of the patriots DICKINSON and MEAGHER. One meeting would not suffice to quench the popular fire of enthusiasm. So two gatherings were made, one in the morning, and the other in the evening. The Committee of Arrangements -- prominent among whom was the omnipresent showman, BARNUM, had planned t make the occasion known far and wide, and their efforts were crowned with success. The city was fairly overrun with the almost numberless vehicles that brought participants to the meeting, while the railway station was crowded from morning far into the night. Fairest of all the fair sights of the day, was the exhibition of Connecticut's fair daughters. Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these, with faces beaming with patriotic smiles, they adorned the vehicles in the procession, or flocked to the vestibules of houses, or helped to pack the mammoth tent in which the orators of the day and evening held forth. Their presence lent an animation and beauty to the scene rarely to be found on similar occasions, and presenting a striking rebuke to the reputation of their unfair sisters of Washington.

abstract: DISGRACEFUL. For several days past Thirtyfourth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, has been the scene of riot that is perfectly disgraceful to the Police authorities of the Twentieth Precinct' and a most serious annoyance to the residents of the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: DISGRACEFUL. For several days past Thirtyfourth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, has been the scene of riot that is perfectly disgraceful to the Police authorities of the Twentieth Precinct' and a most serious annoyance to the residents of the neighborhood. Gangs of boys, of ages ranging from 10 to 16 years, congregate nearly every afternoon, and indulge in pitched battles, seemingly without any interference by the Police. On Sunday, just as the numerous churches in the vicinity were dismissing their worshipers, the usual exhibition took place. Stones, bricks, and any other missile obtainable by the young ruffians, flew as fast and furious as bullets at Bull Run, and not until one of the parties had driven the other from the field did a solitary policeman make his appearance. Seeing that the Station of the Precinct is within sight and hearing of the battle-ground, it is thought it would be well that the nuisance be abated.

abstract: The opinions of a writer so widely known and so generally appreciated as Mr. HUGHES, the author of Tom Brown's School Days and Tom Brown at Oxford on the affairs of the Union, cannot be without interest on this side of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: The opinions of a writer so widely known and so generally appreciated as Mr. HUGHES, the author of Tom Brown's School Days and Tom Brown at Oxford on the affairs of the Union, cannot be without interest on this side of the Atlantic. In the September issue of Macmillan's Magazine, they appear in the form of a letter to the editor, dated from a quiet village on the eastern coast of England, on the 12th August, when the details of the battle at Bull Run had not yet reached that country. Mr. HUGHES had seen only the first accounts, and the comments of the English Press, the tone of which, he observes had, with the single exception of the Spectator, been ungenerous and unfair, and had not represented the better mind of England. Ever ready in the cause of right, he took up his pen to defend the North, and to prevent his countrymen from being blinded by the temporary success of the Secessionists. Of the battle itself he says little, but quotes the dispatch of JEFFERSON DAVIS, written on the night of the event, inferring from it that there was "a determined struggle of many hours before the Northern troops were beaten;" and refers to the reminder of the Spectator that our troops, "in their maddest excitement, did nothing which was not done by the Frenchmen, who, within five days, drove the first infantry in Europe back from the hill of Vaimy." [Ho shows what were, in his opinion, the causes of the defeat, and does full justice to the Unionists:

abstract: Another meeting of the Executive Committee appointed to receive the remains of TERENCE BELLEW MCMANUS, and to superintend their transportation to the soil where the great-hearted exile was born, and for whose freedom he fought, was held last evening at the Astor House. Committees were appointed to wait on the police authorities, in order to secure the procession against the inroads of the populace, and to make arrangements with Archbishop HUGHES for the temporary disposal of his remains, prior to their removal on board some Irish-bound ship. A solemn mass of requiem will be celebrated this morning, at 10 o'clock, in the Cathedral in Mott-street, to which the body will be conveyed from the Stevens House, under a suitable escort. Much indignation was expressed at the action of the agent to whom was consigned the vessel on board of which the dust of poor MCMANUS was carried to this City. One distinguished gentleman, a compatriot of the deceased, emphatically declared that if the indignity offered to MCMANUS' remains were the deliberate act of this Government, his sword should never again be drawn in its behalf. It was determined that the procession from the Stevens House to the Cathedral should be on foot, and that persons unwilling or unable to walk should be at liberty to use carriages from the Cathedral to Calvary Cemetery. A special Committee was also appointed to ask an explanation from the agent of the steamship. When the meeting had adjourned the Committee, in procession, paid a formal visit to the Stevens House, in order to take a last look of their old friend and fellow-countryman.

abstract: THE KNIFE. -- A man named JAMES F. CONWAY, while intoxicated yesterday, went on board of one of the South Ferry boats, in the slip at the foot of Atlantic-street, and, without any provocation whatever, made an attack with a knife upon the engineer, Mr. THOMAS BEARD, whom he stabbed three times before the knife was taken from him. The wounds inflicted are not considered dangerous. CONWAY was arrested and committed to answer.

abstract: The War Department has, with wise forethought, issued a series of regulations for military burials, and the registration of deceased soldiers and their graves, showing date and place of burial, transfers of corpse, and other records, so as to enable friends to find the grave of their dead loved ones. Each grave is to have its number, in the order of interment, distinctly indicated upon a head-sign of cedar, or some other enduring wood, the name of deceased, date of death, and his company or regimental corps initials being engraved thereon. These various records are to be preserved at the Surgeon-General's Office in Washington, and are to be forever open to the inspection of friends of the deceased. There is a deep pathos in the soldier's grave far away from home -- tombs in the battle field, overgrown with grasses and flowers! And those left behind will find consolation in the fact that the tenderest humanities are to be observed towards the graves of their loved ones.

abstract: IN THE DELAWARE. -- Yesterday morning, between 6 and 7 o'clock, the steam ferry-boat Curlew left South-street wharf for Gloucester, having on board 143 head of cattle, a wagon and two horses, and one passenger. When the boat was a short distance below the Navy-yard the cattle became frightened from some cause, and crowded to the bow of the boat. The great weight depressed the bow, until the water rushed into the dead lights, just under the guards of the boat, with such volume, that the boat sunk in a few moments to within a few feet of the upper deck. The cattle then swam about in the river, and the boat floated down with the tide until below Kaighn's Point. The Kaighn's Point ferry-boat went to the assistance of the Curlew and took the passenger and Captain off, and boats from the Harriet Lane and other vessels rowed to the scene, and by surrounding the cattle, drove them to the Jersey shore, by which means all but five were saved. The cattle belonged to Messrs. GEORGE BECKETT and WM. TOURLIN. The horses were also safely landed. The ferry-boat, lightened of her load, continued to float down until a tug-boat fastened a line to her, and towed her to the Jersey shore, a short distance below Kaighn's Point. Capt. STEWART, the owner of the boat, intends getting her upon the shore at the next high tide, and then procure the services of a steam fire engine to pump her out. The surface of the river for some distance was covered with the struggling cattle, and for some time they continued to swim about the boat, and made attempts to clamber upon the upper deck, and, but for the assistance rendered by the small boats, the cattle would have been scattered along the shores on each side of the river; as it was, one steer crossed the Delaware, and landed below the Navy-yard. The accident will not delay the business of the line, as one of the old boats which remained at Gloucester was started in the place of the sunken one. The accident, it is thought, will not do the Curlew much damage.

The cattle belonged to Messrs. GEORGE BECKETT and WM. TOURLIN. The horses were also safely landed. abstract: The Academy of Music will open for the season to-night, but not with opera. For the moment the musical prospect is somewhat clouded. There is a vague rumor, to be sure, that there will be a Winter season of opera, but in the absence of singers, both male and female, we can hardly hope that it is of any significance.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music will open for the season to-night, but not with opera. For the moment the musical prospect is somewhat clouded. There is a vague rumor, to be sure, that there will be a Winter season of opera, but in the absence of singers, both male and female, we can hardly hope that it is of any significance. In the meantime, the powers to be have secured the services of Mr. HERMANN, and to-night the renowned prestidigitateur makes his debut before a New-York audience. Mr. HERMANN will be found unlike any other conjurer in a great many respects. His talent is superior to anything we have ever witnessed here, and his manner is very different to the vulgar pretentiouness and stupid volubility of most wizards. Not the least remarkable thing about his entertainment is that all the tricks are performed without apparatus, and as far as practicable, in the midst of the audience. The regular orchestra of the Academy has been engaged to supply the audience with a due proportion of music, and Mr. THEODORE THOMAS will once more assume the baton as conductor.

abstract: -Hon. JOSEPHHOLT, late of the Post-office and War Department, delivered one of those eloquent Union speeches for which he is so distinguished, at Irving Hall, in this City, on the evening of the 3d inst. ROBT. J. WALKER once remarked in our presence, that Mr. HOLT was "the most eloquent man in the world." "Governor," said we, "that is saying a great deal." "I know it is," replied Mr. WALKER, "but it is nevertheless true." We never heard a public speaker, not excepting HENRY WARD BEECHER, who produced a more thrilling effect upon an audience than Mr. HOLT. The great secret of this is, that both these orators speak from the heart. The influence which Judge HOLT is everywhere exerting upon the Union cause is very powerful. By the way, all our living ex-Postmasters-General, as far back as we can remember, are savagely down on rebellion, namely: Hon. C.A. Wickliffe, Hon. Cave Johnson, Judges Colamer and Hall, Mr. Holt, and Hon. Horatio King. We need hardly add the name of the present worthy head of the Department, as one of the most devoted and vigilant champions of the Union cause, with which the country is now honored, -- Holbrook's United States Mail.

abstract: It promiseswell for peace that the President, in appointing the Commissioners to represent the interests of American exhibitors at the World's Fair, to be held in London, in September, 1862, has named a good portion of his own Cabinet, together with the heads of other important bureaus in Washington. Among them are Mr. SEWARD, Secretary of State; Mr. SMITH, of the Interior; Mr. KENNEDY, Superintendent of the Census Bureau; Prof. HENRY, of the Smithsonian Institute; Mr. ROBERT WALLACH, Mayor of Washington; Mr. EVERETT, and others. We like this; it has the same kind of anticipative confidence as the famous sale in Rome of a plot of ground outside the city walls, which plot was, at the very time of sale, the scene of encampment of the hostile Volsci. It says, a year hence the great rebellion will have been crushed out, and the nation, forced for a while to stop in the bloody House of Mars, will have resumed its normal orbit of creative order. The Secretary of State, relieved from the investigation of nice questions of international law, will unbend to the pacific questions of international industry; representations as to blockades and belligerents will give place to the representation of the fruits of Americanskill and creative industry that have so long led the world. We dare say that John Bull will be as much amazed at the exhibition of American practical genius which we shall send to his Fair next year, as he will be at the completeness with which we shall annihilate the armed foes of the Republic, whom John will then be very much ashamed of himself for having encouraged with one wink of his foolish cotton-blind eye.

abstract: Take notice that wherever you find a snob or flunky -- male or female -- you find a Secessionist. There seems to be a sort of elective affinity that draws the species towards the thing. One encounters at times specimens of the kind in society -- brainless creatures, who, unable to feel what there is noble and dignified in sharing the identity of a great nation, drivel out their feeble and idiotic sneers, and think it a fine aristocratic thing to be a Secessionist. These miserable toadies are infinitely more offensive than out-and-out traitors. It sometimes becomes a duty to squelch an insect of this kind: do it, though the operation disgusts you.

abstract: Our columns this morning contain a legal opinion of more than usual interest. It is the decision rendered by Judge SHIPMAN, in the United States District Court of this District, in the action brought by the Captain and crew of the brig Cuba, to recover salvage. The Cuba, as will be recollected, was one of the first prizes taken by the privateer Sumter.
lead_paragraph: Our columns this morning contain a legal opinion of more than usual interest. It is the decision rendered by Judge SHIPMAN, in the United States District Court of this District, in the action brought by the Captain and crew of the brig Cuba, to recover salvage. The Cuba, as will be recollected, was one of the first prizes taken by the privateer Sumter. A prize crew was put on board, but Capt. STROUT, of the Cuba, with his own crew, rose upon them some days after, and having overpowered them, started for New-York.

abstract: The seventh annual Regatta of the Empire City Club took place from opposite Yorkville Park yesterday afternoon, the prizes amounting to some $400. The river towards Harlem was thickly studded with small yachts and boats of all sizes, while the adjoining shores were lined with spectators. Probably some two thousand able-bodied persons were in attendance.

abstract: With reference to the County Tax, over which the Board has no control except to raise the amount directed, the Committee call attention to the fact that over $1,700,000 is for the Police, and in view of the increase of 400 men this year, and the present decrease in crime, it is suggested that hereafter when deaths, resignations or dismissals occur, the vacancies be not filled, and in this way a large sum can be saved, and by a judicious curtailment of expenditures under the actual control of the Board, a further reduction can be made.

abstract: This regiment, Col. EUGENE LE GAL, is progressing rapidly toward completion. At Factoryville, Staten Island, a new camp has been erected for the accommodation of the men; it covers sixty acres of ground, and is one of the most delightful places imaginable. A cook-house, sutler's quarters, guard-house and prison have been erected of wood, at an expense of $800. Inclosing the camp is a fence seven feet high, which was built by the men.
lead_paragraph: This regiment, Col. EUGENE LE GAL, is progressing rapidly toward completion. At Factoryville, Staten Island, a new camp has been erected for the accommodation of the men; it covers sixty acres of ground, and is one of the most delightful places imaginable. A cook-house, sutler's quarters, guard-house and prison have been erected of wood, at an expense of $800. Inclosing the camp is a fence seven feet high, which was built by the men. A well, sixty feet deep, has also been dug, which supplies the men with excellent water. Within the last ten days three serious fires have occurred at Staten Island. One at Rocky Hollow, another on the Highlands, and the third at CARROLL's livery stable, where $10,000 worth of property was destroyed. At each fire the McClellan Rifles, under the command of Capts. DE LA PATOURELE, GUTMANN, SMART and O'BRIEN, together with Lieuts. LOCKE and MONDET were on the scene of action before any other military body reached the ground. Officers and men manned the breaks, and it was owing to the efficient service of the McClellan Rifles at CARROLL's fire that adjacent properly was saved.

lead_paragraph: Considering that Mr. HERMANN by choice has commenced his career in this country in the evenings, it is, we think, rather hard on the people who have denied that his entertainment should be christened with so overwhelming a title as Prestidigitation. Earlier in the day at a matinee for instance a little refulgency of speech might not be out of place, for there the tongue is nimble and the memory quick to catch a new word. But when a man has worked for his daily bread with the sweat of his brow, and partaken of an honest, perhaps generous evening's repast, it is, we think, requiring too much of him, that he should be expected to walk up stairs and ask the ladies with polite coherency, to go with him to see the Prestidigilateur. The word wizard is a much more charitable cognomen. It has a thick and luscious sound. There is is a kind of beeswing in it. But prestidigitateur is a barricade, and we are not surprised to hear that horses -- who live on a purely temperate diet, you know -- have shied at it. Great conjurers always use big words. In the olden times their garments were bescrawled with hieroglyphics; now they twist and turn the type into something oracular, or at all events horrifying. How acute must be the emotions of Adolphus, who palpipates at monosyllables, and in point of fact, expects to be finished off one these days with the smallest of the lot; how acute must be his emotions where he is impelled by a harsh destiny to ask the severely critical and slightly captious Agelina if she will prestidigitate.

abstract: SUSPECTED SECESSIONISTS ARRESTED AND DISCHARGED. There was much excttement in the Park, yesterday afternoon, in consequence of the arrest of an alleged Secessionist. The man had been talking disrespectfully of the Administration, while in a drinking saloon on Broadway, opposite the Park, and his sentiments not meeting with approbation, it was determined to take him before the Mayor.
lead_paragraph: SUSPECTED SECESSIONISTS ARRESTED AND DISCHARGED. There was much excttement in the Park, yesterday afternoon, in consequence of the arrest of an alleged Secessionist. The man had been talking disrespectfully of the Administration, while in a drinking saloon on Broadway, opposite the Park, and his sentiments not meeting with approbation, it was determined to take him before the Mayor. On the way thither, a crowd of several hundred persons followed him, crying, "Hang him!" "Shoot him!" and making use of other expressions calculated to make him afraid. Marshal BURNHAM directed that the prisoner should be taken to Police Head-quarters, and there he was examined by Inspector CARPENTER. He said that he was a Union man, who could not coincide with Mr. LINCOLN in his war policy, but probably had given too loose a rein to his sentiments, therefore the outcry had been made against him. Mr. CARPENTER told him that in future it behooved him to be more careful, and with this word of caution he was allowed to go. When the City of Manchester arrived at her dock, yesterday, from Liverpool, Detective EUSTACE, and Sergeant GERST, of the Steamboat Squad, went on board and arrested. seven alleged Secessionists, who had come as passengers. They were natives of North Carolina and Maryland, and the charge against them was that on the voyage they had given expression to treasonable language, drank the health of JEFFERSON DAVIS as President of the Confederate States, and been guilty of other acts of equal disloyalty. The prisoners and their baggage were taken to Head-quarters, where the latter was examined, but nothing of a suspicious character was found, and the Southerners went their way rejoicing.
