abstract: JOHN W. LOWE, colonel of the Twelfth Ohio Regiment, who fell in the recent battle between the forces under Gen. ROSECRANS and FLOYD, was formerly of this City. In the year 1825, when about 20 years of age, having learned the trade of a painter, he left New-York to seek his fortune in the far West. He settled in Batavia, entered the office of Judge FISH BACK, pursued the study of the law, and was admitted to practice. He shortly after married the daughter of Judge FISHBACK. He continued to practice law successfully until the breaking out of the War with Mexico, when, with many other noble sons of Ohio, he joined the volunteers, served under Gen. TAYLOR as Captain of the Advance Guard, and acquired a high reputation as an able and brave military officer on the close of the war, he removed to Zenia, where his fine reputation as a lawyer gained for him a very extensive practice. Immediately on the call of the government, in April last, he raised a company for service, and was called to the command of the Twelfth Ohio Regiment. Early in the field, his regiment has been actively engaged in service in Western Virginia, and has taken part in several engagements, in which Col. LOWE fully sustained his reputation as a brave and gallant officer. He was killed while in command of his regiment, during the battle of Carnax Ferry, on Sept. 10, instant. He leaves a family, consisting of his wife and four children, with but little else than the glorious legacy of having sacrificed his life for the union and integrity of his country. He was a man of undoubted probity, a lawyer of unimpeachable honor and ability, a soldier of unquestioned and well-tried bravery. His fellow-citizens will feel the loss of the brave and patriotic defender.

abstract: -- Six balletgirls were burned to death in Philadelphia, on Saturday night last, in consequence of an accident which occurred while they were preparing for their performance on the stage. It is but the other day that two thousand persons were swallowed up by an earthquake in the Island of Antigua. More than a hundred persons every year put violent end to their own life in the City of New-York, and in our State the annual aggregate of violent deaths reaches the enormous figure of fifteen hundred.

abstract: DISTINCTIONS WITHOUT DIFFERENCES. -- Mr. FRANCIS C. BROUCK, who was nominated by the Peace Democracy for State Treasurer, has written a letter declining the offered but doubtful honor. He does so because he finds sentiments in the resolutions adopted by the Convention which he does not approve. At the same time, he proposes to support the residue of the ticket, because he suspects the Union Convention to be a Republican trick to beguile Democratic voters, and because no adequate share of patronage has been distributed by the Republicans to the men who for eight years held office to their entire exclusion, and at last only surrendered their grasp upon power after a struggle that has plunged the country in war. The first of Mr. BROUCK's arguments may satisfy himself, but will hardly prove as satisfactory to others, who cannot see why the platform and the ticket with his name upon it is more palatable than the platform and the ticket without his name. But his allusion to an unfair disposition of patronage will find very ready oppugners among Republicans. They may say that having always been shut from office by a Democratic monopoly, they at last secure it only to find its ease, honors and emoluments almost destroyed by the Democratic occupants, who now stand ready to demand a share even of the fragments. As a matter of right -- the basis upon which Mr. BROUCK rests it -- the Republicans may reasonably deny any partition. The question of policy is another matter, which will no doubt be duly settled at the proper time. We can only add that Mr. BROUCK has said just enough to prove himself one of the most inconsistent and irrational supporters of a ticket, to which he is too conscientious to lend his name.

abstract: Gov. MAGOFFIN has been compelled to the performance of the unpleasant duty of notifying his friends of the Confederate States, and of Tennessee in particular, to leave Kentucky. He struggled desperately against the necessity for an act so intensely disgusting to his personal feelings.
lead_paragraph: Gov. MAGOFFIN has been compelled to the performance of the unpleasant duty of notifying his friends of the Confederate States, and of Tennessee in particular, to leave Kentucky. He struggled desperately against the necessity for an act so intensely disgusting to his personal feelings. In his message to the Legislature he implored that body to join the great rebellion by placing Kentucky in the catalogue of seceded States. At a later period he vetoed the resolutions passed by both Houses by overwhelming majorities, demanding that the invading forces from the South should vacate the soil of the State. The resolutions were again passed over his veto by equally imposing majorities. He then sought to neutralize the effect of these demonstrations by the passage of resolutions excluding in like manner the Government forces. In this he signally failed, and was compelled at last to do the bidding of the representatives of the loyal people of Kentucky, in demanding peremptorily that the rebel forces should be withdrawn from a position they occupied by his acquiescence, if not by his positive invitation.

abstract: Some weeks since, the TIMES announced that the Special Committee on the erection of a new Court-house were directed to proceed immediately with its construction, authorizing them to purchase materials, employ an architect, and to have the work be gun, or portions thereof, as they might elect, and as might conduce to the best interests of the City. Acting on this authority, and the Board of Supervisors having obtained possession of the land, the work of digging for the foundation was commenced yesterday. The ground selected commences 7 feet west of the present Court-house, running 300 feet towards Broadway, and extending back towards the City Hall 200 feet. The building is to be of white marble, for which as yet no contract has been made, but it will probably come from the Connecticut quarries. The mason-work and building generally has been awarded to C.H. TUCKER, Esq.; Mr. Supervisor LITTLE being the architect, and the President of the Board the General Superintendent. Mr. Tucker promises to have two stories completed by Jan. 1, 1862, but as yet no estimate of the total cost has been made. The building is to be 244 feet in front by 112 depth of main building, with two wings of 144 feet in depth, and will be surrounded on three sides by a wide court yard, the southernmost of which will reach nearly to the present City Hall, and will necessitate the taking down of the present bell-tower.

abstract: The policy of the rebels from the first, has been to render the Border States the seat of the war. They alone of those in rebellion are fruitful in the means for supporting an Army; they are relatively stronger in men, and have less to fear from servile insurrections.
lead_paragraph: The policy of the rebels from the first, has been to render the Border States the seat of the war. They alone of those in rebellion are fruitful in the means for supporting an Army; they are relatively stronger in men, and have less to fear from servile insurrections. In them the negro performed only a portion of the labor in the field. Could the tide of war be stayed in them, the Cotton States would escape with very little harm. As cotton is their sole staff, to interfere with its cultivation would imperil their existence. From the Border States it was believed a blow might be struck in the capture of Washington; or still better, in that of Baltimore, Philadelphia, and perhaps of New-York, which would so humble the North that it would, it was believed, enable the rebels to dictate peace. Nothing could exceed the confidence, both in their prowess and in the ease with which the North could be subdued. As it was of the utmost importance that a decided blow should be early dealt, every man the Cotton States could raise was instantly pushed North to swell the Grand Army of the Potomac. All their energies have been concentrated here, leaving, with a fatuity which we shall ere long discover is characteristic of all their operations, every vulnerable point on their coast, either without any, or at least with defences entirely inadequate to resist any considerable attack. We shall find when we get along a little further in this war, that the Southern people are really incapable of works which require forethought, patient industry, a definite purpose, and an abundant supply of money. Any person who has visited them will understand what we mean. Nothing can exceed the shiftlessness, indolence and indifference to any useful work of the great portion of their white population. The same qualities will be seen in whatever they undertake. Their people show best in the field, where dash and impetuosity go far, in the outset, to make up for those solid qualities which reach their highest efficiency only through long training. The history of the Fort Hatteras affair will serve as an illustration and example of what we may expect to find in all the fortifications on the Southern coast. Here was a work, in the hands of the rebels, capable of defending a State, and to a very great extent of protecting its industries and people, but which, in the hands of the enemy, was capable of destroying both, so wretchedly built and garrisoned that it surrendered after a day's bombardment by a few vessels of war, and was captured without the loss of a man by the assailants. These vessels, with a regiment on board, accomplished results that could hardly be expected from an Army in the field of 50,000 men. The letters and documents captured showed that some of the more intelligent officers appreciated the importance of the position, and urged that it should at once be made correspondingly strong. It was not done; not that North Carolina had not a plenty of men, and could easily have raised money enough for the construction of a first-class fortification, but her people could never be made to appreciate the importance of the step till too late, and it consequently fell an easy prey. As we go South we shall find that nearly every fortification we attack is a Hatteras, some of them stronger, perhaps, than that which was to guard North Carolina, but none of them strong enough to resist a well-concerted attack. The rebels in most of the States have neither men nor money for such works. What they possess they have stolen from the United States, after they had been built of Northern material by Northern mechanics. Their attention has been turned elsewhere, so that if we move with promptitude, we can in our attacks have matters pretty much our own way.

abstract: About 90 vessels of various descriptions have been purchased by the Navy Department, and purchases are still being made by Mr. MORGAN, the Government agent. The vessels are sent to one of the Navy-yards as soon as purchased, to be fitted out and receive their armament and stores, and be put in commission. Many of the purchased vessels are commanded by captains of the merchant service who have passed the necessary examination before the Naval Board appointed for that purpose. We have given the names of the purchased vessels from time to time as they have been fitted out. The Monticello, engaged in the affair at Cape Hatteras, was one of them. Up to this time nearly $4,000,000 have been paid for purchased vessels.

abstract: -- It seems by the late arrival from Europe that the number of British troops embarked or to be embarked for the Canadas, has dwindled down from 22,500, who were said to be on the way to those provinces, to 2,450 men all told. When it was announced that the larger number of soldiers was to be accumulated and stationed along the Northern frontier, the question why England should think it expedient at this time to offer what appeared like a menace naturally suggested itself. Had it been true that such an army was on its way to Canada, it would have given color to the idea so industriously promulgated all over the South, that she intended to disregard the blockade of the rebel ports, and that she was bent on supplying Manchester with American cotton, even at the expense of a war with the United States. The small number of the troops, however, actually destined for her American provinces will scarcely occasion any alarm on this subject. Timid people my therefore sleep quietly o'nights, so far as the dread of invasion from the other side of the St. Lawrence is concerned.
lead_paragraph: -- It seems by the late arrival from Europe that the number of British troops embarked or to be embarked for the Canadas, has dwindled down from 22,500, who were said to be on the way to those provinces, to 2,450 men all told. When it was announced that the larger number of soldiers was to be accumulated and stationed along the Northern frontier, the question why England should think it expedient at this time to offer what appeared like a menace naturally suggested itself. Had it been true that such an army was on its way to Canada, it would have given color to the idea so industriously promulgated all over the South, that she intended to disregard the blockade of the rebel ports, and that she was bent on supplying Manchester with American cotton, even at the expense of a war with the United States. The small number of the troops, however, actually destined for her American provinces will scarcely occasion any alarm on this subject. Timid people my therefore sleep quietly o'nights, so far as the dread of invasion from the other side of the St. Lawrence is concerned.

abstract: -- The explanations made by Senor TASSARA, the Spanish Envoy at Washington, do not place the action of the Captain-General of Cuba in a satisfactory light. They simply give official confirmation to the popular statement of the new policy, but leave that policy in no degree less offensive and unfriendly. It remains true that a bounty has been offered to Southern shipping to break through the blockade, and invaluable facilities have been tendered to privateers for the disposition of their prizes and the renewal of their supplies. We can therefore, well understand why the State Department is preparing to give the subject the vigorous attention it exacts, by demanding of Spain the immediate abrogation of the Captain-General's order.

abstract: The Northern states have suffered from the present war as men always do when a malicious or unruly neighbor threatens to burn their buildings, steal their property or take their lives. It may become necessary in such case to maintain a large police force, at great expense.
lead_paragraph: The Northern states have suffered from the present war as men always do when a malicious or unruly neighbor threatens to burn their buildings, steal their property or take their lives. It may become necessary in such case to maintain a large police force, at great expense. This the Northern States are doing, but thus far they know of the effects of civil war only by report. It does not rage in their borders. The mischief-maker is either incarcerated, or is within the limits we have prescribed to him. The articulations of Northern society and Northern industry are as free and undisturbed as ever. Twenty millions of people seek their nightly repose with the same sense of security as if the war was raging in China. To them it is, in all its attributes, a war on foreign soil, and entirely hemmed in from the sea. Both our domestic and foreign commerce have had a season of unwonted activity. The traffic and earnings of our railroads and canals, that bear the most intimate relations to the great routes of our internal commerce, are largely in excess of those of the past year. The contrast is so well stated in the weekly circular of an enterprising house in this City, a portion of which will be found in our commercial columns, that we make free to introduce some of the statements and conclusions it furnishes. From it it appears that the earnings for the present year of sixteen railroad companies, the same that are accustomed to report them monthly, with the earnings of the Erie Canal, have been $29,643,707, against $26,242,568 for 1860, showing an absolute gain of $3,301,139, or a rate equal to 13 per cent., for the year of rebellion over one of peace and remarkable prosperity, The activity at the great centres of trade correspond with that on our public works. The deliveries of grain at Chicago, the present year, have been 38,214,294 bushels, against 22,866,088 bushels for a corresponding period for 1860, and 9,735,582 bushels for 1859. The deliveries at tide-water, through the Erie Canal for 1861, have been 31,304,049 bushels, against 22,632,835 bushels for a similar period for 1860, and 5,234,388 bushels for 1859. The exports of Breadstuffs to England and the Continent have been equivalent to 54,682,639 bushels for 1861, against 11,191,799 bushels for 1860, and 1,644,662 bushels for 1859. The condition of the foreign trade of the country is anomalous beyond example. The imports, exclusive of specie, at the port of New-York alone, since the 1st of July, 1861, compared with those for a similar period for 1860, have fallen off $78,445,007; the imports for last year being $175,292,275; for the present, $96,847,208. The exports, exclusive of specie, in the same time, have gone from $63,843,917, in 1860, to 91,246,351 the present year. The receipts of gold from Europe and California, since Jan. 1, have been $66,739,000, while the exports have been only $3,260,000, leaving a balance in our favor, for the first eight months of the year, of $63,478,000. This is a most remarkable exhibition for a nation that foreigners are assuring themselves, and trying to convince us, is effete, on the verge of annihilation, whose only salvation is a reconstruction upon the models of the despotism of the Old World, and the London Times or Economist favor us with their views of this remarkable exhibit.

abstract: The hall in Sleecker Buildings was filled last evening in obedience to a call for a meeting of the citizens of all parties, to ratify the nominations made by the Union Conventions at Syracuse. Ex-Alderman BRISLEY called the meeting to order, and nominated EDWARD J. HAMILTON for President, who was unanimously elected. Mr. HAMILTON highly eulogized Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, and announced his purpose to sustain the nominations made at Syracuse. The time had come when all men who loved their country must lay aside all party feeling and go heart and soul for the Union. A list of gentlemen, prominent as leaders in both the Democratic, Republican and American parties were elected Vice-Presidents, who took seats on the platform. The Union Glee Club opened the meeting with patriotic songs, after which a letter was read from J. SHERMAN BROWNELL, fully indorsing the objects of the meeting, and adopting the language of Commodore DECATUR, "My country, right, but right or wrong, my country." Hon. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER then came forward and spoke at considerable length upon the present condition of the country and the conduct of the war. His allusion to FREMONT and his late proclamation was received with acclamations, the audience rising to their feet and giving a round of cheers. This outburst of enthusiasm was a marked feature of the meeting. Resolutions were adopted, and a Committee appointed upon organization of a Union Committee for conducting the canvass.

abstract: The insurgents are not disposed to let the position of Kentucky remain undecided. Yesterday, Gov. MAGOFFIN transmitted to the Legislature a dispatch from ZOLLIKOFFER, who commands the rebels in Eastern Tennessee, announcing his intention to occupy Cumberland...
lead_paragraph: The insurgents are not disposed to let the position of Kentucky remain undecided. Yesterday, Gov. MAGOFFIN transmitted to the Legislature a dispatch from ZOLLIKOFFER, who commands the rebels in Eastern Tennessee, announcing his intention to occupy Cumberland Gap, and a portion of the Western slope of the Cumberland Hills. This as a precautionary act, in consequence of the presence of National troops in Kentucky. What action the Legislature will take in the matter we shall learn presently; though we may be sure it will assert itself in the most decided fashion, and to a highly practicable effect. In the meantime, there cannot be too great activity on the part of the Federal Government. Military men have long seen the necessity of securing and holding the very positions assumed by ZOLLIKOFFER, if we would make our occupation of Western Virginia safe and permanent. The difficulty has been that to reach those points the absurd neutrality of Kentucky would have to be violated -- a scruple of so much weight with the President, that he preferred to run the risk of a hostile seizure rather than march an army from Ohio to the Gap. This scruple no longer exists. The enemy is at the rear of our gallant bands in Virginia; and they can only be protected by an energy proportioned to our previous supineness. Let us remember, if we can, that there is something beside Washington to be saved.

abstract: Among the recent arrivals from Europe, we notice the name of Mr. FRANK BELLEW, a gentleman who has been long connected with art-newspaperdom, and who, as a caricaturist, is without a rival here. Mr. BELLEW visited England last Summer, and became immediately connected with Punch, and other well-known but more serious publications. The triangle, by which he is distinguished, has been recognized here in some of the happiest hits of the season. Mr. BELLEW is an artist who combines geniality with sarcasm -- his pencil is never cruel.

abstract: The Continental Guard, which has been encamped at Camp Wyman, near Fort Hamilton, for several weeks past, on Monday received positive orders to prepare to march immediately. At 8 o'clock yeterday morning a steamer came to the Fort Hamilton dock, and in the shortest possible time the regiment embarked, and, taking the Camden and Amboy line, proceeded in the direction of Washington.
lead_paragraph: The Continental Guard, which has been encamped at Camp Wyman, near Fort Hamilton, for several weeks past, on Monday received positive orders to prepare to march immediately. At 8 o'clock yeterday morning a steamer came to the Fort Hamilton dock, and in the shortest possible time the regiment embarked, and, taking the Camden and Amboy line, proceeded in the direction of Washington. The real destination of the regiment no one seemed to know. The following is a correct list of the officers attached to this regiment:

abstract: From Washington we learn of continued activity on the part of the Government. There is no news of any advance of the rebels. Gen. MCCLELLAN and Staff spent the day on the Virginia side. Mr. RAYMOND reviewed the rebel pickets, being honored with a salute from a secession rifle, which, strange to say, was loaded with ball. There was "nobody hurt." Deserters from the Maryland regiment in the rebel Army, tell a doleful story as to the destitute and desponding condition of the enemy. They represent the insurgents as divided among themselves poorly armed, equipped, fed and clothed, and many of them ready to desert. The Government has authorized the raising of a regiment of Union troops in North Carolina.

abstract: We presume the rain of yesterday was the Equinoctial, and that it was as severe in Virginia as in New-York. If so, it is very likely to prove the turning-point in the war. Should the Potomac be rendered unfordable for a week, as has been frequently the case during the Summer, all plans of the rebels for crossing it into Maryland must be abandoned.
lead_paragraph: We presume the rain of yesterday was the Equinoctial, and that it was as severe in Virginia as in New-York. If so, it is very likely to prove the turning-point in the war. Should the Potomac be rendered unfordable for a week, as has been frequently the case during the Summer, all plans of the rebels for crossing it into Maryland must be abandoned. In this time the vast forces we are collecting upon its banks will render all attempts to force a passage hopeless. Such, we assume, will be the fact. What will be the effect upon the rebel Army? Will it waste upon the intrenchments defending Washington, constructed with consummate art, and defended by more than 100,000 men? This would be an act of madness. But if neither alternative should be taken, what will be the policy of the rebels? Will they remain behind their intrenchments at Manassas? This is hardly credible, as by universal confession, even of themselves, it is an insalubrious and inconvenient site for a great camp. Can the Army remain there an indifferent spectator of our operations upon the Southern coast, which will soon assume a magnitude which must crush well-grounded fears of their success. It is vastly more important for the rebels to defend their cotton and rice fields than Virginia. These support the war, while Virginia, in addition to a moderate, supply of certain kinds of food, is only the theatre for its operations.

abstract: The Boston Avertiser, of yesterday, says: "The New-York papers have entirely let the cat out of the bag as to the preparations now in progress for Naval Expeditions. The secret was blown several days ago and widely published. Yesterday, too, the Tribune felt that it committed 'no impropriety in announcing that the preparations for two important movements against the Southern coast are going rapidly forward, so that the expeditions will be ready to set sail within a very few weeks.' We believe, therefore, that we commit no impropriety in recording that Gen. BUTLER is spoken of as likely to command one of these expeditions, and Gen. SHERMAN the other. It is supposed that 25,000 men will be engaged.

abstract: It is very probable that recruiting offices for the regular Army will shortly be opened in various country places, where the sight of a regular soldier will be a novelty. This measure is rendered necessary by the very unsatisfactory returns from the old established city offices, at which there is scarcely anything at all doing.

abstract: We are presented with two statements in reference to the recent slaughter of troops on the Northern Central Railroad. One comes from the Super-intendent of the road, who attributes the mishap to the fracture of an axle, while he makes no attempt to controvert the allegation of sudden and extreme speed. He also gives the engineer in charge a flattering character. The other emanates from Col. KILPATRICK and the officers of the regiment who were upon the train. They enter needlessly into the transactions at Harrisburgh; for whatever occurred there would form no apology for consigning a thousand men to probable death; but they also quote expressions from the engineer, implying an intention to destroy the train, which would clearly found a suspicion of malice aforethought. They state, moreover, that when the engineer reached Baltimore upon his detached engine, he declared his ignorance that an accident had occurred, a declaration so preposterous as to warrant yet further suspicion. In these circumstances, it is of the last importance an investigation should be had. The prisoner still awaits examination. Will not Gen. DIX hasten it?
lead_paragraph: We are presented with two statements in reference to the recent slaughter of troops on the Northern Central Railroad. They state, moreover, that when the engineer reached Baltimore upon his detached engine, he declared his ignorance that an accident had occurred, a declaration so preposterous as to warrant yet further suspicion. In these circumstances, it is of the last importance an investigation should be had. The prisoner still awaits examination. Will not Gen. DIX hasten it?

abstract: The first effect of an intestine or civil war is the destruction of the internal trade of a country, for the reason that production ceases, and merchandise cannot be safely sent over its highways. No rebel soldier has set his foot upon the soil of the Free States, and their industries are pursued without any...
lead_paragraph: The first effect of an intestine or civil war is the destruction of the internal trade of a country, for the reason that production ceases, and merchandise cannot be safely sent over its highways. No rebel soldier has set his foot upon the soil of the Free States, and their industries are pursued without any more apprehension of being interfered with on account of the war than those of Birmingham or Manchester. In proof of this, we give the following table of the earnings of all the railroad companies of the Northern States that report regularly their earnings, with those of the Erie Canal, for 1861, compared with corresponding periods for 1860. It will be borne in mind that the table embraces all the roads that are accustomed to report their earnings monthly, and are those that bear the most intimate relations to the internal trade of the country:

abstract: Within the last few days the venerable shades of Nassau Hall have witnessed some stirring events. Although removed from the immediate scene of action, her loyal sons have, from the beginning of the contest, felt the deepest interest in the struggle to maintain the integrity of our Government, and gladly, ere this, if duty had called, would they all have gone forth to lend their aid for the suppression of rebellion. But they have found an important field of labor here, and have already rendered valuable assistance to the Government in suppressing treason at home.

abstract: This regiment, Col. FRANCIS L. VINTON, numbers over 600 men. At 6 1/4 o'clock P.M. on Monday, the men embarked on board the boat at Albany. After lying in the steam about an hour, they steamed toward New-York. Arriving at Dow's Point, the boat ran aground, and remained in that condition till after 1 o'clock A.M. yesterday, when high water floated them off. At 3 o'clock P.M. the boat arrived off the deck, and shortly afterwards the men were landed and marched to the Park Barracks, where they will remain for about three weeks, in order to recruit the regiment up to the full standard of 1,040 men.

abstract: MUTINY. -- Monday afternoon as the ship Universe was being towed to sea, and when near the Narrows a difficulty occurred among the crew. During the melee one of the seamen was stabbed. His assailant jumped overboard to avoid being taken. Mr. ROBINSON, United States boarding-officer of the cutter Bibb, seeing the man in the water immediately went to him and succeeded in rescuing him and than returned him to the ship, which proceeded on her voyage.

abstract: IS THE ADHESION OF THIS GOVERNMENT REJECTED? -- A rumor, prevalent at Washington, that the adhesion of the Government of the United States to the doctrines of the Parisian Congress has been declined by the great European Powers, is doubtless no more than an anticipation of what is deemed likely to occur. Since the departure of Mr. SEWARD's dispatch there has been ample time for the subject to have been fully considered in every European Cabinet. It might have gone to St. Petersburgh and Constantinople, have engrossed two months of deliberation at each of those distant capitals, and we might have had the response weeks ago. The failure to receive any, if none has been received, is an uncommonly broad foundation for gossip to build upon.

It might have gone to St. Petersburgh and Constantinople, have engrossed two months of deliberation at each of those distant capitals, and we might have had the response weeks ago. The failure to receive any, if none has been received, is an uncommonly broad foundation for gossip to build upon.

abstract: Later and more full advices from Mexico indicate a better state of affairs in that country than the first accounts led us to believe really existed. It appears that the reactionary forces under MARQUEZ and other Generals have been throughly defeated and dispersed by the Government troops under Gen. ORTEGA. It also appears that the Government is emerging from the depressing influences of domestic intrigue, as well as the...
lead_paragraph: Later and more full advices from Mexico indicate a better state of affairs in that country than the first accounts led us to believe really existed. It appears that the reactionary forces under MARQUEZ and other Generals have been throughly defeated and dispersed by the Government troops under Gen. ORTEGA. It also appears that the Government is emerging from the depressing influences of domestic intrigue, as well as the wiles of European diplomacy, which have been an enduring element of evil in Mexican affairs.

abstract: GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Tuesday, Aug. 20, 1861. Several of the Mormon Elders, who have been  missionizing in England, and latterly directing or assisting the emigration through the States, arrived in this city, last week, in advance of the omigrants. As may be expected, some of said Elders appeared on the "stand" in the Bowery, on Sunday, and addressed the audience. Messrs. NATHANIEL V. JONES. JACOB
lead_paragraph: GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Tuesday, Aug. 20, 1861. Several of the Mormon Elders, who have been missionizing in England, and latterly directing or assisting the emigration through the States, arrived in this city, last week, in advance of the omigrants. As may be expected, some of said Elders appeared on the "stand" in the Bowery, on Sunday, and addressed the audience. Messrs. NATHANIEL V. JONES. JACOB GATES and CLAUDIUS V. SPENCER talked more or less of the approaching "brethren." It appears that there are now on the plains, and bound immediately for this city, not less than four thousand Mormons, of both sexes, and all ages and conditions. The last companies, excluding two or three small trains with goods, left Florence, N.T., about the middle of July, and it was "calculated" that on Sunday the van companies were between the Platte and Sweetwater, and the rear trains nearly up to Laramie.

abstract: The excessive prodigality and mismanagement common to all departments of the City Government have, with rare courage, been made the subject of examination by the Supervisors; and, although investigation and suggestion might both have been carried much further, what we have in the way of report contains profit and edification.
lead_paragraph: The excessive prodigality and mismanagement common to all departments of the City Government have, with rare courage, been made the subject of examination by the Supervisors; and, although investigation and suggestion might both have been carried much further, what we have in the way of report contains profit and edification. Everywhere there are officers to be spared, salaries to be saved or reduced, work to be judiciously suspended, and estimates to be cut down. Possibilities of this description the Committee has discovered in every department and bureau. With exquisite prudence, however, they omit two or three millions of really practicable and advisable reductions, confining themselves to the enumeration of a few, which reach within a fraction of $1,000,000 Let us be grateful for thus much, and hopeful of more; and, in a general way, take heart of grace.

abstract: We have previously called attention to the large amount of available material of the best kind for military officers, which we possess in the upper classes of the West Point Cadets. The young men, members of the first and second classes, have been under the best of military training, theoretical and practical, for the terms of three or two years, and are now abundantly able and willing to assume positions in which they can serve the country that has educated them. Some, moved by a noble ardor, and despairing of graduating in a reasonable time, have preferred accepting commissions in our volunteer Army to an inglorious activity at West Point. That they are considered by the War Department well fitted to enter on active duty is evident from the fact that during the month of July an order was received by the head of the Academy to graduate the two upper classes, and send them on immediately to Washington. Presently, however, the order was countermanded, though why, nobody knows. Let the young men be put into harness.

abstract: The New-York Post-office will decline to exchange the new for the old issue of postage stamps after the current week. Those of our subscribers, therefore, who have occasion to transmit to us money in that form, will be good enough to inclose only the new emission, as the others on Saturday next will have ceased to possess value, and cannot be credited either no subscriptions or advertising account.

abstract: The People, &c., ex rel. Edward Falconer vs. Matthew T. Brennan, Police Magistrate. -- This case comes before the Court upon returns to two writs of certiorari issued out of the Supreme Court to Brennan, a Police Justice of this City. The relator was charged and tried before the said Police Justice with a violation of a Corporation ordinance, and being convicted, was sentenced to pay a fine of $10 or imprisonment for ten days. The offence charged upon Falconer was collecting and promoting assemblages of persons, under pretence of exhortation, in the streets of the City. The ordinance provides that no person shall be concerned or instrumental in collecting or promoting any assemblage of persons, under pretence of or for public worship or exhortation, in any streets of the City of New-York, except clergymen or ministers of any denomination who may have obtained a written permission. It is claimed that Falconer was not a minister of the gospel and had obtained no written permission. From the deposition of John Mead, a policeman, who arrested Falconer, it appears that Falconer was, on Sept. 16, 1860, engaged in haranguing a crowd in East-street, making demonstrations and using violent language, which caused the crowd to be disorderly, filling the sidewalk so that it was almost impossible to pass, and using such language as caused the Police present to be made a laughing-stock of. He also invited all present to come next Sunday, to see him disobey and defy all the universe. At this time he stood on top of a house, descanting upon temperance, and again extending an invitation to the crowd to come next Sunday, and he would talk to them from the logs down there, in spite of law and the universe.

abstract: A plan for purchasing the La Crosse Railroad, at any sale that may be made of it, has been receiving assents for the last week, and meets with the approbation of a sufficient number of the bondholders to carry it into effect. It will be seen, by reference to an advertisement in this paper, [and also in the TIMES,] that other bondholders can become parties to the agreement to purchase at any time previous to Sept. 21, 1961, by calling or sending to the office of N.A. COWDRY, No. 29 William-street, and signing the plan. It seems to be the intention of the party represented by this plan, to buy the road whenever it is sold, for the benefit of themselves and associates, and they think they are enabled to do this by having more than three-fourths of all the land grant bonds, which are an equivalent for specie in paying for the road.

abstract: The members of this Convention assembled, at 9 A.M. yesterday, in the Church of the Divine Unity, Broadway. In consequence of the disturbed condition of the country, the number of delegates to the Council was unusually small, the Southern States, of course, being unrepresented. Rev. ELI BALLOU, of Montpelier, Vt., the President of the Council, called the Convention to order. Rev. G.L. DEMAREST, of Cincinnati, was chosen Assistant-Secretary. After hearing from the various Committees, the report on the state of the Churches was ordered to be presented to the Council in the evening, at the Bleecker-street Church. The Sunday-school meeting was held at 2 1/2 P.M., the exercises being conducted by Rev. G.L. DEMAREST. Appropriate addresses were made by Rev. M. BAULCH, of Ludlow, Vt., N.H. BENSON, of Troy, N.Y., and others. The inclemency of the weather prevented a large attendance. There was preaching at the Twentieth-street Church in the evening.

abstract: Capt. KING, who brought the last accounts of this vessel, states that she remained at Surinam on the 21st ult., at anchor off the town, and that she passed the fort below where she lay against the remonstrances of the officer in command, upon the plea that she was a ship of war and not a privateer. The Governor of Surinam, however, protested against her appearance in port, and had ordered her to proceed elsewhere without delay, refusing, at the same time to furnish her with supplies of any kind; but her Captain, knowing the defenceless state of the place, for she lay four miles above the fort, stated that he would remain in port as long as he pleased, and if not furnished with such stores as he might require, he would find a way to obtain them by the use of powder and shot. This, of course, was an idle boast, for artillery, if necessary, could be brought from Fort Amsterdam, to sink her where she lay.

abstract: Nowhere else on all the theatre of war have the Union Armies so well sustained their cause as in Western Virginia,taking into consideration their strength and the immeuse country they have had to defend. The National forces in Western Virginia have never been large.
lead_paragraph: Nowhere else on all the theatre of war have the Union Armies so well sustained their cause as in Western Virginia,taking into consideration their strength and the immeuse country they have had to defend. The National forces in Western Virginia have never been large. They have never, to the popular mind, seemed adequate to the work assigned them Being comparatively feeble in numbers, and unacquainted with the by-ways of a mountainous region they had to penetrate as desolate and inaccessible as any in the Alleghany range, Gen. MCCLELLAN's Army had. in the first place, to feel its way along through a hostile, picket-murdering population, and to find its in trenched enemies in the dangerous mountain passes and expel them thence. This was a hazardous duty for the beat appointed Army and the best General of the times. The enemy knew every mile of the mountain wilderness. They had, everywhere, capable-local spies to furnish information of the movements, of the Union Army. They had occupied and prepared for defence the vital passes of the mountains. But with a rapidity, a resoluteness and a certainty that has no parallel in American warfare, Gen. MCCLELLAN advanced upon the fortified foe, brushed away as trifles apparently the most formidable obstacles, and routed, seattered and captured the surprised and panic-stricken enemy, till not a vestige of organized rebel force remained in northwestern Virginia to oppose the authority of the Union. And then, with care and promptness, the passes from which the enemy had been expelled were fortified, to prevent his return to molest an infranchised people. And to this date, the enemy is effectually excluded.

abstract: - This morning, the Prince and suite leave the Brevoort House for Washington, in the 7 o'clock train. Yesterday, a visit was paid by the Prince and part of his suite to old Dr. MOTT, in Gramercy-park, the Doctor and LOUIS PHILLIPPS having been intimately acquainted during the latter's sojourn in this country. The purchasing of equipments for their tour on the prairies, occupied a part of the day. The party are undetermined whether to start from Washington on their western tour, or after a stoppage there of a week or two, coming back to New-York and starting from here.

abstract: SHAMEFUL DEATH OF A YOUNG WOMAN -- MYSTERIOUS CASE. -- MARY DUNLOP, a seamstress, aged 26 years, died on Sunday morning last, at No. 643 Hudson-street, from the consequences of having an abortion procured. The arrangements had been made for her funeral to take place on Monday morning, but just prior to the removal of the remains, some members of the Police took charge of them, by order of Coroner SCHIRMER, who had received information of the facts in the case. Dr. GEORGE B. BOUTON afterwards made a post-mortem examination of the body, and found undoubted evidence that death had resulted from the cause stated. A Jury was thereupon summoned, and last evening the Coroner commenced an investigation, for the purpose of discovering the perpetrator or instigator of the crime. Much evidence was taken, but it was of a hearsay character, and therefore not entitled to implicit credence. Deceased came to this country from Scotland two years ago, and went to live in the family of her uncle, Mr. HUGH MCALPINE, a blacksmith, bearing a good reputation, who has lived many years in the Ninth Ward. Six months since she obtained work as a seamstress in Leake & Watts Orphan Asylum, and her character for virtue does not seem to have been questioned. On Friday week she was taken ill, and after being sick some days she made confessions to one of her associates, charging her uncle with having abused her and caused her ruin. At her own request, on Tuesday, the 10th inst., she was brought down to her uncle's house, No. 643 Hudson-street, where Dr. NORVAL, late of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, attended and prescribed for her, and after her death made out a certificate attributing it indirectly to disease of the heart, and directly to inflammation of the bowels, or peretonetus. The doctor could not be found yesterday, having gone to the country for a day. Dr. NORVAL returned last night, and, consequently, his testimony was not obtained. Under these circumstances, Coroner SCHIRMER adjourned the investigation, and meanwhile a search will be made for witnesses, who will probably be able to give information of importance in the case.

abstract: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Thursday, Sept.5, 1861. At the close of my letter by the steamer Saladin I informed you that an American man-ofwar was in sight. It turned out to be the United States frigate Richmond, which was on a cruise in search of the privateer Sumter, and called in here for coals and other supplies.
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Thursday, Sept.5, 1861.

abstract: It is altogether logical that a certain class  of English statesmen, after giving their sympathy to the Southern slave-aristocracy in their attempt to destroy the American Republic, should look with favor on the despotic course which the Austrian Emperor has seen fit, in violation of all his constitutional obligation...
lead_paragraph: It is altogether logical that a certain class of English statesmen, after giving their sympathy to the Southern slave-aristocracy in their attempt to destroy the American Republic, should look with favor on the despotic course which the Austrian Emperor has seen fit, in violation of all his constitutional obligations, to adopt towards the Kingdom of Hungary. Mr. ROEBUCK, it is very certain, is not alone in his admiration of the Hapsburgh Government, and while England is cutting herself off on every side from European and American friendship, the Earl RUSSELL boldly affirmed the other day that Austria was "the natural ally of England!" This new development of English Tory "sympathy" is of a certain importance to us, as it furnishes a fresh illustration of the animus of the class. Many have found it an inexplicable enigma who could prompt the ill-concealed chuckle of this party over the disruption of the Union -- with them a foregone conclusion. It may aid the solution when we see this very party applauding the representative of a perjured dynasty in his lawless and despotic attempt to annihilate the fundamental constitutional rights and national self-government of a noble and long suffering race.

abstract: A TOUR OF THE PICKETS--MR. RAYMOND SALUTED. Mr. RAYMOND to-day made the tour of our outer pickets from Chain Bridge to Alexandria. He was frequently within eight of the rebel pickets. At Bailey's Cross Roads he saw the rebel fortifications on Munson's Hill.
lead_paragraph: A TOUR OF THE PICKETS--MR. RAYMOND SALUTED. Mr. RAYMOND to-day made the tour of our outer pickets from Chain Bridge to Alexandria. He was frequently within eight of the rebel pickets. At Bailey's Cross Roads he saw the rebel fortifications on Munson's Hill. While observing them from an open window of the house in which our pickets are stationed, he was honored with a message from a rebel rifle. The ball passed high, going over the house. There was little of interest occurred on the outposts. The men at Fort Ellsworth were practicing at the guns. The balls going over Alexandria, and striking in the river on the Maryland shore. There was artillery practice at Forts Corcoran and Albany this morning with heavy guns. The battery firing was very perfect.

abstract: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. -- A German named HENRY AXT, boarding at No. 45 Mercer-street, Jersey City, attempted to destroy his life, yesterday morning, by severing an artery in his arm. When discovered he was very feeble from the loss of blood. The City Physician, Dr. HADDAN, was called in and attended him, and it is thought he may recover. AXT has a family living on Staten Island, and a letter was found directed to his wife, in which he stated his intention of destroying his life.

abstract: We hear of no movement of either of the armies of the Potomac. BEAUREGARD has not taken Washington. Neither has he made any demonstration towards Baltimore or Philadelphia. In fact, the rapid movement of National troops toward the capital, together with the corps d'armee congregated there, would seem to render such an undertaking extremely hazardous. The health of our Army is excellent.

abstract: In the case of John J. Hays, who was indicted for bigamy, it appeared that he was married in 1845, to a woman who is still living, and that in September last, he was again married to a woman named Jane White, whose acquaintance he made in a disreputable house. It was stated that he subsequently destroyed the marriage certificate, but the defendant endeavored to show that the certificate in question never existed. A verdict of guilty was rendered. Sentence deferred till Saturday.

abstract: A meeting was held at the St. Nicholas Hotel a few evenings since, by well-known citizens of the City, for the purpose of organizing a Union Party, and to nominate an independent ticket for the coming election. An Executive Committee was appointed,
lead_paragraph: A meeting was held at the St. Nicholas Hotel a few evenings since, by well-known citizens of the City, for the purpose of organizing a Union Party, and to nominate an independent ticket for the coming election. An Executive Committee was appointed, who agreed upon various resolutions, which were reported at a meeting held at the same place last evening. The resolutions were adopted enthusiastically, and signed by the gentlemen present, who were our most influential and wealthy citizens.

abstract: A small gold coinage having been lately needed by the Government, the Mint, during the whole of last month, and the first ten days of this month, was occupied three days in each week coining half and quarter eagles, the remaining three days being employed on double eagles. Now that the Government demand for small coin is not so pressing, a return has been made entirely in the gold coinage to double eagles, in order to accommodate banks and the bullion dealers in furnishing gold for the new National Loan subscriptions.
lead_paragraph: A small gold coinage having been lately needed by the Government, the Mint, during the whole of last month, and the first ten days of this month, was occupied three days in each week coining half and quarter eagles, the remaining three days being employed on double eagles. abstract: The Spanish Minister at Washington is zealous in contradicting the report that the CaptainGeneral of Cuba has issued a proclamation inviting Southern contraband trade to the Island, by offering it peculiar immunities.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish Minister at Washington is zealous in contradicting the report that the CaptainGeneral of Cuba has issued a proclamation inviting Southern contraband trade to the Island, by offering it peculiar immunities. We are even assured that the rumor originated at Charleston, and not at Havana. Senor TASSARA may state no more than the truth. But what has been said, and what is vouched for by the correspondent of the TIMES at Havana, whose opportunities to know are indisputable, is that secret orders -- not a proclamation -- had been sent to the various revenue officers of the Island, embodying instructions to extend all possible facilities to the Confederate vessels; and this statement we have no reason to doubt. It would be the interest of the consular authorities to preserve, for the present, the secrecy of such orders; and, especially, to take every precaution against their becoming known to the Government at Washington, a policy which the ignorance of Senor TASSARA would best subserve. Indeed, the transactions of the Cuban Government only become officially known to the Spanish Minister in the United States after they have passed through Madrid. No reason, therefore, has yet been offered for questioning the authenticity of a report, which otherwise has so great an air of probability.

abstract: At the present time the position of Canada, as regards prosperity, contentment and loyalty, is such that the appointment of a Governor-General would be a matter comparatively of trifling importance if the interests of the Province were alone concerned.
lead_paragraph: At the present time the position of Canada, as regards prosperity, contentment and loyalty, is such that the appointment of a Governor-General would be a matter comparatively of trifling importance if the interests of the Province were alone concerned. But, unfortunately, the state of affairs in the neighboring Republic requires that the authority of the Imperial Government should be exercised with a strong and vigorous hand, and that questions of international policy should not be left to the decision of any local legislature or provincial administration. The office of Governor-General of Canada is, in fact, a Viceroyship. The Governor-General is supposed, in virtue of his commission, to control the administration of all the subordinate Governors of the North American Provinces. He has to govern more than three millions of subjects, and he has not only to attend to their domestic welfare, but also to assert the rights and dignity of the mother country. The nobleman who has been selected to succeed Sir EDMUND HEAD has had large experience of public and official life. He has been a useful and industrious member of the House of Commons, he has held the office of a Lord of the Treasury, and he has had the benefit of the professional training of the lawyer. Viscount MONCK, however, must remember that he is about to assume an office which will require higher qualifications than those of balancing the claims of the political parties which in Canada, as elsewhere, are bidding for power. No one in this country much cares whether the "Clear Grits" are in office, or whether Mr. BROWN or Mr. CARTIER head the Provincial Administration. The most important duties which Viscount MONCK will have to perform will be to maintain the neutrality of the province, to develop its resources, and promote its material prosperity, and to show to the world that the monarchical institutions of Canada confer more real freedom, and have in them elements of permanency far greater than those of the neighboring Republic. It would seem that while the people of the once United States are finally separating, British North America is only anxious for that federal union which would give national power and organization to every province on the continent which owns the sway of her Majesty. We do not anticipate that Viscount MONCK will have a very difficult task. Even if by some accident peace should be restored in the United States, and the half a million men in arms should be let loose upon Canada, the province is quite ready, and has full strength enough to hold its own. Viscount MONCK, however, may accomplish great good by elevating the tone of public men in Canada. At present it is believed that the members of the Provincial Government (composed chiefly of lawyers) are not altogether innocent of complicity in those jobs which have made the Grand Trunk Railway a scandal and disgrace to the Province. In the present circumstances of the United States he will not only have to maintain the dignity and neutrality of Canada, but he may foster manufactures and commerce, and, above all, attract to the Province that vast stream of emigration which hitherto has so unaccountably proceeded to the States of the American Union. He will govern, at all events, a loyal, contented and peaceable people, who enjoy and appreciate as large an amount of political freedom and material prosperity as ever has fallen to the lot of man in the world.

abstract: Last night, at 8 o'clock, a train on the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, containing a portion of Col. TORCHIN's Nineteenth Illinois Regiment, while passing over a bridge near Huron, Ind., one hundred and forty-three miles west of Cincinnati, fell through, killing and wounding over one hundred soldiers. Intelligence of the disaster reached here late last night, when a special train was dispatched to their assistance.

abstract: Accounts from Nevada Territory state the overland emigration is passing through on the way to California at the rate of fifty to seventy wagons per day. The majority appear to come from Missouri, but many are from Kentucky. They report that thousands are behind them, and mention particularly one very large train, which has the best outfit that has left. This is called the Bloomer train, as there are about fifty ladies in it, all wearing Bloomer costumes and boots, and armed with bowie-knives and revolvers.

abstract: -- Mr. CHARLES D. DESHLER announces his retirement from the editorial charge of the Jersey City Standard. It is understood that Mr. DESHLER transfers his talents to the Newark Daily Advertiser, taking the place of Mr. SAMUEL J. GARDNER, who has for eleven years furnished the leading articles and otherwise assisted in the conduct of that popular journal, with most creditable ability and indefatigable industry. abstract: A special meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held yesterday afternoon at the County Jail, Supervisor CROOKE, President of the Board, in the Chair. A communication was received
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held yesterday afternoon at the County Jail, Supervisor CROOKE, President of the Board, in the Chair. A communication was received from Messrs. MORRIS & Co., contractors for supplying the Almshouse with tea, coffee, sugar, liquor, &c., asking to be released from their contract with the county, owing to the great rise, on account of the rebellion, in the price of the larger part of the articles which they agreed to supply. The matter was referred to the Almshouse Committee and Superintendents of the Poor.

abstract: The effects of the blow at Hatteras are beginning to be felt, and it looks as though they would be very great not only in the immediate vicinity, but upon the rebel Army in Virginia,
lead_paragraph: The effects of the blow at Hatteras are beginning to be felt, and it looks as though they would be very great not only in the immediate vicinity, but upon the rebel Army in Virginia, and thus upon the whole course of the rebellion, and we should not be surprised if the historian of these times should place the turning point of the rebellion, from which its progress to utter destruction was more and more rapid, at the time when the Stars and Stripes replaced the rebel flag upon the North Carolina forts.

abstract: It is stated that the War Department has at last decided to discharge the Texan soldiers, who, under Gen. TWIGGS, had to surrender themselves prisoners of war, and who for several months past have been encamped at Fort Hamilton. This measure will be
lead_paragraph: It is stated that the War Department has at last decided to discharge the Texan soldiers, who, under Gen. TWIGGS, had to surrender themselves prisoners of war, and who for several months past have been encamped at Fort Hamilton. This measure will be tantamount to disbanding the several companies of the First, Third and Eighth Regiments of Infantry, which are now at the Fort, and steps will be taken at once to reorganize these companies, and form them into, a battalion on Governor's Island. Recruiting parties will be told off from Company A, Permanent Party, on the Island, and will proceed immediately to recruit for the disbanded companies of the regiments named above.

abstract: Whatever may be true of our other Democratic theories, we must admit that this war has very effectually exploded the theory of a Democratic Army. We have had universal
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be true of our other Democratic theories, we must admit that this war has very effectually exploded the theory of a Democratic Army. We have had universal suffrage among the soldiers. Colonels, majors, and we hardly know what other officers have attained their posts of honor and danger by the ballot. The process has been simple. A martial clerk from some village shop, who has figured on "training days" on the green, or a broken-down city adventurer who has served in a target company, gathers together some ardent and unemployed young men for the purpose of serving their country. He borrows or begs money enough to keep his band together a few days, until he can obtain permission from the authorities to raise a regiment. When this is secured, he gathers the men in assembly, and the precious privilege of American citizens is conferred upon them, and they proceed to elect their own officers. Of course the mover of the whole enterprise, though he may know no more of strategy than of astrology, is at once elected Colonel, unanimously, and his particular friend -- though he may be equally qualified -- is chosen Lieutenant-Colonel, and another Major, for similar reasons, until the regiment is officered. Or, taking a more favorable, but more unusual instance, a man of some military experience is chosen Colonel, and the subordinate officers are elected by the men, because they are "popular," or good fellows, or because they have some especial social position in their towns or wards. The position to which the democratic theory is thus applied has no precise analogy in the offices of civil life. A military officer is towards his men more as a ship captain is towards his passengers, or a pilot to the crew. Universal suffrage is about as applicable to the one case as the other. The Colonel of a regiment has the lives and honor of his men in his hands, he can lead them into useless and dangerous positions, from which they can never extricate themselves, or by some act of base cowardice he can demoralize his corps. He is at once leader and pilot. So, in less degree, with the subordinate officers. Even the Quartermasters, Commissaries and Captains have the health and comfort of the men entirely in their power. If they are dishonest or incompetent the soldiers will find their strength gone before the battle.
headline: {'main': 'Universal Suffrage in the Army.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Universal Suffrage in the Army.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Two of the Sachems of Tammany, ELIJAH F. PURDY, Chairman of the General Committee, and PETER B. SWEENEY, Chairman of the Corresponding Committee, in a letter addressed to the Tribune, have repudiated the platform of the Syracuse Convention. They affirm the devotion of Tammany to the Constitution, and its earnest determination to aid in the prosecution of the war with all the vigor of which the nation is capable,and that when the Society shall come together their voice will but echo the sentiment of the people of this State on this subject. This is all as it should be, as far as it goes. But will Tammany support the nominees of the Syracuse Convention? Words are cheap. They amount to little in times like these. But action tells for good or evil on events which the people of this State are shaping. The "Democratic candidates" are supposed to represent the sentiments enunciated by those who made them such. To vote for them is to declare in favor of the resolutions of the Syracuse conclave. If Tammany would vindicate itself from the odium attached to all who are connected with those resolutions, if it would be true to the democratic masses so nobly represented in the National Armies, and to the overwhelming sentiment of the State, it swill repudiate the candidates as well as the platform. It will not only do this, but it will go further, and vote in favor of the People's candidates who occupy the precise position claimed for Tammany by the gentlemen above named. This would be adding effective action to professions, and show that Tammany is in earnest in its patriotism.
lead_paragraph: Two of the Sachems of Tammany, ELIJAH F. PURDY, Chairman of the General Committee, and PETER B. abstract: One of the finest bodies of men which have passed through this City since the second call for volunteers, arrived yesterday morning, from Buffalo, via the Erie Railroad, and is known as the Second Buffalo Regiment. There are eleven companies, numbering 765 rank and file, accompanied by a corps of twenty drummers. The regiment has been encamped at....
lead_paragraph: One of the finest bodies of men which have passed through this City since the second call for volunteers, arrived yesterday morning, from Buffalo, via the Erie Railroad, and is known as the Second Buffalo Regiment. There are eleven companies, numbering 765 rank and file, accompanied by a corps of twenty drummers. The regiment has been encamped at Camp Porter, near Buffalo, since about the 12th of August, during which time they have been constantly drilled by competent and experienced officers, and have attained a praiseworthy degree of proficiency. The regiment is composed mainly of sons of farmers from the adjacent counties, all educated and thinking men, who, when the completion of the harvest left them a choice of occupation or idleness, chose to enlist in their country's cause, and cheerfully give their aid to crush the great rebellion. The orders for marching were received on Saturday night at 9 o'clock, and at 6 o'clock on Monday morning the regiment was in the cars of the Erie Railroad, en route for the seat of war. Just as the cars were about starting, an entire company, which had been recruited at Jamestown, Chatauque County, came up, and joining the regiment, came on with it, forming the eleventh Company, L. With the exception of this company and a few recruits who joined a day or two before the camp was broken up, all the men are clothed in uniform similarto that worn by the regulars of the Army. They have no arms, knapsacks, nor indeed any of they equipments, but Gov. MORGAN assured the commanding officer that these should be promptly provided in this City. They brought no horses, wagons, tents, or any other necessary for field operations, all of which will, however, be provided here. The regiment is at present quartered at the Park Barracks, where they will probably remain until Saturday. They are accompanied by Hon. F.A. ALDBERGER, Mayor of Buffalo, Aldermen ADAMS, HOWARD, STORK, and ISAAC HOLLOWAY, a wealthy gentleman of Buffalo, who has been very liberal in his assistance to effect the organization of the regiment, and who will remain to see that the men lack nothing before they leave for the seat of war. Yesterday afternoon one of the men managed to pass the sentries, and was making rapid tracks through the Park, either intending to desert or perhaps from a desire to see more of New-York than he could from the barracks, but he was overtaken by a couple of officers who escorted him back to quarters, where he was introduced to the guard-house.

abstract: It is a maxim as old as warfare, that to command the sea is to command the land. The sea is the highway of commerce, the loss of which so impoverishes a nation as to render it incapable of putting forth any great degree of military strength. In war,
lead_paragraph: It is a maxim as old as warfare, that to command the sea is to command the land. The sea is the highway of commerce, the loss of which so impoverishes a nation as to render it incapable of putting forth any great degree of military strength. In war, success is simply a matter of movement -- of transportation both of men and. their arms and equipments, in which celerity is certain to win. Naval victories have, consequently, been far more decisive in their results than those on land, because, from their freedom of movement, they have involved the destruction of armies that defied whatever force could be directly brought to attack them. The Greeks saved themselves in the great Persian invasion by the command of the sea; the Romans, in that of HANNIBAL. The battle of Lepanto settled the question whether Europe should be Christian or Mahommedan.

abstract: A WATCHMAN DROWNED IN THE CROTON WATER: WORKS.--An inquest was held yesterday upon the body of MICHAEL CROWLEY, a night watchman employed at the Receiving Reservoir, in Eighty-sixthstreet, who was drowned on Monday night. He was
lead_paragraph: A WATCHMAN DROWNED IN THE CROTON WATER: WORKS.--An inquest was held yesterday upon the body of MICHAEL CROWLEY, a night watchman employed at the Receiving Reservoir, in Eighty-sixthstreet, who was drowned on Monday night. He was last seen alive about 10 o'clock that night on his post near Ninety-second-street and Eighth-avenue, and no direct evidence as to the manner of his death was obtained, but the circumstances leave no room to doubt how it occurred. In order to connect the Aqueduct with the new Reservoir, the brick arch forming the top of the Aqueduct had been removed, and CROWLEY, probably in leaning over the stream to dip a drink of water, fell into it head foremost, striking his head against the wall with sufficient force to stun him. The grade of the Aqueduct at this point is only three-sixteenths of an inch to the hundred feet, but the velocity with which the water passes into the Reservoir is very great in consequence of the narrowness of the conduit, (only four feet,) and there being nothing to which the unfortunate man could cling, he was swept by the current through the flood-gate into, the Reservoir. On Tuesday morning, when the laborers went to work, they found the body floating. CROWLEY resided at the corner of Second-avenue and One hundred and Twenty-second-street, and has left a large family. He had been in the employ of the Croton Department many years, and was a sober, steady man.

abstract: Five companies of this new regiment were last evening inspected and sworn in at the Division Armory, by Major TAYLOR, Brigade Inspector of the Fourth Brigade, to which brigade the Twenty-second is attached. This is an entirely new regiment, having
lead_paragraph: Five companies of this new regiment were last evening inspected and sworn in at the Division Armory, by Major TAYLOR, Brigade Inspector of the Fourth Brigade, to which brigade the Twenty-second is attached. This is an entirely new regiment, having been formed during the past few months, and numbers amongst its members -- both as officers and privates -- very many young men of our most respectable and well-known families. It numbers between four and five hundred at present, but before many weeks it is expected to fill up to the full complement. The inspection last evening was certainly of a most satisfactory character, and notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather, a large number of spectators were present, amongst the number Gen. BURNSIDE. After the completion of the inspection, Major TAYLOR addressed the battalion, stating the great pleasure it had given him in having been able to muster into the State service and the Fourth Brigade a regiment which, from the evidence before him, he had no hesitation in saying, was destined to become ere long second to none in the service.

abstract: The crash of a new political world is an awful phenomenon. War has dashed like a comet upon the great American Republic, and all the institutions and destinies of that mighty Union seem scattered in fragments around. It is impossible to predict the forma
lead_paragraph: The crash of a new political world is an awful phenomenon. War has dashed like a comet upon the great American Republic, and all the institutions and destinies of that mighty Union seem scattered in fragments around. It is impossible to predict the formations which may survive after the convulsion has passed away, but all that we now see tends irresistibly to convince us that we shall never again behold that specimen of political organization which so amazed us with its growth, and impressed us with its apparent vigor. The United States of North America have ceased to be. Whether their place will be taken by two Unions or twenty -- whether the principle of confederation will be merely limited or absolutely discarded -- nobody can venture to foretell; but we cannot so much as imagine any course of events which will leave the last state of things with much resemblance to the first. Enough has now been learnt to show that the subjugation of the South is next to impossible, and its submission in the highest degree improbable. The Territories of the old Union will be divided, nor will the partition be territorial only. Between North and South there will be barriers of feelings, interests and traditions. They will long look upon each other with jealousy and suspicion, if not with still worse sentiments, and the "frontier" will require the same garrisons and observances as that between two monarchies of the European Continent. This, however, presumes the maintenance of standing armies, warlike estimates and oppressive taxation; while these burdens again will exercise an influence upon all social and political institutions. Never could a more wonderful problem be presented.

abstract: The KELSEY family, by whom the auriferous qualities of American rivers in California were first discovered, had suffered much on a trip from Western Texas to Los Angeles from the Indians, who were associated with desperate whites. They robbed them of a quantity of provisions and a number of animals, and worse than all, a young girl of thirteen years was surprised by the Indians, made a prisoner, and left for dead on the road with the loss of her scalp. Strange to relate she did not die, and the little sufferer finally made out to rejoin the caravan.

abstract: The War Department has made the necessary orders to carry out the Act of Congress relative to allotments of pay. Hereafter the recruit, upon enrolling his name, has only to designate what proportion of his monthly stipend shall be given to his family, to have the necessary minute made, and the sum paid regularly. The step is an important one. Large numbers of very desirable men have turned away from the recruiting station, because the officer could give them no assurance as to provision for their families while they are absent on duty. Such assurance can now be had. It will be no difficult business for the families of needy volunteers, to obtain advances from friends and the charitable, on the strength of the allotment ticket, so that the means of support, may be made available from the very day the recruit has entered the ranks. If some organization, with small capital, could be framed for the purpose of saving the holders of such tickets from extortion and oppressive discounts, a still heavier weight of anxiety would be taken from the mind of the volunteer, and another inducement offered to enlistments.
lead_paragraph: The War Department has made the necessary orders to carry out the Act of Congress relative to allotments of pay. abstract: There was a large meeting of citizens, without distinction of party, at the Fifth Ward Hotel last evening, called for the purpose of giving expression to the sentiment of the residents of the lower Wards in relation to the present state of the country.
lead_paragraph: There was a large meeting of citizens, without distinction of party, at the Fifth Ward Hotel last evening, called for the purpose of giving expression to the sentiment of the residents of the lower Wards in relation to the present state of the country. The meeting was unanimously and enthusiastically in favor of a vigorous prosecution of the war for the crushing out of rebellion. The Chair was occupied by School Commissioner W.B. EAGER, and Mr. J.H. CANTRELL acted as Secretary. The principal speech was made by Gen. abstract: The will of Mrs. Susan Parish was on the 18th admitted to probate. She leaves to her brothers and to their wives and children her household furniture, horses and carriages, plate and jewelry.
lead_paragraph: The will of Mrs. Susan Parish was on the 18th admitted to probate. She leaves to her brothers and to their wives and children her household furniture, horses and carriages, plate and jewelry. To Mrs. Monson, widow of the late Judge Monson, and to her daughters, the only relations of Mr. Parish for whom she had not provided, and who had not taken part against the testatrix, the sum of $20,000. To various faithful servants annuities and gifts. To the vestry of Grace Church for its free chapel, $1,000. To the Ladies' Depository, $500. To the Society for the benefit of the newboys, $1,000. To the Five Points School Institution, by Mr. Pease, $1,000. The will then continues: "ITEM. -- I do hereby direct the Executors of my late husband, Henry Parish, to pay over to my brothers Joseph, Henry, Edward, Richard and Rufus H. Delafield, the sum or fund of $200,000, given to me by his will. ITEM. -- All the rest and residue of my estate I give to my said five brothers in equal proportions, share and share alike." She appoints her brothers, Joseph and Henry Delafield, and in case they do not act, her nephews, Lewis L. and Edward Delafield, executors. The instrument is dated March 21, 1861. Mrs. Parish was the widow of Henry Parish, a well known merchant, who died on the 2d of March, 1856, leaving an estate estimaed at about $1,300,000. His brothers were Daniel and James Parish, and his sisters, Ann Parish and Mrs. A.M. Sherman. By his will made in 1842 he left his wife $331,000, out of an estate valued at $732,000. The remainder of his estate he disposed of in legacies, leaving $36,000 to his brothers as residuary legatees. In 1849 he was attacked with paralysis, by which, in the words of the Surrogate, "he was not permanently deprived of testamentary capacity." Immediately after this attack he made a codicil by which he gave his wife property bearing about the same proportion to the value of his estate at this time as that which he had previously given her by his will in 1842. By a second codicil he increased his wife's portion to $730,000 out of an estate then valued at $1,060,000 and left $50,000 in charity.
