abstract: The British brig Mystery, of St. Johns, N.B., was seized by the Surveyor of this port as she was passing the Narrows inward, on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: The British brig Mystery, of St. Johns, N.B., was seized by the Surveyor of this port as she was passing the Narrows inward, on Sunday morning. The arrest was made upon information received from some parties who have been cognizant of her movements, and under the belief that she had been engaged in illegal commerce with some ports of the seceding States. By papers found on board, it is apparent that it was the original intention of the charterers to send a cargo of ice, with a small quantity of butter, to Georgetown, S.C., provided the port was not blockaded, and the time consumed in making the voyage from St. John to Havana, viz., from June 26 to Aug. 7 -- some forty days -- proves that considerable time was wasted somewhere between the two ports -probably in fruitless efforts to enter the port of Georgetown, S.C. Her clearance was dated at Boston and Charlestown Custom-house, June 20, certifying that THOMAS WADE is master of the brig, bound for Havana, with a cargo of merchandise. The following letters, found among the Captain's papers, describes the character of the proposed voyage and the cargo:

abstract: The extraordinary proceedings which have characterized the resignation of Capt. MANSFIELD LOVELL, Deputy Street Commissioner, and the appointment by Capt. G.W. SMITH, Street Commissioner, Of EDWARD EWEN, Esq., at present Superintendent of Street ...
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary proceedings which have characterized the resignation of Capt. MANSFIELD LOVELL, Deputy Street Commissioner, and the appointment by Capt. G.W. SMITH, Street Commissioner, Of EDWARD EWEN, Esq., at present Superintendent of Street improvements, which has just transpired, is likely to cause vexatious troubles and litigation in the Courts, the result being, as a matter of course, that the City will be called on to pay the costs of both sides. Mr. EWEN is particularly close-mouthed, desiring, as he says, not to complicate matters further than they now are by any expressions or declarations, which may affect the case when it shall come up for action. He, however, says that he knew nothing of Capt. LOVELL's resignation or of his own appointment, until Monday, when a package was handed to him, containing Capt. LOVELL's resignation, accepted by Capt. SMITH, and his own appointment.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday to consider the Tax Levy, which at the last meeting Mr. PUEDY assured members, he would press to a vote, but when the roll was called, Mr. PURDY's seat was found vacant. Mr. BLUNT, however, presented a minority report on the proposed reduction of taxes...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday to consider the Tax Levy, which at the last meeting Mr. PUEDY assured members, he would press to a vote, but when the roll was called, Mr. PURDY's seat was found vacant. Mr. BLUNT, however, presented a minority report on the proposed reduction of taxes differing in every essential particular from that of his colleague, Mr. ELY. It was a lengthy document, and advanced the opinion, supported by copious extracts of law, that the Supervisors have no right to reduce the tax levy, unless by reducing the regular county appropriations; that they have no right to inquire or determine whether the City appropriations are necessary or judicious, but they must raise the amount specified by the Legislature; and that it was injudicious to ask the heads of Departments whether reductions could be made, because whether the whole of an appropriation should be expended or not, depended alone upon the Common Council, who directed the Departments. The report concluded by recommending the adoption of the ordinance previously submitted by the Comptroller, levying the tax as stated in the enacting clause of the act passed by the Legislature.

abstract: There has been a decrease of over 21,000 in the number of European immigrants who have arrived at the port of New-York to the present date this year, as compared with the arrivals to the corresponding date of 1860  the figures being: in 1861, to the 18th inst., 56,466; in 1860, to the same period, 77,526. Nearly two-thirds (or 13,000) of this fallingoff is in the Irish element alone
lead_paragraph: There has been a decrease of over 21,000 in the number of European immigrants who have arrived at the port of New-York to the present date this year, as compared with the arrivals to the corresponding date of 1860 the figures being: in 1861, to the 18th inst., 56,466; in 1860, to the same period, 77,526. Nearly two-thirds (or 13,000) of this fallingoff is in the Irish element alone -- the Germans [???] behind their number of last year only some 3,000 souls. Up to the month of May the Irish emigration was considerably greater than it was to the same time last year, and bade fair then speedily to attain to something like the volume it reached in the Celtic flood-tide of 1857, and it is since that month that the great decrease, as compared with last year's arrivals, has taken place. At present the stream of humanity hitherward from Ireland is almost completely dried up. This may be due, in a partial degree, directly to the political perturbations; but it is undoubtedly owing much more to the scanty demand for labor, and to the doleful accounts doubtless sent home by the thousands of Irish laborers, railroaders, servant maids, &c., who have been thrown out of employment by the stagnation of business, the stoppage of public enterprises, and the collapse of incomes. In regard to the heavy arrival of German immigrants at this port, it must be borne in mind that there has been diverted hitherward by the blockade the whole of the large continental immigration which formerly entered the Mississippi Valley by way of New-Orleans and other Southern ports -- so that the probabilities are, that, taking the whole country, there has been quite as great a falling off in the Teutonic as in the Celtic migratory element.
headline: {'main': 'Falling Off in Immigration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Falling Off in Immigration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is quite evident that the proclamation of Gen. FREMONT in reference to the confiscation of the slaves of parties found in rebellion against the Government is not an important element in the difference between himself and the Administration. Whether this was or was not expedient or proper, it had nothing to do with the general conduct of the campaign, or the fitness of its commander for his most difficult and arduous duties. It was promptly disposed of by Mr. LINCOLN. Were there nothing beyond, we are confident that the Administration would be greatly relieved. That the kindest feeling, and unbounded confidence was felt toward General FREMONT, his recall from a foreign country where he was sojourning, and the great honors and vast responsibilities heaped upon him fully prove. We may presume that the personal relations between him and the President are as amicable as ever, for the latter is slow to withdraw confidence and esteem when once placed.

abstract: A DUEL WITH BROADSWORDS GAMBLERS AND THEIR HONOR. The sporting fraternity they who, arrayed in fine apparel, stand musingly upon Broadway corners; whose hirsute appendages are of the longest and sleekest, and whose manners are more than Chesterfieldian does not often allow itself to exhibit the vulgar excitement which marked it yesterday. The occasion of this disturbed equanimity, however, was excusable.
lead_paragraph: A DUEL WITH BROADSWORDS GAMBLERS AND THEIR HONOR. The sporting fraternity they who, arrayed in fine apparel, stand musingly upon Broadway corners; whose hirsute appendages are of the longest and sleekest, and whose manners are more than Chesterfieldian does not often allow itself to exhibit the vulgar excitement which marked it yesterday. The occasion of this disturbed equanimity, however, was excusable. Two of its members had fought a duel by the early morning light, and offended honor had been appeased. The weapons, broadswords, and the place, romantic and secluded -- McComb's Dam, on the banks of the Harlem River. In the street your real gambler is ever taciturn upon professional topics, except to his colaborers, and where so important a thing as "a meeting" is concerned, involving unpleasant consequences to the participants, it is to be expected that he will be almost mute. Therefore, reticence was the rule yesterday, but from "another source" we obtained the story of the affair. The names of the principals are BOB WILLIS and SAMUEL HYMAN. WILLIS keeps a salon at No. 540 Broadway; HYMAN, who is recently from New-Orleans, acts as a decoy. A few evenings since a dispute arose between them respecting the way in which a "green one" had been "plucked." HYMAN demanded of WILLIS that a large portion of the money should be restored, but WILLIS was not willing to make restitution to the extent which had been named. A challenge was the result, but from which our informant could not say. It was accepted, and the preliminaries having been arranged according to the code, the meeting occurred yesterday morning in presence of at least two dozen friends of the principals. The weapons were broad-swords or sabres, and both men are said to have fought bravely. Neither was over skillful, but WILLIS' impetuosity won him the victory. The contest was very brief -- HYMAN having received two wounds, one on the forearm and the other on the knee, which were sufficiently severe to disable him. He was immediately brought to his residence in a carriage, while the others returned to the City by different routes as quietly as possible. WILLIS escaped even a scratch. We have not heard that any attempt will be made to arrest him.

abstract: We have highly important intelligence from Missouri. The rebel Gen. PRICE, who evacuated Boonville, attacked Lexington on Monday, but was repulsed by the National forces, after suffering severe loss. Gen. LANE is reported marching to the relief of Lexington with nearly 3,000 men. On Monday, Gen. PRICE summoned Gen. MULLIGAN to surrender, to which Gen. MULLIGAN profanely replied, "Go to Hell." We have no news of the death of Gen. PRICE. BEN MCCULLOCH was marching on the Osage Bridge, eleven miles east of Jefferson City.

abstract: A mass meeting of the citizens of the Twenty, first Ward, irrespective of party, was held at Broadway Hall last night, when the following permanent organization was effected favorable to the Union Ticket adopted at Syracuse, and to the vigorous prosecution of the war to perpetuate the Union: President, A.V. STOUT, Dem.; Vice-Presidents, GARRET L. SCHUYLER, Rep., HENRY W. DAVIDS, Union, RICHARD F. CARMAN, Dem.; Executive Committee composed of one from each Election District in the Ward, and also a Committee on Resolutions were appointed. The membership was divided equitably among the political parties represented. The meeting adjourned to Wednesday evening next at the same place.

abstract: COLLISION BETWEEN FERRY-BOATS. A violent collision occurred between one of the Pavonia-avenue ferry-boats and the Paterson, of the Hoboken line, early on Wednesday evening, by which the latter was badly damaged.
lead_paragraph: COLLISION BETWEEN FERRY-BOATS. A violent collision occurred between one of the Pavonia-avenue ferry-boats and the Paterson, of the Hoboken line, early on Wednesday evening, by which the latter was badly damaged. The boats were crossing the river in opposite directions, and the bow of the Pavonia-avenue boat struck the wheel-house and crushed in the gentlemen's cabin, breaking into quite large timbers. There were but few passengers on board and no one was injured. It is stated that the engine of the Pavonia-avenue boat was not stopped until after the collision.

abstract: The letterfrom Mr. FREDERICK FOLLETT, which we publish to-day, has a clear, metalic ring that falls pleasantly on the ear. Though a Democrat of the straitest sort, the writer proves himself a patriot such as the country needs now. Unlike the partisan leaders who met at Syracuse on the 4th, he has been able to comprehend the fact that devotion to the country is of higher obligation than mere fealty to party, and that when the Union is imperiled, political associations, party affinities, all the prejudices and antagonisms growing out of conflicts over the dead issues of the past, should be forgotten in the higher duty of saving it from dismemberment. With Tammany attacking them in front and Mozart in the rear, while such Democrats as DICKINSON, TREMAIN, and FOLLETT, are thundering on either flank, we suspect the framers of the Syracuse resolutions will begin to think they may have mistaken the sentiment of the Democratic masses.

lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held their regular meeting yesterday. The Street Commissioner was directed to have the carriage-way of the Ninth-avenue Railroad Company repaired at the expense of the Company. Mr. EWEN sent in his first official communication, as Deputy Street Commissioner, in answer to a resolution of inquiry as to the condition of the Fourth-avenue pavement, stating that this subject properly belonged to the Croton Department. The sum of $1,000 was appropriated for a portrait and frame of Ex-Governor HORATIO SEYMOUR, and the same sum for a portrait of Ex-Governor MYRON H. CLARK.

abstract: From the regular weekly statistical report to the Commissioners yesterday, it appears that there remained in the various Institutions on the 7th inst., 8,229 inmates; admitted since, 2,310; making a total of 10,539. Of these, 2,312 had been sent to the Island or State Prison, discharged, or died, leaving at present 8,227 in charge of the Commission, which is a decrease of only two. The next regular semi-monthly meeting of the Board should be held next Thursday, but that being the general Fast day, some change will doubtless be made, to meet the occasion.

abstract: Yesterday, great fear was experienced that a serious disturbance would take place on the Battery. It appears that the Elmira Regiment, Col. STEWART, was assigned a portion of the Battery, on which to erect the tents for the accommodation of the men during their stay in this City.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, great fear was experienced that a serious disturbance would take place on the Battery. It appears that the Elmira Regiment, Col. STEWART, was assigned a portion of the Battery, on which to erect the tents for the accommodation of the men during their stay in this City. This the Fire Zouaves objected to, as they already had possession, and ordered Col. STEWART to withdraw his men within an hour. To this Col. STEWART pad no attention, but ordered his men to proceed to pitch their tents. Seeing this, the Zouaves made a rush and endeavored to break through the lines, but were repulsed at the point of the bayonet. The Elmira regiment has at present only a few old muskets -- these the Colonel gave orders to have loaded, and for those men, who had them, to load their revolvers. This was done.

abstract: Much more activity is now observable on Governor's Island than was the case a short time ago. The recruits for general service of whom there are two full companies are drilled three times a day in company drill. Hitherto they have been drilled twice a day only. This looks as though they will shortly be required elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Much more activity is now observable on Governor's Island than was the case a short time ago. The recruits for general service of whom there are two full companies are drilled three times a day in company drill. Hitherto they have been drilled twice a day only. This looks as though they will shortly be required elsewhere. No orders on this subject, however, have yet been received.

abstract: The Engineer Regiment, commanded by Col. CHARLES B. STUART, which has been encamped at Elmira since August, arrived in this City yesterday morning via the Erie Railroad.
lead_paragraph: The Engineer Regiment, commanded by Col. CHARLES B. STUART, which has been encamped at Elmira since August, arrived in this City yesterday morning via the Erie Railroad. The regiment numbers about 1,000 men, made up mostly of mechanics of various kinds, engineers, machinists, &c. Col. STUART is a civil engineer of eminence, and served several years as State Engineer. The Lieutenant-Colonel is a graduate of West Point, and the Major has seen service as Lieutenant of the Eleventh Pennsylvania Volunteers. On the arrival of the regiment they were marched down Broadway to the Battery, where they will encamp, until ordered to the seat of war, which will probably be in a few days. The following are the officers of the regiment:

abstract: Martin W. Brett vs. The Bark Laura. -- In this case the proceeds of the vessel being in court, to the amount of several thousand dollars, Mr. Benedict, for the libelants, applied to the Court for an order to have the fund invested in the Government Loan. He stated that he had consulted his clients, and that they were heartily willing that this course should be taken. Judge Beebe, who appeared for the claimants of the vessel, stated that his clients also approved of the motion, and the Judge accordingly directed the order to be entered, to have the fund so invested in the Government Loan, on such consent of the parties.

abstract: The destiny that has hunted the Aboriginal tribes of this country to their destruction, will not be retarded by the fact that some of those still remaining have been induced to engage in a war against the Government that has protected them.
lead_paragraph: The destiny that has hunted the Aboriginal tribes of this country to their destruction, will not be retarded by the fact that some of those still remaining have been induced to engage in a war against the Government that has protected them. Above and beyond the infamy which must rest upon the rebel States on account of the employment of such allies, is the heartless and cruel selfishness of imposing upon the ignorance and credulity of these savage people, of tempting them into a course that can only end in their extinction, however the present rebellion may terminate. Humanity is shocked at the employment of such barbarous instrumentalities in these enlightened times, as well as at the terrible recoil which must follow upon the Indians themselves when the war shall be over. From the first landing of white men upon this Continent, the Indian tribes have been moving back or perishing before the civilization they inaugurated. In all the New-England States there is not a single tribe left, and that they ever existed there, history and tradition alone inform us. Like the deer, the elk, the wolf, and the panther, they have disappeared as the fields advanced and the old forests were swept away. In New-York are the fragmentary remains of once powerful tribes that reckoned their warriors by thousands, decreasing in number every year and becoming bleached and changed by the constant admixture of European blood.
headline: {'main': 'The Indian Allies of Secession.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Indian Allies of Secession.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped in the Quarantine grounds for some time past, has been rapidly filling up, and is now nearly completed. They expect soon to receive marching orders. Since their encampment at Staten Island they have elicited much praise from the citizens for their general excellent deportment and quiet disposition. They particularly deserve great credit for their untiring exertions at the disastrous fire of the 9th, at Quarantine. The following card from the citizens shows their appreciation of the regiment and its services.

abstract: The extraordinary exhibit presented by the records of the commerce of the Port of New-York for the first eight months of the year, is but the legitimate evidence of the financial or material condition of the country. In this period we have been subjected to the severest test a nation can undergo, with a most triumphant result, without the least warning or preparation. With the trade of nearly one-half of our country a blank, we found ourselves, when the day of reckoning came, the creditor nation of the world. Our completecommercial independence is owing to the fact that the world must have what we produce in agriculture, while we can easily dispense with whatever other countries produce, either in agriculture or in the arts. None of the nations of Eastern Europe regularly raise a sufficient supply of food -- Great Britain never. The United States is their granary, for the reason that, from the cheapness of production, they can undersell all other nations. We have the advantage of cheap soil, which has been accumulating fertility since the creation, and avenues for moving its crops to market vastly superior to that of any other nation. The natural fertility of our soil is an estate really exceeding in value the wealth possessed by any other country in the world. In some portions of the country, the same crop has been produced on the same soil a half century in succession, with hardly a perceptible diminution in the yield. The vast prairies of Illinois are planted year after year, without the least evidence of an exhausted strength. They are a placer infinitely richer than the mines of California. Their products count by hundreds of millions of bushels. The cost of producing Indian Corn on them will hardly exceed ten cents the bushel; that of Wheat not more than fifty. Illinois is only a good specimen of the West, and does not excel many other States in wheat. They are all so fertile that in breadstuffs and provisions they are the favored spot of the world, and can always drive a competitor out of the markets of Western Europe, by underselling him at a profit. The production of food is the specialty of our people, just as the production of iron is that of England, wines and silks of France, and sugar of the fervid regions of the tropics. We might as well attempt to rival other nations, whose superiority depends upon natural gifts not possessed by ourselves, as for them to take from us the superiority in cheapness of food.

abstract: We have published two notices of meetings held at the St. Nicholas Hotel by prominent merchants and business men, having in view the Union of all parties in the coming election to nominate candidates for City and County offices, without regard to party, and with sole reference to their honesty, capability and fitness for office. Since this movement originated another organization has arisen, purporting to have the same objects in view, and their first general meeting was held at the Fifth-avenue Hotel last evening. About two hundred gentlemen were present, comprising a large number of prominent merchants and business men, and no very small sprinkling of politicians. Ex-Mayor TIEMANN was elected Chairman, and a Committee was appointed, of which Ex-Judge PIERREPONT was Chairman, to draft resolutions. During the absence of the Committee speeches were made upon National and City matters, the war, &c., by P.M. WETMORE, Esq., Hon. A. WAKEMAN. Ex-Alderman MURPHY, RICHARD B. CONNOLLY and others -- all containing patriotic sentiments, urging a vigorous prosecution of the war, and favoring a union of all parties. In aid of the General Government, and for the nomination of fit men for City offices.

abstract: The privateer Sumter, after leading us a chase as adventurous as that of the Flying Dutchman, turns up at length at Trinidad. She had turned up previously at various other places. Thus we have news of her appearance at a Venezuelan port -- Puerto Cabello -- on the 27th of July, whither she came bringing a prize schooner and sent officers on shore to ask permission of the authorities to be allowed to sell the said prize at public auction. After taking some time todeliberate over the matter, the answer was returned that the authorities had decided to preserve a strict neutrality, and could, therefore, only give her an asylum for twenty-four hours, when she must leave. A fortnight after she turns up at Surinam. Surinam, everybody knows, is a Dutch possession. The Dutch have made no pompous proclamation of neutrality. Nevertheless, on arriving at this island and making a request for coal, of which the Sumter was then short, the Government refused to supply her. It is reported that she then threatened to fire upon the town -- a threat which, however, she did not venture to execute, probably for the very good reason that the fort, menacingly near, would have blown the Sumter out of the water.
lead_paragraph: The privateer Sumter, after leading us a chase as adventurous as that of the Flying Dutchman, turns up at length at Trinidad. She had turned up previously at various other places. abstract: The prosecution of the Slave-trade out of our Northern ports has received another severe blow in the condemnation and forfeiture of the bark Augusta for being engaged in that traffic.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution of the Slave-trade out of our Northern ports has received another severe blow in the condemnation and forfeiture of the bark Augusta for being engaged in that traffic. Judge SHIPMAN's opinion in the case is found in full in our columns this morning. The bark, it appears, was being fitted out at Greenport, L.I., when she was seized. One APPLEY claimed to own her, and APPLETON OAKSMITH, of this City, formerly connected with some alleged fillibustering enterprises out of this port, and more lately a publisher and printer here, appeared to have acted as his agent in the matter. These parties, alleged, that so far from intending to make a voyage for "black birds," they were only going after black-fish; that the voyage was a whaling-voyage; that the vessel was an old whaler, and her outfit only such as was appropriate to a perfectly honest character. There seemed, to the Judge, however, to be some circumstances of suspicion about her, which led him to believe that she was not intended for a whaler. The whole trade is in a very depressed state, requiring great care, skill and economy to make it a very profitable one, while these parties had no experience in the matter. The parties stated that they had proposed to send the Augusta on a short cruise of fifteen months, while it appeared that such voyages were almost entirely given up in the trade, and that the Augusta was altogether too large for such a voyage, for, from her size, she required too many hands to navigate her, which would make the voyage too expensive to be by any possibility profitable. Then, also, there had been no steps taken to engage competent officers for a whaling voyage, although the time of her departure was near at hand. Moreover, her provisions were suspicious. She was greatly deficient in the supply of many articles absolutely necessary for a whaling voyage; and there was a superabundance of many articles especially adapted for a slave voyage. The greater part of the beef on board was more or less tainted, though enough of it was sweet to supply a crew for a short voyage, such as a slave voyage would be. The claimants explained this singular fact about the beef, by saying that they had bought a lot cheap, which required repacking, and meant to have had it repacked after the vessel went to sea, and as she had been detained it had spoiled; but they did not prove where they bought this lot, nor why they did not save it by repacking it after the vessel was seized, if that was all that was necessary to save it. Furthermore, the bark had on board an uncommon number of casks of water, and though some of them had oil in them, yet it was shown that this would not prevent the use of the water, though it would make it unpalatable.

abstract: THEFT OF A GOLD WATCH. A German peddler, named JACOB GOLDSTEIN, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of stealing a gold watch and chain, valued...
lead_paragraph: THEFT OF A GOLD WATCH. A German peddler, named JACOB GOLDSTEIN, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of stealing a gold watch and chain, valued at $125, from BERNARD SPRINCE, residing in Grand-street. SPRINCE, it appears, was playing cards in his house, and GOLDSTEIN was watching the game. By some means, the chain which held SPRINCE's watch became loosened from his vest, and GOLDSTEIN, as charged, slyly drew the watch from his pocket and then left. The property was missed soon afterwards, and suspicion fell upon GOLDSTEIN, who, on being arrested, was locked up for examination.

abstract: If any doubt remains as to the terrorism beneath which the loyal sentiment of the South is smothered, it may be cured by reference to our California advices. From Texas, through wild tribes of Indians and over deserts, the Unionists are finding their way to the Pacific, telling tales, as they arrive, of the fierce persecution behind them, and of the tenacity with which their fellows, who still linger about their homes, cling to their old national tradition and flag. This in Texas, the remotest of the revolted States. The patriots who are clamoring for peace at the expense of the Union may perhaps define the right and equity by which they consign those Southerners, whose loyalty so bitterly tried is found perfect, to the tyranny of self-elected anarchs and traitors. If no other motive impelled the Government to a relentless prosecution of the war, its obligation to Southern loyalists would be sufficient.

abstract: Some English journals, notorious for their hostility to liberal politics, din us from day to day with doleful statements concerning the expense of the conflict to the North. They forget that the white population of the South, with less wealth and smaller numbers, have an equal pressure to sustain. President DAVIS, in his last Message, refers to the abundant crops with which the South has been blessed. But even if the supply of corn be equal to two years' consumption of the population, how are the people to buy it, if their industry is oppressed by severe taxation and an interruption of the channels of trade? A loan in cotton is a costly and awkward substitute for a loan in cash; and if the war lasts only a portion of the "three or five years" thought possible by the Secessionist chief, England, their principal customer, will have found other sources of supply, and will not go back to the markets she has left on anything like the old terms. Mr. DAVIS speaks of the demands of the "large and increased expenditure for the support of the Army," and of the great numbers who flock to join its ranks. The first statement indicates the early advent of financial pressure, and the second tells of a population which has no other work to do. "Calm and sublime devotion" to negro Slavery is a burlesque of sentiment, and will certainly not cause "sacrifices to be made from year to year with unfaltering purpose." Of genuine public spirit the South may have its share; but the bulk of the planters are not fighting for an idea, but for the sheer act of their property being in "niggers," and endangered by the free principles which are avowed, if not practiced, in the North. A sense of weakness is also shown in the constant hankering after European aid. England, they pretend, must come to their rescue to prevent the stoppage of Manchester mills, and Prince NAPOLEON was invested with a mission to examine into the state of affairs, and indicate to his cousin the best moment for acknowledging the Confederation of the South. The fact is, neither party can afford the collision they have provoked; and if the New-York merchant is punished in credit and in purse, we may be sure that the negro driving planter is much nearer the road to ruin than the way to wealth.

abstract: The Collector has made very large seizures of brandy, which was originally shipped from Bordeaux, in July and August last, to New-Orleans and other rebel ports before the blockade was declared.
lead_paragraph: The Collector has made very large seizures of brandy, which was originally shipped from Bordeaux, in July and August last, to New-Orleans and other rebel ports before the blockade was declared. On arriving at the mouth of the Mississippi they were ordered away, and coming to New-York, sought to enter their cargoes. Mr. HOFFMAN informed the applicants that they would have to produce consular certificates, showing that the goods were not the property of parties residing in rebel States. The cargoes were thus delayed and stored in the bonded warehouse. Meantime, information has been received which shows the property to have been liable to seizure, on the grounds suspected by the Deputy Collector. If proof is made that the property belongs to French citizens, it will be released. This has been done in two instances. One vessel, the David, has gone to Philadelphia, where she will no doubt be looked after.

abstract: The rebels have not yet made their promised demonstration against the National lines on the Potomac, and the chance of their doing so appears every day to be growing less.
lead_paragraph: The rebels have not yet made their promised demonstration against the National lines on the Potomac, and the chance of their doing so appears every day to be growing less. They yesterday confined their operations to firing upon our pickets, in which Christian amusement they appear to have come off second best, as several of them were wounded by the return fire of our pickets, none of whom were hurt.

abstract: A Special Meeting of this Board was held yesterday, for the purpose of taking final action on the Tax Levy. Nearly an hour was passed in a some-...
lead_paragraph: A Special Meeting of this Board was held yesterday, for the purpose of taking final action on the Tax Levy. Nearly an hour was passed in a somewhat acrimonious debate, Mr. PURDY complaining of assertions in the minority report presented by Mr. BLUNT, and finally other members took part in a debate which extended so wide of the questions before the Board, that points of order were raised, but at length the tax levy was reached, Mr. TWEED having made a motion to take it up item by item, and if no objection was made, the item as read should be considered as adopted. The County tax levy, amounting to $2,675 05, was passed without discussion, as was the State tax, amounting to $2,108,635. The City tax was then taken up seriatim. Mr. ELY, as the items were read, moved the reduction as recommended in his report, taking the street-cleaning contract as a test question, from which he proposed to deduct $30,000. This being lost by a vote of 4 to 8, he offered no further objection to the other items which he had proposed to reduce, and the whole tax levy for City purposes, as directed by the Legislature to be raised, was finally passed, footing up a total of $6,534,822 -- and a grand total to be raised by tax of $11,318,514, being an increase of $1,566,006 50 over the taxes of 1860.

abstract: Capt. EDWARD BOOTH, of the bark Buckeye, which left this port in May, 1860, for the coast of Africa, and subsequently landed a cargo of slaves on the Island of Cuba, was arrested, yesterday, by United States Marshal MURRAY, and committed to the Toombs to await an examination, which will take place at 11 o'clock this morning. He was taken into custody just as he was about starting home in a boat for Greenport, L.I. He had made an engagement to go out as Captain of the bark Augusta, recently condemned as a Slave-trading craft. Two seamen, who lately arrived on the United States ship Sumter, from the coast of Africa, and who formerly served on board the slavers Nightingale and Wm. R. Kibby were also arrested yesterday as witnesses, and committed to the house of Detention.

abstract: This vessel has been ordered up from Quarantine, and her Captain, THOS. WADE, and his brother, the mate, have been examined pretty closely at the Surveyor's office -- an operation which has afforded some little amusement on account of both the Captain and his brother being inveterate [???], which, the Captain says, runs in the family. Their story that the voyage to Havana occupied 39 days, during which his cargo of 200 tons of ice melted to 80 tons, is not so improbable, if we except the great length of the trip; and there have been examples of as long voyages as this in slow-sailing vessels before. It is plain that if the suspected vessel had run the blockade at all, she would not have carried a mere fraction of the cargo to Cuba. The only proof against the vessel is presumptive, and depends upon the letter found on board, which the Captain, if he had regarded of any consequence, would no doubt have destroyed before coming into port. The voyage appears to have been a losing one.

abstract: Prince NAPOLEON visited the Brooklyn Navyyard yesterday quite unexpectedly. He was conveyed there in a very small propeller, the Mouche, not much larger than an ordinary first cutter, which is attached to the yacht Jerome Napoleon.
lead_paragraph: Prince NAPOLEON visited the Brooklyn Navyyard yesterday quite unexpectedly. He was conveyed there in a very small propeller, the Mouche, not much larger than an ordinary first cutter, which is attached to the yacht Jerome Napoleon. As the authorities were not aware of his intended visit, there was no one in readiness to receive him, but as soon as it was known that his Imperial Highness had arrived, Commodore BREESE and Capt. ALMEY waited upon him, and conducted him round the yard, pointing out everything of interest. The Prince spent an hour and a half inspecting the various works now in progress, and appeared to be much gratified with the result of his visit. On his departure all the marines in the barracks turned out, and the band of the North Carolina played "Partant pour le Syrie," and other French as well as American airs. The Prince was accompanied by his Aide-de-Camp and the captain of the Jerome Napoleon.

abstract: the notice issued by Postmaster TAYLOR, the time allowed for the exchange of postage stamps expires to-day. The people have unanimously acquiesced in the necessity of rendering useless the stamps scattered through the rebel States, and have done their utmost to comply with the conditions declared indispensable to this end; but the cue attached to the cashier's window at the Post-office yesterday evening, was twice as long as that formed there on Monday, and this fact alone shows how ludicrously short was the time fixed for the transaction of such an amount of business as this exchange of stamps involved.

headline: {'main': 'THE GREAT REBELLION.; Highly Important News from Missouri. Additional Particulars of the Battle at Lexington. Desperate Attacks of the Rebel Forces. abstract: Thedemonstration last evening, in favor of the People's ticket and platform, responded to all reasonable expectations. The people were in attendance in numbers large enough to authorize the use of their name; and if there were less speaking than usual, it was because of the universal conviction that the stimulus of oratory is no longer needed. The address of Mr. D.S. DICKINSON partook of the ardent patriotic qualities which have marked that gentleman's support of the Government, from the day he came to understand the treasonable aims of his old political associates, and manfully separated himself from them forever. Terse, vigorous, fervid -- characteristically larded with quotations -- it utters with singular fidelity what everybody is just now thinking and feeling. It is very likely that a meeting less imperfectly organized and confusedly conducted might have had a better effect; but enough was demonstrated to show the entire unanimity of public sentiment.

abstract: Time is always necessary to disclose the real significance and effect of any act or event. An apparent misfortune may be far from being one; while success is often a prelude to a disastrous defeat.
lead_paragraph: Time is always necessary to disclose the real significance and effect of any act or event. An apparent misfortune may be far from being one; while success is often a prelude to a disastrous defeat. Our present strength is the result of the Bull Run disaster -- the unfortunate position of the rebels the result of their victory. Upon every principle of war they should have been in Washington a week after the battle. To delay the assault till we recovered our losses, and accumulated such a force as to render attack, not only upon that city, but any movement with a view of crossing the Potomac too hazardous to be attempted, was to lose a crowning advantage, and to suffer all the consequences of a disastrous defeat.

abstract: The time is certainly very unpropitious for such a step. Indeed no period could have been selected when the intentions of the Home Government, ...
lead_paragraph: The time is certainly very unpropitious for such a step. Indeed no period could have been selected when the intentions of the Home Government, -- whatever they may be, -- were so liable to be misunderstood. The speed which we draughted, five or six weeks ago, soldiers and artillery to Quebec by the Great Eastern was a nine days' wonder; but this last movement is still more unaccountable, and, in the judgment of people who have nothing to guide them but the ordinary intelligence open to the world, a blunder of an extremely irritating kind. If Parliament were sitting, a day would not have been allowed to pass without eliciting from the Treasury Bench an explanation of an act so puzzling and incomprehensible, but as we grope about for a solution of the cause, we arrive at a conviction of the wisdom of the Swedish Chancellor, who told his son, when going on his travels, to observe the ease with which the world was governed -- a process in which blundering appears to be an essential element.

abstract: The contractor for building the new Courthouse, J.C. TUCKER, Esq., commenced yesterday to fence in the ground appropriated for its site in the Park, viz.: 300 feet in length by 200 in depth, extending back so as to inclose the old bell-tower. It shuts off several paths, and of course will necessitate the cutting down of many fine trees. The high board fence which is being erected, is anything but an ornament to the Park, but is necessary to keep idlers and loafers away from the work. It will be a long time before those accustomed to pass through the Park for so many years, will be able to reconcile themselves to the change.

abstract: Alfred Havermeyer et al. vs. John A. Cunningham, et al. This was an action to recover damages for the non-performance of an alleged contract of sale for the transfer of a large quantity of sugar.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Havermeyer et al. vs. John A. Cunningham, et al. This was an action to recover damages for the non-performance of an alleged contract of sale for the transfer of a large quantity of sugar. The case is of some interest, commercially, as it turns upon the question whether or not contracts for the sale of goods or merchandise "to arrive," pass any property in the goods so named, and the further question whether the words "to arrive" amount to a stipulation on the part of the party vending, or contracting to vend, that they shall arrive, -- whether they are words of express warranty.

lead_paragraph: An application was made in the United States District Court, on Thursday by the parties to a litigation pending there, in relation to a fund which had been deposited in the registry of the Court, that the fund, instead of remaining there, should be invested in the Government loan. Judge SHIPMAN said it should appear to be by the consent of all parties, as it was an innovation upon former practice, but, as that fact did appear, he directed that the fund should be so invested.

abstract: With the intent of ratifying the People's Union State Ticket, nominated at Syracuse on the 10th and 11th inst., a vast meeting assembled at Cooper Insti-
lead_paragraph: With the intent of ratifying the People's Union State Ticket, nominated at Syracuse on the 10th and 11th inst., a vast meeting assembled at Cooper Institute last evening. The building could not contain the thousands who flocked to testify their devotion to the Union, and from this cause the streets in the vicinity swarmed with the disappointed. The entrance to the platform, at the side door on Fourth-avenue, was the scene of no little chagrin. A strong force of policemen guarded the passage, and, with vigorous muscle and ready baton, sought to exclude all unauthorized distinguished guests. They found this no easy task, as several sets of tickets of admission had been issued, and several cliques of committeemen insisted each on its peculiar ticket as the genuine simon pure. The red ticket men were particularly severe on the white ticket-holders. It was the old war of the Roses renewed -- York against Lancaster. The last of the tricolors was supplied by the feelings of the ejected, for while the tickets were red and white, they were decidedly blue. Certainly such an incongruous assemblage never before crowded the platform. It was asserted that the white tickets were freely distributed on the corners of the adjacent streets, and the places of the legitimate red ticket invited guests were filled by the canaille. Certainly the proportion of men of note occupying the platform was quite below the usual standard -- as to numbers. A number of ladies agreeably dotted the dense plane of black coats.

abstract: However well armed the rebel forces in Vir ginia may be, there is little doubt that they are poorly off in respect to clothing and shoes two articles which are nearly as important to the efficiency of an army as arms are.
lead_paragraph: However well armed the rebel forces in Vir ginia may be, there is little doubt that they are poorly off in respect to clothing and shoes two articles which are nearly as important to the efficiency of an army as arms are. The Richmond Whig states that soldiers have been taken out of the ranks to work in making army clothing, and Richmond merchants urge that every soldier who is a shoemaker should be at once discharged and set to making canvas shoes. In the cold and wet of the approaching Fall and Winter, the lack of these articles will be much more injurious to the rebels than it has been thus far, but we may be very sure that nothing but the keenest sense of necessity would induce them to supply that lack by taking men out of the ranks. To be sure, if all the shoemakers and tailors were taken out of their Army, it would not be so much felt as if that Army had been recruited from Lynn or from Williamsburgh, but with the dread of seacoast attacks urging them to attack MCCLELLAN -- an undertaking which will call for the utmost expenditure of means and the largest gathering of their forces -- we may be sure that they would not allow of the departure of a sisgle man from their ranks to make coats and shoes, but for the knowledge that this was the only way to prevent a much more severe diminution of their forces by disease.

abstract: CONVENTION OF CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATIONS.  A Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations of the United States is about to meet to consider the propriety of united and energetic action to more effectually supply the Army with religious reading matter and comforts and delicacies for the hospitals.
lead_paragraph: CONVENTION OF CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATIONS. A Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations of the United States is about to meet to consider the propriety of united and energetic action to more effectually supply the Army with religious reading matter and comforts and delicacies for the hospitals. Heretofore but few of these societies have acted, and if others would join them and the whole act unitedly, greater good could be done by this means than almost any other. Societies are organized of able and unemployed young men in nearly every large city of the Union, and as they acted usefully at other times, as in the yellow fever panics at Norfolk and New-Orleans, and during the revival in 1857, and as yet have scarcely begun to move in this war, there is no good reason why they should not wake up and render effectual and powerful aid in this crisis. The leading societies of New-York, Philadelphia, and Boston have been consulted, and agreed to send able delegates, and other cities will doubtless respond as they can be heard from.

abstract: The citizens of Hempstead, Rockville, Centre, Near Rockaway, Far Rockaway, and Jamaica, are practically taking steps to extend the Brooklyn Central and Jamaica Railroad East, from the village of Jamaica, so that railroad communication direct shall exist between South Ferry, Brooklyn, and the Rockaway bench. On Saturday last, a preliminary meeting was held at Rockaway, to consider the subject. Subsequent meetings were resolved upon, to be held at Jamaica. Those who were active and foremost in this enterprise give the assurance that property owners along the route of the contemplated extension will not only give the roadway and depot lots, but that they will subscribe liberally for the stock. The extension can be constructed at small cost -- the whole route being nearly a level grade.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington indicate a very dull time there, yesterday, in the military way  the only item worth mentioning being the killing  of three or four of our pickets by the rebels, near the Chain Bridge. They belonged to the Second Michigan Regiment. Last night, at dusk, Gen. McCLELLAN went over the river into Virginia, but his visit was probably only one of observation.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington indicate a very dull time there, yesterday, in the military way the only item worth mentioning being the killing of three or four of our pickets by the rebels, near the Chain Bridge. They belonged to the Second Michigan Regiment. Last night, at dusk, Gen. McCLELLAN went over the river into Virginia, but his visit was probably only one of observation. It is expected that he will soon have added to his Staff the Count DE PARIS and the Duc DE CHARTRES, whose military services have been tendered to the Government and accepted. Major BUSENWEIN, late Aid-de-Camp to GARIBALDI, has also been commissioned. No definite action with regard to the case of Gen. FREMONT has yet been taken by the Government.

abstract: The Commissioners now engaged in revising the Charter of this City lately solicited suggestions, in the line of improvement or reform, from the officials in charge of the various Bureaus of the Municipal Government.
lead_paragraph: The Commissioners now engaged in revising the Charter of this City lately solicited suggestions, in the line of improvement or reform, from the officials in charge of the various Bureaus of the Municipal Government. Mr. DELAVAN, of the City Inspector's Department, has already responded for his branch, in a characteristic report -- characterized, we mean, by those small assaults on the medical profession, and on the rules of grammar, which are chronic with him -- but which contains, nevertheless, some good suggestions for the organization into one Health Department of the various bodies which now nominally attend to the sanitary interests of New-York. Good in the main, we mean, and as far as they go -- though the Inspector has certain prejudices, enmities and interests which perhaps prevent him from treating some parts of the subject with perfect justice and disinterestedness.

abstract: Col. LORIN ANDREWS, late President of Kenyon College, died, in Gambier, O., on Sept. 18. Col. ANDREWS was born in Vermont, but was brought up in Ohio, receiving his education at the institution of which he subsequently became President. To his untiring energy the people owe much for their excellent public school system. Upon the breaking out of the rebellion he joined a company raised in Gambier as a private. When it was organized he received the captaincy, and on the formation of the Fourth Ohio Regiment he was elected Colonel. He contracted the camp fever while on service in Western Virginia, and returned home, where his disease assumed the typhoid form, and terminated fatally on the 18th.
lead_paragraph: Col. LORIN ANDREWS, late President of Kenyon College, died, in Gambier, O., on Sept. 18. Col. He contracted the camp fever while on service in Western Virginia, and returned home, where his disease assumed the typhoid form, and terminated fatally on the 18th.

abstract: The recently reported victory of Gen. ROSECRANS over FLOYD, in Western Virginia, at the battle of Carnifex Ferry, turns out to be, after all, a very indecisive and unsatisfactory one. After a gap had been left in our lines, to afford FLOYD an opportunity for an entrance, for the purpose of entrapping him and capturing his command, the rebel General has been allowed to slip off, after a battle, with little substantial harm, leaving to our troops only a few barren trophies, and the nominal honor of a victory. The very brief report of Gen. ROSECRANS offers no adequate explanation of this unsuccessful result; but the full reports received from other sources throw a very distinct light upon the subject.
lead_paragraph: The recently reported victory of Gen. ROSECRANS over FLOYD, in Western Virginia, at the battle of Carnifex Ferry, turns out to be, after all, a very indecisive and unsatisfactory one. After a gap had been left in our lines, to afford FLOYD an opportunity for an entrance, for the purpose of entrapping him and capturing his command, the rebel General has been allowed to slip off, after a battle, with little substantial harm, leaving to our troops only a few barren trophies, and the nominal honor of a victory. The very brief report of Gen. ROSECRANS offers no adequate explanation of this unsuccessful result; but the full reports received from other sources throw a very distinct light upon the subject.

abstract: Why should we have any Fort Lafayette, if MAGOFFIN and BRECKINRIDGE, of Kentucky, be not invited speedily to enter its precincts? That prison fortress has now a taste of traitors, and it literally yawns for the coming of these two men.
lead_paragraph: Why should we have any Fort Lafayette, if MAGOFFIN and BRECKINRIDGE, of Kentucky, be not invited speedily to enter its precincts? That prison fortress has now a taste of traitors, and it literally yawns for the coming of these two men. There will be no poetic justice in punishment, until its portals are opened wide and the prince of rebels enters in.

abstract: Mr.  THOMAS BAZLEY, who enlightened the recent social science gathering at Dublin with his views upon cotton, has scattered others of his rays upon the deliberations of the Association for the Advancement of Science, in session at Manchester. The scope of his argument remains without alteration.
lead_paragraph: Mr. THOMAS BAZLEY, who enlightened the recent social science gathering at Dublin with his views upon cotton, has scattered others of his rays upon the deliberations of the Association for the Advancement of Science, in session at Manchester. The scope of his argument remains without alteration. Mr. BAZLEY believes that England cannot too soon render itself independent of American caprice and hostility; and that, without waiting upon the event of the war, every energy should be directed to converting the tropics into cotton fields. In all these things the lecturer is unmistakably right. He only goes wrong, as Englishmen uniformly do either through willfulness, or an ignorance which the national self-conceit renders incurable, when he inquires into American questions, and endeavors to define the issues which separate the loyal from the insurgent States. Thus:

lead_paragraph: FLOUR 5c. better, with a fair demand. Several small lots of White Michigan Wheat changed hands on private terms; 100 bbls. choice do. sold at $1.30. RYE, 65c. OATS-Sales in car lots, 9,000 bush, delivered from railroad at 33 c@34c., mainly at 33 c. CORN in fair supply, but no disposition on the part of receivers to press a market. Sales includes 6,500 bush. Western Mixed, afloat, at 53c., and 6,600 bush. at 52 1/2c.; this P.M. buyers offer freely at 53c. WHISKY -- Sales, 125 bbls. at 18 1/2c. WOOL -- Sales, 18,000 lbs. mixed fleeces and 5,000 lbs. Lambs' Wool on private terms. Received by Central Railroad for New-York -- 5,860 bbls. Flour, 1,378 bags Wheat, 185 bales Wool, 1,183 boxes Cheese, 338 bbls. Highwines, 749 bbls Oil, 200 bush. Wheat. Shipped by boats to New-York, Sept. 19 -- 139,400 bush. Corn, 164,000 do. Wheat, 2,000 bush. Feed.

abstract: This match was played on Friday, the 20th inst., on the grounds of the St. George's Club, Hoboken, in the presence of the most numerous assemblage collected on the grounds this season. The weather, though rather warm, was suitable for play, and the ground was in excellent condition. The game began at 11:25, and in an hour and a half the Eleven were all out for the small score of 39. The Twenty-two then went in to the bat, and in about the same time they had all retired for a score of 58. The second innings of the Eleven gave them 56 more -- a grand total of 95, which left 38 for the Twenty-two to make to win. Of these they had obtained 27, when the stumps were drawn. As the Twenty-two had but 11 runs to get to win, the Eleven, in consideration of the fact that many of their players could not get over the following day, finally concluded to acknowledge themselves defeated, and gave up the ball.
lead_paragraph: This match was played on Friday, the 20th inst., on the grounds of the St. George's Club, Hoboken, in the presence of the most numerous assemblage collected on the grounds this season. abstract: The Oriental, the pioneer steamship of the NewYork, Nuevitas and St. Jago Steamship Company, made her trial-trip on Tuesday and Wednesday from Philadelphia to this port, and now lies at Pier No. 4, North River, preparing to depart on her first voyage. She is a first-class iron vessel of 1,214 tons register, built with five water-tight compartments. Her dimensions are length over all, 230 feet; width, 34 feet, and depth, 22 feet.
lead_paragraph: The Oriental, the pioneer steamship of the NewYork, Nuevitas and St. Jago Steamship Company, made her trial-trip on Tuesday and Wednesday from Philadelphia to this port, and now lies at Pier No. 4, North River, preparing to depart on her first voyage. She is a first-class iron vessel of 1,214 tons register, built with five water-tight compartments. Her dimensions are length over all, 230 feet; width, 34 feet, and depth, 22 feet. Speed, strength and convenience are combined in her construction, and everything about her is substantial and neat. Her saloons are of polished oak. They are spacious and elegantly fitted, but in no instance has good taste been sacrificed to gaudy decoration. Ample accommodation can be furnished for one hundred first-class passengers, and her freight-carrying capacity is about ten thousand barrels. She has a condensing vertical inverted direct-action engine of 60-inch cylinder and 54-inch stroke, and her propeller-wheel is 14 feet 6 inches in diameter. During her trial-trip the weather was thick, and the engine wrs not worked to its extreme speed. Its operation, however, gave great satisfaction, as the vessel made ten knots with 48 turns of the screw. Capt. BENJAMIN TUZO, an experienced sailor and thorough gentleman, is the commander, and MORA BROTHERS, NAVARRO & Co. are the agents in this City.

abstract: "The obligations of secrecy have been removed from a bill passed by Congress, under authority of which the Executive will proceed to inflict retaliation upon the persons of the Yankee prisoners in our hands, 'in such numbers as he may deem expedient,' for the inhuman treatment of our prisoners of war in New-York. The act of Congress, which has given the President authority for retaliation in such measure and kind as may seem to him proper and just, recites the fact, by way of preamble and in vindication of its objects, that 'the Government of the United States has placed in irons, and lodged in dungeons, citizens of the Confederate States, acting under the authority of letters-of-marque, issued in accordance with the laws of the Confederate States, by the President thereof, and have otherwise maltreated the same, and have seized and confined sundry other citizens ofthe said Confederate States, in violation of all principles of humane and civilized warfare.'"

lead_paragraph: The large saloon of Palace Garden, the head quarters of the Shepard Rifles, commanded by Col. E. FERRERO, was yesterday thronged with ladies, (a black coat being interspersed here and there to harmonize the colors,) the occasion being the presentation of a stand of colors to the regiment, the gift of ELLIOT F. SHEPARD, Esq., Aid to Gov. MORGAN, whose name the regiment bears. With a punctuality worthy of more general imitation, precisely at the hour named, all the men who had uniforms were marched into the saloon and formed two sides of a hollow square, the Color-Sergeant and his guard, and the officers in the centre. The colors, after some eloquen and patriotic remarks from Hon. F.A. CONKLIN, were presented by Col. SHEPARD, who spoke as follows:

abstract: The long voyage from St. John, N.B., to Havana, of the brig Mystery, now under arrest, with her cargo, upon suspicion of having run the blockade at Georgetown, S.C., has been one of the chief causes of suspicion against the vessel. A little inquiry, however, will satisfy anyone that the case in question is hardly an exceptional one at the same season of the year. The square-rigged brig M. & J.C. Gilmore from Boston, bound to Key West, in the month of July, 1858, with a cargo of ice, was forty-four days in performing the passage. During this long period she was becalmed most of the time in the Gulf Stream, the warm water of the Gulf melting nearly all the ice, leaving scarcely enough for ballast. A Maine bark, the same month and year, which sailed from Matanzas, bound to New-Orleans, was fallen in with by a ship, and supplied with provisions, atfer she had been forty-five days out, and was anchored on Salt Key Bank, one day's sail from Matanzas. Twelve sail of vessels from Philadelphia and New-York, the same year, were from fifty to sixty days on their passage to Mobile. Some of them made the passage three times around Abaco. The Gulf Stream and calms were the cause of these protracted voyages. Our authority for these statements is Capt. ELDRIDGE, of the bark Abd-el Kadir, now in this port.
lead_paragraph: The long voyage from St. John, N.B., to Havana, of the brig Mystery, now under arrest, with her cargo, upon suspicion of having run the blockade at Georgetown, S.C., has been one of the chief causes of suspicion against the vessel. A little inquiry, however, will satisfy anyone that the case in question is hardly an exceptional one at the same season of the year. The square-rigged brig M. & J.C. Gilmore from Boston, bound to Key West, in the month of July, 1858, with a cargo of ice, was forty-four days in performing the passage. During this long period she was becalmed most of the time in the Gulf Stream, the warm water of the Gulf melting nearly all the ice, leaving scarcely enough for ballast. A Maine bark, the same month and year, which sailed from Matanzas, bound to New-Orleans, was fallen in with by a ship, and supplied with provisions, atfer she had been forty-five days out, and was anchored on Salt Key Bank, one day's sail from Matanzas. Twelve sail of vessels from Philadelphia and New-York, the same year, were from fifty to sixty days on their passage to Mobile. Some of them made the passage three times around Abaco. The Gulf Stream and calms were the cause of these protracted voyages. Our authority for these statements is Capt. ELDRIDGE, of the bark Abd-el Kadir, now in this port.

abstract: The steamship Great Eastern, Capt. WALKER, from Liverpool Sept. 10, passed Greenport, Long Island, Saturday morning, about 9 o'clock, bound up the Sound. She comes this time to Morris Dock, from which point her cargo will be lightered to New-York. During her stay she will, it is understood, be thrown open for a few days to visitors, and the steamer Flushing, from Fultonslip, will make regular calls at Morris Dock, to land and receive passengers who may wish to inspect the mammoth steamer. She has, no doubt, already reached her moorings.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Great Eastern, Capt. WALKER, from Liverpool Sept. 10, passed Greenport, Long Island, Saturday morning, about 9 o'clock, bound up the Sound. She comes this time to Morris Dock, from which point her cargo will be lightered to New-York. During her stay she will, it is understood, be thrown open for a few days to visitors, and the steamer Flushing, from Fultonslip, will make regular calls at Morris Dock, to land and receive passengers who may wish to inspect the mammoth steamer. She has, no doubt, already reached her moorings.

abstract: It is evident, from information which comes to us through Southern journals, and in which the TIMES of to-day is unusually rich, of the condition of the Army, as well as of the Government and the people of the seceding States, that we have already seen the beginning of the end of the rebellion. From its commencement it was easy to see what must be the result of a warfare undertaken by the Southern States on a scale required to meet the power of the North. It was a fair inference, that just so far as the former were inferior to the latter in wealth, must so far would they be in results. The whole, as are all modern wars, other things being equal, was a question of money. We have placed an Army of 150,000 men on the Potomac, thoroughly equipped, and with an admirable commissariat. The South essayed to do the same, but an universal cry arises that its Army is most wretchedly fed and clothed, and as a necessary consequence, has so large a portion of its men upon the sick list as to leave only a skeleton of an Army for active operations. But for this there is no means of transportation for a forward movement, the want of which rendered it impossible for it to follow up any of the advantages gained in the early part of the campaign.

abstract: We learn that Ex Gov. MOREHEAD, of Kentucky, who was among the first persons arrested in Louisville, for treason, has been or-  dered to Fort Lafayette for confinement. We know nothing of the evidences of the ExGovernor's treason; and we know very little, good or bad, of the man himself. He is a gentleman of commanding appearance, and rather courtly in his manners, but rather too gracious and insinuating for perfect sincerity.
lead_paragraph: We learn that Ex Gov. MOREHEAD, of Kentucky, who was among the first persons arrested in Louisville, for treason, has been or- dered to Fort Lafayette for confinement. We know nothing of the evidences of the ExGovernor's treason; and we know very little, good or bad, of the man himself. He is a gentleman of commanding appearance, and rather courtly in his manners, but rather too gracious and insinuating for perfect sincerity. He has enjoyed, nearly all his life, in Kentucky, the soubriquet of "Ephraim Smooth;" and, to an honest, blunt Kentuckian, the name was very expressive of the Ex-Governor's qualities. He had always a few political followers, but never any ardent personal friends.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG WOMAN. -- A young lady named JULIA P. ROSS, resident of Fairhaven, Conn., has been missing since Thursday last. She was staying with her brother-in-law, at No. 290 South Second-street, Jersey City, and on the day above mentioned went out in search of employment as milliner or dressmaker, and since that time, notwithstanding diligent inquiry has been made, no tidings as to her whereabouts can be ascertained. Miss Ross is 19 years of age, of prepossessing appearance, five feet, two inches in height, blue eyes, and dark brown hair. She had on a black silk flounced dress, and white straw hat, with purple trimmings.
lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG WOMAN. -- A young lady named JULIA P. ROSS, resident of Fairhaven, Conn., has been missing since Thursday last. Miss Ross is 19 years of age, of prepossessing appearance, five feet, two inches in height, blue eyes, and dark brown hair. She had on a black silk flounced dress, and white straw hat, with purple trimmings.

abstract: At the inauguration of President LINCOLN, when many supposed there would be two Governments made out of one, there was a strong sentiment here in favor of doing the same thing in the Argentine Republic. But now that the integrity of the Union is likely to be maintained, we have the anomaly of having two hostile armies in the field, both contending for the same thing, the Constitution as it is.

abstract: SIR: I have read with attention the various newspaper articles that have appeared upon the subject of the rights and duties of the President, with respect to the writ of habeas corpus, including the opinion of Chief-Justice TANEY,...
lead_paragraph: SIR: I have read with attention the various newspaper articles that have appeared upon the subject of the rights and duties of the President, with respect to the writ of habeas corpus, including the opinion of Chief-Justice TANEY, and the speech of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE; and as the question has become more important by the increase of "rebellion," and the vigorous action of the Executive departments, I will take the liberty of laying before you the facts and conclusions that have induced me to form the opinion I shall express in this letter.

abstract: The feats of the prestidigitator, at the Academy of Music, and the graceful genialities of Mrs. JOHN WOOD, at the Winter-Garden, have brought the past week to a very succeseful termination.
lead_paragraph: The feats of the prestidigitator, at the Academy of Music, and the graceful genialities of Mrs. JOHN WOOD, at the Winter-Garden, have brought the past week to a very succeseful termination. In Broadway and in Fourteenth-street there have been overflowing audiences. Mr. HERMANN has introduced several new tricks with great success, and Mrs. JOHN WOOD, not to be outdone, has interpolated two or three new comic songs -- singing them with that heartiness of manner for which she is so remarkable. The burlesque of "Cinderella," as now played, is one of the prettiest pieces that has ever been seen on a New-York stage. The scenery is extremely beautiful, and the tableaux are conceived with a true eye to artistic effect of color.

abstract: -- The young Count of Paris, who is the head of the Orleans branch of the Bourbons, has entered the service of the Government. A member of the elder branch, known as Old Bourbon, has been doing active duty in the ranks of the insurgents from the beginning of the war, and has the credit, it is not known how justly, of having secured the victory of Bull Run, not only by animating the courage of the rebels, but by picking off several important officers of the National Army during the engagement. If the Count of Paris proves as efficient, our success will be largely owing to his abilities.

abstract: The negotiation of the first installment of the great National Loan, renders Mr.CHASE's role for the future a very easy one. Being entirely relieved of all anxiety about raising money, his whole attention-can now be given to its economical expenditure.
lead_paragraph: The negotiation of the first installment of the great National Loan, renders Mr.CHASE's role for the future a very easy one. Being entirely relieved of all anxiety about raising money, his whole attention-can now be given to its economical expenditure. The negotiation was a crowning success in more ways than one. It completely established confidence in the Government; rendered it respectable at home and abroad; gave full assurance of the defeat of the rebellion, and was the first important step toward a renewed commercial activity. With a strong Government, all the interests of society take care of themselves. Individuals can embark in full confidence upon their customary enterprises. All our flagging industries, consequently, have been again set in motion. Fortunately, that devoted to agriculture has been amply rewarded by abundant crops, and by an active foreign, as well as domestic, demand. A foundation is thus laid for manufactures and commerce, both of which are beginning to assume something like their former activity. We have daily intelligence of resumption of work in the great manufacturing districts, helped to a considerable extent by Government orders. The volume of trade is at present much less than in former years, as the most rigid economy is being everywhere practiced; but everything is fast getting into a healthy condition.

abstract: The turn that matters have taken in Kentucky promises to give the Confederate rebellion a most disastrous blow.
lead_paragraph: The turn that matters have taken in Kentucky promises to give the Confederate rebellion a most disastrous blow. Gen. POLK invaded Kentucky, and occupied two strong posts, under "a military necessity," as he explained the movement to the Executive of the State. He is now warned out of the State by the representatives of the people, and, to make the warning efficient, the military power of Kentucky is called out and placed under competent command, with directions to expel the rebel General and his hordes if they refuse to go. There is no ambiguity in the issue thus presented. Kentucky does not ask the National Government to send an Army to drive out her invaders. She proposes to do that duty promptly through her own soldiers, without the intervention of red tape. And Bishop POLK will be obliged to leave Kentucky for the same reason that brought him in -- military necessity.

abstract: Some years since, the Old World was sighing for a new sensation it wanted a poet. The Laureate seemed to be slumbering on his laurels.
lead_paragraph: Some years since, the Old World was sighing for a new sensation it wanted a poet. The Laureate seemed to be slumbering on his laurels. Beyond annually congratulating the Queen, the nation, and the world upon the last "happy event," he added very little to the sum of human poesy. And the world was anxiously looking around for some one else to crown. The world seldom looks for anything in vain, and soon the cry went up: We have found him. The name of the stronger was SMITH. Despite its lack of sonorousness, the name speedily became a famous one, and was echoed in the trump of fame. Such a welcome was given its bearer as young bard never before received. The reviews all said: This is he for whom we have long waited. Young ladies said: Tell us not that the Age of Poesy is past; and everyone was jubilant. The numerous and respectable family of Smiths lifted up their heads, and ceased to torture their patronymical appellation with interpolated and added letters; door-plates bearing that name were burnished, and your old friend JOHN no longer blushed when he gave you his card. But very soon there came a change. The world read the pages of the poet carefully, and came to the conclusion that it had been befooled. "This young singer," it said, "has made us drunk with adjectives and epithets; he has bewildered us with words; he led us captive with the melody of his voice, but his utterances are idle as the wind. We revoke our verdict. He is not the Poet for whom we have so long looked and waited!" Careful critics reconsidered their praise. They professed now to discover in his pages crudity, nudity, and all that, blended, however, with power, imagination, and that rather vague specialty commonly known as "promise;" and they bade the world wait. So the world has been content to wait, and as the reward of its waiting, it now has Edwin of Deira, republished this side the water by the HARPERS, in their magazine for October, and by TICKNOR & FIELDS in book form.

abstract: In accordance with a resolution of the Police Commissioners passed recently, the Police force is to be divided into four sections, and will be drilled in the manual of arms, that it may be able to act in a military capacity should disturbances occur in the City.
lead_paragraph: In accordance with a resolution of the Police Commissioners passed recently, the Police force is to be divided into four sections, and will be drilled in the manual of arms, that it may be able to act in a military capacity should disturbances occur in the City. Capt. CHARLES S. TURNBULL, late of the Seventeenth Precinct, has been appointed military instructor, and the men will be drilled with muskets three times a week, while the customary drillings will be suspended. The nine Precincts of Brooklyn, the detached force of that city, and the First, Second, Fourth, and Seventh Precincts of New-York, will be comprised in the First Division, under Inspector JOHN S. FOLK. The Twenty-seventh, Third, Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, Twenty sixth, Twenty-eighth, and Ninth Precincts, the first and second Police Court Squads, the Steamboat and Railroad Squads, will comprise the Second Division, under Inspector LEONARD. The Tenth, Thirteenth, Fourteenth, Fifteenth, Eleventh, Seventeenth, Eighteenth, and Twenty-fifth Precincts, the third Police Court Squad, and the Broadway and Sanitary Squads, will comprise, the Third Division, under Inspector CARPENTER. The Sixteenth, Twenty-ninth, Nineteenth, Twenty-third, Thirtieth, Twenty-first, Twenty-second, and Twelfth Precincts, and fourth Police Court Squad, will comprise the Fourth Division, under Inspector GEORGE W. DILKS.

abstract: The delusion cherished by the Southern leaders that Mr. CALEB CUSHING, and that portion of the Northern Democracy which he represents, sympathized with their treason, or would withhold their aid from the Government in crushing it, will be rudely dispelled when the report of his late speeches shall reach them. They will then find that they have no party at the North; that they must encounter the hazards and fight the battles their madness has rendered inevitable, alone; that those whom in their folly they counted upon as friends are among the sternest enemies of their treason; and that those upon whom they reckoned to embarrass the action of the Government in its struggles to maintain its supremacy and vindicate its authority, are among its firmest and most earnest supporters. Instead of finding Mr. CUSHING and his followers in opposition to the war in defence of the Union, they are among the foremost of those who demand that it shall be carried on with all the vigor of which the nation is capable, without prating of peace until revolt has laid down its arms and the Union is reestablished in its length and breadth.
