abstract: The October number of Harper's is a remarkably lively one, considering the dead weight of "Edwin of Deira," which, with remarkable ingenuity, is inserted in the body of the Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The October number of Harper's is a remarkably lively one, considering the dead weight of "Edwin of Deira," which, with remarkable ingenuity, is inserted in the body of the Magazine. What the readers of Harper's have done to merit this infliction, we cannot conceive, unless, indeed, they have proven dilatory in paying up their subscriptions, or refractory when requested to laugh at the jokes in the "Drawer." It may be that in republishing this poem the HARPERS, have meditated a sly but direct thrust at their Boston friends, who have also swaddled "Edwin of Deira," but the blow assuredly falls upon their readers. If bent on following up this style of thing, we would suggest to the editor that he republish some of the refreshing sonnets of TUPPER, or a few pages from Smith's Wealth of Nations. Whatever is worth doing at all, is certainly worth doing well. If we are to be bored at all, love us to death at once.

abstract: Among our Washington reports is one of a young officer, who having escaped from the lines of BEAUREGARD, had a story to tell in confidence to the Secretary of War. The story is all delightfully rose-colored on the rebel side. It gives to the insurgent leader, at or near Manassas, a force of 185,000 men; men armed with the most perfect weapons; clad with the amplest garments; shod with Cordovan, and sheltered beneath the stoutest canvas. Of sickness disaffection and want, the witness has nothing to testify. All is comfort and satisfaction. The report has proved so grateful to the War Department, that the maker has at once received a commission in the National Army.
lead_paragraph: Among our Washington reports is one of a young officer, who having escaped from the lines of BEAUREGARD, had a story to tell in confidence to the Secretary of War. abstract: - England and France have apparently determined to exchange diplomatic intercourse with Mexico for intercourse of a more decided character. A conjoint naval expedition, we are now told, is to leave at once for Vera Cruz, where it will demand a compliance with all the conventions which the newly installed Liberal Government has been obliged to postpone; and as compliance is as impossible as the payment of the British national debt, it is safe to anticipate the seizure if not the destruction of Vera Cruz, and perhaps an armed occupation of the Republic.

abstract: Whether the money necessary to carry on the war will be raised admits now of no dispute.
lead_paragraph: Whether the money necessary to carry on the war will be raised admits now of no dispute. The demonstrations of the readiness and promptitude with which the National loan is taken has settled that matter, and the only question open to discussion relates to the ability of the nation to meet the interest upon and finally extinguish the large National debt which, under the pressure of an imperious, necessity, is being contracted. It would seem to be a sufficient answer to those who doubt on this subject to point to the fact that the loan which constitutes this debt is made from and advanced by the American people themselves; and if they have the ability to advance, in a crisis like the present, the amount of principal necessary to carry on the war, it would seem to a logical sequence, that they would be able to meet the interest as it accrues, and to pay the principal at the times fixed for its liquidation.

abstract: While the policy of Gen. McCLELLAN was very properly a defensive one till he had repaired the Bull Run disaster, and put his Army in condition for operations in the open field, we cannot help believing that the time is not far distant in which he will resume the offensive.
lead_paragraph: While the policy of Gen. McCLELLAN was very properly a defensive one till he had repaired the Bull Run disaster, and put his Army in condition for operations in the open field, we cannot help believing that the time is not far distant in which he will resume the offensive. While he been daily accumulating strength, the enemy has been constantly weakened, at least relatively, by his inability to carry on war upon anything like the scale assumed by the United States. The defeat of the rebels will be in their commissariat by which they can neither be properly paid, nor fed, nor clothed; their great Army must, if Gen. MCCLELLAN remains in his intrenchments, gradually fall to pieces and disappear. But we cannot afford to rest our cause entirely upon negative action. We have the disgrace of a defeat to efface, while we must make an adequate display of our power. The success of our Army must not only be up to the nation's expectation, but to a nation's dignity, and to the magnitude of the crisis. Such, we are confident, is the feeling of the Army at Washington, and and of the Administration, and we consequently anticipate an early advance from the Potomac. Gen. MCCLELLAN has been successful in his efforts to create any army complete in any department, infantry, artillery, and cavalry. He has brought it to such a state of perfection, that he probably will not long hesitate to encounter the rebels on their own ground. We believe that not many days will elapse before we shall see a grand advance of all our forces, and if the rebels oppose, a great battle.

abstract: Eighteen men were enlisted last week at the old offices in this City. Thirteen of them were transferred to Governor's Island;
lead_paragraph: Eighteen men were enlisted last week at the old offices in this City. Thirteen of them were transferred to Governor's Island; the remainder were enlisted for the mounted service. Although these figures show that recruiting for general service has improved, there is yet ample room for still further improvement. Three old established offices ought to be able to book more than eighteen men per week, especially in New-York.

abstract: With the abundance of leisure at command by so many in the community, a County Fair will furnish relief to the monotony of political and military affairs. The Agricultural Society of Westchester County holds its annual exhibition at Mount Vernon, on the New-Haven Railroad, some half-hour distant from the city, on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of this week. The grounds are well located and well arranged, near the depot -- and about the same distance from Hunt's Bridge, on the Harlem Road -- affording ready access from all directions. A spacious track has been gradedfor displaying the action of the fine horses on exhibition. Secretary SEWARD's fine Arabians, with other distinguished stock, will be on the ground.

abstract: The British War-office, according to latest advices, has again suspended the shipment of troops to Canada. No reason is given for this new order. The probability, however, is, that the unanimous opposition offered to the measure by the Press, metropolitan and provincial, convinced the ministers of the unpopularity of the step, and of the likelihood that a majority might fail them when the subject should be brought forward by the Conservatives in Parliament; and they have wisely decided to escape the proper consequences of their mistake.

abstract: The monotony, which has lately settled down upon Washington, continued yesterday, the only ripple disturbing the military surface being the news from Missouri. In the morning there were two reviews by Gen.
lead_paragraph: The monotony, which has lately settled down upon Washington, continued yesterday, the only ripple disturbing the military surface being the news from Missouri. In the morning there were two reviews by Gen. MCCLELLAN over the river -- the first, of Col. VAN ALLEN's Regiment of Cavalry, and some other companies of cavalry in the vicinity, and the second of Gen. MCDOWELL's Division, consisting of two companies of artillery, a squadron of cavalry, and nine regiments of infantry. This review is pronounced one of the most brilliant which has taken place, and Gen. MCCLELLAN was received by the troops with the greatest enthusiasm.

abstract: Fort Lafayette, named by some the American Bastile, is not a Bastile at all, in fact the fortis more like a hotel than anything else, where the proprietor is rather strict and has a wholesome dread of fire, insisting upon all lights being out at 9 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: Fort Lafayette, named by some the American Bastile, is not a Bastile at all, in fact the fortis more like a hotel than anything else, where the proprietor is rather strict and has a wholesome dread of fire, insisting upon all lights being out at 9 o'clock. Beyond that, the fare is excellent, and the view of the ocean extensive. Lately there has been quite a number of prisoners released; they, in secret, have told their friends, who, in turn, told our reporter in secret, consequently he is thus enabled to tell the readers of the TIMES what the prisoners in Fort Lafayette eat, drink, and do.

abstract: The list, published in another column, of prisoners confined within Fort Lafayette is, by no means, what it ought to be. There are certainly names enough upon it, and very many of the names deserve the place they occupy; but there are numbers which should be instantly replaced by those of bad men whom Government has permitted to go about their mischievous business unmolested. What are we to think of the youthful newspaper dealer on an obscure railroad being rigidly confined upon the exceedingly spare diet of the garrison cuisine, for having formerly sold, among his wares, the Daily News, -- the arrest having been made three days after the News had ceased to exist, while those who published, edited and sold the News are left at liberty? Why are REEVES and MCMASTERS, whose readers probably counted by scores, shut up, while the proprietors of the Albany Atlas and Argus, of the Day Book, of the Courrier des Etats Unis, labor without disturbance in the cause of sedition? Why is ELIAS B. SCHNABLE, whose obscurity and impotence might fairly have protected him, a State prisoner, while BRECKINRIDGE, MAGOFFIN, BURNETT and VALLANDIGHAM, men of infinite capacity for mischief, and who have been doing it with most formidable energy, permitted to rant treason in the very shadow of the Capital, and to act it in Kentucky?

abstract: When the Cotton States set up the standard of rebellion, the Border States at once became the grand theatre of their intrigues, the object of which was to carry them with the South.
lead_paragraph: When the Cotton States set up the standard of rebellion, the Border States at once became the grand theatre of their intrigues, the object of which was to carry them with the South. The National Government was equally desirous of retaining their allegiance, for the reason that so long as this was held, it was believed that the insurrection would fall to the ground of its own weakness. For months it was in the power of these States to have composed the revolt, and restore peace and unity to the country. If Virginia and Kentucky had assumed an attitude dictated by patriotism or manliness, or a sense of self-preservation the rebels would have been awed into submission without the movement of a soldier or the firing of a gun. But the position taken by both was that calculated to make rebellion the power that it is, rather than to support the Government and sustain the laws. While the rebels were either seizing or destroying everything belonging to Government within their reach, and straining every nerve for its subversion and ruin, the Border States planted themselves on the anti-coercion ground, and notified the National authorities that no soldier should cross their soils to enforce the law or protect the forts and property of the United States. As their territories extended from the Atlantic to the Mississippi, their attitude was the very one at the time best calculated to promote the object of the rebellion, and to embarrass the action of the Government. Anti-coercion was the ground upon which the Democratic party, North as well as South, then stood. When neutrality could be no longer preserved, the mask was thrown off in Virginia, as well as by the Executives of both Kentucky and Missouri. Kentucky did not go over to the enemy, but still asserted the right to remain neutral in the contest, the most disgraceful and undignified role a State could possibly assume. No sentiment of patriotism, or sense of duty, or gratitude toward a Government which had been the source of all her honors and prosperity, appeared to animate her people. As far as they inclined in either direction, the whole weight of their influence was thrown in favor of the rebels. Kentucky allowed their army to be recruited from her sons. She supplied their wants when all other avenues were closed to them. Under her fostering care towards them, and indifference towards the Government, the rebellion grew to the vast proportions and power it now displays. She hugged to the idea of neutrality till a military necessity compelled the rebels to throw an immense force into her territory and seize upon its most important strategical points. Kentucky cannot long be neutral. Her Governor takes sides with the rebels, and her Legislature with the National Government. This difference corresponds to an equally marked and virulent one existing throughout the whole State. A majority of her people still maintain their quasi-loyalty, which has been greatly strengthened by the invasion. But the minority make up for inferiority in numbers in earnestness and activity, so that, without aid from the North, the State would undoubtedly be overrun, and annexed, willing or not, to the Southern Confederacy. Sustained by the National troops, she may be enabled to drive back the invaders, but not without a terrible contest, in which she must suffer all the horrors of a civil war on a broader scale, and in a more embittered form, than have yet been enacted in any State. Kentucky is to be, in reality, the dark and bloody ground. The war, then, is to be one of giants. Murder and rapine is to stalk abroad through the whole extent of her land. The hand of neighbor is to be turned against neighbor, of brother against brother, till her fair fields are deluged with blood, blasted with fire and sword. In idea she already presents a spectacle from which every sensitive mind recoils with horror.

abstract: At a regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, held yesterday, the President of the Hudson River Railroad Company transmitted a remonstrance against a repeal of the authority heretofore granted to them, to run a dummy engine through the City, as ...
lead_paragraph: At a regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, held yesterday, the President of the Hudson River Railroad Company transmitted a remonstrance against a repeal of the authority heretofore granted to them, to run a dummy engine through the City, as they have just completed a new and improved engine for such purpose, at great expense; and inviting an examination of its working. It was accepted, and Wednesday, 12 M., fixed upon. A preamble and resolutions of condolence, on the death of JAMES GULICK, Ex-Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, were received, and ordered to be transmitted to the relatives of the deceased.

abstract: There has nothing transpired in Missouri for many weary weeks to cheer the hearts of the Union men there. On the contrary, discouragements and disasters have followed each other in unbroken succession, until hope deferred has made the heart sick.
lead_paragraph: There has nothing transpired in Missouri for many weary weeks to cheer the hearts of the Union men there. On the contrary, discouragements and disasters have followed each other in unbroken succession, until hope deferred has made the heart sick. The friends of the Government, everywhere, have reason to be ashamed of the impotency of patriotic effort in Missouri. The calamities there have been endured until they are National crimes. Who is to blame for the anarchy and rebel rule and devastation west of the Mississippi? We make no charges; but in the name of a wronged country, we declare that there are deep blood stains on some hands, that cannot easily be washed out.
headline: {'main': 'The Situation in Missouri.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Situation in Missouri.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG LADY. Miss JULIA P. Ross, of Fairhaven, Conn., mentioned as having mysteriously disappeared from the residence of her brother-in-law in Jersey City a few days since, has been heard from.
lead_paragraph: THE MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG LADY. -- Miss JULIA P. Ross, of Fairhaven, Conn., mentioned as having mysteriously disappeared from the residence of her brother-in-law in Jersey City a few days since, has been heard from. She left the house with the avowed intention of seeking a situation as seamstress. Instead of this, she accompanied a young man (a respectable engineer) to Brooklyn, where Rev. E.M. JOHNSON, of St. Michael's Church, made them man and wife. The friends of the young lady were not consulted in the matter, as it was feared they would interpose and prevent the union. The publication of the disappearance of the young woman brought the above facts to light.

abstract: The New-York and other papers throughout the country appear to be very much engrossed with the case of Gen. FREMONT, and the merits of his late proclamation. Most of the journals that I have read assume that the proclamation of Gen. FREMONT, liberating the slaves of traitors, and the supposed personal difficulties between the General and Col. F.P. BLAIR, are the only questions brought before the Government at Washington. These assumptions are erroneous.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Friday, Sept. 20, 1861.

abstract: Orderly-serjeant JOHN E. DUNHAM, of Company B, Fifth Regiment N.Y.S.V., better known as DURYEA'S Zouaves, who was accidentally wounded soon after the battle of Great Bethel, returns to Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Orderly-serjeant JOHN E. DUNHAM, of Company B, Fifth Regiment N.Y.S.V., better known as DURYEA'S Zouaves, who was accidentally wounded soon after the battle of Great Bethel, returns to Baltimore on Wednesday evening, at six o'clock, having almost entirely recovered from the effects of his injuries. He will gladly take, to the members of the regiment, any letters or small parcels which their friends may send to him at No. 152 Spring-st., or No. 75 East Thirteenth-st. Serjeant DUNHAM distinguished himself by his cool conduct in the action of Great Bethel, and will doubtless be warmly welcomed by his comrades on his return to active duty.

abstract: The rebel leaders have not extinguished the hope of a revolution of Northern sentiment in their favor. From a private letter, written in England, and printed in another column, we learn that a confident calculation is made upon such a revulsion, and, indeed, the entire expectation of success is founded upon it. On the approach of Winter, it is reasoned, the masses of Northern people will begin to suffer the pinch of want. Capital will lie idle; labor will look forward to a Winter without employment and wages; public uprisings will destroy peace and property in all the great cities. In those days an exhausted and hopeless people will compel the Government to make peace on any terms. We are told, moreover, that these results are not merely conjectural among the Southern people, but that they have numerous and influential Northern allies who are pledged to bring them about, and who are actually using every energy at this moment to realize them. The earlier weeks of December is the period prearranged for the great popular conversion.

abstract: This handsome and popular establishment was reopened to the public last evening, and a crowded and unusually fashionable audience gave a hearty welcome to the fair lessee. Good taste determines a great many things in the world.
lead_paragraph: This handsome and popular establishment was reopened to the public last evening, and a crowded and unusually fashionable audience gave a hearty welcome to the fair lessee. Good taste determines a great many things in the world. It is a gift which so few possess, that they who have it are very apt to find themselves mysteriously enriched thereby. Miss KEENE we all know is an actress of great merit. In a certain line of legitimate business she is probably without a superior in this City. Happening by a blunder of fortune to become a manager instead of continuing to be an actress, she has unexpectedly developed a genius for spectacle which will probably govern her actions for many years to come. In a word, she possesses taste. The fanciful things of the imagination become pleasant realities beneath her hands. She presents them to the eye as pictures, to the ear as music, but seldom to the intelligence as serious plays. We have not heard that Miss KEENE ever made any pretence of literary merit in the "Seven Sisters," and in the "Seven Sons," the piece selected for her opening night, she expressly disclaims anything of the kind. According to her own words it is an "incomprehensible mass of dramatic nonsense" -- a definition which no one can object to. Criticism is gagged by a modesty so overpowering, all that can be done is to regard the piece as it is placed before us, and to applaud effects which, if frequently illogical, are always very beautiful and pleasant to the eye.
headline: {'main': "THEATRICAL.; Laura Keene's Theatre Opening Night.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THEATRICAL.; Laura Keene's Theatre Opening Night.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Unusual festivities enlivened Hamilton Park yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the presentation of a stand of colors to the Forty-fifth Regiment German Rities more familiarly known as the Fifth ...
lead_paragraph: Unusual festivities enlivened Hamilton Park yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the presentation of a stand of colors to the Forty-fifth Regiment German Rifles -- more familiarly known as the Fifth Regiment, in consequence of the enlistment therein of many members of the militia regiment of that designation under command of Col. SCHWARTZWAELDER. The Forty-fifth is, however, commanded by Col. VON AMSBURG, and comprises many new recruits of ability and experience, whose military ardor leads them more to the sober work of war than to the less onerous parades of peace. The Forty-fifth commenced recruiting only on the 17th ult., and on the 9th inst. were mustered into service. The roll yesterday numbered 800 officers and men, and, though the arms are not yet furnished, it is expected that the regiment will proceed to the seat of war on Wednesday or Thursday, to be attached to Gen. BLENKER's Division, and procure arms, as promised by Gen. MCCLELLAN, at the Capital. They will receive -- as have the remainder of the Division -- the Springfield rifle. This is a most appropriate weapon, as most of the men are good shots, and one of the companies at least -- that of Capt. SHOENECKER's -- is composed of sharp-shooters. The men are uniformed in the State blue, and, barring their arms, are nearly equipped. They are a hardy, sinewy set of men, and bid fair to do credit not only to New-York but to the nationalities from which they hail. The following are the Field and Staff officers:

abstract: The  letter of the Secretary of the Treasury, which we published yesterday, (to which the telegraph, by mistake, appended the name of the Secretary of State,) on the subject of the forfeiture of property belonging to citizens of ...
lead_paragraph: -- The letter of the Secretary of the Treasury, which we published yesterday, (to which the telegraph, by mistake, appended the name of the Secretary of State,) on the subject of the forfeiture of property belonging to citizens of insurrectionary States, contains new views of the law on this subject. According to Mr. CHASE's interpretation, neither under the act of Congress of July 13, nor that of Aug. 6, 1861, can the property of rebels be forfeited except "such as is in transit, or provided for transit to or from the insurrectionary States, or is actually used for the promotion of the insurrection." In this he entirely ignores the sixth section of the act of July 13, which, in express terms, declares that "any ship or vessel belonging in whole or in part to any citizen or inhabitant of a State declared in a state of insurrection found at sea, or in any part of the rest of the United States, shall be forfeited to the United States." There is in this section nonqualification or pretence of qualification to the forfeiture. It is absolute. By the common law, when a citizen rebels against the Government to which he owes allegiance, his property, as well as his life, is forfeited, whether his property has been "used for the promotion of the insurrection" or not; and the reason is, that when he embarks in the rebellion, the law presumes that he intends to use not only his physical powers in "promotion" of the treason he is engaged in, but all his property. The act of rebellion, in legal contemplation, fixes the intent, and it therefore presumes that all the goods, all the money, all the estate and possessions of the rebel, as well as his arm and brain, are used or to be used in aid of accomplishing the overthrow of the Government. Had the Secretary remembered this rule of the common law, he would have found no difficulty, we think, in respect to the forfeiture of rebel property. In construing the statutes creating the forfeiture, he would not have required actual proof of the use, or of the intention to use it "in promotion of the insurrection." He would have said that the act of rebellion itself, in legal contemplation, determined the intent so to use it, -- that in law it was so used, from the moment the owner became a rebel, and that the forfeiture therefore attached.

abstract: Last Wednesday ELLEN BEMIS and BRIDGET RILEY, both of whom are married, and live at the tenement house No. 16 Leonard-street, quarreled with reference to their respective rights and privileges as tenants, and Mrs. BEMIS gave emphasis to her ...
lead_paragraph: -- Last Wednesday ELLEN BEMIS and BRIDGET RILEY, both of whom are married, and live at the tenement house No. 16 Leonard-street, quarreled with reference to their respective rights and privileges as tenants, and Mrs. BEMIS gave emphasis to her indignation by striking Mrs. RILEY upon the head with a bottle. The bottle broke and pieces of the glass injured Mrs. RILEY in a serious manner. She then caused the arrest of Mrs. BEMIS, who was required to furnish bail to answer at the Court of General Sessions. On Sunday, Mrs. RILEY, who was still suffering from the effects of the gashes and bruises she had received, attempted to go down stairs, when she was seized with vertigo, and fell to the bottom. She was taken up insensible, and yesterday the physician in attendance informed the police that she was dying. Notice of the fact was sent to the Coroner's office, and Mrs. BEMIS was rearrested, pending the result of the matter.

abstract: Whatever degree of importance is really to be attached to the new French pamphlet, entitled, "The Emperor, Rome, and the King of Italy," just issued from the press of the official publisher in Paris, the journals are nearly unanimous in ascribing to it an Imperial authorship.
lead_paragraph: Whatever degree of importance is really to be attached to the new French pamphlet, entitled, "The Emperor, Rome, and the King of Italy," just issued from the press of the official publisher in Paris, the journals are nearly unanimous in ascribing to it an Imperial authorship. This, it is affirmed, is the real thunder of which the numerous articles and brochures that have appeared on the Roman question, were but the premonitory mutterings; this, the trumpet-sound which is to bring down the fabric of temporal sovereignty, built up with so much fraud and violence by the Bishops of Rome.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS, of the Sixth Ward, in the Chair. The Committee on Schools, Arts and Sciences, submitted a report relative to the appointment of Truant Officers.
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS, of the Sixth Ward, in the Chair. The Committee on Schools, Arts and Sciences, submitted a report relative to the appointment of Truant Officers. When Mayor KALBFLEISCH came into office he refused to sanction the appointment of the usual Truant Officers, to pick up vagrant children, giving as a reason that it was a duty which properly belonged to the Police, and was an unnecessary expense. The matter was referred to the above Committee, and they reported last night that the appointments are necessary, and therefore indorse the action of the Truant Committee in making them. The report was adopted by unanimous consent. The Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies notified the Board that work in the corporation shop had been suspended, as the appropriation was expended. A communication was received from Hon. F.B. SPINOLA, Chairman of a Committee of Arrangements for the burial of the late Capt. JAMES MCQUEEN, of the Fifteenth New-York Volunteers, notifying the Board of his death -- that his funeral was to take place next Sunday -- inviting the Aldermen to be present, and asking an appropriation for expenses. Alderman STRONG presented a resolution, which was adopted, accepting the invitation, and appropriating $250. Subsequently Alderman GREEN offered the following, which was adopted:

abstract: BOGUS DISPATCHES FROM LONG ISLAND. -- Not many weeks ago startling reports were received from Greenport that there had been a fierce naval engagement off Gardner's Island between an American man-of-war and two privateers, the latter being captured after a five hours' battle, and carried into New-London. The same inventive genius, probably, sent a telegraphic dispatch, on Saturday, to the ship-news agent here, announcing that the Great Eastern passed Greenport about 9 o'clock A.M. of that day. As information has been received that the big ship has returned to Liverpool, we are left to infer that the dispatch announcing her arrival at the entrance of Long Island Sound must have emanated from the same veracious source as the story of the great naval engagement.
lead_paragraph: BOGUS DISPATCHES FROM LONG ISLAND. -- Not many weeks ago startling reports were received from Greenport that there had been a fierce naval engagement off Gardner's Island between an American man-of-war and two privateers, the latter being captured after a five hours' battle, and carried into New-London. abstract: -- Later letters from the London Times correspondent at Washington, reprinted elsewhere in this paper, will be found to contain various items of information not currently known in this country. Mr. RUSSELL has enjoyed unusual facilities for observing what the Government is doing for the defence of Washington. He has no means of knowing the movements of the rebels. The consequence is that his reports contain details of the utmost value to the latter; details which, at the present moment, they have very imperfect means of obtaining through any less circuitous channel. The number, condition, morale and efficiency of our troops; the policy and probable plans of Gen. McCLELLAN; the extent and character of the new works about the capital; the inadequacy of our forces for their defence; all these things, in regard to which the American Press is unapprised, or, knowing, declines for patriotic reasons to make public, Mr. RUSSELL having, of course, no patriotic reasons, publishes with impunity. If steamers and telegraphs were less rapid, the mischief would be less remarkable. As it is, we conceive it to be high time the case of Mr. RUSSELL should have more careful consideration than even the Secretary of State has condescended to give it. It is clearly unjust to the enterprise of American journals to invoke their silence touching matters which none the less surely reach the public by way of London,

abstract: -- It may be some consolation to the rebellious States, amid the mortifications incident to the blockade which the National Government has set over their ports, to know that they are not left without a companion in misfortune. The Montenegrins have just been served in the same way by the Turks, who have blocked up all the issues of the Black Mountain, thus exposing the population to die of hunger. The troubles between the Montenegrins and Turks have long formed -- not a "question," indeed -- but the ghost of a question, which occasionally flits in a European newspaper item. It is claimed by these mountaineers that the razzias or raids which they periodically make into the Turkish territory are simply a necessity for them, the population of 800,000 being far too large for the small and rocky country. To obviate this, the Turkish Government has repeatedly offered to join as much of the lowland to their territory as would suffice for all stomachs, asking merely a nominal recognition of the suzerainty of the Porte. But the Montenegrins prove recalcitrant, and the Turks have very properly put a stopper to their outgoings. Meanwhile, the Prince of Montenegro has addressed to the Ambassadors of the great Powers at Constantinople a protest against the Turkish blockade. But there is as little chance of their being gratified as there is in the case of another rebellious territory of which we wot.
lead_paragraph: -- It may be some consolation to the rebellious States, amid the mortifications incident to the blockade which the National Government has set over their ports, to know that they are not left without a companion in misfortune. The Montenegrins have just been served in the same way by the Turks, who have blocked up all the issues of the Black Mountain, thus exposing the population to die of hunger. The troubles between the Montenegrins and Turks have long formed -- not a "question," indeed -- but the ghost of a question, which occasionally flits in a European newspaper item. It is claimed by these mountaineers that the razzias or raids which they periodically make into the Turkish territory are simply a necessity for them, the population of 800,000 being far too large for the small and rocky country. To obviate this, the Turkish Government has repeatedly offered to join as much of the lowland to their territory as would suffice for all stomachs, asking merely a nominal recognition of the suzerainty of the Porte. But the Montenegrins prove recalcitrant, and the Turks have very properly put a stopper to their outgoings. Meanwhile, the Prince of Montenegro has addressed to the Ambassadors of the great Powers at Constantinople a protest against the Turkish blockade. But there is as little chance of their being gratified as there is in the case of another rebellious territory of which we wot.

abstract: -- The Day-Book hasposted up its accounts. Last evening's issue tells its readers that it "bows before the inexorable decree of force" -- which is a very good thing to bow before. "While in the exercise of our legitimate rights as public journalists, the Administration of ABRAHAM LINCOLN stepped in and denied our subscribers the right of receiving their papers through theUnited States mails. At a single blow, over thirty, thousands subscribers, scattered from Maine to Oregon, were deprived of their undeniable rights as American citizens." What, all my chickens at one swoop? We sympathize with the "thirty thousand!" We ourselves do not learn without a regretful pang the demise of a sheet which has often made us laugh at, if it has never made us laugh with it. To think of the ethnologic VAN EVRIE, -- his occupation gone, and an unbelieving world not yet converted to his doctrine that, as the negro, from the position of his os calcis, cannot stand up straight, he should therefore be flattened out as thoroughly, as possible!

abstract: When the Government laid its hand upon Ex-Gov. MOREHEAD, of Kentucky, and removed him from the sphere of his treason, the country looked for another arrest in that State. Senator BRECKINRIDGE was quite as active, and vastly more efficient in the rebel cause than MOREHEAD, and it was doubtless intended that he should have shared the seclusion of the latter, until reflection might have taught them their folly, the power of the Government, and the hopelessness of revolt against its authority. But BRECKINRIDGE, escaping the tardy movements of the authorities, has fled into Tennessee. Thus the man who a little while ago occupied the second place in dignity in the nation; who a little later was a candidate for its highest honors, and at the time of his flight was a Senator in Congress, has become through his own treason an exile, and is to spend the rest of his life as a fugitive. He aimed at the destruction of the Constitution which he repeatedly swore to defend, and the recoil has ruined him. Such are the melancholy fruits of this wicked rebellion, and such the retribution which will sooner or later be gathered by those who are seeking to overthrow the freest and best institutions in the world.
lead_paragraph: When the Government laid its hand upon Ex-Gov. MOREHEAD, of Kentucky, and removed him from the sphere of his treason, the country looked for another arrest in that State. abstract: We have at last a full confirmation of the report of the surrender of Lexington, Mo., to the rebels under Gen. PRICK, and some particulars of the events which preceded it. The surrender, as be-
lead_paragraph: We have at last a full confirmation of the report of the surrender of Lexington, Mo., to the rebels under Gen. PRICK, and some particulars of the events which preceded it. The surrender, as before stated, took place on Friday morning, the men having previously fought fifty-nine hours without water, and with nothing but three barrels of vinegar with which to quench their thirst. The apparent anomaly of a scarcity of water on the very banks of the Missouri river is satisfactorily explained. There were no springs or wells of any kind inside the intrenchments, the supply of water having been entirely drawn from the river. On that side there were no breastworks, and there the hardest fighting took place. The rebels, anticipating the advantage to be gained in cutting off access to the river, procured a large number of bales of hemp, and rolling them gradually along, under their protection succeeded in effecting their object, and thus had the fort completely surrounded. Their overwhelming numbers -- estimated at fully twenty-seven thousand -- rendered a successful sortie, on the part of the little garrison, out of the question, and they were thus enabled to wait until Col. MULLIGAN was compelled to succumb to a more terrible foe. A fair fight, in an open field, with the odds at four to one, was declined by PRICE previous to the surrender. When that event took place, the rebels mounted the breastworks, tore down the National flag and dragged it in the dust. The men were all released on parole on the morning after the surrender, but the officers were retained as prisoners. The National loss during the siege is reported at 37 killed and 140 wounded. That of the rebels is at present unknown, but it is believed to be not less than one thousand. They will probably solace themselves, however, with the plunder which has fallen into their hands in Lexington, including a large sum in gold, stated at a quarter of a million dollars.

abstract: One of the most encouraging indications of the times is the confidence which the nation is daily acquiring, by a thorough examination of its means and strength. Nothing is so cal-
lead_paragraph: One of the most encouraging indications of the times is the confidence which the nation is daily acquiring, by a thorough examination of its means and strength. Nothing is so calculated to shake faith in public credit as civil war, which, as its name implies, may paralyze all the functions of a Government by destroying its unity. This remains to us intact, with the greater portion of the people loyal, and possessing by far the larger portion of the property, and nearly all the enterprise of the country. We thus retain that which in modern times is the basis of all power -- financial or monetary strength. The public subscribe eagerly to the new loan, because they are satisfied of the ability of the nation to make good all its obligations. These can. be probably promptly met without resorting, in addition to our ordinary sources of revenue, to more than one or two of those which are so prolific in income to other nations, but which have hitherto been untouched by ourselves. Thus far Customs revenue has been our only resource. The public lands have produced something, but not more than enough to meet the charges of their management, and the annuities to the various Indian tribes. from whom they were purchased. In England, Customs, on an average, produce only one-third of the National revenues. Of the gross sum of $350,000,000. collected the past year, $117,000,000 were received from Customs; $100,000,000 from Excise; $50,000,000 from Income and Property tax; $42,000,000 from Stamps. Of the Customs, $22,000,000 were derived from Wines and Liquors, $28,000,000 from Tobacco, $32,000,000 from Cigars, and $37,000,000 from Tea. As the Excise tax is levied upon beer and spirits home-distilled, liquors, tobacco, tea, and sugar, pay $217,000,000! From similar sources of income the United States, the past year, collected $13,616,467, viz.: From sugars, $8,949,437; from wines and spirits, $3,192,563; from tobacco, $1,374,467; tea having, till the late act of Congress, been admitted by us free of duty. Stamp duties are unknown, and so has been an Income tax, which is now only levied to take effect prospectively; so that from sources that England has been accustomed to raise five-sixths of its revenues, or over $300,000,000 annually, we have, in times past, raised something less than $20,000,000. These sources, so fruitful in the old country, remain yet to be resorted to, except the Income tax. That we shall resort to them, if necessary to carry on the war, or meet the interest and principal of the loans contracted, there can be no doubt. The economy of our Government, and the pacific policy which it has always studiously maintained, has not driven it, as has been the necessities of other Governments, to make taxation a science, which levies and collects so skillfully that the burdens create little complaint, and no great approval, whatever may be the real inconvenience. For the penny a person pays for sipping a cup of tea, or a mug of beer, or glass of wine or brandy, or for puffing a cigar is a trifle easily earned and readily parted with. A smoker pays, perhaps, five pounds annually to Government, whose thrift, for a life time may not have sufficed to accumulate so large a sum. Taxes levied and collected in gross are always burdensome. Were the sums necessary to support the British Government levied in this manner, whether upon processes or results, one-half the amount could never be collected. But by connecting their payment in the smallest sums, with the daily indulgence or avocation of nearly every person in the Kingdom, not the least difficulty is found in raising amounts to us almost fabulous, and which, if necessary, could be vastly increased -- probably doubled. In the Crimean war, the income and property tax went from $27,000,000 to $80,000,000, and fell off at its close to $20,000,000. The ability of the British people to contribute to the support of the Government seems to be unlimited, from the manner in which taxes are levied. Apparently, a third of the whole profits of the labor and capital of the nation could be turned into the National Exchequer, should an occasion arise calling for such a sacrifice. We do not present the system or experience of our mother country as a theme for eulogy or imitation. We hope never to have fastened upon us her social and political systems, which have caused the evils under which she is laboring, and which render their correction, so long as these systems remain, impossible. The ruling classes in that country will not allow their property to be taxed to any considerable extent for the support of Government, but throw the burden upon labor. The miner can drink as much whisky or tea, or use as much tobacco or sugar, as a Lord, and he pays almost as much to the support of the Government, taking the great source of its revenues. In the United States property pays the greater portion of the taxes. Sugar and coffee have for a long time been on the free list. Tobacco we do not import in any considerable quantities. Duties on sugar are almost the only ones in which rich and poor meet pretty much on the same level. But if driven by a temporary stress, we can and shall copy, from the experience of our neighbors. To sustain institutions which are the foundation of their prosperity, and their marvelous material progress, our people will pay more readily than those of other countries, from a more lively sense of benefits received, and of the value of the institutions and Government they are called upon to sustain.

lead_paragraph: The following list, which has been arranged with great care, gives the names of our prisoners now at Richmond, and the nature of the wounds of those who are under surgical treatment. While it is probable that the list is not perfectly accurate, it doubtles contains fewer errors and omissions than any yet published. To the kind thoughtfulness of the surgeons who have recently returned from captivity, the friends of those who were left behind are indebted for the valuable information here given, and we here append their names: Alfred Power, Surgeon, and W.H. abstract: The worst fears of the country have been realized in the defeat and surrender of Col. MULLIGAN, at Lexington, Mo. By this disas-
lead_paragraph: The worst fears of the country have been realized in the defeat and surrender of Col. MULLIGAN, at Lexington, Mo. By this disaster not only has a very important division of our Army been annihilated, but one of the most valuable strategic points in the West has been wrested from us by the enemy, and with it immensely valuable stores, money and munitions of war. The topic is a deeply painful one, but we are compelled to look the calamity in the face, as it is our duty to advise the country of the full extent of it.

abstract: Late Monday evening, Officer LYNCH, of the Third Precinct, Brooklyn, heard the report of a gun or pistol at the corner of Conover and Reade streets. He hastened to the spot, where he found Mrs. ELLEN REENAN shot dead, with eight balls in her body. He searched the premises, but could not find the murderer. He notified Capt. HOLBROOK, of the Third Precinct, of the case, and he proceeded immediately to the house. A general search was then made along the docks, without finding any evidence of the author of the crime. They then procured a boat and drag and searched the water, when they found the body of the murderer about fifteen feet from the dock, at Red Hook Point, in the Twelfth Ward, where he had drowned himself. The name of the murderer and suicide is BERNARD REENAN, who resided at the corner of Conover and Reade streets, and kept a grocery and liquor store. He was about 40 years of age, and is reported to have been in a state of intoxication for several days previous to the commission of the deed. His wife is reported to have been a sober and industrious woman. They leave a family of three children -- two boys and a girl. The eldest is about seven years of age, and the youngest about six months. There is considerable property, which will fall to the children. Officer LYNCH found upon his person $7 in money a musket-ball and some caps. The Coroner was notified, and held an inquest yesterday morning, when a verdict was rendered that Mrs. REENAN came to her death by means of gun-shot wounds inflicted by her husband, and in his case the verdict was that he committed suicide.

The name of the murderer and suicide is BERNARD REENAN, who resided at the corner of Conover and Reade streets, and kept a grocery and liquor store. He was about 40 years of age, and is reported to have been in a state of intoxication for several days previous to the commission of the deed. His wife is reported to have been a sober and industrious woman. They leave a family of three children -- two boys and a girl. The eldest is about seven years of age, and the youngest about six months. There is considerable property, which will fall to the children. Officer LYNCH found upon his person $7 in money a musket-ball and some caps. The Coroner was notified, and held an inquest yesterday morning, when a verdict was rendered that Mrs. REENAN came to her death by means of gun-shot wounds inflicted by her husband, and in his case the verdict was that he committed suicide.

abstract: THE PEOPLE'S CONVENTION.?MARTIN KALBFLEISCH, Mayor, and C.W. GODARD, President of the Kings County Republican General Committee, who were authorized by the People's Meeting recently held in Fort Greene Park, to select three gentlemen from each ward and county town, to meet in convention for the purpose of selecting such candidates for local offices as members of all parties could vote for, have discharged this duty and yesterday made public the list of delegates.
lead_paragraph: THE PEOPLE's CONVENTION. -- MARTIN KALBFLEISCH, Mayor, and C.W. GODARD, President of the Kings County Republican General Committee, who were authorized by the People's Meeting recently held in Fort Greene Park, to select three gentlemen from each ward and county town, to meet in convention for the purpose of selecting such candidates for local offices as members of all parties could vote for, have discharged this duty and yesterday made public the list of delegates. The Committee say that they have endeavored to present such as will command the confidence and respect of our citizens, and who, we trust, will look above the mere elevation of any one man to place, or any party to power, while our country is engaged in this great struggle for its very existence, and who will strive to place such men in nomination as will meet the approval of all our people, and enable us to present an undivided front at the ensuing election." The Convention to make nominations will be held in the City Hall, Saturday next, at 2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Mr. WALLACK'S new and charming establishment, of which we have already given a full account, was opened to the public last evening.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WALLACK's new and charming establishment, of which we have already given a full account, was opened to the public last evening. From an early hour the ample entrances on Broadway and Thirteenth-street were thronged with old friends and admirers of the veteran manager -- friends and admirers who have followed his fortunes from the lowest point, down town to the high latitudes where fashion now reigns. The house was, of course, densely crowded. Not a seat was to be had for money or favor, and we understand that for several days to come the prospect is the same. Mr. ROBERT STOEPEL, the conductor of the orchestra, was the first to receive a welcome from his old patrons. After the last note of the national overture had been played, the curtain ascended for the first time, and Mr. WALLACK stepped forward. Amid frequent bursts of Approbation, he addressed a few words on the subject of his new theatre, and referred to the kindly assistance he had received from various parties and the obligations he felt himself under for the same. He spoke of the spirit of the times, and expressed the hope that he would not be found lagging behind. A few general expressions of this character terminated a ceremony which was the more interesting because it was hearty, and to some extent informal.

abstract: Samuel M. Pettengill vs. Robert F. Mather.  This action was brought to recover a balance alleged to be due from the defendant for moneys collected while in plaintiff's employment.
lead_paragraph: Samuel M. Pettengill vs. Robert F. Mather. -- This action was brought to recover a balance alleged to be due from the defendant for moneys collected while in plaintiff's employment. The defence was that the demand, if any existed, which was denied, had been settled by a bond and mortgage upon real estate in Brooklyn. The allegations in the complaint, amounting to an averment that the action was brought to recover for money received in a fiduciary capacity, and judgment having been rendered in favor of plaintiff for $1,500, an application was made for leave to issue an execution against the person. It appeared in evidence that the defendant had given a deed of the mortgaged property to the plaintiff, and $300 had been allowed therefor on the original claim. Testimony was also read to show that the bond and mortgage had been received as collateral security and not in payment of the demand.

abstract: We should be ashamed to repeat all the obvious objections which we must presume to have been answered by Mr. SEWARD in his own mind before he ventured on this step. He cannot have been ignorant that, while passports often deter the innocent traveler from pursuing the route of his choice, they are mere playthings to the conspirator. He must know that the strictest surveillance never prevented MAZZINI from traversing Italy, or the confederates of ORSINI from entering France with their carpet-bags stuffed with murderous projectiles. He must have weighed all the consequences of creating inducements to smuggle, not goods, but persons, and of the political vices which seldom fail to be developed by a system of espionage. The difficulty of sealing up a seaboard of several hundred miles cannot have escaped him, and that of restricting all communication with Canada seems to have impressed him so much that any such construction is negatived in a supplementary circular. If the object be to check the tide of immigration we can understand this distinction between ports and frontier towns, but for any other purpose it strikes us as quite indefensible. We have all heard of the philosopher who cut one hole in his door for the cat and another for the kitten, but we never heard of his stopping up the smaller of the two holes in the hope of excluding the kitten, as if she would never think of going round by the other. The way of transit is not unknown to the agents of the Confederates, and we have very little doubt that, what with a free use of money and the aid of sympathizers, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, or GARIBALDI himself, if the South should outbid the North and secure the services of that redoubtable leader, might succeed in making the passage from Richmond to Quebec, or from Quebec to Richmond. If, therefore, the Passport system is to be adopted permanently, or at least during the war, we must expect to hear that a chain of officials has been posted along the Southern shores of the great Lakes and the border of Lower Canada and New-Brunswick. Meanwhile, however, every fresh obstacle to free trade or free locomotion must redound to the advantage of our own colonies. This will not be the result of any unfriendly rivalry on our part, but of causes by which America profited more than any other country during the early part of this century. It is not for us to quarrel with legislation which adds so much bone and sinew to our own Empire. We have a right to complain of Mr. SEWARD's discourtesy in leaving Lord LYONS to learn the new arrangement from the newspapers, but to affect any further vexation would be like a tradesman complaining that a rival had shut up his shop.

abstract: In a previous letter, I nearly exhausted details of the battle of Carnifex Ferry. But I met with serious embarrassment in forwarding it. Communica- tion by courier had not been regulated, and there were aggravating delays.
lead_paragraph: In a previous letter, I nearly exhausted details of the battle of Carnifex Ferry. But I met with serious embarrassment in forwarding it. Communica- tion by courier had not been regulated, and there were aggravating delays. Even the condensed report, by telegraph, for the Associated Press, was provokingly, but unavoidably, detained. The fifty-seventh article is so strictly applied that nothing for the Press is permitted to be sent forward without official consent, and the General was so occupied the day after the battle, that his indorsement could not be procured until late in the evening. The messenger who carried the message to Summerville -- eight miles distant -- was also detained, so that the report was not forwarded until next day. To aggravate matters, the operator at Clarksburgh, for what purpose I do not know -- unless it was to convey an impression that he was extremely attentive to his business -- changed the date and locality of the report, and made some other unwarranted alterations.

abstract: No explanation of anything mysterious is half so popular as the assumption of a conspiracy. It saves a great deal of trouble and covers a great deal of ground.
lead_paragraph: No explanation of anything mysterious is half so popular as the assumption of a conspiracy. It saves a great deal of trouble and covers a great deal of ground. As a matter of course, it is a very common resort at the present time. Some time since the Boston Courier asserted, with great emphasis and precision, that at the outbreak of this rebellion, and immediately after the blockade of Baltimore, a conspiracy was formed in New-York for the purpose of dethroning President LINCOLN and installing GEORGE LAW in his stead; and the TIMES was designated as the organ of the conspirators, because we happened, in a hasty paragraph, to use the expression that the President ran some risk of being "superseded" in the functions of his office by the aroused and alarmed impatience of the public, just after he had consented that no more troops should pass through Baltimore. This alleged conspiracy is still doing duty with a certain portion of the Press. The semi-Secessionist newspapers of the Democratic stamp, which are much more alarmed at the prospective destruction of their party than at that of the Union, continue to use it, and the Herald, of course, rolls it as a sweet morsel under its forked tongue. But it was never anything better than moonshine. We do not believe that any human being ever had the slightest idea of "superseding" President LINCOLN, -- or that there was ever any shadow of a conspiracy for anything of the kind.

abstract: The Ninth Regiment of Maine, enlisted for the war, arrived in this City yesterday morning, en route for the seat of war. They came on the steamer Bay State, and landed at Pier No. 3 North River about 10 o'clock. The regiment left Augusta on Monday, and were well received in Boston on Tuesday. There are in all 1,100 men, hailing from Calais, Canton, Hilton, Cornish and Aroostook Counties -- all parts of the State being represented. They consist of mechanics and laborers, and though comprising a number of Germans and Irish, are mainly native-born. Physically, they will bear comparison with any regiment in the field. They are to receive Enfield rifles at Washington. They have the regulation uniform, of excellent material, commissariat wagons, camp equipage and four days' rations for each man. The band numbers twenty-four pieces. They left for Washington in the evening train. The following are the officers:

abstract: Two great battles, such as have never been witnessed on this continent, and rarely on any other, are now impending, and must soon be fought.
lead_paragraph: Two great battles, such as have never been witnessed on this continent, and rarely on any other, are now impending, and must soon be fought. On the Potomac two vast, armies -- numbering together near four hundred thousand men -- are confronting each other, with pickets in speaking distance, and each menacing attack daily. In Missouri two other great armies, of near forty thousand men each, are hurrying to a collision. The National troops under. Gen. FREMONT are anxious to meet the enemy, and wipe out by their courage and prowess the memory of recent disasters; and the rebel forces, flushed with a barren victory, are equally in earnest to increase their laurels by new triumphs. That there will be immense slaughter when at either point these forces shall come in conflict, there can be no doubt. The rebel cause hangs suspended on the issue. If they shall be beaten, as we feel morally certain they will be, the great rebellion, which will occupy so prominent a place in history, will be practically subdued. A lingering campaign or two may have to be carried on, -- a scattered and hopeless resistance at certain points may remain to be overcome, but the backbone of the revolt will have been broken. A victory in Missouri, and that State will be fixed as a star in the Union, and all impediments in the way of the expedition that is to sweep down the Valley of the Mississippi will be removed. If MCCLELLAN shall be victor on the Potomac, the way will be open for the central column to advance in a triumphal march to Richmond on its way to the Gulf. No rally can ever be made by the rebel Army after a defeat on the Potomac. It will disappear as the locusts before the east wind. The last hope of secession will have vanished, and the boasted Southern Confederacy will become one of those dissolving views of history that are never witnessed but once.

abstract: Few have pretended to give, and fewer still have succeeded in giving, a consistent view of the casus belli in America. The truth is, that wars generally spring from mixed motives, and can seldom be traced to a single cause. Who can say whether CHARLEMAGNE's wars were wars of empire, or wars of race, or wars of religion? Who would undertake to prove that zeal for Catholicism, or dynastic ambition, or the instinct of self-aggrandizement, or any other of the many reasons that might be imagined, was the secret of such contests as those between the Guelphs and Ghibellines, or the Thirty Years' War? But never was the origin of a great struggle more inscrutable than that of the one now raging. As in the case of those fires that have lately terrified this metropolis, the causes of the mischief have been almost obliterated by its rapid progress and ruinous effects. Future historians may perhaps detect the dominant element in the great fermentation of passions and interests, but we shall not affect to do so. One or two things, indeed, we do know, for the event has already revealed them. Commercial jealousy, or rather a natural impatience of monopoly, certainly had its share in breaking up the Union. A longing for independence, with a fixed resolve to make the South the centre of a new experiment in Government, has shown itself too clearly to be mistaken. Long bickerings and mutual antipathies, only differing in their scale from those which are daily dragged to light in Sir C. CRESWELL's Court, may have found expression in a fierce demand for a national divorce. Idle, however, as it would be to seek in any or all of these predisposing circumstances the ultimate cause of a fact but half realized, we are not altogether at the mercy of conjecture. It is easier to say what is not than what may thus I dismiss is the notion that "the liberty of the African' race" is the gage of battle. We do not mean to argue that it is a mere accident that the fracture took place at the point of junction between the Slave and Free States, or that Abolitionist principles had nothing to do with Mr. LINCOLN's election. Doubtless the Republicans were in earnest about checking the spread of Slavery into the Territories, and the Southerners felt their defeat as a rebuke to their pecular institutions. But that this was not the true object of the  movement on either side, even at its the outset, admits of every proof short of demonstration, and that the Slavery question has since been utterly lost in the melee of civil war, is capable of actual demonstration. Mr. LINCOLN volunteered pledge after pledge that he would be no party to Abolitionist measures. In the great majority of messages, addresses, and party manifestoes that have since been issued, Slavery is altogether thrust into the background. Its maintenance is not the war-cry of the South; its abolition is not the war-cry of the North. Free trade, foreign policy, national sovereignty, social superiority, even civilization, -- anything rather than the old watchword of domestic rights, has been the shibboleth of the Secessionists. On the other hand, the Northern Press and the Northern Army have equally forgotten the "idea" which might have sanctified their arms in the eyes of many excellent persons. So far from inviting servile insurrections, their Generals have in some cases threatened to put them down, and in others returned fugitive slaves who had escaped to their camps, while no abatement of the slave laws has been promised in the event of the "rebellion," as it is still called at Washington, being suppressed.

abstract: Agreeably to notice there was a gathering of the Sons of Connecticut last evening, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, for the purpose of adopting measures to entertain the volunteers from their native State during their journey to the seat of war. Messrs. P. M. WETNORE, P. PERIT, R.N. BLATCHFORD and other prominent gentlemen were present. Speeches of a highly patriotic nature were made, and a committee was appointed to greet and entertain any troops from Connecticut that should pass through or temporarily sojourn in this City during their transportation to the seat of war.
lead_paragraph: Agreeably to notice there was a gathering of the Sons of Connecticut last evening, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, for the purpose of adopting measures to entertain the volunteers from their native State during their journey to the seat of war. abstract: TRIAL OF A DUMMY ENGINE ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. The new dummy engine, just completed by the Hudson River Railroad Company, for running cars from the station at Thirtyfirst-street to the depot in Chambers-street, was subjected to a trial of its merits, yesterday, in presence of a majority of the members of the Common Council, and other citizens.
lead_paragraph: TRIAL OF A DUMMY ENGINE ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. -- The new dummy engine, just completed by the Hudson River Railroad Company, for running cars from the station at Thirtyfirst-street to the depot in Chambers-street, was subjected to a trial of its merits, yesterday, in presence of a majority of the members of the Common Council, and other citizens. The Railroad Company have spent much time and money in perfecting the improvements contained in this engine, and, in the unanimous judgment of those who witnessed its operation yesterday, they have now attained complete success. The dummy is entirely free from any possible objection that can be urged against it as a street-engine; in fact, it is more safe, and less a nuisance, than the horse-cars now in use, while at the same time it is sufficiently powerful to meet the wants of the Railroad Company. The engine is entirely concealed from view in a car resembling a passenger-car; no smoke or steam is emitted, (the former being avoided by the use of coke, and the latter being condensed as fast as used, by passing through a water tank with which the car is lined,) and yet it is capable of drawing ten loaded cars at the lawful rate of speed, and can be stopped almost instantaneously. In the trial trip from Chambers-street to Thirty-first-street, yesterday, three cars were attached, loaded with passengers, and, by actual test, the train was brought to a dead stand, while moving at the legal rate of speed, in three seconds and a half. The train was several times stopped in a distance of from four to six feet from the time the signal was given. So far as danger to pedestrians is concerned, it was pronounced by all to be superior to horse-power, while its liability to frighten horses is no greater than that of an ordinary passenger-car. It appears that the Hudson River Railroad were several years ago permitted, by. resolution of the Common Council, to run a dummy engine between their two stations, which they did for a short time; but, owing to a want of capacity and other defects in the dummies then in use, they were finally abandoned, and the old horse-power was again resorted to. And now when, at a great expense, they have just overcome the difficulties, and are about to restore the dummy, the Board of Aldermen have rescinded the resolution allowing them to use it. The rescinding resolution is now before the Board of Councilmen for their indorsement, which, judging from the opinions expressed yesterday, it will never get.

abstract: For the second time in this year our people are called upon by their Chief Magistrate to keep an appointed day as a day of Humiliation, Fasting and Prayer.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in this year our people are called upon by their Chief Magistrate to keep an appointed day as a day of Humiliation, Fasting and Prayer. Such days are not so much in consonance with our National character as some others. We are too proud a people to willingly accept the necessity of humiliation; too self-reliant to acknowledge readily and heartily that of ourselves we can do nothing; and Fourths of July are more heartily celebrated among us than Fast days. Still it cannot be doubted that this second Fast day will be better observed than the first was. We have had occasion since then to familiarize ourselves in some degree with the air of the Valley of Humiliation, and the sense of dependence upon a higher power has grown somewhat among us.

abstract: We are indebted to a Frenchman, who writes a letter from Richmond to the last number of the Paris Revue Contemporaine, for two valuable pieces of information. "It is very curious and very sad," he writes, "to learn that LINCOLN and DAVIS, the two Presidents, are very closely related, having married sister!" This relationship, he goes on to state, had inspired hopes of an arrangement of the troubles between the two sections -- but all in vain; and such, he concludes, are the horrors of oivil war.

abstract: The naturalizationlaws of the rebel States have been construed by its legal authorities to mean that no foreigner can become a citizen without joining and serving in the Army. This is the only way in which any man, note "native and to the manor born," can entitle himself to the rights and privileges of citizenship in that celebrated nationality. We can imagine how the frugal and industrious German, the hardworking Irishman, the thrifty Scotchman, the cautious Englishman and the liberty-loving Frenchman, will rush to embrace these terms -- how patiently they will endure the privations and hardships of camp life -- how earnestly they will drill, and how courageously fight for the overthrow of a Republic, the freest in the world -- how they will prize the right of citizenship among a people where the aristocracy of class and caste is more inveterate even than that which drove them from their own country -- where labor is social degradation, and where the poor white is held in deeper contempt, if possible, than even the slaves themselves. We can imagine too, how the Confederate treasury will be filled by heaps of emigrant gold, and the Confederate Army swollen by thousands upon thousands of hardy emigrants, who swing out from the political and social oppressions of the Old World to find freedom, social equality and thrift in the New. Emigrants, ready to fight, bare-headed and bare-footed, with lean rations and leaner pay, for freedom against the free, and in favor of a Republic based upon Slavery -- a new civilization resting upon the everlasting bondage" -- will do well to run the blockade, and enlist under JEFF DAVIS.

abstract: Another important reconnoissance took place yesterday across the Potomac. In the morning, at 8 o'clock, 5,000 infantry, three companies of cavalry and three batteries, left Chain Bridge  under the command of Gen. SMITH, for the neighborhood of Lewinsville.
lead_paragraph: Another important reconnoissance took place yesterday across the Potomac. In the morning, at 8 o'clock, 5,000 infantry, three companies of cavalry and three batteries, left Chain Bridge under the command of Gen. SMITH, for the neighborhood of Lewinsville. About 2 o'clock in the afternoon, while our troops were at Lewinsville, a large party of rebels, consisting of about five regiments of infantry, a regiment of cavalry and six pieces of artillery, approached from the direction of Falls Church. They opened on our men with their battery, and their firing was immediately responded to by Captains GRIFFIN's and MOTT's guns. Thirty shots, both of shell and solid, were fired from our batteries, which silenced the rebel cannon, and the enemy immediately retired to Falls Church. It is not known what damage was sustained on their side. One man of ours was slightly wounded by the explosion of a shell. The object of the expedition having been accomplished, our troops fell back to their original position at the Chain Bridge, bearing with them a man representing himself as an Aid-de-Camp to Col. STEWART, of the Virginia rebel cavalry.

abstract: The Brooklyn Navy-yard has not presented such a scene of activity for some time past as it does now. Great exertions are being made to have the vessels now fitting out ready for active service with the least possible delay.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Navy-yard has not presented such a scene of activity for some time past as it does now. Great exertions are being made to have the vessels now fitting out ready for active service with the least possible delay. The purchased steamer Augusta will be the next vessel to go into commission. She has been at the Navy-yard about two weeks and will very soon be ready for her officers and crew.

abstract: We are sorry that we have nothing yet that looks like a redeeming feature in the loss of Lexington, Missouri. The more recent accounts rather add to, than diminish, the apparent value of the conquest to the rebels.
lead_paragraph: We are sorry that we have nothing yet that looks like a redeeming feature in the loss of Lexington, Missouri. The more recent accounts rather add to, than diminish, the apparent value of the conquest to the rebels. It is now said that they obtained $1,500,000, found in the Banks there, instead of half that amount, as we estimated. The rebels themselves report that they captured 21 cannon, 6,000 stand of arms, and 4,000 prisoners. They make no mention of the value of horses, but of these it is said that a large number in the fortifications -- as many as 400 -- were killed.

abstract: Not a single bale of American cotton is now known to be at sea, and those engaged in the cotton trade must not expect their stock of it to be replenished during the blockade of the Southern ports. After calculating the total stock of cotton in the port...
lead_paragraph: Not a single bale of American cotton is now known to be at sea, and those engaged in the cotton trade must not expect their stock of it to be replenished during the blockade of the Southern ports. After calculating the total stock of cotton in the port of Liverpool on the 23d August last, and adding there to the probable further receipts to the 27th December next, our contemporary estimates that the stock in Liverpool on the last mentioned date will be about 549,000 bales, which, as the supposed rate of consumption, would keep the mills going for about eleven weeks beyond Christmas. As it is difficult to see how, with the continuance of the American block demand can be much longer prevented from exceeding the supply, the positive is very alarming, as in the manufacturing districts the system of short time must be generally introduced, and the privation and suffering which this system causes are too well known to need recapitulation.

abstract: We see notices in sundry quarters of public meetings held to sustain military officers, against their superiors. A meeting of citizens of Pennsylvania, was held a few days since to "demand the immediate release" of Col. EINSTEIN, who, if seems, has been placed under arrest for some offence, and is awaiting his trial. These citizens declare him to be a "man of strict integrity, and a profound soldier from practice," and they "protest" against the treatment he has received. So also in Ironton, Mo., a meeting of the "commissioned officers, of the Twenty-first Regiment of U.S. Volunteers' was held lately to sustain Gen. FREMONT, as a "great military chieftain," and to protest against the "efforts being made to effect his removal."

abstract: -- Until we have accounts from the vessel itself, it will be premature to pronounce the late misadventure of the Great Eastern evidence that the ship is a failure. The presumptions are, however, strongly against her. Having sailed from Liverpool on the 11th inst., she is met in the course of the fourth day putting back, with the loss of both side-wheels, of very nearly all her boats, with bulwarks stove in, and rolling so heavily that the passengers could only maintain their footing on deck by clinging to ropes stretched across for the purpose. Here are nearly all the conditions for which the Great Eastern claimed superiority, if not perfection, violated. She cannot outride even a moderate storm. For on the day of her departure, the Saxonia sailed from Southampton for New-York, passing very nearly over the course taken by the Great Eastern; and while her log reports storms of wind and rain, it lays no stress upon the weather as of more than ordinary severity, and she certainly passed through it herself without damage. What special disaster or stress the great ship may have encountered we have yet to learn. But it must have been one to which smaller vessels were less sensitive.
lead_paragraph: -- Until we have accounts from the vessel itself, it will be premature to pronounce the late misadventure of the Great Eastern evidence that the ship is a failure. The presumptions are, however, strongly against her. Having sailed from Liverpool on the 11th inst., she is met in the course of the fourth day putting back, with the loss of both side-wheels, of very nearly all her boats, with bulwarks stove in, and rolling so heavily that the passengers could only maintain their footing on deck by clinging to ropes stretched across for the purpose. Here are nearly all the conditions for which the Great Eastern claimed superiority, if not perfection, violated. She cannot outride even a moderate storm. For on the day of her departure, the Saxonia sailed from Southampton for New-York, passing very nearly over the course taken by the Great Eastern; and while her log reports storms of wind and rain, it lays no stress upon the weather as of more than ordinary severity, and she certainly passed through it herself without damage. What special disaster or stress the great ship may have encountered we have yet to learn. But it must have been one to which smaller vessels were less sensitive.
