abstract: As the exact and official returns of the Census are being made public, we behold more clearly the precise march and direction of the population which has been filling up, during the last ten years, the unoccupied territory of the Union.
lead_paragraph: As the exact and official returns of the Census are being made public, we behold more clearly the precise march and direction of the population which has been filling up, during the last ten years, the unoccupied territory of the Union. Its grand and main course is Westward, with some currents to the Northwest and some to the South-west. The flood of population over some of our new States in the far West, has probably never been equaled in the history of emigration, both in the character of the emigrants and in the number placed upon new soil, where before were the animals of the prairie and the forest, and the roving Indian. Minnesota, for instance, increases from 6,077 inhabitants in 1850, to 162,022 in 1860, or at a rate of increase of over twenty-five hundred per cent; Oregon from 13,294 to 52,464, or at the rate of two hundred and ninety-four per cent; Iowa from 192,214 to 674,948, or at 251.22 per cent; Texas from 212,592 to 602,432, or 183.37 per cent; Wisconsin from 305,391 to 775,873, or 154.06 per cent.

abstract: The recommendation of the President for the observance of yesterday as a National Fast Day, was almost universally respected by the citizens of Hudson County.
lead_paragraph: The recommendation of the President for the observance of yesterday as a National Fast Day, was almost universally respected by the citizens of Hudson County. Business of all classes was almost entirely suspended, and the people were as orderly or more so than on the Sabbath, and no persons were observed under the influence, of liquor.

abstract: -- Orders have been issued from Washington, suspending the drafting for soldiers in Iowa. This is the only Northern State in which it has been found expedient to resort to that method of recruiting the Army. Voluntary enlistments have been found sufficient elsewhere, and the Secretary of War does well in putting a stop to it there. There is patriotism enough in the loyal States to furnish spontaneously, and without compulsion, all the men and money necessary for the defence of the country. If Iowa shall be laggard, the deficiency will be more than made up in Connecticut, or even in little Rhode Island. Impressed soldiers have little stomach for fighting, and still less for the drills and discipline of camp life. The leaven of patriotism is quite as essential in an Army as elsewhere. The man who fights simply because he is compelled to do so, will be very likely to forget his devotion to his country when bullets are whistling around him, and prove his devotion to himself by running away.
lead_paragraph: -- Orders have been issued from Washington, suspending the drafting for soldiers in Iowa. abstract: The Baptist church, corner of Broome and Elizabeth streets, Was most densely and uncomfortably crowded yesterday afternoon every possible standing, sitting or seeing spot being occupied.
lead_paragraph: The Baptist church, corner of Broome and Elizabeth streets, Was most densely and uncomfortably crowded yesterday afternoon -- every possible standing, sitting or seeing spot being occupied. Owing to a mistake in the hour of service, as announced, a delay of half an hour took place, which was improved by an improvised prayer meeting, in which Rev. Mr. SOMMERS and others took part. The sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. WESTON, who had been unanimously selected by the Conference of Pastors, and who took his text from 1 Kings, chap. viii., verse 57: "The Lord our God be with us, as he was with our fathers; let him not leave us, nor forsake us." The sermon was a finished and didactic discourse. He claimed that patriotism was a Christian virtue, implanted in the hearts of man by the Divine hand. No nation on earth had so glorious a history as our own, and none the promise of so glorious a future, but if we were to stifle patriotism, our name as a nation would rot, and we would, instead of a blessing, leave a curse to those whom we have robbed of that fair heritage. Our Government has a building designed of God, and could we stand supine when men were ruthlessly attempting to subvert it? There were even now blind Sampsons in our midst, feeling about for the pillars, that they might tear them from them places, and involve the whole fabric in one common ruin. It was, therefore, our duty to pray for our Government, and our country which God had given us. It should be impressed upon every heart that Government was an ordinance of God, and that in yielding obedience to it, we were yielding to God's voice, and that alone would be worth to us all the war could cost. But if we felt that war depended on human sufferance, its ruin was certain, and it must perish as surely as that everything human perishes. Government was made for the people, and woe to that man who attempted to divert it from the people. It could not be entertained that God, who had desired all things for man's good, should have left this to men to establish for themselves, only to be subject to human caprices and changes. Divine Providence always was on the side of established Governments, and when a man goes forth to fight for his Government, he fights for a divine and not a human organization. Our Government overflows with blessings to all under it. It watches over fathers, sons and brothers. Its glorious flag floats in every port to protect those who live under it, and its shield is more potential than that of Rome in her most glorious days, and in fact we have best known that we had a Government by its blessings. The destruction of this Confederacy was sought for by some because they thought more money could be made by its destruction; and those who so thought, had emblazoned on their banner, "Cotton is King." Even some men were to be found at the North who could coolly calculate the value of our Government and say, "Let the South go -- we can make more money without her." The South says that we at the North are fighting for a sentiment, while they were fighting for their homes and firesides -- and, therefore, they must prevail. He admitted the proposition, but denied the inference. The speaker proceeded to draw a comparison between the evils attendant upon the conditions of war and peace, and contended that those of peace, though less sensibly felt, were the most dangerous and insidious. This war had aroused the spirits of all patriots; it had abolished all distinctions of politics and ties of party. Nor were the disasters which had thus far attended our arms a cause for the abatement of hope, and he instanced the history of Benjamin and Judah, where the latter, after twice encountering defeat at the hands of Benjamin, having been commanded by the Lord to go forth and meet him, went forth a third time to God, and asked if it was his will they should go out again; and again they were ordered to go forth, but on this occasion with the promise of the Lord, "Be sure on that day I, even I, will be with you;" and in that contest Judah triumphed. So it would be with us, if we remembered our God, and put our trust in his Divine mercy and power. The speaker closed with an earnest exhortation to prayer, so that this day should be an era in the Nation's history, of a whole people coming to God in penitence for the past and hope for the future.

abstract: Congress at its recent War session directed, in the general Loan act, the use by the Treas- ury of any part of fifty million dollars in United States Notes of Circulation, of small...
lead_paragraph: Congress at its recent War session directed, in the general Loan act, the use by the Treas- ury of any part of fifty million dollars in United States Notes of Circulation, of small denominations, not below five dollars, payable on demand at New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, Cincinnati or St. Louis. Twenty millions in these Notes, of fives, tens and twenties, have been prepared under direction of the Secretary of the Treasury, and are now being circulated as rapidly as they can be signed and registered at the Department, though not as fast as the public all over the country would like to take them, in place of gold coin, for the Government dues. They were promptly approved and warmly recommended for the Army by an order from the veteran Lieutenant-General, WINFIELD SCOTT. For Army payments they are eagerly accepted, as the greatest imaginable convenience to all ranks, and by none with more grateful promptness than by the common soldier in our volunteer Army. The alternative of gold coin at the same time is not withheld, but the Paymasters at Fortress Monroe report that six out of seven of the men and officers give preference to the United States Circulating Notes. At Arlington, twelve out of nineteen thousand dollars paid to a single regiment, some days ago, were in these Notes. At the Sub-Treasury in this City, where there is yet no adequate supply of the Notes for original distribution, the Cashier is every day applied to to repay out the Notes which return from Washington and the West for redemption, which he is doing to the full extent of these redemptions. At the West they are received with the greatest favor by all the people and by all moneyed institutions in Cincinnati, Chicago, &c., a rumor put afloat in this city to the contrary notwithstanding. There is no good reason why this should not be so. The United States Notes are not so much employed for the profit as for the convenience of the Treasury. They are not made so much to create a money capital at Washington as to save the undue disturbance of the Money markets on the seaboard by the frequent and heavy transfers of gold coin to the interior for Army purposes, where such coin is intrinsically less valuable to the trade of the country than these United States Notes, payable in coin on the seaboard, to which all the interior exchanges inevitably tend. At the North and East they are universally acceptable among the people. The exceptions among the bankers are quite rare, and confined, as we believe, to certain parties in this City, who have made the exclusive bullion system a sort of hobby. At the general Bank Convention of the three great cities, on the 15th of August, these parties were left in a small minority on making the question of interference with the National circulation. Since then the bankers of Philadelphia have unanimously reaffirmed their sanction of United States Notes redeemable on demand, and from Boston we have yet to hear the first word of objection.

abstract: We publish below the article of the St. Louis Daily Evening News on the "Fall of Lexington," for the publication of which its proprietor, Mr. CHARLES G. RAMSEY, and editor, Mr. D.M. GRISSOM, were arrested and the paper suppressed. It seems that military authorities are willing enough to be praised, but cannot endure to be criticised by the newspapers. The Evening News is, and has always been, a slaunch Union paper, and its statements in regard to the loss of Lexington are moderate compared with the utterances of the Press generally on that shameful affair:

abstract: Rev. Dr. VINTON delivered a very argumentative discourse last evening at St. Ann's Church, inEighteenth-street, in which he argued, and so far as sound argument will do it, he demonstrated most conclusively, that the doctrine maintained by the South, that the people of a State owed to it a duty paramount to that which the National Government imposed was erroneous. The State Rights' doctrine, was discussed at length, and the fallacy of CALHOUN's nullification doctniue exhibited in a light not at all flattering to the wisdom of the South Carolina statesman. The Doctor attacked the favoriteargument of the cSeeders, which he stated to be, that in as much as each State, separately and for itself, adopted the Federal Constitution, therefore it had an undoubted right to secede whenever it saw fit, it being its own judge of the sufficiency of the causes which impelled it to the separation. The speaker claimed that the sixth article of the United States Constitution necessarily extinguished the State's sovereignty, and made it of paramount obligation upon the citizen's of all the States. He was listened to with great attention throughout, by a very large audience.

abstract: Richard T. Spencer vs. The Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works. -- This was an application for a discharge of attachment. In May last an attachment was issued against the defendants as a foreign corporation, under which the Sheriff levied upon property which is now in his hands. On the 4th of this month, on papers alleging that the value of the property attached was less than the amount claimed by the plaintiff in the action, and an appearance on behalf of the defendants, an ex parte order was made that an inventory and appraisement of the property be made under section 241 of the Code, by the Sheriff of this County, with the assistance of two disinterested freeholders, due notice of time and place being given to plaintiff's attorney. The appraisement was waived by the plaintiff's attorney, who consented that the value, should be estimated at $700, the demand being over $3,000.
lead_paragraph: Richard T. Spencer vs. The Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works. -- This was an application for a discharge of attachment. abstract: Yesterday evening a Union prayer meeting was held at the above Church, under the auspices of the Army Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association. The religious exercises were opened by the congregation singing a hymn; Rev. Dr. GILLETTE then read a portion of the 8th chapter of the 1st Book of Kings, after which Rev. Mr. COOKMAN offered up a prayer on behalf of our soldiers. Dr. GILLETTE then exhorted any of the brethren or sisters present, who felt the spirit move them, to pray for those who were away fighting for the defence of our country. Many did so, and begged God in his mercy to relieve us from the horrors of civil war, as soon as He in his infinite wisdom might deem fit. At this juncture, Dr. GILLETTE asked that blessings should, be asked, and Divine aid implored, on behalf of the prisoners taken by the rebels, and who were captives at Richmond. He spoke feelingly, as he had a son who was a prisoner in the hands of the insurgents. In conclusion, the reverend doctor said, if it were needed, he would, himself at once shoulder a musket and march to the defence of his country.

abstract: A writer in the Philadelphia Bulletin says: "The rebel JEFF. THOMPSON, now figuring so extensively and defiantly, is known by the writer to be an infamous scoundrel. He is a native of Jefferson County, Virginia, and practiced law at Charlestown bar. Being of handsome size and proportions, and winning address, he was exceedingly popular, and had he had talents and virtue commensurate with external appearances, would have risen to distinguished position. But his true character did not long remain concealed, for he proved false to an amiable, loving wife and three children, by seducing a young lady of Charlestown. Fearing the steel of the outraged brothers of the unfortunate lady, he hastily fled, and his whereabouts were not known for some years, when he turned up in Missouri. Fifteen years are passed, and the rebel adulterer has become famous for the crime in aiding in the destruction of his country. Brand the infamous wretch, and pass his name in the chapter with FLOYD, WIGFALL, WISE, MASON & Co.

abstract: We are perfectly safe in saving that, within the memory of but few residents of this City, was never a proclamation fixing a day for Fasting, Humilation and Prayer, more generally or fittingly observed than the one which was set apart yesterday for such a purpose. On other occasions of a similar character, the closing of the public offices and principal business houses, has been usual, while places less prominent pursued their usual course, at best, with half-closed blinds and doors. But yesterday the cessation of business was far more general than is customary, even upon the Sabbath. All persons, all parties, all religious denominations, of Christians and Jews, with one accord abstained from their customary week-day avocations, and repaired to their several places of worship for humiliation and prayer for the safety of our Government. The only exceptions found were among the keepers of eating and drinking-saloons. Never before, we believe, were so many of our City Churches filled to overflowing on any single day. And never before was there the same unanimity of thought and of feeling expressed from our pulpits as on yesterday. In nearly every case, all other topics than the great one which absorbs the attention of all, were laid aside. How to crush out rebellion, and perpetuate our Government were the only themes, and to their elucidation the Divine aid was supplicated from every pulpit in the City. And, with a view to furnishing our readers with an idea of the peculiar character of the services, we append brief notices of what was done in a large number of the principal Churches and Synagogues in the City.
lead_paragraph: We are perfectly safe in saving that, within the memory of but few residents of this City, was never a proclamation fixing a day for Fasting, Humilation and Prayer, more generally or fittingly observed than the one which was set apart yesterday for such a purpose. abstract: Both the text and subject of Dr. THOMPSON's discourse, last evening, were found in the President's proclamation and the circumstances of the day. He, however, read a portion of the 80th Psalm as being especially appropriate to the occasion. We had met together, he said, under the pressure of a great calamity and peril to our country as a nation. It was not the peril which at one time threatened Washington -- not the peril of a violation of the blockade -not the peril of universal bankruptcy -- from all these we had emerged. It was a greater peril than any of these, for the rebellion aimed to strike a death-blow upon popular liberty. He should speak of this danger and its remedy. He defined this popular liberty, of which we were in the enjoyment, and contrasted it with the liberty enjoyed by the people of less favored nations. The measures which had been adopted by the Government for preserving it, in the suppression of newspapers and the establishment of martial law, met his hearty approbation. They were measures of military necessity, consequent upon the action of the leaders of the Southern people, who would strike down every right of the people in the aggregate and detail, to substitute therefor a military despotism. After mentioning the privileges resulting. from popular liberty -- a free Press, feee discussion, and popular suffrage -- all of which the success of this monstrous insurrection would forever destroy, he said that the rebellion also assaulted the right of the Republic to exist as a Government, by its fallacious doctrine of secession. The question for the people now to decide is whether this Government shall stand, in its present form; adapted as it is to all the wanis of human. society. Illustrating a point by describing the mode of welding the metal in making a rifled cannon, he said that the Nation should be united, and we should come out of the furnace a gigantic columbiad shaking the mountains of the Sierra Nevada. In the name and strength of Almighty God, and by his blessing sought and won,we must crush out this rebellion effectually by the strong arm of force. The Government is doing more, and is a better friend to business by exerting itself to put down this rebellion than he who would ask peace. It is necessary to wipe out Slavery, from the South. The instigators of this rebellion are the foes of civil and religious liberty, and hostile to every Institution and principle of civilization. While Slavery exists, therefore, our dearests rights are Imperiled. It is prying upon our vitals, and must be cut out with the sharp edge of the sword. The Church was densely crowded, and the Reverend Doctor was frequently interrupted by applause.

abstract: Gen. LANE's command surprised a superior force of rebels at Papinsville, Mo., on the 21st, and after a severe fight, routed them, losing 17 killed and a large number wounded. The rebels lost 40 killed, 100 prisoners, and all their tents, wagons and supplies.

abstract: If every natural law that man turns to his account and makes his servant, instead of being his master, is a triumph of his genius,
lead_paragraph: If every natural law that man turns to his account and makes his servant, instead of being his master, is a triumph of his genius, how much greater must that be when he recasts a continent and adapts it to his convenience and his will. The colonists of this country found its great rivers -- its natural highways -- discharging their waters two thousand miles from the future seats of commerce, wealth and population of the Atlantic slope fronting the Old World. They speedily set to work to correct this oversight of nature. A whole continent had to be reformed. The outlet of the great lakes was diverted into the magnificent estuary of the Hudson -- the Mississippi into the great lakes -- so that the two great rivers of the continent, watering its fairest portions, and a territory unequaled in the world for the productiveness of its soil and salubrity of its climate, were, in effect, turned into our harbor, and flow past our docks and wharves, bringing to us a commerce greater in bulk and value of the kind than that of any other country in the world. In peace it was a grand spectacle, and a source of untold wealth. In war, it is the stay and support both of the Government and people, and the astonishment of other nations, who judged of the effect of a civil war in this country by their own experience. They could be brought to an understanding of our condition and strength only by facts which are every day forced upon them by the freedom and extent of our internal commerce. The country really needs no other outlet for its products than the harbor of New-York. The great system of public works resting upon it, penetrates nearly every county of each State, and afford not only the most expeditious, but, in most instances, the cheapest routes to markets, whether at home or abroad. Every Southern port closed, swells the commerce of our own. Up to this period in the season, the Southern embargo has affected only breadstuffs and provisions that were wont to go down the Mississippi. These are all turned north, and come to us over our railroads and canals. We have no statement of the increased traffic of the former, for the present year, as these only report yearly, but we get weekly accounts from the canals. The excess of breadstuffs over last year, which have already reached tide-water through this avenue, equals 10,000,000 bushels; the quantity for the past year being 23,000,000, for the present 33,000,000 bushels. The increase of traffic on the railroads has probably been in still greater ratio. The total quantity brought to tide-water the past year by the Erie and Central Railroads, and the Erie Canal, was 73,000,000 bushels; the present year it will exceed 100,000,000, giving us for exportation, in addition for what is wanted for domestic consumption, a quantity valued at the lowest estimate, at $100,000,000.

abstract: Rev. Mr. BARTLETT prefaced his discourse by reading the proclamations of the President, the Governor and Mayor KALBFLEISCH, relative to the observance of the day. This, he said, was preeminently the time for prayer.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Mr. BARTLETT prefaced his discourse by reading the proclamations of the President, the Governor and Mayor KALBFLEISCH, relative to the observance of the day. This, he said, was preeminently the time for prayer. The physicians were gathered around the bed of a sick nation, which had been smitten in its infancy with a malignant malady. At its birth a plague-spot showed itself, which far-sighted political surgery would have cauterized at once, instead of applying the emollients and poultices of compromise; but a temporizing policy was pursued, and a dire extreme had resulted, which required honest and skillful surgery to meet it. All this while, too, her unnatural mother watched with bitter jealousy, casting and calculating the share of her legacy at her offspring's death.

abstract: The Reverend gentleman took his text from the 18th Chapter of 2d Samuel, from the 9th to the 19th verses, both inclusive. After some-preliminary ob-
lead_paragraph: The Reverend gentleman took his text from the 18th Chapter of 2d Samuel, from the 9th to the 19th verses, both inclusive. After some-preliminary observations explanatory of the text, he drew a parallel between the rebellion of Absalom, the son of King David, and the present rebellion, instigated by the sons of King Cotton. "The wretched conspiracy," said the speaker, "which was instigated by that rebel son of David, has perhaps no parallel in the whole history of the world, save in this equally shameless and causeless rebellion instituted by the sons of the South. The rebel Absalom, we are told in the context, must needs begin his nefarious scheme of plotting to overthrow his father's kingdom by sending out spies through all the tribes of Israel; and we find a striking coincidence in the fact that this work of rebellion was begun in the southern part of the King's dominions. What is there in the mild breezes of the "Sunny South" to inspire treachery and rebellion? Thanks be to Heaven, not every one who is native of a Southern clime is traitor to his home, his country and his God! From personal acquaintance, I know that throughout the States of Virginia, North Carolina and Tennessee there are some whose love of country is stronger than the ties of consanguinity, and holier than that for money or kindred. But nothing on earth or in Heaven is too holy to be sacrificed by a traitor. He who will plot treason against the land that gave him birth, and against the Government which from earliest infancy has protected him in his life, his liberty and his pursuit of happiness, is to be trusted never. He is a rebel all over, and would betray the mother that bore him and the God who gave him life. Traitors have existed in all ages of the world, but their nature is everywhere the same -- wicked beyond comparison. In the infancy of this country, a BENEDICT ARNOLD sought to betray the cause he had espoused, but what shall we think of men who seek the entire overthrow of the best and most benign Government the world has ever seen? Wicked beyond measure, wholly depraved.

abstract: This Church was crowded yesterday to its utmost capacity. The Reverend gentleman's text was taken from Hebrews, 12th chap., 1st verse: "The Sin which does so beset us."
lead_paragraph: This Church was crowded yesterday to its utmost capacity. The Reverend gentleman's text was taken from Hebrews, 12th chap., 1st verse: "The Sin which does so beset us." He said that man in his individual capacity generally has one besetting sin which stamps his character, although it does not fix its brand upon his brow; and so it is with nations, which pay the penalty therefor. As an instance, he quoted France, which paid the penalty of her persecution of the Huguenots, by the withdrawal of their industry from their fatherland. The circumstances of assembling to-day were well known to every one. A gigantic array of rebels had assembled to dismember the Union, and should we ever submit to their demands, no treaty of peace could ever suppress the inevitable breaking out of the smoldering flame engendered by the rancor of the present contest. The great and only permanent remedy must be the crushing out forever this unholy rebellion. This is the unanimous opinion of twenty millions of men at the North, who are sympathized with by a large number of Union men at the South; for it was no use to inquire now, whether the present state of things was brought about by the impertinent intemperance of Northern Abolitionists, or the work of disappointed Southern politicians; as Mr. STEPHENS, the Vice-President of the seceding Confederacy declared only a few months ago; for the thousands of miles or fertile country is now devastated by war; thousands of brave hearts now engaged in the struggle will cease to breathe, leaving widows and orphans to mourn their loss. Incalculable treasure and the business and industry of the country will be swallowed up in the struggle, but we have nothing left to hope for, but in completely conquering the South.

abstract: Yesterday morning, the Rev. I.S. KALLOCH preached a sermon in the above church appropriate to the National fast.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, the Rev. I.S. KALLOCH preached a sermon in the above church appropriate to the National fast. He took for his text the fifth verse, eighty-third chapter of Psalms: "They are confederated against thee." The reverend gentleman said that we had listened to the rumors of war in foreign nations with the proud security of peace in our own blessed land. We had now awoke from that sweet dream to the untold horrors of fratricidal war. There are many who regret the result of the last Presidential election, because if the result had been different we should have been saved from this war. Is peace so great that it is to be purchased at the price of chains and slavery? No! In the language of PATRICK HENRY, "Give me liberty or give me death." We are willing to give the rebels all the rights that we enjoy under the Constitution, but no more. Our flag, the symbol of our prosperity, the guardian of our property, the protector of our lives, the shielder of our honor, we will guard from being sullied, and if need be, will shed our last drop of blood in its defence.

abstract: Dr. ABEL STEVENS preached to a crowded assembly at the Seventeenth-street Methodist Episcopal Church. His text was the whole of the 58th chapter of Isaih.
lead_paragraph: Dr. ABEL STEVENS preached to a crowded assembly at the Seventeenth-street Methodist Episcopal Church. His text was the whole of the 58th chapter of Isaih. He spoke first of reasons for National repentance. 1. The national irreligion. A large portion of our people acknowledge no religion whatever. The preacher spoke of this as an anomaly in history, unseen in any other nation. All people have at least some forms of religion individually observed; among us perhaps a third or more of the people practically ignore any and every religious observance. Our population is 31,000,000; our "accommodations" for church sittings do not suffice for 14,000,000.

abstract: The Tribune, of this City, yesterday had the astonishing misstatement that Kentucky is wholly unprepared for the present emergency, and that while "thousands of her wild...
lead_paragraph: The Tribune, of this City, yesterday had the astonishing misstatement that Kentucky is wholly unprepared for the present emergency, and that while "thousands of her wild and reckless youth "are already enrolled in the armies of JEFF. DAVIS, "not five hundred natives of the State have till now shouldered a musket for the Union." We do not claim that Kentucky has been training the Army that she needs at the present moment, but it is certainly a gross oversight for the Tribune not to remember Camp Robinson, in Garrard County, where for over two months Gen. NELSON has been recruiting and drilling regiments for the United States service. In Camp Robinson there had been gathered an Army numbering certainly very nearly 6,000 at the time when Kentucky was invaded, and with the exception of a few hundred exiled East Tennesseeans, it was purely a Kentucky force. At Louisville, also, it should not be forgotten that Gen. LOVELL H. ROUSSEAU has been, for two months, at least, gathering a Kentucky force in his camp on the Indiana side, and that he had between 2,000 and 3,000 well-disciplined men under his command, ready to march, and that did march, on the first note of danger, to the threatened points on the railroad south of Louisville.

abstract: Rarely has Dr. BELLOWS' Church presented a more impressive scene than during the Fast Day services yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: Rarely has Dr. BELLOWS' Church presented a more impressive scene than during the Fast Day services yesterday morning. Promptly every seat was filled, and many, who could not even procure the poor privilege of a chair in the aisle or lobby, were compelled to go away disappointed. Although the exercises occupied over two hours and a half -- consisting of the customary singing, prayers and reading of the Scriptures, together with addresses by Dr. BELLOWS and Dr. OSGOOD -- the greater portion of the audience evinced the most patient attention. The excellent music of the choir, together with the unusually fine congregational singing, contributed much to the effectiveness of the service.

abstract: The attendance at Calvary Church yesterday was good, but not numerous. Dr. HAWKS selected for his text the 14th verse of the 8th chapter of 2d Chronicles: "If my people which are called by my name shall humble themselves, and pray, and seek my face, and turn themselves from their wicked ways; then will I hear from Heaven, and will forgive their sin, and will heal the land." The reverend gentleman commenced by characterizing the occasion as a special, solemn and National act of public humiliation, designed to obtain relief from sorrows and calamities which could not have befallen us without the Divine will. He exhorted his hearers to metaphorically put off their shoes from their feet, as the act was one [???] must affect their well-being to all eternity. All National acts necessarily included individual ones. The Bible afforded many cases in illustration. Our first duty on the occasion was rigid self-examination. About eight months ago we had met for precisely such a work as that of to-day. Since then, many and more grievous calamities had [???] us. Let each of us ask himself: "How many sins since then are still dominant over me at this second day of humiliation?" Are pride, luxury, drunkenness, gambling, Sabbath-breaking, abstinence from the house of God as prevalent among us? Is He any more in our thoughts? Have we watched and prayed? Let us question our consciences. If we have neglected these things, let us attend to them now in our closets. We deserve damnation, the best of us. Confession was a distinct Christian duty -- also contrition; but the latter must be accompanied byFaith, which made all the difference between the contrition of Peter and of Judas. Let us come to God with faith in our hearts, that He will hear us, specially recognizing that all chastisements come from His hand. Until we recognized this, we should be astray. The practical end, therefore, or the fast, was to induce holier lives and a truer recognition of the Almighty. If we were all Christians in this land, there would be no need of them. The Doctor concluded by exhorting his hearers to go to their closets and pray.

abstract: Yesterday was a still day in Washington, and along the lines of the Army across the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a still day in Washington, and along the lines of the Army across the Potomac. The rebels kept remarkably quiet, not even showing themselves at any point. It has recently been discovered, by the Potomac flotilla, that new batteries have been erected by the rebels at Freestone Point, and on Wednesday two or three vessels approached the place, and threw in a few shells, which elicited a response. The location of the batteries having been ascertained, it is thought that measures will soon be taken to capture them, as they have rifled cannon, which prove a considerable annoyance to vessels passing up or down.

abstract: The only occurrence of moment near Washington yesterday was the discovery of still another rebel battery on the Lower Potomac this time at the mouth of the Occoquan Creek.
lead_paragraph: The only occurrence of moment near Washington yesterday was the discovery of still another rebel battery on the Lower Potomac -- this time at the mouth of the Occoquan Creek. The schooner William Allen, from this City, loaded with hay, was fired upon by it, some twelve shots in all. Two shells entered her deck load, and another struck her cabin, but fortunately did not explode. These shells were fired from a thirty-pound rifled cannon, supposed to be the Parrot gun captured at Bull Run.

abstract: This regiment is now in active service, and is doing special duty at Williamsport, Md., in the Virginia Brigade, commanded by Gen. WARD H. LAMON.
lead_paragraph: This regiment is now in active service, and is doing special duty at Williamsport, Md., in the Virginia Brigade, commanded by Gen. WARD H. LAMON. The regiment, when full, will comprise sixteen companies, four of which will be cavalry, one a battery of rifled cannon, and the remainder rifles, and will number 1,500 men, two-thirds of whom have already been recruited, and are fully armed, equipped, clothed and comfortably quartered and subsisted at the above rendezvous. The officers have seen active service in the Army, Navy and militia. Pensions are granted the disabled, &c. Squads and companies are being transported daily to Williamsport, when they are immediately mustered in. Any suitable person who shall recruit men for this regiment previous to the 5th of October, and will report the result to the Colonel, shall be entitled to official positions in the regiment as follows:

abstract: AN EX-"P.F." OUTWITTED. The Coney Island Railroad Company some months ago secured the right of way for their road through Brooklyn so far as the city authorities could grant it, but they found some difficulty about laying their rails in South-street, between Fulton-avenue and State-street.
lead_paragraph: AN EX-"P.F." OUTWITTED. -- The Coney Island Railroad Company some months ago secured the right of way for their road through Brooklyn -- so far as the city authorities could grant it, -- but they found some difficulty about laying their rails in South-street, between Fulton-avenue and State-street. It seems that Ex-Mayor SAMUEL SMITH originally opened this street for the benefit of his own property, and he alleges that in ceding it to the city he reserved some control over the street -- sufficient, at all events, to stop the laying of rail tracks there. The managers of the road coaxed and threatened, but in return they were threatened with an injunction in case they attempted to tear up the street. The Company found there was no use in attempting to avail themselves of the ordinary methods of obtaining possession of the street without a long litigation, so they resorted to strategy. Thursday having been appointed as a National Fast-day, when it would be impossible to obtain an injunction from any of the Courts, they arranged to put 300 men at work upon the street at an early hour in the morning, and before night the track was laid and the dirt and rubbish moved away. Mr. SMITH, when he saw what was going on, applied to a judge for an injunction, but was told that none could be granted on that day, and he returned home a wiser man. This, it is believed, was the only regular work done on Thursday, and the Railroad Company excuse this on the ground of public necessity.

abstract: Zeal in recruiting  passes often the limits of honesty, and very frequently those of discretion. Of dishonest inducements to enlist, are misrepresentations of the immediate pay the private is to receive; of the bounty he is entitled to; of the land warrant that will be his after discharge.
lead_paragraph: -- Zeal in recruiting passes often the limits of honesty, and very frequently those of discretion. Of dishonest inducements to enlist, are misrepresentations of the immediate pay the private is to receive; of the bounty he is entitled to; of the land warrant that will be his after discharge. Advertisements and posters abound in engagements which the Government has not undertaken to fulfill, and the fulfillment of which would be a practical impossibility. Before the close of the war, it is probable that three-quarters of a million of soldiers will have seen service and become entitled, one as much as the other, to whatever bounties Congress might be disposed to bestow. If such bounties were to take the shape of money, they would call for the outlay of nearly a hundred millions of dollars; if they were to be given in land, they would require more than a hundred millions of acres. Such donations are simply impracticable. It is sufficient for the soldier to know that he is to be well paid, well clad; well sheltered, and cared for in case of sickness; that he will be enabled to make his pay available for the support of his dependents; that if disabled he will be provided for by a pension -- a pension that will be paid to his family in case of death. When these, with the previous impulses of patriotism and love of adventure, cease to be sufficient inducements to volunteers, it will be time to resort to drafting.
headline: {'main': 'FRAUDULENT RECRUITING.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FRAUDULENT RECRUITING.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The recent triumphs of rebel privateering are not such as answer the extravagant hopes and fears of three months ago.
lead_paragraph: The recent triumphs of rebel privateering are not such as answer the extravagant hopes and fears of three months ago. There were weeks, last Spring, each day of which had its tale of captures and confiscations, until certain journals of a statistical turn could enumerate and foot up losses to the extent of millions. New-Orleans was the head-quarters of the buccaneers. Up the Passes of the Mississippi Delta there was an apparently endless procession of prizes. The prizes, as soon as unladen, were converted into privateers, charged with men, muskets, cannon and cutlasses, and sent away to reap new harvests of maritime plunder. Piratical enterprise soon found the value of other points of departure and rendezvous. The bayous of East Florida, and the inland waters of Albemarle and Pamlico, were reported as swarming with privateers, who, defiant of embargo or pursuit, were enriching themselves at the expense of our commerce.
headline: {'main': 'The Decline of Privateering.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Decline of Privateering.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Kansas is at this moment in most imminent danger of a second subjugation by the ProSlavery rebel-ruffians of Missouri and of the Southwest.
lead_paragraph: Kansas is at this moment in most imminent danger of a second subjugation by the ProSlavery rebel-ruffians of Missouri and of the Southwest. Its fate may be said to hangupon the issue of the impending battle at Lexington, but a few miles from its eastern border. If we suffer another defeat there, Kansas falls. No wonder the settlers of that young and free, but thrice-desolated State, are preparing for defence with the energy of desperation, for the time is short. It is now known that it has all along been BEN MCCULLOCH's scheme to subjugate Kansas first; that once accomplished, he and the Secessionists of Western Missouri would have allies on all sides, excepting only the Iowa border; and he could then make Kansas the base of operations against the loyal citizens of North Missouri. He would thus also divert the Kansas regiments and the other National troops in Missouri to a field where he could carry on his peculiar style of warfare with the greatest advantage to himself, and with the least damage and danger to the sacred soil of Secessiondom. Ever since the battle at Springfield, large bodies of the rebels, under RAINS and others, have been gathering and foraying along the Southeastern border of Kansas, from Fort Scott up as far as the Kansas River; and so serious have been the menaces against Leavenworth, and other river towns, that all citizens are now called out for military duty daily. Only yesterday, the telegraph reported that MCCULLOCH, with 15,000 men, was within a few miles of the Kansas line on the night of the 21st inst.; and although it is not likely that he will now make any serious demonstration against the State until after the impending fight at Lexington, the fact of his hovering so long, and with such large force, along the border, shows sufficiently what are his designs. It is highly probable, too, that, since the battle at Springfield, MCCULLOCH has made another visit to the Indian Nations in the Territory to the south of Kansas, and got them in readiness for an advance movement whenever he shall give the signal. A short time since, the Fort Smith (Ark.) Times gave a list of companies of red men that had been raised in the various tribes by Capt. ALBERT PIKE and Gen. D.H. COOPER; and told us that the savages were thirsting to begin the work of butchery. The tribes there number 70,000 souls, and it is supposed can bring into the field eight or ten thousand warriors, who would form a most effective auxiliary in border warfare. Kansas has thus a savage enemy on her front and at her flank, and a howling desert in the rear.
headline: {'main': 'Imminent Danger of Kansas,', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Imminent Danger of Kansas,', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A public meeting of the Union Electors of the town of West Farms, Westchester County, who are in favor of supporting the Government in a vigorous prosecution of the war, irrespective of party, was held on the 23d inst., and was largely attended. S.M. PURDY, Esq.,-presided. Patriotic addresses were made -- a Town Committee and County delegates chosen -- strong and patriotic resolutions passed -- and the meeting adjourned unanimously in favor of knowing no party but the one that was for upholding the Government as long as the war shall last.

abstract: Mora et al. vs. The Sun Mutual Insurance Co. -- This was a motion to set aside a precept, granted with $10 costs. The plaintiffs demurred to the several counter-claims in defendants' answer. On argument, judgment was ordered for the plaintiffs on all the demurrers with costs. Held that these costs are not recoverable, unless the plaintiffs succeed in the action and recover a sum carrying costs, and in that event are to be collected by execution on the judgment. They are the costs of the trial of an issue of law, and are not the costs of a special motion, nor interlocutory costs within the meaning of laws of 1840, p. 333, $15, and laws of 1847, p. 491, $2.
lead_paragraph: Mora et al. vs. The Sun Mutual Insurance Co. -- This was a motion to set aside a precept, granted with $10 costs. The plaintiffs demurred to the several counter-claims in defendants' answer. On argument, judgment was ordered for the plaintiffs on all the demurrers with costs. Held that these costs are not recoverable, unless the plaintiffs succeed in the action and recover a sum carrying costs, and in that event are to be collected by execution on the judgment. They are the costs of the trial of an issue of law, and are not the costs of a special motion, nor interlocutory costs within the meaning of laws of 1840, p. 333, $15, and laws of 1847, p. 491, $2.

abstract: Mr. HERMANN'S second programme of prestidigitation excels in interest and variety the one with which he made so favorable an impression on our public on the occasion of his debut.
lead_paragraph: Mr. HERMANN's second programme of prestidigitation excels in interest and variety the one with which he made so favorable an impression on our public on the occasion of his debut. The same remarkable facility of manipulation is noticeable in all that he does; the same astounding ease in making all sorts of things disappear. In the latter way a very beautiful trick was introduced for the first time. It was effected somewhat in this fashion: Mr. HERMANN walked among the audience and casually plucked from coat-collars three live canaries. These he placed in an ordinary bird-cage. Then producing a. glass box, he transferred the birds to its depths. Here they hopped about until they were placed under the thin folds of a silk handkerchief, held in the hands of Mr. HERMANN. You could see the shape of the glass case distinctly. But presently shaking out the bandanna, the cage, together with the birds, disappeared. It is not easy to describe the effect which a feat of this kind produces on the spectator, but we may measure its excellence by the hearty applause which ensued. Mr. HERMANN's sleight-of-hand is so very clean and unembarrassed that it places his performances on a totally different level to any that have ever been seen in this City. In the new programme which he has now brought before the public, he is seen to the most pleasant advantage. The tricks are not painful in their interest like the gun trick, but of a light and, in some instances, humorous character.

abstract: A DEPUTY UNITED STATES MARSHAL HORSEWHIPPED BY A WOMAN. Ex-Alderman WILSON, of Hoboken, at present a Deputy United States Marshal, was the recipient of a horsewhipping early on Thurs- day evening at the hands of a woman, which at the ...
lead_paragraph: A DEPUTY UNITED STATES MARSHAL HORSEWHIPPED BY A WOMAN. -- Ex-Alderman WILSON, of Hoboken, at present a Deputy United States Marshal, was the recipient of a horsewhipping early on Thurs- day evening at the hands of a woman, which at the time caused considerable excitement in the neighborhood where it occurred. It appears that he was walking along Meadow-street, Hoboken, when he was suddenly confronted by Mrs. WM. LAVENCE, residing near by, who commenced laying a horsewhip over Mr. WILSON's shoulders with great vigor. WILSON finally gained possession of the whip, when the lady, in the presence of quite a gathering, resorted to another weapon -- her tongue -- by which means she relieved her mind at a rapid and violent rate. She especially invited Mr. WILSON to cause her arrest in order that she could "expose his villainy," as she said, "practiced under the cloak of religion." Mr. WILSON very obligingly granted the request, and Mrs. LAVENCE gave $200 for her appearance at Court. The parties are said to be relatives, and the difficulty grew out of business matters in the family.

abstract: The National Fast Day was strictly observed in the Military and Naval Departments in this City. The Navy-yard was closed entirely, and the only duty performed on Governor's Island was the inevitable guard duty. There were morning and after
lead_paragraph: The National Fast Day was strictly observed in the Military and Naval Departments in this City. The Navy-yard was closed entirely, and the only duty performed on Governor's Island was the inevitable guard duty. There were morning and afternoon services at St. Cornelius' Church on the Island. The recruiting offices for the regular Army were closed, with the exception of Cedar-street and Chatham-street rendezvous, and there was no necessity for their being open, as the Doctor's office in Grand-street was closed, and recruits, therefore, could not be examined.

abstract: Many years ago, when actors were a more shabby class than they are now, and the stage was regarded as the most convenient and best lighted path to perdition, there existed in this metropolis a theatre yclept the Park.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, when actors were a more shabby class than they are now, and the stage was regarded as the most convenient and best lighted path to perdition, there existed in this metropolis a theatre yclept the Park. Being the only place of amusement of any consequence, it speedily became popular. Artists who came to this country waited upon the manager with fear and trembling. They crooked the pregnant hinges of the knee to his awful garrulity. They listened to his little shibboleth of art and rejoiced. It was well for them that they did, for the Park, like an aesthetical boa-constrictor, crushed what it did not swallow. To make money it was necessary to play at the Park; to know anything of acting it was necessary to have graduated from that Temple of the Muses. Critics of easy virtue wrote tremendous disquisitions on the affinity of all that was truly great with all that was done at the Park, and actors at the Park, breathing the salubrious atmosphere of Mount Parnassus, looked down, like gods, upon common people. About this time there arrived in this country a gentleman whom we now call the "veteran manager." He was in the prime of life; gifted with rare talents as an artist, and still rarer faculties as a manager. For some reason he did not "sec" the Park. Doubtless he was told, as we are even now told, that it was the best place of amusement in the world. Some eminent tragedian, smelling strongly of tobacco, undoubtedly recommended him with exuberant generosity to try the provinces. But shutting his eyes alike to perfection and disinterestedness, this new-comer resolved to open a theatre of his own. You may imagine if you like the jokes of the low comedy man, the lofty scorn of the leading tragedian, the sarcastic considerateness of the manager, and the beery doubts of the critics, when the news became known in the purlieus of the Park Theatre. If, in our day, the Governor of Coney Island were to send a missive to the Mayor of New-York, warning him to remove the women and children, because it was his intention to bombard the City within twenty-four hours, the surprise could not be greater. But the public, which looks to facts, accepted the thing with favor. Mr. WALLACK opened his theatre, and from that day to this has been quietly accepted as the best manager we have ever had. The rosy fiction that nothing could surpass the glories of the Park, has vanished into that very thin air which old and superseded actors are apt to use when they "blow " about their former triumphs.

abstract: We are informed by a gentleman, lately from Georgia, that coffee in most parts of that State was 50 cents per pound, bacon 22 cents, and money extremely scarce. Flour could be had at reasonable
lead_paragraph: We are informed by a gentleman, lately from Georgia, that coffee in most parts of that State was 50 cents per pound, bacon 22 cents, and money extremely scarce. Flour could be had at reasonable prices, while fresh beef commanded but 7 to 8 cents. But as other articles of food for which they have depended upon the North become scarcer and higher, of course these articles will rise in price. The Georgians have, in some parts of the State, raised good crops of wheat, but there were fears that the cotton crop would greatly injured by the long continued rains, which, our informant says, he observed had already effected it. Still later, the Southern papers are expressing similar fears, and if the rains have continued till now, the crop will be greatly lessened, both in quality and quantity. The publishers are alarmed for a supply of printing paper, for while they have any amount of material in the shape of cotton for making it, the manufacturers cannot obtain the chemicals necessary for its perfection. The blockade is growing closer, and still closer, and they are becoming more and more disheartened in view of the future. There were great complaints against the Commissariats for the stinted provisions for the Army, which were constantly growing worse, and they had been forwarded in such quantities to Virginia to keep the Army provisioned that they were growing scarce. The knowing ones showed signs of distrust in the success of the experiment they are engaged in, but were keeping up the contest in the vague hopes that something as yet unthought of "might turn up" to their advantage.

abstract: The force employed in the work about the yard is 1,700 men, and 22 yoke of oxen, for the latter of which the owners are paid fifty cents per day and keeping. The monthly pay roll to the men is not far from $35,000. Fifty men are constantly employed on gun-carriages alone, and last week an order for sixteen from Gen. FREMONT's command were sent off at an hour's notice. There are Four war vessels now building -- two side-wheel steamers and two gun-boats. One of the gun-boats (the Kearsage) was launched a few days ago, and is now in the dry dock, coppered, and being rapidly finished. The other is on the stocks, nearly planked up, and is to be launched in about 25 days. The steamers also are being pushed forward with all possible dispatch.
lead_paragraph: The force employed in the work about the yard is 1,700 men, and 22 yoke of oxen, for the latter of which the owners are paid fifty cents per day and keeping. The monthly pay roll to the men is not far from $35,000. Fifty men are constantly employed on gun-carriages alone, and last week an order for sixteen from Gen. FREMONT's command were sent off at an hour's notice. There are Four war vessels now building -- two side-wheel steamers and two gun-boats. One of the gun-boats (the Kearsage) was launched a few days ago, and is now in the dry dock, coppered, and being rapidly finished. The other is on the stocks, nearly planked up, and is to be launched in about 25 days. The steamers also are being pushed forward with all possible dispatch.

abstract: Flag-officer LOUIS M. GOLDBOROUGH, recently appointed to the command of the Northern division of the Atlantic Squadron, was born in the City of Wash-
lead_paragraph: Flag-officer LOUIS M. GOLDBOROUGH, recently appointed to the command of the Northern division of the Atlantic Squadron, was born in the City of Washington, and is a son of the late CHARLES W. GOLDEBOROUGH, for many years Secretary to the Board of Navy Commissioners. He entered the Navy at an unusually early age, June 18, 1812, having personally solicited his appointment from President MADISON, and passing through the various grades because a Post-Captain Sept. 14, 1855. When a Lieutenant on board the Porpoise, Oct 16, 1827, he was distinguished by the dashing manner in which he captured a piratical brig, by boarding, driving the pirates who their boats, and finally to the shore, keeping up a running fire and producing great slaughter among them.

abstract: In the United States District Court, before Judge CADWALADER, proclamation for the third time was yesterday made in the following cases, requiring claimants to "come forward and file their claims,
lead_paragraph: In the United States District Court, before Judge CADWALADER, proclamation for the third time was yesterday made in the following cases, requiring claimants to "come forward and file their claims, if any they have, or submit to condemnation of their interest in the vessels and other property seized by the United States." The first proclamation was made on the 13th, and the second on the 20th inst. The third and last proclamation having been yesterday made in open Court, and no parties having filed their claims, a final decree of condemnation will be to-day entered; and, after a notice of ten days, the property will be put up at public auction, and sold to the highest bidder by the United States Marshal.

abstract: -The Union victory in California has the gigantic proportions of everything which comes from that State. In expressing their loyalty to the cause of Government, the people were not content with supporting a no-party ticket; they placed upon it men belonging to the party which raised Mr. LINCOLN and his friends to office, and then voted for it almost unanimously. Not only is the Government thus emphatically indorsed, but the actual administration, of the Government receives the assurance of a practically undivided popular approval.

abstract: There are three classes of people at the North who, talk about the blessings of peace, and who deprecate the horrors of war. The first is composed of men
lead_paragraph: There are three classes of people at the North who, talk about the blessings of peace, and who deprecate the horrors of war. The first is composed of men who sympathize with the rebellion, who are at heart traitors to the Constitution and the Union. Their cry for peace is but a hypocritical pretence, adopted only to give aid and comfort to the enemy, and embarrass the Government in its efforts to defend and perpetuate itself. The second class is composed of men whose own personal interests are the god of their idolatry -- who, in their calculating selfishness, can see in this war only the temporary disturbance of commerce and of trade, the increase of taxation for the time necessary for its prosecution, without one thought of the stupendous issues involved. All they comprehend is the decrease of their present gains, and the prospect of being compelled to pay a few dollars of increased taxation. They care nothing for national honor, nothing for the Constitution and the Union. They would sacrifice all these to their own lust of acquisition. To say that they sympathized with secession would be to elevate their selfishness to the dignity of a sentiment. They prate of peace simply because the war interferes with their pecuniary interests.
headline: {'main': 'Peace and its Advocates.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Peace and its Advocates.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The effectual closing of the Potomac, by the rebels, so that Washington is no longer accessible by sea, is now distinctly announced. For month the insurgents have devoted them-
lead_paragraph: The effectual closing of the Potomac, by the rebels, so that Washington is no longer accessible by sea, is now distinctly announced. For month the insurgents have devoted themselves to the construction of powerful batteries at various points on the river; patiently toiling at their completion and armament, without exciting premature alarm by firing into our naval vessels and transports; which, nevertheless, reported constantly at Washington the progress of such threatening works. We have now proof that wherever the river narrowed, so as to bring the passing vessel within reach of guns placed upon the shore, guns of the most destructive character have been placed in formidable numbers, and, as we have every reason to believe, with men enough not only to work but to defend them. With the stream thus thoroughly enfiladed, so that a vessel must substantially run the gauntlet of miles of rifled cannon, the river may be regarded as hermetically sealed. And the relief of Fort Sumter was child's play in contrast with a task so tremendous as the reopening of the Potomac.

abstract: The following is from the London Field: One-quarter of a pound of saltpetre to half a pound of raw brown sugar; make them very hot, and rub into legs of mutton over night. Next morning salt them with common salt. Let the mutton lie about a week, move it over and rub in fresh salt, and let it remain another week in pickle. Then hang it up to dry. When dry, keep it in canvas bags to prevent it being fly-eaten. N.B. -- Do not let the mutton lie in the wet brine, but place something under to raise them from the drippings that will fall from them.

abstract: It is evident that the world is at the commencement of a new era in naval warfare, in consequence of the introduction of steam as a propelling power for ships, and its application by the chief maritime nations to vessels
lead_paragraph: It is evident that the world is at the commencement of a new era in naval warfare, in consequence of the introduction of steam as a propelling power for ships, and its application by the chief maritime nations to vessels of war. This power, by entirely annulling the limitations and disabilities imposed by the wind on the evolutions of fleets, opens the whole surface of the ocean as a battle-field. Being thus, in a great measure, independent of atmospheric conditions, the commander of a fleet is free to execute whatever strategical combinations he may have determined on -- whether to keep his ships concentrated in columns, or lines of bearing en echelon, or making a flank movement. In fact, as Capt. DAHLGREN has remarked, military tactics will hereafter enter largely into the manoeuvres of fleets, and steam is likely to operate in maritime warfare a revolution analogous to that created in land warfare by the introduction of fire-arms.
headline: {'main': 'Naval Warfare with Steam.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Naval Warfare with Steam.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Rev. Dr. ADAMS, of the Essex-street Church, Boston, preached, on Fast Day, from Ezekiel, 37: 15 to 19. He believed the Union a necessity both to the North and the South, and that for purposes of self-defence we must be one people. If we come out of the war one people, the capacity of men for self-government would be settled forever. If we are defeated, Republics will be thought impossible. We have sinned against each other, and reviled each other, but the Government has not sinned against the South.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. ADAMS, of the Essex-street Church, Boston, preached, on Fast Day, from Ezekiel, 37: 15 to 19. He believed the Union a necessity both to the North and the South, and that for purposes of self-defence we must be one people. If we come out of the war one people, the capacity of men for self-government would be settled forever. If we are defeated, Republics will be thought impossible. We have sinned against each other, and reviled each other, but the Government has not sinned against the South.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, Judge MCCUNN presiding, the following sentences have been passed upon parties whose cases were previously noticed, and in which sentence was deferred: John W. Adams, for attempt at grand larceny -- State Prison two years. William Taggart, for an assault with a dangerous weapon -- State Prison two years. Wesley Powell, for forgery in the fourth degree -- State Prison two years. Robert Kehoc, for assault and battery -- City Prison for ten days. Ellen Robinson, for passing counterfeit money -- Penitentiary for six months. Jas Murray, for petty larceny -- Penitentiary six months, and fine of $100. Adjourned to Monday morning.

abstract: The stay-at-"Home Guard," and others of a military turn of mind, who delight, like the war-horse to " sniff the battle " preferring, however, like that very sagacious animal, to sniff it " from afar " will...
lead_paragraph: The stay-at-"Home Guard," and others of a military turn of mind, who delight, like the war-horse to " sniff the battle " preferring, however, like that very sagacious animal, to sniff it " from afar " -- will be especially pleased with an entertainment now offered them at Hope Chapel. It consists of a series of dioramic and panoramic pictures, presenting the principal events of the war, and constituting a complete rebellion record on canvas. Thus it is possible to, experience a battle without actually encountering the inconveniences of the field. The beholder is brought into juxtaposition with nothing more formidable than an occasional pinch of resin, a bass drum, and a few judicious flashes of blue fire. Sitting in his well-cushioned seat, he has a fine view of the bombardment of Fort Sumter, without being in any more danger than those who actually look part in it. The Baltimore riot, the landing of troops at Annapolis, the march of the regiments, Washington, Georgetown, Harper's Ferry, the exploit of SIEGEL at Carthage, and a dozen more exciting themes have been seized upon by the enthusiastic artist; we have the Big Bethel big blunder, the celebrated Locomotive charge, and finally the battle of Bull Run. It is a pity in depicting this latter event the artist thought proper to lend his pencil and palette to that pleasant fiction of the Fire Zouaves and the Black Horse Cavalry. Subsequent events have proved that the talent of this regiment is more particularly adapted to tossing reporters in blankets than to repelling Black Horse charges or encountering the charge of that Pale Horse, whose rider is Death.

abstract: Congressman VAN WYCK was on Monday unanimously elected Colonel of the Tenth Legion, which is now being recruited in this region, and which owes its inception and advanced condition, in a great degree, to the personal exertions of Mr. VAN WYCK. After his election, he addressed the assembled soldiery in an eloquent and patriotic strain, setting forth the merits of the cause in which they had enlisted, as also their duties as good and loyal soldiers. The new honor thus conferred upon Mr. VAN WYCK is one which he did not covet, and which he sought to avoid; but the voice of the regiment was single-toned and imperative, and he had to yield his own to its preference.
lead_paragraph: Congressman VAN WYCK was on Monday unanimously elected Colonel of the Tenth Legion, which is now being recruited in this region, and which owes its inception and advanced condition, in a great degree, to the personal exertions of Mr. VAN WYCK. abstract: A CONFIDING ACTRESS BROUGHT TO GRIEF.  A young man named RICHARD R. MONTGOMERY, residing at No. 65 London-terrace, was arrested yester-...
lead_paragraph: A CONFIDING ACTRESS BROUGHT TO GRIEF. -- A young man named RICHARD R. MONTGOMERY, residing at No. 65 London-terrace, was arrested yesterday on the complaint of Miss ALICE G. WOOD, living at No. 25 Spring-street, charged with having defrauded her, by means of false representations; out of property valued at the sum of $1,400. The fair complainant states that about eighteen months ago she arrived in this City, from Texas, having come here with the intention of attaching herself to one of our theatres. Soon after her arrival, she became acquainted, with MONTGOMERY, who, by promising to become responsible for her board, induced her to take rooms at the St. Denis Hotel. He, moreover, represented himself to her as a single man, and the two young persons got on very well for a time. When her money was exhausted, he induced her, by false statements, to part with her jewelry, from time to time, until, at length, she learned to her surprise, that it had all been pawned under a fictitious name, he keeping the money received on it. When her jewelry and other property was all gone, the complainant for the first learned that she had been deceived; that MONTGOMERY had a wife and child living in this City, and that she had been defrauded of her property. After advising with a friend, she decided to have him arrested. The accused was taken before Justice BRENNAN, and locked up for trial in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: JOHN A. WASH  INGTON, as heir to the Father of his Country, became the owner of Mount Vernon, the spot of all others which the American people hold most sacred, for there lived and died the great...
lead_paragraph: -- JOHN A. WASHINGTON, as heir to the Father of his Country, became the owner of Mount Vernon, the spot of all others which the American people hold most sacred, for there lived and died the great WASHINGTON, and there his remains are entombed. In Kentucky is another consecrated spot, a Mecca towards which the pilgrimages of American patriotism must always tend, for there lived HENRY CLAY, and there is his grave. His home, with its surroundings, and the tomb of the honored dead, passed into the hands of his son and heir, JAMES B. CLAY.

abstract: It will be seen by our Washington dispatches, that Muson's Hill, from which the rebels have for some time been threatening our lines, and on  which they have been at considerable pains to erect fortifications, has been evacuated by them, and the position is now in possession of our troops. About 10 o'clock yesterday morning, our...
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by our Washington dispatches, that Muson's Hill, from which the rebels have for some time been threatening our lines, and on which they have been at considerable pains to erect fortifications, has been evacuated by them, and the position is now in possession of our troops. About 10 o'clock yesterday morning, our pickets reported that the rebel pickets had been withdrawn, information of which fact was telegraphed to Gen. MCCLELLAN, who, in the afternoon, went over with his staff, and sent forward Gen. RICHARDSON, with a body of troops, to take possession of the latter. This he did, without opposition, and found that the rebels had taken everything of value with them. Eight regiments were immediately moved forward, with sufficient support, and the hill will be permanently held by our troops. The probable reason for the evacuation is the fact that the hill is commanded by Upton's Hill, which was already in our possession, and the rebels feared an attack, which they could not successfully resist.

abstract: A man living at Nantyglo, who keeps pigeons, a few days ago came to the resolution to decrease his number by shooting some of the young birds, taking care he did not injure one of the old ones. This was rather a difficulty, but after he had shifted from one side to the other for some time, with the loaded gun in his hand, four of the young birds stood well for a shot, and he fired. Down fell three pigeons, quite dead, and a fourth, being winged, fluttered about. But the shot produced other results more remarkable. Seven panes of glass in a house in the distance were broken, and a basin of broth and spoon were thrown down, the basin being broken and the broth spilt. The crash so startled a man who was at dinner, and who had not been able to move for rheumatism for months without his crutches, that he ran to the front door without them this time, and commenced jumping about in front of the house, declaring that he was shot in the forehead, although there was no mark to be seen. The man who had discharged the gun, becoming alarmed, hastened to the cripple as soon as possible, and finding that he was not hurt, told the woman of the house that he would pay all damage done to the window. She, however, was not willing to receive a farthing, saying it was the best thing that had happened to her for a long time, and she would willingly pay all damages herself, as they had been trying a great many remedies before, all to no purpose; but now the man was quite cured, and she could not think of taking anything. The sportsman, however, insisted on paying. The cured man went to work on the morrow, and has not touched his crutches since. The sportsman belongs to the Second Breconshire Rifles, who may now safely assert that it possesses one of the best shots in the world -- a man who killed three birds, wounded a fourth, broke seven panes of glass, and cured a rheumatic cripple, all at one shot. -- Bristol Mercury.

abstract: JOHN ROSS, the Cherokee Chieftain, continues firmly to resist all attempts made by the rebels to swerve him from the consistent position of neutrality assumed by him at the outbreak of the present unhappy contest. ALBERT PIKE, the Indian Agent of the pretended Southern Confederacy, has written to the old Chief, full of the blandishments of flattery, ingeniously intended to court the old man into an abandonment of his policy. Having essayed to bring about a conversion by the gentle tones of persuasion without effecting his object, the Little Rock poet, despairing of success, then tries what virtue there is in a mild kind of a threat. It appears that a generous proposition had been made to Ross by the Confederates in relation to the Indian lands lying on the border. In allusion to this proposition, PIKE intimates to Ross that, whereas, the latter "having rejected the terms offered by him of an alliance offensive and defensive, the proposition that the Confederate States will ever feel bound to pay the Cherokee people the purchase money of the 80,000 acres of land lying between Kansas and Missouri is now withdrawn forever."
lead_paragraph: JOHN ROSS, the Cherokee Chieftain, continues firmly to resist all attempts made by the rebels to swerve him from the consistent position of neutrality assumed by him at the outbreak of the present unhappy contest. abstract: Advices received here by the last steamer report that Mr. JOHN BIGELOW had arrived in Paris, and assumed the duties of his new position as American Consul. The opportune arrival of Mr. BIGELOW was peculiarly grateful to the Americans in Paris, who had been previously subjected to many inconveniences in consequence of the want of business facilities. Mr. BIGELOW's familiarity with the French language, and his wide acquaintance in Paris, render him eminently qualified for his post. It is certain that the Southern Secessionists, who have swarmed in the French Capital since the outbreak of the rebellion, will find no favor at his hands, but that they will be met, and their schemes effectually circumvented, by an officer of the Government who is at once diligent and capable. -- Evening Post.

abstract: Mussina et al. vs. Stillman et al.?This cause came up on appeal from an order denying motion to strike out the answer of defendants, Stillman  Bel-...
lead_paragraph: Mussina et al. vs. Stillman et al. -- This cause came up on appeal from an order denying motion to strike out the answer of defendants, Stillman & Beldon, on the ground that the answer was false. It appeared, from the order appealed from, that the motion at Special Term was denied, on the ground of laches -- the Court, at Special Term, (Leonard, Justice,) holding that the motion should have been sooner made. It appeared that the amended answer sought to be stricken out, was filed or served, in May, 1859. It also appeared that the plaintiff, soon after the filing of defendants' original answer, in March, 1858, made a motion to strike it out, for the want of a proper verification, which was denied. The plaintiff subsequently obtained an order for the examination of defendant Stillman as a witness, upon whose statements the verification of the answer purports to have been made, who, refusing to obey the order as to the completion of his examination, a motion was made by plaintiff to strike out the answer, unless he should appear and testify, which was granted. The testimony of Stillman, and one of the other defendants, Alling, was taken under the order for their examination.
