abstract: Of all the reigns known in history, few, itany, offer so much interest, invite so much the attention of the thinker and the statesman, as that of LOUIS PHILIPPE. Founded by one revolution,
lead_paragraph: Of all the reigns known in history, few, itany, offer so much interest, invite so much the attention of the thinker and the statesman, as that of LOUIS PHILIPPE. Founded by one revolution, destroyed by another, the eighteen years of its existence are filled by the honest attempts of the King and his Ministers to settle upon a firm basis the form of Government best suited to the French people. That which makes this reign still more interesting is, that during these eighteen years no form of freedom, however liberal, was denied them. Like us, they received the freedom of association, of the Press, and of speech, from the hands of the Government they had called to power. From 1830 to 1832, France was enjoying as much freedom -- universal suffrage excepted -- as England or the United States. She had her clubs, her meetings, her private and public associations; her Press, as free as our own, was allowed to speak with as little restraint as any of the secession papers now printed in the City of New-York. As to parliamentary freedom, which, by the way, was never restricted as long as LOUIS PHILIPPE was in power, it has oftentimes been admitted, even by English writers, that it compared favorably with parliamentary freedom in Great-Britain. French justice, celebrated all over the world for its impartiality and independence of the Government, uninfluenced by politics, equally distant from popular as from courtly favor, was exercised by enlightened and upright judges, who applied all their cares to the maintenance of the Constitution and laws of the country without any regard for the revolutionary, passions howling at their doors and threatening their lives. The French clergy, though unfavorable to LOUIS PHILIPPE's administration, though wanting in respect for its policy, and in affection and devotedness to his dynasty, remained neutral and obedient. The agricultural, industrial and commercial interests of the nation received all possible encouragements -- letters, arts and science were encouraged; the navy, and army increased; a new science, political economy, the principles of which have been applied by the present Emperor to his international relations with England and Belgium, and the effects of which are likely to modify deeply, not only the position of the working classes at home, but also the future policy of the world, began to be cultivated in France at that epoch, and the name of MICHEL CHEVALIER, BASTIAT, BLANQUI, the great political economists of this age, became popular all over the world. In fact, there is not one of the improvements introduced by LOUIS NAPOLEON which had not previously been matured and planned by the Government of LOUIS PHILIPPE; and it needs only to look at the names of the men who illustrate the present Government in the field of science, literature and arts, nearly all of whom belong to the preceding reign, to know what, would have been its greatness had it been allowed to exist longer, instead of being superseded by the revolution of 1848.

abstract: The Theatres are in the enjoyment of a full flood of success. Even on the stormy nights of last week they were well attended. At the Winter Garden, the burlesque of "Cinderella" has remained the principal attraction.
lead_paragraph: The Theatres are in the enjoyment of a full flood of success. Even on the stormy nights of last week they were well attended. At the Winter Garden, the burlesque of "Cinderella" has remained the principal attraction. This is owing, in a great measure, to the admirable way in which it has been placed upon the stage. The tableaux are very fine, especially the final one, which is one of the prettiest fancies we have ever seen. In the literary part of the work a great many curtailments have been made, the effect of which is to afford Mrs. JOHN WOOD a better opportunity for the display of her comic powers. There will be a new comedietta produced to-night, called the "Actress by Daylight," in which the lady will also appear. The title suggests abundance of fun. The management has engaged two celebrated dancers who will make their debuts to-night. Senora ISABELLA CUBAS and Senor JUAN XIMINES, come to us with the best of reputations. Quite recently in London they created a great success.

abstract: On Sept. 24, Mr. WOLFE, of the Special Legislative Committee, appointed to ask Gen. ANDERSON to take command of the forces in the State reported. He said that the Committee proceeded to Louisville, called upon Gen. A., and delivered a copy of the resolutions of the General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 24, Mr. WOLFE, of the Special Legislative Committee, appointed to ask Gen. ANDERSON to take command of the forces in the State reported. He said that the Committee proceeded to Louisville, called upon Gen. A., and delivered a copy of the resolutions of the General Assembly. He replied by thanking the Legislature with great cordiality for the honor conferred upon him. He said he was deeply sensible of the responsibility which had devolved upon him, and that, while he bore an undying love for the Union, he cherished the warmest attachment for his native State, and deeply deplored the necessity which called him to repel an invasion of Kentucky, conducted by men who were born in her midst, and had drawn their nourishments from her bosom. He was prepared to do his duty sternly and calmly while his life lasted. Referring to the resolution which expressed the determination that no man should be molested for the sake of his opinions, and that private property should not be confiscated, he said that they represented his own personal feelings, and that he should regulate his conduct by them as far as possible; but he remarked that he was acting under his obligations to a higher authority to which he should yield implicit obedience, though he did not doubt that the spirit of the resolution would be fully recognized. So far as his own action was concerned, he breathed the most friendly spirit towards the people of Kentucky, and he hoped that a returning sense of duty would unite all citizens, of whatever party complexion they had been, in the effort to expel the fiend-like spirit of party, looking only to the elevation of this or that man to office, and devote themselves to the restoration of the peace of the State and the safety of her citizens.

abstract: After the rebellion had been thoroughly matured, its execution for a long time hung upon the action of the Border States.
lead_paragraph: After the rebellion had been thoroughly matured, its execution for a long time hung upon the action of the Border States. Their decision, from their position, power and political influence, was regarded by the South, if favorable to it, as decisive of its success; by the North as giving such strength to the rebellion as to involve a war on a vast scale for its subjugation. It was for those States to say whether harmony should be restored to the nation, perhaps without firing a gun, or whether the country should be deluged in blood. The South sought to carry them with it, to precipitate the crisis; the North to retain them, to avoid it. To this end the Government made sacrifices compatible neither with its dignity nor strength. It was willing to try every expedient before resorting to arms. We all know the process and the result. Every Border State, although several professed to maintain their allegiance, either secretly sided with the rebellion, or took a position almost equally calculated to strengthen it. All denied the right to coerce the rebels. Virginia and Kentucky refused to allow their territory to be crossed to execute the laws in the seceding States; the former out of sympathy with the rebellion, the latter from a want of sympathy with the Government, and for the purpose, undoubtedly, of gaining time to see which would turn out the stronger party.

abstract: rebel privateer Judah, and the spiking of the columbiad, under the very guns of the Pensacola Navy-yard, by an expedition from the United States ship Colorado, is one of the most brilliant exploits of the war.
lead_paragraph: rebel privateer Judah, and the spiking of the columbiad, under the very guns of the Pensacola Navy-yard, by an expedition from the United States ship Colorado, is one of the most brilliant exploits of the war. A graphic account of the affair will be found in me letter of our correspondent, which we publish in another column. Too much praise cannot be awarded to the officers and men to whose gallantry the success of the enterprise is owing. The achievements of which the nation has thus far occasion to be proud are principally those of the Navy. What that has undertaken to do has been done with an energy worthy; of all praise, and this shows the immense importance of that branch of the public service. It is attacking the enemy in his most vulnerable points, carrying the war to his own doors, and striking where blows are most. damaging. There is scarcely a city on the Southern coast that may not be captured by a properly organized naval expedition, carrying with such land forces as can be spared from the Northern armies; and it is especially important that Pensacola should be captured in time to supply a harbor of refuge for our shipping, which otherwise must badly in the storms of Fall and Winter.

abstract: -- The late storm has been especially severe on the western division of the Erie Railroad, (from Hornellsville to Dunkirk,) some six or eight bridges on this portion of the road having been rendered impassable by the swollen streams. Several culverts and water-ways have also been carried away, and at quite a number of points the track is entirely washed away, in some places to the extent of a thousand feet. The night-express train coming east from Dunkirk on Saturday evening was thrown through a culvert, one mile west of Scio -- the engine turning completely around and over, followed by the tender, baggage car and one passenger car. HARVEY MILLER, the engineer, OSCAR BEASEY, fireman, and JASPER WEAVER, machinist, were instantly killed. JOHN CAMPBELL, brakeman, had his leg broken, and received cuts about the head. One passenger, named H.A. WALTON, of Columbia, Penn., had his leg broken; and another, named CORNELL, sergeant of Twenty-seventh Regiment New-York Volunteers, was slightly wounded. Conductor GOSS was slightly injured about the head, and one or two other passengers received trifling hurts.
lead_paragraph: -- The late storm has been especially severe on the western division of the Erie Railroad, (from Hornellsville to Dunkirk,) some six or eight bridges on this portion of the road having been rendered impassable by the swollen streams. abstract: The evacuation of Munson's Hill by the troops of Gen. BEAUREGARD marks an important stage in the progress of military events at Washington.
lead_paragraph: The evacuation of Munson's Hill by the troops of Gen. BEAUREGARD marks an important stage in the progress of military events at Washington. The position was one of singular consequence to that one of the parties who could seize and maintain it. A height of greater elevation than others nearer the Capital, it was within easy shooting distance of Forts Corcoran and Albany. With rifled cannon it could inflict serious damage upon those tremendous works, and there were military authorities who believed it could render them both untenable. It was even pronounced possible, by the use of the more recently improved artillery and projectiles, to shell and burn Washington itself from this commanding eminence. And as almost simultaneously with the occupation of the hill, and the commencement of fortifications upon it, the enemy seized and began to intrench Mason's Hill, a mile and a quarter to the southward, and Edsall's Hill, in the same range, upon the line of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, thus completing a new line of works extending from Vienna to the neighborhood of Alexandria, there was apparently an intention of prosecuting the investment of the Capital with so much vigor as to compel Gen. MCCLELLAN to abandon his intrenchments and attack theirs, as the only means of defeating their project. The premature abandonment of the several points we have named shows their plans to have been very different from this. From the beginning of the war the rebels have manifested no disposition to risk a contest with equality of numbers in the open field. They have in no instance, either in Virginia or Missouri, offered battle upon such conditions; and they have only fought so, even when in greatly superior force, when surprised, as at Wilson's Creek, or Carthage, and compelled to accept the contest. And in all conflicts in the open field, whatever their numbers, they have uniformly been beaten. The policy of Gen. BEAUREGARD is dictated by this distrust of his men. It is absolutely necessary for him to fight without delay; but it is also indispensable to the safety of the cause he contends for, that he should not fight without winning. Hence it is not his purpose to risk an engagement without his defensive lines to fall back upon; much less is it any part of his plan to storm the lines of Arlington. The occupation of Munson's Hill and the ranging heights was, therefore, simply a lure to draw Gen. MCCLELLAN from his intrenchments. It was hoped the National commander, chafing at the audacious proximity of the rebel force, would forthwith attack it; and the conflict once inaugurated, it would be easy to retreat slowly to the protection of the same formidable batteries which shot death and confusion among our men at Bull Run. Thus another victory would be gained, with this advantage to the rebels, that they would know that they had it early enough to follow it up vigorously and gain Washington. The whole of this astute strategy Gen. MCCLELLAN has probably understood. He has resisted the temptation; and the enemy, disappointed in his experiment, and driven to some more promising method of attaining his capital object, has abandoned Munson's Hill and the hills to the southward. We shall not be surprised to learn that his entire force has been withdrawn to the southward of Centreville.

abstract: "We have received from the North a list of the failures in New-York and Boston, and the name of the Yankee dealers who have 'stopped' or suspended' a legion. Failure of Southern remittances is the reason universally assigned.
lead_paragraph: "We have received from the North a list of the failures in New-York and Boston, and the name of the Yankee dealers who have 'stopped' or suspended' a legion. Failure of Southern remittances is the reason universally assigned. When bankruptcy shall become, as it has already almost, general among Northern merchants and manufacturers, they will learn the value of Southern trade, and become as clamorous for peace as they now are for war." -- Montgomery (Ala.) Mail.

abstract: The Church of the Puritans, Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S, in Union-square, was crowded last evening to listen to the Doctor's discourse on the rebellion, or as he styled it, God's approved method of putting it down.
lead_paragraph: The Church of the Puritans, Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S, in Union-square, was crowded last evening to listen to the Doctor's discourse on the rebellion, or as he styled it, God's approved method of putting it down. The text, like the discourse, was a continuation of that commenced on Fast Day, and was the 6th verse of the 58th chapter of Isaiah: "Is not this the Fast that I have chosen, to loose the bands of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens and to let the oppressed go free, and that ye brake every yoke." In the opening he said: But we throw ourselves on God, and we speak from Him, and by His authority, out of His word, when we demand, in His name, that our Government prove themselves the ministers of good and not evil to the country, and that they bear the sword against evil doers, rebels and traitors, and not against the poor victims of the tyranny of those traitors. We speak from God and his word, when we demand that our Government, by the power committed to them of God for good, for a terror of evil doers, break the arm of the oppressor, the right arm of this rebellion, and let the oppressed go free. We speak from God, and at His command, when we call upon our Government to keep the fast, which they themselves have appointed, in professed recognition of the authority of God and His word, for the whole nation -- when we call upon them to keep that fast themselves, in the very way that God has enjoined, by breaking every yoke, and putting down this hideous and blood-thirsty rebellion, by destroying its central power and wickedness. Let them advance to its central shrine, and cut down its moloch of Slavery from his throne, and open the prison doors of the millions still fattened for his sacrifices; let them do this, and the priests of that hellish Confederacy will fly howling from its altars, and the armies of the Confederacy will be disbanded in terror, and a free people will take the prophets of this Baal and let none of them escape. The people, indeed, are longing for the Government to give the signal for this righteous exercise of power.

abstract: -- About 3 o'clock, yesterday, the ship Ocean Monarch, lying at Pier No. 40 East River, and now loading grain for Liverpool, was discovered to be on fire. It originated in the lower hold in a corn bin, but was extinguished with trifling damage to the vessel, but to the cargo the damage by water was considerable. Mr. SHERMANN, first officer of this vessel, deserves great credit for his promptness in discovering the place it originated, for a few minutes longer would probably have caused the destruction of the noble vessel and cargo, involving great loss to the Insurance Campanies.

abstract: The Church of the Puritans, Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S, in Union-square, was crowded last evening to listen to the Doctor's discourse on the rebellion, or as he styled it, God's approved method of putting it down.
lead_paragraph: The Church of the Puritans, Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S, in Union-square, was crowded last evening to listen to the Doctor's discourse on the rebellion, or as he styled it, God's approved method of putting it down. The text, like the discourse, was a continuation of that commenced on Fast Day, and was the 6th verse of the 58th chapter of Isaiah: "Is not this the Fast that I have chosen, to loose the bands of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens and to let the oppressed go free, and that ye brake every yoke." In the opening he said: But we throw ourselves on God, and we speak from Him, and by His authority, out of His word, when we demand, in His name, that our Government prove themselves the ministers of good and not evil to the country, and that they bear the sword against evil doers, rebels and traitors, and not against the poor victims of the tyranny of those traitors. We speak from God and his word, when we demand that our Government, by the power committed to them of God for good, for a terror of evil doers, break the arm of the oppressor, the right arm of this rebellion, and let the oppressed go free. We speak from God, and at His command, when we call upon our Government to keep the fast, which they themselves have appointed, in professed recognition of the authority of God and His word, for the whole nation -- when we call upon them to keep that fast themselves, in the very way that God has enjoined, by breaking every yoke, and putting down this hideous and blood-thirsty rebellion, by destroying its actual power and wickedness. Let them advance to its central shrine, and cut down its moloch of Slavery from his throne, and open the prison doors of the millions still fattened for his sacrifices; let them do this and the priests of that hellish Confederacy will fly howling from its altars, and the armies of the Confederacy will be disbanded in terror, and a free people will take the prophets of this Band and let none of them escape. The people, indeed, are longing for the Government to give the signal for this righteous exercise of power.

abstract: The rebel States of Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, Arkansas and Tennessee, according to the official reports of their departments, have put in the field 140,000 men. Of these troops there are about 59,000 in Virginia, mostly in Gen. BEAUREGARD'S Army.
lead_paragraph: The rebel States of Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, Arkansas and Tennessee, according to the official reports of their departments, have put in the field 140,000 men. Of these troops there are about 59,000 in Virginia, mostly in Gen. BEAUREGARD's Army. This is a low estimate if he commands near 200,000 men, for it would require that he should have 141,000 drawn from the States of Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Florida, Virginia and Maryland -- a number they can hardly yield.

abstract: It has been so often asserted that the commercial balances between Europe and Ameri  ca are dependent for adjustment upon the cotton crop, that it has come to be very generally received as a practical fact. There never was a greater fallacy entertained  by intelligent commercial men.
lead_paragraph: It has been so often asserted that the commercial balances between Europe and Ameri ca are dependent for adjustment upon the cotton crop, that it has come to be very generally received as a practical fact. There never was a greater fallacy entertained by intelligent commercial men. It is entirely true that millions of cotton bales have heretofore found their way to England and France, amounting in value to many millions of dollars' annually, and it is equally true that many millions in value of merchandise have been imported from those countries. But the South consumed of European productions an amount equal to the cotton exported, while the North was dependent upon other resources to meet whatever of indebtedness might accrue against it in Europe.
headline: {'main': 'The Place of Cotton in Our European Trade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Place of Cotton in Our European Trade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- In advancing to occupy the grounds vacated by the retiring rebels, the National troops have repeated the calamitous mistake of firing into their own ranks. Two regiments approaching from different directions, each mistook the other for the enemy, and began so effectively the work of destruction, that a dozen lives lost and a score of wounded, were the result of the encounter. It is absurd to repeat the commonplace excuses for these mistakes. They certainly have occurred in all wars where men of the same nation have come in collision, but that very fact should dictate such precautions on the part of our troops as to prevent the possibility of the blunder recurring. The display at the head of each regiment of the National standard, or the wearing of a distinguishable badge, or the liberal employment of scouts and videttes, and at night the exchange of preconcerted signal lights, are all available safeguards against such errors, neglect of which shows how little our six months of military practice has borrowed of historical and recent experience. It is to be hoped no further advance will be made, until this subject has had careful attention. That men who have offered their lives for their country should lose them in this inglorious fashion, is adding a new and gratuitous horror to war.
lead_paragraph: -- In advancing to occupy the grounds vacated by the retiring rebels, the National troops have repeated the calamitous mistake of firing into their own ranks. abstract: The Associated Banks of New-York, Boston and Philadelphia met, through their respective Committees, on Saturday, at the Bank of Commerce in this City, and accepted from Mr. Secretary CHASE, who was present, the second option of $60,000,000 of the National Loan, to date from 15th of October.
lead_paragraph: The Associated Banks of New-York, Boston and Philadelphia met, through their respective Committees, on Saturday, at the Bank of Commerce in this City, and accepted from Mr. Secretary CHASE, who was present, the second option of $60,000,000 of the National Loan, to date from 15th of October. The Stock Market closed steady on Saturday, the Government Stocks and Treasury Notes being firm on the above arrangement. Within the last forty-eight hours, important changes have been made in the disposition of the two armies now fronting each other across the Potomac. The evacuation of Munson's Hill, it appears, was but one movement in the general retirement of the rebel lines. Munson's Hill, Upton's Hill, Fall's Church, and other important strategic points lately occupied by the enemy, are now in possession of the National troops, who will hold them until it becomes proper to take up still more advanced positions. Fall's Church was occupied early yesterday morning by the pickets from Gen. SMITH's Division, without opposition. His subsequent advance from the Chain Bridge, with a considerable force to occupy the place permanently, was marked by another of the blunders which seem to be inseparable from the movements of our troops, the first of which occurred before the battle of Great Bethel. Col. OWEN's Irish Regiment, from Philadelphia, mistaking, in the darkness, some of our own troops for rebels, fired upon them, killing and wounding several. The mistake was not discovered until the fire had been returned with like fatal effect. The meaning of this general retirement of the rebels is, of course, left to conjecture; but it is believed in Washington to be intended as a feint, made in order to draw our troops out of their intrenchments, and induce an engagement. Whether it means this, or that they are moving in force towards the Potomac, either above or below Washington, we shall probably soon ascertain.

abstract: The recruiting returns for the last week are most unsatisfactory. There has not been such a lack of business during any period within the last five years.
lead_paragraph: The recruiting returns for the last week are most unsatisfactory. There has not been such a lack of business during any period within the last five years. Until recently, the difficulty has been to select a few of the best men from the numbers who presented themselves for enlistment; but now the difficulty is to get men of any kind. The standard has been reduced from five feet four and a half to five feet three inches, without effect. The next step will probably be the suspension of the regulation prohibiting the enlistment of married men. This regulation forbids officers to enlist married men, or men with children, "except in time of war," but it is now observed even mere rigidily than it was twelve months ago; or rather the officers are more particular in their inquiries as to whether an applicant is married or not.

abstract: The St. Louis Republican says: "It is possible that the peculiar condition of the delegation in Congress from Missouri may require the action of our State Convention. Congress meets in December. One member, Gen. CLARKE, has been expelled from the House; another, Gen. READ, is in open arms with the Confederates, and can hardly purpose to take his seat again; and a third, it is believed, and we are sorry to say it, has gone over to the cause of disunion and the support of the Confederate Status. We expected better things of Judge NORTON, but fear that he has been misled to his own undoing."
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Republican says: "It is possible that the peculiar condition of the delegation in Congress from Missouri may require the action of our State Convention. abstract: The people of the Southern States are now receiving a lesson, which, if they lay seriously to heart, cannot fail to be of very great benefit to them.
lead_paragraph: The people of the Southern States are now receiving a lesson, which, if they lay seriously to heart, cannot fail to be of very great benefit to them. The blockade, which the National Government has established over their coasts, by cutting them off from their usual supplies of the products of the useful arts, must, bring keenly home to that proud and indocile race the value of those industries which have been so long despised. When clothes, boots, blankets, hats, ordnance, wagons, cars, boats, leather, soap, paper, medicines, are articles of such prime necessity, it is probable that the folly of sneering at mechanical skill will quickly become unfashionable. A barefooted F.F.V. or a sansculottic "cavalier" is in a poor plight to sneeze at your spinner of Lowell, or snub your shoemaker of Lynn. Indeed, we are not left without signs that a great change of temper in this regard is even now being brought about among the Southerners. The "greasy mechanic" is assuming a new aspect in their eyes, and they are sighing for what they have slighted, craving what they have so long contemned. Here is a noteworthy symptom from the Richmond Examiner:
